DOC.HEAD: Bush Gets Support from Congress
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEDES with four grafs to reflect Nunn comments; picks up 2nd graf: 11The Arab,''
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers rallied Wednesday behind President Bush's decision to dispatch troops to Saudi Arabia, but cautioned against U.S. forces defending the oil-rich nation without the help of other countries. A key senator warned that ``the next 48 hours is crucial.'' Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Armed Services Committee, told reporters in Atlanta that Iraq's president ``won't be bluffed. But I don't think what we're doing is a bluff.'' Chances of an attack on Saudi Arabia will decline if one does not take place within 48 hours, Nunn said, adding, ``I hope and pray there will not be an attack,'' but if there is one, ``it's likely to come before we have all our intelligence in place.'' ``The Arab countries must come to the party, too,'' Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas told reporters. ``I hope we will not be the `Lone Ranger' like we were in Vietnam,'' Sen. Alan Cranston of California, second-ranking Democrat, said in a telephone interview from Los Altos, Calif. The handful of senators and representatives still in the nation's capital during a month-long recess also expressed concerns that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein could act quickly to seize Saudi oilfields before troops are in place. ``There is a danger of a hot war,'' said Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee. ``Saddam sees us coming. He knows more troops will be there tomorrow and still more next week. If he wants to move, now is better than later.'' Aspin also commented that Abu Nidal, the leader of one of the most infamous terrorist groups, ``is back in Baghdad. He (Saddam) may be fixing to loose Abu Nidal on the world.'' The overriding reaction on Capitol Hill from Democrats and Republicans was praise for Bush's action, which calls for U.S. troops to take up defensive positions in Saudi Arabia to deter further aggression from Iraq. The move was precipitated by Iraq's invasion and takeover of Kuwait last week. Bush declined to discuss the size of the U.S. military force at a news conference, but government sources said at least 5,000 ground troops were involved, along with 140 sophisticated fighters and bombers and naval supply ships. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said he supported Bush's decision and hoped ``this action, taken in cooperation with other friendly nations, will deter an Iraqi attack on Saudi Arabia and convince Saddam Hussein to withdraw his troops from occupied Kuwait.'' Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said the ``participation of U.S. military forces in the defense of Saudi Arabia is clearly justified as part of the timely international effort to deter further Iraqi aggression.'' Bush must ``set foreign policy goals for a military action and objectives which tell us whether the deployment is effective; the president has done both,'' said House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo. ``I applaud President Bush for his decision to send in American forces to support Saudi Arabia against the threat of aggression from Saddam Hussein. It is not just the Saudis who are at risk: America's national security is at risk as well,'' said Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn. Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, said the president was doing the right thing. ``This action puts U.S. forces in a position to inflict a very punishing attack on Iraq if it should decide to invade Saudi Arabia,'' Boren said. Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, another member of the Senate Intelligence Committee, said he supported Bush's decision, describing it as in the best interest of the United States and the world. ``It is disappointing that more of the Arab nations are not standing shoulder to shoulder with the rest of the world in defending the independence and freedom of Kuwait and Saudi Arabia,'' Metzenbaum said. Rep. William Broomfield of Michigan, ranking Republican on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said it was important ``that other regional powers understand that the world will not put up with naked aggression.'' A senior member of the House Armed Services Committee, Rep. Ike Skelton, D-Mo., also stressed the importance of a joint operation. ``I hope other Arab states can get involved,'' Skelton said. Britain has said it would commit an unspecified number of its forces but Egypt and Morocco denied reports from some U.S. sources that they would participate in a multinational operation. ``I'd prefer to leave that to'' the Saudis to announce, Bush told reporters when questioned about Arab involvement. Dole, asked about the length of time U.S. forces would participate in the defense of Saudi Arabia, said the president ``left the clear impression this morning that this could be quite long.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Orders U.S. Forces to Saudi Arabia; Economic Noose Tightens on Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with details on U.S. units involved, possible multinational force, U.S. travel advisory, other details. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NK1
DOC.TEXT: President Bush ordered U.S. troops and warplanes to the front line of the explosive Persian Gulf standoff Tuesday to guard oil giant Saudi Arabia against military giant Iraq. Capitol Hill sources said the troops would be part of a multinational force, a condition set by the Saudis, and that Egypt and Morocco were joining the attempt to deter Iraq's million-man army from storming Saudi oil fields. A fresh U.S. Navy task force set sail for the region, meanwhile, as an economic and military noose slowly tightened around Iraq. Turkey shut down the Iraqis' vital oil outlet to the Mediterranean, honoring a U.N. trade embargo ordered to punish Iraq for last week's lightning conquest of Kuwait. In Saudi Arabia, the Iraqi oil flow was reported slowing to a trickle through another pipeline. Despite the global pressure, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein remained defiant, declaring in a nationwide speech that he would never back down and leave Kuwait. ``We would rather die than be humiliated,'' he said, ``and we will pluck out the eyes of those who attack the Arab nation.'' A crisis atmosphere took hold in official Washington, where Bush called together his Cabinet to review options for squeezing Iraq and rolling back its invasion force, which the White House declared an ``imminent threat'' to outmanned Saudi Arabia. A Pentagon source later said the president ordered U.S. combat troops and warplanes sent to Saudi Arabia to help protect the U.S.-aligned desert kingdom against Iraq. The first U.S. Army units reported headed out are specially trained and equipped for rapid deployment in crisis zones. Pentagon sources said the units included the 18th Airborne Corps, a command-and-control umbrella organization based at Ft. Bragg, N.C.; the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division at Ft. Stewart, Ga.; the 101st Airborne Division at Ft. Campbell, Ky., and the 82nd Airborne Division at Ft. Bragg. Diplomats, meanwhile, worked to arrange for evacuation of Americans and other foreigners stranded in Kuwait and Iraq. The State Department advised Americans not to travel to eastern Saudi Arabia or the gulf states of Bahrain, Qatar, Oman or the United Arab Emirates. Travel to Kuwait and Iraq has not been possible since the invasion last week. One military option was a multinational naval blockade against Iraq. But in Moscow, the Foreign Ministry deflated expectations that the Soviet navy might join in, saying ``naval muscle-flexing ... is not the best line of action.'' Early foreign reaction to the U.S. move described it as certain to strengthen the Saudis, but unlikely to bring a swift end to Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. ``It is a protective measure,'' said Sir John Moberly, a former British ambassador to Iraq who is now with the Royal Institute of International Affairs in London. ``But I agree that to get Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait is a very different question, and it's a very long haul.'' Aftershocks of the Gulf explosion still reverberated through the world economy: _The Tokyo stock market fell sharply again Tuesday. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones average was down slightly. The London market edged upward. _Crude oil prices continued to rise and stood one-third higher than prices two weeks ago, driven up by fears of oil shortages. _Senate and House subcommittees met in Washington to investigate what some called a ``rip-off'' by oil companies that raised gasoline prices by as much as 19 cents a gallon after the invasion. Iraqi forces poured into Kuwait last Thursday after Saddam complained that Kuwaiti overproduction had driven down world oil prices and Iraqi oil revenues. He also accused Kuwait of stealing oil from a border oilfield both countries claim. In his speech Tuesday, Saddam said the invasion rectified unjust borders drawn up by colonial powers. The takeover of Kuwait gave Iraq control of 9 percent of world daily oil production. A conquest of Saudi Arabia would raise the Iraq-controlled of world oil to almost 20 percent. But the Iraqis have repeatedly denied any plans for a follow-up invasion of Saudi Arabia. Many governments Tuesday were drawing up regulations to enforce the anti-Iraq trade embargo ordered Monday by the U.N. Security Council at U.S. urging. If fully enforced, the boycott could cripple Iraq, which depends heavily on its oil exports for economic survival. At a maritime terminal in southeastern Turkey, Turkish officials began turning away tankers seeking to take on Iraqi oil and said they would shut down the pipeline from Iraq within days, cutting off more than half of Iraq's oil exports. At Yanbu, Saudi Arabia, terminus of Iraq's other key pipeline, no tankers had loaded oil since the weekend, oil executives said. They spoke on condition of anonymity. They said the oil flow had slowed to 200,000 barrels a day from 800,000 because of the sharp falloff in demand for Iraqi crude. MORE

DOC.HEAD: Survivors of Navy's Worst Sea Disaster to Hold Reunion
DOC.TEXT: Glenn G. Morgan remembers the small purple fish that darted around his life raft and the malt tablets he used as bait to catch them in nets. He remembers catching rainwater in a tarpaulin, and the huge shark that lunged halfway into the raft, then slid out just as abruptly and swam away. But mostly Morgan remembers the elation 45 years ago when, after five days adrift, he and about 300 other survivors of the USS Indianapolis were pulled to safety. The cruiser was sunk by a Japanese submarine during World War II in the worst disaster in U.S. maritime history. Nearly 900 crewmen were killed. About 70 survivors and some of their rescuers gather in Indianapolis, the ship's namesake, for a three-day reunion starting Friday. They have traveled here every five years since 1960. Morgan expects more than 350 people to attend. The Indianapolis was sunk halfway between Guam and the Philippines on July 30, 1945. Two days earlier it had unloaded key parts of the atomic bomb at Tinian, where the Enola Gay would take off on its flight to end World War II. Most of the ship's 1,196 crewmen were asleep. Morgan, a 21-year-old buglemaster third class, had just gotten off watch and was on the bridge. ``When I hit the water off the side of the ship, I swam away from it because I'd always heard it would suck you under,'' he said in a recent telephone interview from his home in Franklin, Texas. Clutching a rubber tube he often had used as a pillow, Morgan stayed afloat and watched in the moonlight as the ship tilted on its end, propellers still churning, then slipped underwater _ all within 12 minutes. Morgan caught sight of four life rafts and crawled into one with about 20 colleagues. Most crewmen weren't so fortunate. Those who found life jackets bobbed in the oily water with no rations. Others were eaten alive by sharks or succumbed to their injuries. Morgan's raft was equipped with rations, small kegs of water and a first-aid kit. A couple of the men were badly burned. One died the next day. The raft drifted away from the others _ 45 miles away when they finally were rescued. The isolation was terrifying, Morgan said. ``Nobody knew we were sunk. That was the brutal thing about this,'' he said. ``We were beginning to get down in the mouth after being in the water four and a half days.'' But they kept their spirits up by fishing, scanning the horizon and watching a big shark. ``We called him Charlie. Every time we'd throw a Spam can over, he'd get real curious and he'd come around,'' Morgan said. Although it did lunge into the raft once, ``Old Charlie never got violent, by golly,'' Morgan said. On the fifth day, aviator Wilbur Gwinn spotted some survivors during a routine patrol, and rescuers were alerted. One of them was Graham Claytor, commander of the destroyer Cecil J. Doyle. ``The warm spot I have for Graham Claytor was that ... he broke some Navy regulations by turning on the big blue searchlights,'' Morgan said. ``They certainly looked good to me. Oh, how good they looked.'' Claytor went on to become secretary of the Navy and is now president of Amtrak. The survivors were taken to hospital ships and medical centers at Guam and the Philippines. When they were fit, they were reunited in San Diego. Their skipper, Capt. Charles McVay III, was the only captain ever court-martialed for the loss of his ship in battle. He was charged with failing to take evasive maneuvers, or zigzag, in dangerous waters. McVay shot himself to death with his Navy pistol in 1968 at his home in Litchfield, Conn. Some of his crew believe he was a scapegoat, Morgan said.

DOC.HEAD: Modern Lombard League Seeks Autonomy from Rome
LaserPhoto MIL1 sent Aug. 1.
DOC.TEXT: Winds of independence, blown from the north by an 800-year-old ghost incarnate, are giving Rome a few shivers. Northern politicians have revived the Lombard League, a 12th century alliance of autonomy-loving cities that fought the oppression of the Holy Roman Empire. They want to remove Lombardy, the most productive part of Italy, from the grasp of a slow-moving, tax-eating, notoriously inefficient central government. Rome was stunned this spring by the league's strong showing in local elections. It became the second-ranked party in the region, behind Premier Giulio Andreotti's Christian Democrats. Part of the Lombard League's popularity stems from northern resentment of Rome for sending workers from the underdeveloped south for the past 40 years to deliver their mail, teach their children and police their streets. Northerners have disdained some of those jobs, particularly police work, because of the low pay and high risk. Others jobs, such as teaching, are based on national competitions the northerners claim are weighted in favor of people from the south. In addition, many bureaucratic posts are political appointments, and northerners say southerners get most of them. The league wants to end a virtual open-door policy that is bringing a tide of poor immigrants to Italy. Most of the latest arrivals are poor, from North Africa and Asia. On a wall of the league headquarters, in a working-class district of Milan, is a poster showing a plump chicken whose golden eggs tumble into a basket held by a fat farmer's wife. As the league sees it, the chicken is productive Lombardy and the peasant woman a parasitic south. Lombard League newspapers denounce Rome for, they say, using money from the north for wasteful development programs in the south. Hundreds of millions of dollars were poured into construction projects in the Naples area after the 1980 earthquake there, for example, but thousands of people made homeless by the disaster still live in makeshift housing. Sen. Umberto Bossi said in an interview the party wants Italy to become a federalist state with the central government's role limited to defense, foreign policy, taxes and some judicial matters. Bossi, league president and its only member of Parliament, looks to Switzerland, Lombardy's neighbor across the Alps, as a model. Many Lombards say they identify more with the rest of Europe than with Italy, whose international image often is that of the south. Soccer may well be country's strongest bond, but north-south bitterness emerged even during the World Cup competition Italy hosted this summer. Argentine soccer star Diego Maradona, who plays for Naples during the regular season, was booed for trying to get his fans to root for Argentina when it played the Italian national team in Naples. He was accused of exploiting north-south hatreds. ``I never said that the Neapolitans should root for Argentina,'' he said later. ``I just made a few observations ... like the banners in Verona,'' when Naples played there, ``that said `Wash yourselves' and `Welcome to Italy'.'' Charges that the League is racist make some northerners cautious in expressing sympathy for the party. Bossi rejects the racist label. ``I didn't vote for the league, but some of my friends did,'' said Claudio Tarini on the train ride home to Milan from Rome, where he had spent two days dealing with the bureaucracy to obtain the necessary permits for a business trip to Nigeria. While racism undoubtedly motivated some to vote for the league, Tarini said, public disgust with Rome was the principal reason for the election success. As a newspaper columnist wrote in describing the average citizen's entanglements with clerks and paperwork to meet ordinary requirements of daily life: ``Will I have to vote for the league to get a driver's license?'' The column appeared in La Stampa, a national daily based in Turin, capital of the Piedmont, which borders Lombardy and has its own regional party. Bossi says the League will begin collecting signatures in September to force a referendum on a law that allowed tens of thousands of Third World immigrants to stay in Italy. After his election to the Senate in 1987, Bossi sponsored a bill that stopped the practice of sending convicted Mafiosi from the south to internal exile in northern towns.

DOC.HEAD: A Boycott Grows in Brooklyn
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Bong Jae Jang rises before dawn and goes to the Brooklyn Terminal Market, where he stocks up on green plantain, Haitian mangos and other fruits and vegetables popular with the Caribbean immigrants who used to shop at his store on Church Avenue in Flatbush. These days, Jang's trip is an academic exercise; he knows most of the produce will sit unsold on the shelf, rot in the July heat and wind up in the trash bin outside. ``Who's going to buy this?'' he asks, holding up a cellophane-wrapped hunk of a vegetable called pium kim that is besieged by a swarm of tiny flies. After six months, a black-led boycott of Jang's greengrocery continues, even though the television cameras are gone and the pickets who gather outside the front door each afternoon have dwindled to a handful. The boycotters' avowed aim is to force the store to close. Jang's troubles began Jan. 18, when Giselaine Felissaint, a Haitian immigrant, got into an argument with several of his employees over some merchandise. One of them touched her. She says the man knocked her down; another employee says the man put his hands on her and she laid down. Five months passed before the store's manager, Pong Ok Jang, was charged with assault, but the incident immediately became a symbol of the tensions between the city's black and Korean communities. Within a few months, hundreds of demonstrators were gathering outside the store each day, along with almost as many police and journalists. Pickets yelled racial slurs at the Koreans and urged them to ``go back to where you came from.'' Tensions were heightened by the trial of some white youths accused of killing a black youth in the Bensonhurst section. In a special televised speech to the city, Mayor David Dinkins pleaded for calm and understanding. The problem runs far beyond a simple assault charge. Many blacks resent the way they are treated in some of the Korean grocery stores that have opened in their communities, and some are jealous of the immigrants' business success. The self-employed account for 6.7 percent of all city workers, but only 3.4 percent of all black workers. Skeptics derided the boycott as a news media creation that would end as soon as the last camera crew departed. They were wrong. By 5 p.m., there usually are about a dozen demonstrators behind the blue police barricades that line the sidewalk outside the store. Few neighborhood residents defy their cries of ``Boycott!'' and venture inside or visit another Korean grocery across the street. ``The stores have become a symbol of what has happened across this city in terms of the lack of recognizing the humanity of black people,'' says George Dames, a spokesman for the Flatbush Coalition for Economic Empowerment, a boycott group. ``It was not an isolated incident.'' Since May, however, ``tensions there have been lessening, if not dramatically, then incrementally,'' says Lonnie Soury, spokesman for the city's Human Rights Commission. The Rev. Roy Thompson of St. Paul's Episcopal Church agrees: ``I can drive by the store without getting stuck in traffic for a half-hour.'' Dinkins has appointed a fact-finding panel and called for an end to the boycott, but none seems likely soon. There still have been no direct negotiations between the Korean and Haitian communities, let alone Jang and Mrs. Felissaint. She has refused to denounce the boycott and has filed a $6 million suit against the store. ``People say, `End it,' but we can't just wave a magic wand,'' says Soury of the human rights commission, which is trying to get talks started. ``We're trying to identify leaders who represent those with legitimate interests. There are people who don't have an interest in settling the issue,'' he says. ``We think that if we can get a group of people who can meet, we can make progress. But they're not meeting now.'' According to a poll taken last month, only 13 percent of New Yorkers supported the boycott, while 58 percent supported the Koreans. Among blacks, only 27 percent sympathized with the boycotters, while 37 percent sided with the Koreans. Boycott leaders say the results simply reflected biased news coverage. Jang, 35, says he came here in 1983 and worked for five years at another store before opening his own. Before the boycott, he says, he routinely worked 17 hours a day, and was robbed three times. He shows off the scar where a robber's bullet entered his abdomen last year. His business is being sustained largely by $5,000 to $7,000 a month in donations from the city's other Korean grocers. ``They will support him until the boycott is over,'' says Michael Kang of the Korean Produce Association. ``He is their Maginot Line. They think they're going to be next.'' Jang is infuriated by the refusal of the police department to enforce a judge's order that the protesters be kept 50 feet from his door. The city has appealed, arguing that the police should be allowed to use discretion in deciding where the protesters should stand. Jang says neither Dinkins nor Police Commissioner Lee Brown wants to stand up to the boycotters, and pass responsibility for dealing with them back and forth. He does not speak English very clearly, but he gets his point across: ``They play a ping-pong game. They killing my dream.'' To Soury, the boycott is a tragedy. ``Two immigrant groups are pitted against each other,'' he says, ``when they should be fighting together to demand more government aid for small businesses _ for blacks and Koreans and everyone else.''

DOC.HEAD: Hurricane Diana Hits Mexico
DOC.TEXT: Hurricane Diana battered Mexico's Gulf Coast with 85 mph winds Tuesday, toppling trees and electricity poles in Poza Rica, 25 miles inland, Federal Highway Police said. Red Cross spokesman Moises Gutierrez Pina said by telephone that at least one person was injured, adding, ``I don't doubt that there are more.'' Hundreds of residents fled low-lying areas before Diana hit and hundreds more were left homeless in this city surrounded by oil fields. Police said 120 families were evacuated from their flooded homes in two city neighborhoods. About 300 more people were taken to makeshift shelters when the storm blew the roofs off their houses. The Veracruz state government reported many areas were without electricity, dozens of roads in the Gulf Coast area were blocked by fallen trees, and at least 14 towns had no telephone service. Journalists driving through the area said storm damage extended as far inland as Huachinango, a town about 90 miles southwest of Poza Rica. The government news agency Notimex said the army was preparing to declare an emergency in the area and send in food and other relief. At 10:30 p.m. EDT, the eye of the storm was about 80 miles west of the Gulf Coast town of Tuxpan, according to the U.S. National Hurricane Center near Miami. Tuxpan is 180 miles northeast of Mexico City. The storm was moving in a westerly direction at 10 mph, with winds diminished to 45 mph, the center said. It said people in mountainous areas north of Mexico City were threatened by flash floods and mud slides from heavy rains. Diana carried 90 mph winds while still at sea, and winds of up to 85 mph when it hit the coastal regions. Telephone lines to Tuxpan were out. The Red Cross and highway police in Poza Rica, on higher ground 30 miles southwest of Tuxpan, said they had no radio contact with the coastal town. Poza Rica police said Diana blew down palms and other trees and power lines, cutting off electricity to Poza Rica. Fallen trees and telephone lines blocked some streets but major roads to the city were open, the Red Cross said. Gutierrez Pina said a man in Poza Rica was cut when hit by falling roof tiles, and that another person was treated for hysteria. Small craft were warned to remain in port from Baffin Bay, Texas, southward. Phone lines to some cities along the 400-mile stretch of Mexican coast threatened by the storm were out. One man was killed Monday night in Veracruz, down the coast from Tuxpan, when winds blew over a tree, said Rosalio Romero Hernandez, a Red Cross spokesman in Veracruz. Rainfall of 10 inches or more was expected along Diana's path, said Max Mayfield, a specialist at the U.S. National Hurricane Center near Miami. Tides were expected to be four to six feet above normal, he said. ``The main threat to life will be the rising waters on the coast and the heavy rains producing flash floods and possibly mud slides inland,'' said Mayfield. A tropical storm warning was in place from La Pesca to Boca Jesus Maria, about 100 miles south of Brownsville, Texas. Tropical storm force winds extended up to 200 miles out from the center, the weather service said. Diana is the second storm of the Atlantic season to reach hurricane strength. As a tropical storm, it soaked Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula on Monday but did little damage. Tropical Storm Cesar, meanwhile, weakened to a tropical depression and was in the mid-Atlantic about 1,150 miles east-southeast of Bermuda with top sustained winds of nearly 35 mph. Tropical depressions become named storms once sustained winds reach 39 mph. A storm becomes a hurricane when winds hit 74 mph.

DOC.HEAD: Movement Against Official English Grows in India
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: A growing movement is afoot to rid India of a pervasive vestige of the British colonial Raj: the English language. It won't be easy. English is the language of law, government and some of the best modern Indian literature. It is spoken by the wealthy and well-educated who have dominated politics and business since independence in 1945. They often are called, derisively, the Brown Sahibs. Kapil Kapoort, a linguistics professor, predicted the movement would grow because knowledge of English ``provides privileges to a few, but it deprives privileges to many.'' Experts estimate 35 million Indians know some English. That is more than the population of Canada, double that of Australia and about half the number of people in Britain, but only 4 percent India's 880 million. Anti-English sentiment has arisen periodically, sometimes accompanied by violence. This year, the campaign has gone farther than before toward eliminating English from official business in some of India's 25 states. Mulayam Singh Yadav, who leads the government of Uttar Pradesh, the most populous state, banned the official use of English in April. He instructed the courts to conduct their business exclusively in Hindi, the language of about 200 mllion people in northern India. Yadav also suggested forbidding English as the language of instruction in private schools, where the children of many well-to-do Indians are educated. Two other Hindi-speaking states in northern and central India have ordered all official correspondence and public announcements made in Hindi. In Goa, on the southwest coast, the local government tried to cut off public funds for English-language schools and teachers blocked the main highway for three days in protest. At a seminar in New Delhi last month, Yadav of Utter Pradesh said: ``I will happily accept any Indian language as our national language, but English must go.'' There are plenty of indigenous tongues to choose from. India has 15 recognized official languages, including English. A census in 1971 indicated 1,652 languages and dialects were spoken, 33 of them by more than a million people each. English billboards and signs rule the streets of New Delhi, in the heart of the Hindi belt. One-fourth of all the newspapers circulated in India are in English, as are 40 percent of the books, said publisher Ravi Dayal. ``It's not that easy to get rid of English,'' said M.P. Chhaya, a consultant for the Education Department. ``It's only possible if one common language besides English is accepted. That won't happen soon.'' One advantage of English is its neutrality. Although Hindi is by far the most widely spoken language, southern Indians say adopting it as the official national tongue would amount to accepting northern domination. Chhaya said in an interview: ``English was thrust on us by the British. They were the rulers and we had no choice. Now we are a democracy. You can't thrust Hindi down everyone's throat.'' Even politicians who rail most loudly against English send their children to English-language schools, he said. In the English-language Indian Express, publisher Dayal wrote: ``Regional languages now dominate administrative activity in the states. English has its own niche in the government at the Center (federal level) and in communications with the states, in the higher courts, in some universities.'' Home Minister Mufti Mohammed Sayed, questioned in Parliament about his sincerity in promoting Indian languages, admitted his office had 633 typewriters in English and only 57 in the Devnagri script used for Hindi. ``The constitution was written in English,'' said Kapoor, director of the Center for Linguistics and English at Jawaharlal Nehru University. ``Maybe 98 percent of the people can't read it, but they are supposed to swear by it.'' ``English is an instrument for making people feel inferior,'' he said in an interview. Persian was the administrative language of the Mogul emperors who united most of India in the 16th century, then English became the tongue that linked the nation together. Sanskrit, ons and the medium of India's classics, has been dead as a spoken idiom for 1,000 years. After 40 years of studying English, Kapoor said, he began to appreciate his own culture when he discovered the importance of Sanskrit and early Indian literature to Western thinkers. ``In this prestigious university, there is no department or chair in Sanskrit,'' he said. ``We have chairs in all kinds of classical languages, but not our own.'' Resentment of India's ruling class feeds the anti-English movement. ``They are a class of people deliberately created by the British,'' Kapoor said. ``They are English in taste and opinion, and Indian in blood and color.''

DOC.HEAD: Terror, Starvation Rule Monrovia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos AMS7,102 sent Aug. 7.
DOC.TEXT: EDITORS: Associated Press photographer Alistair Sinclair spent 10 weeks in Monrovia until his evacuation by U.S. Marines on Monday.

Life in Monrovia has collapsed into random terror and widespread starvation as rebel forces close in on beleaguered President Samuel Doe. Since rebels began besieging the capital a few weeks ago, Doe's troops have been ransacking shops, restaurants, warehouses, offices and homes. In the morning, countless dead bodies bear witness to the random violence of the night before. Some are headless, others are missing parts of skulls or limbs. Liberians say the missing parts are used in cannibalistic rituals by soldiers of Doe's Krahn tribe. A coconut plantation near Monrovia's beaches has become known as ``the killing field'' because of the number of corpses dumped there daily in troughs dug by bulldozers. Civilians blame Doe's troops for the killings. The stench of rotting bodies pervades Monrovia, a city scarred by rocket and mortar fire. But the rebels have also been blamed for killings. In one incident last week, Prince Johnson, a rebel leader, shot a Liberian man wearing a Red Cross bib twice as he pleaded for his life. Johnson had accused the man, who was handcuffed to a foreign relief services worker, of profiteering from rice sales. ``You are traitor,'' Johnson said as he fired a burst of fire from his AK-47 assault rifle at the man. The man fell to the ground, wounded, and lifted his head. ``Why, why?'' he asked. Pointing at the dying man Johnson said to the French relief worker, Jacques Monthouroy: ``You are lucky you are a foreign diplomat.'' He then fired another burst at the pleading Liberian man, killing him. The victim's identify was not known. Monthouroy, a Frenchman working for the U.S. Catholic Relief Services was released after the U.S. Embassy vouched for him. Rice, the staple of Liberia's 2.3 million people, is scarce in the capital. Starving Monrovians eat grass and weeds from seaside swamps and river banks to survive. The city's water supply was cut nearly two months ago. People scoop water from creeks, drains and ponds. Crowds stampede into gardens of homes with wells. No car is safe from robbery by Doe troops, who menace occupants including ambassadors, relief workers and Liberian legislators with their rifles. In late July, Johnson won control of the city's northern Bushrod Island suburb and two bridges linking it to downtown Monrovia, where Doe is holed up in his heavily fortified cliffside mansion. Johnson's guerilla rival, Charles Taylor, has moved into Monrovia's eastern suburb of Paynesville and randomly slaughtered civilians of the Krahn and Mandingo tribes. The Mandingo are accused of supporting Doe. Doe's troops have targeted civilians of the Gio and Mano tribes, which support the rebels. The rebels invaded Liberia in December, accusing Doe of corruption and human rights abuses. Relief workers are often accused of taking sides in the war. The International Committee of the Red Cross, which had given its protection to refugees at St. Peter's Lutheran Church where 600 refugees were massacred, said its two representatives in Monrovia were in hiding and incapable of protecting refugees. When Johnson began distributing rice to starving Monrovians, his soldiers had to fire into the air to control the huge crowds that came begging for food. They later began firing at knee level, wounding at least four people, including a 24-year-old woman.

DOC.HEAD: Mysterious Woman Pays Fines For Convicted Pro-Democracy Activists
DOC.TEXT: A mysterious woman has paid the fines for five pro-democracy activists convicted of illegally using megaphones and collecting money without a permit. Court officials said a woman in black, who declined to identify herself, paid the fines, totaling about $100, on Monday. The five activists had refused to pay the fines, saying they would rather go to jail. They said they did not know the mystery woman or her motives for helping them. Their supporters have described the case as a ``show trial'' aimed at suppressing political activity in this British crown colony. They accuse Britain of bowing to China, which will regain sovereignty over Hong Kong in 1997 and is opposed to a faster pace of democracy for Hong Kong. The five were prosecuted under a 1933 law that forbids the use of bullhorns. The law has rarely been invoked and is widely ignored by teachers and tour guides who use bullhorns. The five activists, members of the United Democrats of Hong Kong, have appealed their July 27 conviction. ``The prosecution against us is clearly politically motivated and we will continue to appeal,'' said one of the activists, Yeung Sum, a lecturer at the University of Hong Kong. Although their fines have been paid, Yeung said the activists will still seek a court hearing on their appeal.

DOC.HEAD: Enormous Obstacles To Peace In South Africa Despite Cease-fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The African National Congress' decision to end its armed struggle against the South African government is just a first step in what promises to be a long and difficult quest for peace. There is no guarantee the two sides will find a peaceful solution to three centuries of racial conflict. There is growing violence and the threat of major confrontation as rival groups struggle for power. ANC leader Nelson Mandela announced Tuesday after talks with the government that his group was ending its military operations. The cease-fire clears the way for talks on ending white-minority rule. ``The way is now open to proceed towards negotiations on a new constitution,'' the two sides said in a joint declaration. The two sides have made enormous strides since President F.W. de Klerk legalized the ANC and other opposition groups in February and freed Mandela after 27 years in jail. In just a few months, the white government that created apartheid has pledged to share power with the black majority. But both sides admit that this is just a beginning. South Africa's racial conflict has been going on for some 350 years. In that time there have been virtually no attempts to have blacks and whites live together in peace and equality. Political violence has soared since de Klerk legalized opposition groups and began political reforms. Most of the violence pits rival black factions against each other as they scramble for power. Some 4,000 blacks have been killed in savage fighting in Natal Province in recent years between ANC groups and Inkatha, a conservative political movement. The violence is spreading to other provinces and enveloping other groups. The violence seems to be growing despite repeated promises from the ANC and the government to make every effort to stop the killings. The peace process also faces violent resistance from right-wing whites who oppose any settlement with the black majority. The extremists have demanded the creation of a separate white state. White extremists have been implicated in a recent wave of bombings and killings. Security officials say even a few dozen white extremists, heavily armed and with supporters in the security forces, could cause havoc. Enormous divisions remain between whites and blacks. Each group has little understanding or knowledge of the other. Contact between most whites and blacks is minimal and there is enormous distrust and fear on both sides. Whites still dominate politics and the economy. Official figures indicate that 5 percent of South Africans, virtually all of them white, own 88 percent of the country's wealth. The ANC and other opposition groups contend that political equality must be matched by a drastic redistribution of wealth to quickly ease the plight of the millions of poor blacks. The government agrees there is a need for change, but opposes any scheme that would threaten free enterprise and private property. Some observers fear that if a government led by the ANC attempts to ease black poverty by redistributing wealth by legislation or other means it could provoke a white revolt. Others say it will wreck the economy. De Klerk has indicated he is seeking guarantees under any future black majority government that will leave whites with considerable power and wealth. There are indications some ANC leaders believe the negotiations are to arrange a hand over of power. Such a misunderstanding could make it very difficult for the two sides to find a workable compromise.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Steps Up Efforts To Jam BBC World Service
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has stepped up its efforts to jam the Arabic-language broadcasts of the British Broadcasting Corp. World Service, the BBC said. The BBC expanded its Arabic-language broadcasts from nine to 10{ hours a day last week following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. BBC engineers have detected interference with the World Service's Arabic transmissions on a range of short-wave frequencies serving the Middle East. They have traced the jamming to a site south of Baghdad, the BBC said Tuesday. English-language broadcasts have not been affected. ``Jamming the BBC is always the last resort of those who wish to suppress the truth _ and in a way it is a tribute to the role of the World Service at times of crisis,'' said David Witherow, deputy managing director of the BBC World Service. ``Jamming is never entirely effective and I am sure that listeners throughout the region are relying on the BBC for news,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Restaurants Are Fed Up Over Weather Forecasts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Forecasting weather is an imprecise science, at best, but the chance that people might heed a bleak forecast that doesn't come true has some Massachusetts restaurant operators up in arms. All too often, complains Frank Catania, a television weather forecaster will predict rain or snow, and instead the sun will shine over empty tables at his restaurants. ``They're not God. They're going to make mistakes,'' Catania said. While many people would like more detail in the forecasts, and a warning of even a chance of rain or snow that might affect their lives, some people in the restaurant business have mounted a campaign to get television prognosticators to tone down their predictions. ``We're not asking them to say the weather's always going to be nice,'' said Cindy Eid, public affairs coordinator for the Massachusetts Restaurant Association. ``We're looking for some responsibility on their part.'' The restaurant group has formed a ``weather task force,'' which aims to educate meteorologists about the way their nightly forecasts can affect business. The group especially doesn't like five-day forecasts. Bruce Schwoegler, a forecaster for WBZ-TV in Boston, says he is always careful to call that a ``five day outlook,'' trying to draw a distinction with short-range forecasts that tend to be more reliable. Schwoegler said he also has told viewers not to make their weekend plans based on Monday's weather predictions. John Orgler, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boston, said he, too, would not encourage people to make plans based on long-range predictions. ``It only makes sense to wait for the day before to get something more reliable and up to date,'' he said. But the restaurateurs think that apparently hasn't sunk in with some people. The restaurant group has collected letters from members around the state to illustrate their point. E. Thomas McCabe Jr., president of Tom Foolery's in Westboro, described how on more than one occasion, no snowstorms materialized after ``alarmist'' weather forecasts, ``turning $13,000 Fridays into $7,000 Fridays.'' Even the prestigious Harvard Club of Boston joined in. A letter from the club said a weather forecaster who ``cried wolf'' last year led to the cancellation of a dinner for 250 people. The industry is especially sensitive on Cape Cod, where people will make weekend plans well in advance. Catania, vice president of Dan'l Webster-Hearth 'n Kettle, which runs an inn and several restaurants on the Cape, recalled how a TV forecaster earlier this year advised people to scrap their Sunday golf plans because it was going to rain. ``Guess what? I played golf on Sunday on the Cape and I got a suntan,'' he said. Some restaurant operators suggest weather forecasters simply add a few more cautionary phrases to their delivery, and refrain from ``sensationalized'' pronouncements. ``We're not trying to impinge on their creative talents,'' Eid said. ``We just want them to be aware that there are economic implications when they make forecasts.''

DOC.HEAD: US Sending Warplanes, Troops to Saudi Arabia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 9-12: ``The New,'' with reports of possible invitation to Soviets, reports of gas weapons being prepared in Iraq
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Tuesday dispatched American warplanes and ground troops to Saudi Arabia where sources said a multinational military force was being created to defend the vulnerable oil kingdom from attack by Iraq. Capitol Hill sources said Egypt and Morocco were joining the effort, part of an accelerating international response to Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait. While using an oil embargo in an effort to reverse the Kuwaiti invasion, allied forces hoped the unusual multinational defense of Saudi Arabia would deter Saddam's million-man Iraqi army from storming the Saudi oil fields as well. There was no announcement from the White House of the military moves. Word came from authoritative Pentagon sources and from Capitol Hill. The White House said President Bush would address the nation on television at 9 a.m. Wednesday. ``We're not playing games. There are strategic reasons why I can't tell you,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. He declared, ``We believe there is an imminent threat to Saudi Arabia.'' Plans drawn up by U.S. officials called for the international force to serve as a ``trip wire'' to deter Saddam. Explaining the government's reasoning for pulling together troops from a number of nations to protect the Saudi kingdom's outnumbered 38,000-man army, one Pentagon official said: ``If Saddam Hussein sees a group of Saudi, American, Moroccan _ and even German _ soldiers staring at him across the border, he may have little inclination to move any further.'' In what appeared to be an effort to enlist America's European partners in Iraqi sanctions or the Saudi defense effort, Secretary of State James A. Baker III made plans to meet Friday in Brussels with the foreign ministers of the 15 U.S. allies in Europe after a quick consultation trip to Turkey. The New York Times said in Wednesday editions that the United States was prepared to invite the Soviet Union to participate in an international naval blockade, and had ``signalled'' to the Soviet Union, China, Britain and France that a blockading force would be needed soon. In Moscow, however, the Soviet Foreign Ministry, called a blockade ``not the best line'' to take. The Washington Post said Britain had agreed to cooperate in a blockade. Both newspapers attributed their reports to unidentified U.S. officials. The Post also said unidentified U.S. intelligence officials reported that Iraqi forces appeared to have been loading poison gas aboard combat aircraft Tuesday. Iraq has a large stock of chemical weapons and has used them against Kurdish rebels as well as against Iranian troops in its 1980-1988 war with Iran. Pentagon sources, who spoke on condition of not being identified by name, said they expected Army units heading for Saudi Arabia to include elements of the 82nd Airborne Division from Fort Bragg, N.C.; the 24th Division (Mechanized) from Fort Stewart, Ga. and the 101st Airborne Division from Fort Campbell, Ky., near Clarksville, Tenn. The 82nd and the 101st make up the 18th Airborne Corps. The three divisions together would total about 44,800 soldiers, if all elements of each division, including a Georgia National Guard Brigade in the 24th, were assembled. The airborne divisions would protect Saudi air bases, so that other troops, aircraft and equipment can be sent in. A congressional source said Bush had decided to send F-16 fighters, F-15 fighters and tanker aircraft from bases within the United States, adding to the option of using fighter aircraft from Navy carriers. NBC News said Tuesday evening that Special Forces troops had been in Saudi Arabia for the previous 24 hours. Meantime, the carrier Saratoga and four escort ships steamed out of Mayport Naval Station in Florida on a week's voyage to the Mediterranean. The battleship Wisconsin was to leave Norfolk, Va., too, joining the Eisenhower and the carrier Independence in the region. Pentagon sources said the Eisenhower would pass through the Suez Canal Tuesday night en route to the Persian Gulf. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said if the deployments in Saudi Arabia were taking place as reported, ``I think this is the right thing to do. ... It discourages Iraq from invading.'' Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said the reported deployment would amount to a ``clear signal of our commitment to defend Saudi Arabia from a possible Iraqi attack.'' But, he said the United States ``should not expect that Saudi Arabia will implement United Nations sanctions against Iraq and close the Iraqi oil pipeline through its territory.'' The Bush administration has asked the Saudis to shut off the flow of Iraqi oil through its territory, as Turkey said it would Tuesday. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney was in Egypt Tuesday to seek that country's cooperation and later traveled to Morocco to discuss the situation with King Hassan. His whirlwind tour had begun with a stop in Saudi Arabia. Fitzwater said Bush told his Cabinet ``that he views the Iraqi troops lined up in Kuwait facing Saudi Arabia as a threat to United States security interests.'' The spokesman also reported that in a tense, two-hour session Monday between Saddam and the highest ranking American official in Iraq, charge d'affaires Joseph Wilson, ``Saddam indicated he had no intention of leaving Kuwait and had every indication of staying and claiming it as his own.'' The Iraqi leader underscored that reading in a message over Baghdad radio in which he defended the invasion as necessary to correct flawed regional borders drawn up by colonial powers. The invasion marked ``a new period in which the sun will shine on us in the coming days,'' he was quoted as saying. Fitzwater would not comment on a Washington Post report that Saddam had warned Wilson that he would attack Saudi Arabia if his pipeline through that country were cut off. Two State Department officials, insisting on anonymity, said Saddam leveled no such threat. Elsewhere, Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez promised to do everything he could to make up the 4.5 million barrel-a-day shortfall in oil stemming from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, an administration official traveling with Vice President Dan Quayle said. Quayle met Perez while both were in Bogota for the inauguration of Cesar Gaviria as president of Colombia. Perez was quoted as telling Quayle that Venezuela and other OPEC states were working to stabilize oil prices at or near the cartel's agreed price of $21 a barrel. The price has soared to more than $28 a barrel since the invasion. The New York Times said in Wednesday editions that Saudi Arabia was expected to increase output by 2 million barrels a day, about a 40 percent increase. Bush had declared on Monday that sanctions approved 13-0 by the United Nations Security Council ``will be enforced, whatever it takes.'' But on Tuesday he had nothing to add, saying at the White House, ``I'm just not going to take any questions today, thanks.'' Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said an international naval blockade to isolate Iraq _ which depends on imported food _ is ``very likely unless the Iraqis back off and start moving out of Kuwait,'' undoing last week's invasion. Concern over the fate of Americans and other Westerners trapped in Baghdad appeared to ease. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said that 28 Americans picked up Monday by Iraqi troops in Kuwait have turned up in a Baghdad hotel but ``are not being allowed to leave.''
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Smithsonian Girding for Threat of Lean Times Ahead
DOC.TEXT: The gaily painted carousel on the National Mall is still taking tourists on a gentle musical swing through yesteryear, but officials at the Smithsonian Institution's nearby headquarters are bracing for a bumpy financial ride into the future. Anticipating a new era of austerity after a quarter-century of extraordinary expansion, the Smithsonian is delaying the start of several major construction and renovation projects and searching for ways to trim its costly payroll of 6,600 employees. At the moment, Robert McC. Adams, secretary of the Smithsonian, is gratified that a House subcommittee recently voted to boost his federal appropriation next year by nearly 18 percent, from $267 million to $313 million, even more than he had requested. Nevertheless, Adams is worried about ominous portents of a long-term budget squeeze, including economic disruptions from the Persian Gulf crisis and the threat of ``almost unbelievably devastating'' automatic spending cuts in mid-October under the Gramm-Rudman deficit reduction law. ``The Smithsonian has been generously treated for a very long time,'' Adams said recently. ``But I think it is the case that the numbers are large enough now that we cannot expect them to continue as they have in the past.'' ``We have to face the fact that we are likely to grow more slowly in the years ahead,'' he said in a telephone interview from his vacation home in Basalt, Colo. An early casualty of the impending budget crunch was Undersecretary Dean W. Anderson, who resigned in late July as Adams' day-to-day overseer of the sprawling Smithsonian complex of 14 museums and galleries, plus the National Zoo. After 17 boom years at the Smithsonian, Anderson made clear he had little stomach for presiding over personnel and program cutbacks in future years of retrenchment and streamlining of managerial staff. Anderson's resignation resulted in scare headlines suggesting that the Smithsonian had plunged into a severe financial crisis. Adams wrote a letter to the editor of The Washington Post complaining that the press reports ``may leave the public with the erroneous impression that the Smithsonian is about to close its doors.'' The Smithsonian is still very much in business, but the growing budgetary pinch that it shares with other federal agencies may be more visible at the Smithsonian's vast cultural and scientific enterprises, which attracted 24.2 million visitors last year. The National Museum of Natural History, for example, has more than 50 staff vacancies, leaving gaps in the museum's far-flung research activities and threatening to delay curatorial work for future exhibitions. In April, the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden temporarily closed an entire floor of its galleries of modern art because it couldn't afford to pay the guards. The National Museum of American History has abandoned its school programs, bilingual activities and its plans to bolster hiring of minority staffers. The Smithsonian receives virtually no federal money to mount major exhibitions, even though 84 percent of its current $353 million budget comes from congressional appropriations and the rest from various trust funds, gifts and profit-making ventures. As a result, American History was forced to rely on computer and telecommunications industry donors to finance its ambitious ``Information Age'' show which opened in May, raising questions about corporate influence over exhibition content. The National Air and Space Museum desperately needs additional storage space, but Adams says construction of a planned $330 million museum extension at Dulles International Airport may be in jeopardy if budget cuts require postponement of building plans. At the National Zoo, Director Michael Robinson said ``additional budget cuts could have grave consequences'' by forcing the zoo to suspend modernization projects and curtail education, conservation and research activities. Adams said his major priorities are to build a $175 million National Museum of the American Indian on the Mall _ the Smithsonian's 15th museum _ and decide what form an African-American ``presence'' should take in Washington. He also is determined to expand cultural diversity at the Smithsonian, with greater focus on minority interests, and pursue research and education on protecting the environment. Last week, the White House budget office told the Smithsonian to begin preparing for a 32 percent spending cut if budget negotiators fail to meet Gramm-Rudman's deficit reduction target by the Oct. 1 start of the fiscal year. To compensate for a projected loss of $77 million in federal funds next year, Adams envisioned cancellation of museum programs, drastically shorter museum hours and widespread job layoffs.

DOC.HEAD: Voters Narrowly Approve Zoo Expansion
DOC.TEXT: Voters narrowly approved a $50 million bond issue to renovate and expand the aging Kansas City Zoo. With all precincts reporting, the issue had 37,514 yes votes, or 58.4 percent, and 26,517 no votes, or 41 percent. It needed 57 percent of the vote to pass. The money will be used to more than double the size of the 80-acre zoo on the city's east side, and increase the number of species from 168 to 263. The plan also calls for new African and Australian exhibits that allow species to interact as they do in the wild. Supporters said renovation would boost slumping attendance and assure better care for animals at the 81-year-old zoo. Opponents said the city should focus on more pressing problems, such as drugs, crime and homelessness. They also said it was the wrong time to add to Kansas City tax bills. The bond issue will add an estimated $10 a year to the average homeowner's property tax. Residents of the school district already face a likely 24 property tax hike for teacher salaries, approved by a federal judge and awaiting school board acion.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Bert Parks says he may take up Miss America Pageant officials on their offer to return. But he won't do it for a song. Parks serenaded the newly crowned beauty queen with ``There She Is'' for 25 years before he was fired as emcee in 1980 to give the show a younger look. The pageant director who dumped him, Albert Marks, died last year. Marks' successor, Leonard Horn, wants to bring back Parks for the pageant's 75th anniversary this year. The pageant will be held Sept. 4-8 and shown on NBC. Parks, 75, said Tuesday that terms of his return are still being worked out. Horn said Gary Collins and Phyllis George will be hosts this year for the second time. Parks wasn't thrilled about that news. ``I don't want to appear in something fourth-fiddle,'' he said. And he said he will not appear merely to sing the traditional song. ``If it's just that, we ain't doing nothing,'' Parks said.

Mick Jagger says the Rolling Stones will perform in Czechoslovakia, and he hinted they'd like a gig in the Soviet Union. The Czechoslovakia show, expected to draw 100,000, is scheduled for Aug. 18 at Strahov Stadium in Prague, Jagger said Tuesday. He indicated the Stones would like an extended tour in Eastern Europe, including the Soviet Union. Their only previous Eastern European appearance was in Poland in 1964. Proceeds of the Prague concert, which could be more than $467,500, will go to the Czechoslovak Children's Foundation, which benefits handicapped children, Romanian refugees and victims of the nuclear disaster at Chernobyl. The charity is headed by Olga Havel, wife of Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel.

Prince Charles will show 50 of his watercolors and lithographs next month to raise money for repairs to the Salisbury Cathedral spire. The exhibition will open Sept. 5 in Salisbury, 84 miles from London, Buckingham Palace said Tuesday. The prince is president of a trust that is trying to raise $12 million for restoration of the 404-foot spire, which is 730 years old.

Robyn Astaire, Fred Astaire's widow, says in a lawsuit that CBS Records owes her more than $50,000 in royalties on her husband's recordings. The lawsuit filed Friday says CBS Records underreports and underpays royalties to entertainers. A CBS Records receptionist Tuesday said lawyers had no comment on the lawsuit. The lawsuit demands return of an estimated 50 to 100 master recordings, including the soundtracks to such Astaire films as ``Easter Parade,'' said Thomas White, an industry consultant who manages the Astaire music assets. Astaire albums sell hundreds of thousands of copies a year worldwide, White said. He said CBS Records' license to distribute the records has been terminated. Astaire died in 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Cool August Weather Concerns Corn, Soybean Growers
DOC.TEXT: Cool weather in August is concerning many farmers whose late-planted corn and soybeans might run into an early frost in a few weeks. That would reduce grain yields and put a crimp into Agriculture Department predictions of bumper harvests this fall and a generally rosy outlook for the coming year. But it's premature to make such dire weather predictions, says USDA meteorologist Jeffrey A. Andresen. Farmers, bankers and grain traders will have to sweat a while longer. ``Based on normal weather, I would think the odds and statistics would favor the crop maturing normally and not having any problems,'' Andresen said. The USDA will issue its first survey-based estimate of 1990 production of corn, soybeans and other fall-harvested crops on Thursday. Those estimates will be updated again in September, October and November. Heavy rains kept farmers out of their fields over much of the country last spring, delaying planting and reducing the chance for optimum yields. But the growing season has been a dandy, for the most part, and now the worry is about early freezes in the northern areas. A weekly weather and crop report on Tuesday showed corn development still running far behind normal in much of the main production areas. In Iowa, for example, 85 percent of the corn was in the silking stage, compared with a normal development of 98 percent. Illinois was even more behind at 79 percent, compared with 100 percent usually by now. Andresen said in a telephone interview Tuesday that he knows of ``no precursor to help predict an early frost.'' Most, he said, are ``micro-climatic phenomena'' that happen only occasionally on a significant scale. The last time an early frost did major economic damage was in 1974, when freezing weather ``clipped some of the corn and soybeans,'' Andresen said. On the other hand, farmers in 1984 had a very late spring and crops were planted well into June, he said. Those crops went on to mature for the fall harvest. The threat of frost begins in the Corn Belt ``sometime in the first couple of weeks of September,'' he said. That early area would include southern Minnesota and parts of northern Iowa. ``But most of the major part of the Corn Belt does not experience the first 32-degree Fahrenheit weather until sometime in early October,'' Andresen said. The recent below-normal temperatures have been ``fantastic as far as pollination and silking'' of corn is concerned, he said. But some warmer weather would be welcome now for development ``to speed it up a bit.'' Andresen added: ``We're just going to have to keep our finger crossed, but I would say again the statistics and the odds still do favor a normal completion of the season.''

Soybeans might be more attractive as human food if a world standard for protein nutritional quality is adopted, according to Agriculture Department officials. A new method of measuring food proteins was proposed by the department's Agricultural Research Service and Canada's Food Directorate, said William H. Tallent, assistant administrator of the research agency. The U.S.-Canada proposal and evaluation were made for the Food and Agriculture Organization, an agency of the United Nations. An FAO committee is recommending that countries adopt the new method. ``With the current method based on nutritional needs of rats rather than humans, soy protein ranks only about two-thirds as high as animal protein,'' Tallent said Tuesday. ``The new method is simpler, cheaper and more meaningful because it's based on human needs.'' Tallent is U.S. delegate to the vegetable protein committee, part of the Codex Alimentarius Commission that sets food standards for the FAO. Retired food technologist Frank McDonough, who organized much of the international testing of the method's reliability, said the new method could help the image of vegetable protein, particularly U.S. soybean products. ``Soy protein scores higher for nutritional quality under the new standard, and the United States produces most of the soy protein in world markets,'' McDonough said.

Apple juice is gaining favor in Japan, says an Agriculture Department trade report. ``This increasing thirst is expected to grow at an annual rate of more than 10 percent for the next several years from the 1989 level of 54,000 metric tons as consumers switch to high-quality fruit juices the report said. Until recently, it added, juice consumption was limited to ``relatively poor quality fruit beverages'' because of strict government controls on fruit juice. That limited the supply of 100 percent fruit juice. ``But supplies are improving due to expansion of import quotas and Japanese liberalization of apple, grape and pineapple imports on April 1, 1990,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Simulating Baby Turtles With Ping-Pong Balls
DOC.TEXT: One man's ping-pong balls are the Navy's ``model baby turtles.'' The Navy plans to float ping-pong balls this week from the hatching grounds of threatened turtles near the Dry Tortugas to determine whether hatchlings might drift into an explosives testing zone. Navy officials said they will delay tests of 1,200-pound explosives 15 miles from the island chain until they feel confident the babies won't be hurt. ``If they (the balls) drift into the area, we'll have a problem,'' said Dan Probert, head of the Navy's ordnance testing program in Key West. The weapons research is aimed at helping produce new systems for submarines. Richie Moretti, who runs the Hidden Harbor Environmental Project, called the ping-pong ball exercise ludicrous. He said Monday the Navy should hold off on explosives testing until after the August-to-October turtle hatching season. ``Mother Nature provided them with a shell, but not one that can withstand a blast,'' Moretti said. Michael Eng, the National Park Service superintendent for the Fort Jefferson National Monument on Dry Tortugas, said his staff counted 40 turtle nests on the Tortugas islands. Each nest contains 100 to 120 eggs.

DOC.HEAD: High-Stepping Frogs Will Dance No More in Carl's Corner
DOC.TEXT: A trio of high-stepping frogs will dance no more at the truck stop. A fire Monday gutted the gas station and restaurant owned by Carl Cornelius, mayor of this town of 230 people near Dallas. The gigantic fiberglass frogs atop the business survived, but Cornelius sold them for $35,000. ``I didn't want to sell them, but I have people I owe money to. The man caught me in a vulnerable situation, so I had to do something,'' Cornelius said Tuesday. The three frogs, posed dancing on their hind legs, were the truck stop's big draw. One plays a guitar. Another holds a trumpet. The third just dances along. The truck stop near Hillsboro, about 55 miles southeast of Dallas, was not insured, Cornelius said.

DOC.HEAD: Makeup of U.S. Units Headed for Mideast
With PM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The first U.S. Army units said to be headed for Saudi Arabia are specially trained and equipped for rapid deployment in crisis zones. The units are elements of the 18th Airborne Corps, a command-and-control umbrella organization based at Ft. Bragg, N.C. It was not immediately known how many of the troops were to be sent from each unit, and how they would be equipped. Here is a brief look at the three units:
DOC.HEAD: 24th Mechanized Infantry Division _ Ft. Stewart, Ga.
DOC.TEXT: Two active-duty brigades and one ``round-out'' brigade from the Georgia National Guard. The brigades have a total of 10 battalions _ five infantry and five armored, three battalions in each category on active status. Each armored battalion has 58 M-1 tanks. Each infantry battalion is equipped with Bradley Fighting Vehicles, an updated version of the standard Armored Personnel Carrier. The Bradley Fighting Vehicles have combat capability. The 24th has a total of 16,600 personnel.
DOC.HEAD: 101st Airborne Division _ Ft. Campbell, Ky.
DOC.TEXT: The 101st Airborne is not a jumping paratroop division. It has three active brigades, a total of nine battalions. Each battalion has 20 TOW anti-tank weapons. The division is equipped with 90 Blackhawk helicopters for troop transport. Additionally, it has 18 Apache and 18 Cobra armor fighting helicopters, referred to as ``tank killers.'' The 101st has a total of 15,400 personnel.
DOC.HEAD: 82nd Airborne Division _ Ft. Bragg, N.C.
DOC.TEXT: This jumping paratroop division has three brigades, with three battalions in each brigade. Each battalion is equipped with 20 TOW anti-tank weapons. The 82nd has a total of 12,800 personnel.

DOC.HEAD: Prison Prepares for Execution By Staging a Mock One
DOC.TEXT: Oklahoma is preparing for its first execution in 24 years by staging _ and videotaping _ a mock one. Up to 40 prison officials will take part next week in the mock execution at the Oklahoma State Penitentiary. ``We will role-play the entire process and video it,'' said Warden James Saffle. ``We want to make sure we are maintaining professionalism and the dignity of the inmate.'' The last person executed in Oklahoma was James French, who died in the electric chair in 1966. Charles Troy Coleman has been sentenced to die by injection Sept. 10 for the 1979 shotgun slaying of John Seward, 68, of Muskogee. Seward and his wife, Roxie, were killed after they apparently surprised a burglar. In 1987, Coleman came within 36 hours of execution before he received a stay.

DOC.HEAD: Benny Carter Premieres `Good Vibes'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will stand for PMs.
DOC.TEXT: Good title: ``Good Vibes.'' It describes precisely the first composition commissioned by Classical Jazz at Lincoln Center as conducted Tuesday by its creator, Benny Carter, the night before his 83rd birthday. ``Good vibes'' is what the audience felt for 35 minutes, the vibraphone the solo instrument. Each of the six movements was a delight musically and, somehow, set the mood of an enjoyable social occasion. Carter led a 17-piece band, sometimes playing his saxophone. He wrote for unusual instrumentation, putting the spotlight on two vibraphones. His soloists for the premiere were Bobby Hutcherson and Milt Jackson. They are splendid players and so was the band. Carter has written for a melodic swing band, like Fletcher Henderson or Count Basie, more than the driving big band style of Buddy Rich, Woody Herman or Stan Kenton. Hutcherson, who was inspired to play vibraphone by hearing a record by Jackson, makes a dashing attack on the instrument. His notes are clean and clear and heard individually. Jackson is more subtle, playing smooth phrases. But Carter didn't always compose to those leanings. He gave Hutcherson the solo in the movement titled ``Ballad for Bobby'' which had some melancholy and lovely chords and turned romantic. And Jackson was given some fast, urgent passages. It was marvelous to hear both vibraphonists play enough to get a rounded sense of their abilities. The first half of the concert in Alice Tully Hall had pianist James Williams, bassist Ron Carter and drummer Billy Higgins. Hutcherson played with them on a tune which went from slow to fast to mellow, a pretty ballad and a jump-right-in number. Jackson then played with them on ``If I Were a Bell,'' ``Willow Weep for Me'' and a flowing, elegant riff. Before presenting his ``Good Vibes,'' Carter led the big band in a few of the songs he has written, ``Vine Street Rumble,'' ``Sao Paulo,'' ``The South Side Samba'' and the lovely ``Evening Star,'' which he said he titled ``Blue Star'' until he wrote lyrics for it and needed an additional syllable.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: America's Three Best Friends Stand to Gain _ If Iraq Pulls Back
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: If _ and at this point it's a big optimistic if _ U.S. and world pressure forces Iraq's Saddam Hussein to pull back from Kuwait, three of America's best friends in the Middle East stand to gain new stature. The three are Egypt, which has stood virtually alone in the Arab world alongside the United States; Jordan, which ironically stood apart; and Israel, which has sounded warnings about Baghdad that until now were considered exaggerated. Saddam's drive into Kuwait shocked the Bush administration into a starker perception of the Iraqi leader than policymakers were willing to consider only a few weeks ago. Sanctions urged by Congress were sidestepped then as too harsh, although consideration was given to restoring Iraq to the State Department's list of countries that support terrorism. Now, with Kuwait in the hands of an invading Iraqi force and U.S. troops preparing to defend Saudi Arabia's oil fields, the United States seems poised to take Saddam on _ preferably through an economic blockade backed by an international armada. In pursuit of this strategy, President Bush sent Defense Secretary Dick Cheney on the road to persuade the Saudis their oil fields must be secured and then to Egypt to stake out bases there. Today, Secretary of State James A. Baker III was flying to Turkey and then to Brussels on Friday where the 16 NATO countries will develop a blockade strategy. Historically, the sense of brotherhood that permeates the Arab world makes it difficult for outside powers like the United States to gain overt support from one country against another. That makes Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak's decision to line up with Washington against Saddam's invasion of Kuwait all the more remarkable. Egypt, by virtue of being the only Arab country to sign a peace treaty with Israel, already is held in special regard by the U.S. administration. Mubarak also is the key U.S. conduit to the Palestine Liberation Organization in Baker's so far unsuccessful attempt to set up negotiations between Israel and Palestinian Arabs. Cairo receives nearly $3 billion in annual assistance from the United States. Any reasonable request for additional economic or military help is apt to get a sympathetic hearing at the White House and on Capitol Hill. If Iraq submits to pressure and withdraws, Jordan also will benefit, but under very different circumstances. Unlike Mubarak, the Jordanian monarch, King Hussein, did not rally to the U.S. banner. In fact, he disputed the Bush administration's assessment of the Iraqi leader. On Saturday, as Iraqi troops solidified their hold on Kuwait, the king said it was premature for Arab countries to condemn the invasion. Hussein called the Iraqi leader a patriotic man. Whatever motivated the king to defer to his more powerful neighbor, Jordan offers safe passageway from Iraq, and 78 tourists, most of them Japanese, exited that way on Monday. And if under increasing pressure Saddam elects to seek a diplomatic compromise, he might well ask Jordan to play a middleman role. The third biggest gainer could be Israel, which understandably is maintaining a low profile as the United States marshals the forces to stop Saddam. Nine years ago, Israel destroyed Iraq's only nuclear facility in what Jerusalem described as a pre-emptive strike. In today's Middle East, the Israelis worry just as much about Iraqi missiles and chemical weapons. But they may not be inclined to take the same political and diplomatic risk they chanced in June 1981 by leveling the Osirak reactor near Baghdad. Nor may Israel have to. The United States, with infinitely more prestige than the small Jewish state could ever hope to muster, is leading a world campaign against the Iraqi leader. Saddam's invasion of Kuwait could backfire against him in any number of ways, all of them enhancing Israel's security. Forcing him to withdraw would clip his wings. Although officials are reluctant to discuss hypothetical situations, a military collision with Iraq conceivably could lead to his ouster _ and a drastic change in the security situation in the Middle East.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid is the AP's chief diplomatic writer.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Plans to Resume Shuttle Flights Next Month, Officials Say
DOC.TEXT: NASA plans to roll Columbia back to the launch pad late this week and prepare the space shuttle for an early September liftoff that will put Americans back in orbit for the first time since April. At a news conference Tuesday, NASA Associate Administrator William Lenoir said the agency is so confident about the repair of a hydrogen leak on Columbia that it has canceled plans to make an additional test for the leak. ``We're back on track and more or less are in our normal operating scheme,'' Lenoir told reporters. He said a new plumbing connection, called an umbilical, has been placed on Columbia and engineers believe this has eliminated the hydrogen leak. Meanwhile, scientists working with the Hubble Space Telescope said Tuesday they are getting closer to a complete description of the focusing flaw that has crippled the $1.5 billion spacecraft. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has not launched a space shuttle since April. Launch attempts of Columbia and of Atlantis were scrubbed after hydrogen leaks were discovered on the craft. The leaks forced the agency to ground the shuttle fleet until engineers found the source of the leaking hydrogen and corrected the problem. Lenoir said tests of Columbia's leaky umbilical determined that hydrogen was escaping from seals near two valves. The flawed umbilical was replaced with new hardware from Endeavour, a space shuttle now being built. Tests showed that the leak on Atlantis was not in the valve seals, but in another place in the maze of pipes that carry liquid hydrogen, Lenoir said. This means, he said, that the leaks were from two separate problems and did not indicate a design or manufacturing weakness in the shuttle system. Atlantis, still on the launch pad at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida, will be rolled back to the hangar for repairs late this week. Columbia will take its place on the launch pad and be prepared for a liftoff on Sept. 4 or 5, Lenoir said. NASA earlier had announced plans to test Columbia for leaks by pumping liquid hydrogen into the shuttle's fuel tank. A similar test on Atlantis led to discovery of its leak in June. But Lenoir said Columbia now will be tested for leaks only as the shuttle is being fueled for launch. He said that even if a special test detected a leak in Columbia, it could not be fixed in time for a mission in September. NASA engineers have to spend much of September preparing for the Oct. 5 launch of space shuttle Discovery and its payload, the Ulysses space probe.
