The Ulysses, which is destined to go into a polar orbit of the sun, can only be launched during a planetary alignment of the Earth and Jupiter that occurs once every 13 months. The purpose of Columbia's mission is to carry into orbit an array of astronomy instruments. A seven-man crew will use the instruments to study the stars during a nine-day flight. Atlantis had been scheduled to fly a secret military mission. That flight has yet to be rescheduled. The current schedule calls for Atlantis to fly a science mission in November and for Columbia to fly a space laboratory mission in December. Regarding the Hubble problem, mission scientist Ed Weiler said NASA engineers expect by Labor Day to understand enough about the focusing problem to start the grinding of eight corrective lens for a replacement camera now being built. An instrument, called the wide field planetary camera, will be installed in the Hubble during a space shuttle flight in 1993. Corrective optics in the camera will compensate for the flawed focus in the primary mirror of the telescope. Weiler said scientists are taking a series of pictures with the camera now on board Hubble and that by analyzing these pictures, experts should be able to draw up a prescription for the corrective optics on the new camera. He said with this schedule, the replacement camera could be ready in time for a space shuttle repair mission to the orbiting Hubble by January 1993.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaiti Refugees Tell Of Their Ordeal, Guests Of Saudi Government
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Numbed by terror and loss, Kuwaiti refugees are telling of desperate attempts to escape the Iraqi assault wave and of invaders killing people who tried to stop them from entering private homes. But the refugees appear to be finding some solace in the generosity shown by leaders of neighboring Persian Gulf states. One refugee, 7-year-old Fahd, said Iraqi soldiers had forced their way into his family's Kuwait city home and made them turn over everything they owned. Ghanem al-Asimi, who worked at Kuwait International Airport, described how Iraqi troops were ``beating up people, stealing cars and forcing drivers to stop, shooting them if they disobeyed.'' Asimi and others Kuwaitis spoke Tuesday in the cafeteria of a hotel in Bahrain, to which they had fled after Thursday's invasion. ``Everybody was hysterical,'' he said. ``We kept getting calls from friends saying that a few families who tried to stop Iraqis from entering their homes were shot dead.'' The bulk of refugees who made it out were those who fled south on the first and second days of the invasion, before the Iraqis stretched their forces along the borders. More recent arrivals slipped through the desert. In Dubai, the capital of the neighboring United Arab Emirates, a number of Europeans said Tuesday that they had sneaked across the Kuwaiti desert to safety, pushed by a general desperation and a fear of food shortages in Kuwait. Jeremy Upton, a 28-year-old Briton, said Iraqi artillery hitting targets in Kuwait city persuaded him he ``had to go for it fast. ``I was looking north to the city, and about 15 miles away saw the shells hitting,'' he said. ``It was probably the palace and that really brought it home.'' Upton, a shipping company employee, grabbed his 2-year-old daughter, Hannah, and his Kuwaiti wife, Ashmahan al-Abdul Hadi and fled. Leaving behind all personal belongings, they jumped into a small jeep and drove 840 miles to Saudi Arabia and on to Dubai on the southern Persian Gulf. Helena Von Schantz, a 31-year-old Stockholm native, and her electronics engineer husband Mikael Wiberg fled by car with their daughter and son and a German technician. They left Kuwait shortly after sunrise Sunday, driving to Bahrain from Abu Halifa, a southern suburb of Kuwait City. ``It was safer to risk our lives this way than remain behind,'' said Mrs. Von Schantz said. ``Food supplies were beginning to run out in Kuwait.'' ``The soldiers in our area seemed almost apologetic and uncomfortable about having invaded Kuwait. But soldiers near the border were different, exuding a feeling of power,'' she said. The Kuwaitis and other nationals who escaped their occupied oil-rich kingdom have been greeted warmly bytheir southern neighbors. In the United Arab Emirates, the government is paying the hotel bill of 800 Kuwaitis who arrived there. Each was given more than $500 on arrival. Kuwait had a population of some 1.8 million, of which more than 60 percent were foreigners. When the invasion was launched, about half the population was reportedly out of the country, escaping the gulf's burning summer. Saudi Arabia's King Fahd has issued orders to consider all Kuwaitis guests of the kingdom, according to official sources reached by telephone from Bahrain. Saudi banks were ordered Tuesday to purchase Kuwaiti dinars from cash-starved Kuwaitis at a higher rate than the plummeting market value after the Iraqi invasion. In addition, Kuwait Airways has started operating out of the eastern Saudi city of Dhahran. The sources estimated the number of refugees from Kuwait now inside the kingdom at about 40,000. They include the emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, who was spirited to Saudi Arabia in the first hours of the invasion. The emir has apparently taken up residence in an opulent palace.

DOC.HEAD: Vice President Conferring With Peruvian Leader
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle was discussing drug control and economic development today with the new president of Peru, a country the Bush administration considers laggard in the drive against cocaine. President Alberto Fujimori, who took office only 11 days ago, is looking for development aid as he tries to repair a collapsing economy. But Quayle's message was expected to be that without strong anti-drug measures by Peru, Congress won't approve the kind of aid the country needs. It was the second stop on Quayle's mission to the three nations that joined the United States at the Cartagena, Colombia, drug summit last Feb. 15. In Bogota, Colombia, on Tuesday, the vice president said the campaign against illegal drugs is ``a common fight _ it is a partnership.'' Quayle went to Bogota for the inauguration of Colombian President Cesar Gaviria, and said his visit symbolized the U.S. commitment to work with that government against drugs and for expanded trade and development there. He told Gaviria that talks the Colombians seek to implement a new trade agreement between the two countries will open by the first week in September. In his inaugural address, as Quayle sat among visiting leaders, Gaviria emphasized that drug-consuming countries must reduce their demand for cocaine, because the cocaine-producing nations cannot solve the problem otherwise. Fujimori has made that point, too. Quayle also was meeting in Lima with 11 Peruvian business leaders. The topic, again, was economic development for an economy in which inflation has rocketed to over 3,000 percent a year. The vice president was attending a luncheon with Peruvian officials before heading on to La Paz, Bolivia. While Quayle aides said Congress would be the problem in a bid for new aid without tough drug measures, the administration's own Office of National Drug Control Policy put it even more sharply in a paper on the Andean drug strategy. That account, distributed aboard Quayle's Air Force jet, said the United States is monitoring and evaluating drug-fighting efforts to see whether they ``justify the provision'' of additional aid next year. The drug policy office said the situation in Peru ``is the most problematic'' among the three Andean countries. ``Peruvians commonly perceive the economy and the insurgency as bigger national issues than narcotics,'' the paper said. ``To date, Peru has demonstrated limited effectiveness in curtailing its cocaine industry and its national will to do so remains to be demonstrated.'' The drug policy office said the Andean strategy is designed to ``assist Peru by strengthening its institutional will and capability to take action against the cocaine industry.'' Quayle is to meet tonight in La Paz with Bolivian President Jaime Paz Zamora. After a final round of meeting in Bolivia on Thursday, he flies to Haiti and then returns to Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Bush To Discuss Mideast Situation On National Television
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's speech to the nation scheduled for Wednesday morning will be televised live by ABC, CBS, NBC and CNN, officials at the networks said Tuesday. The White House announced late Tuesday that Bush, who dispatched American warplanes and ground troops to Saudi Arabia, would address the nation on television at 9 a.m. EDT.

DOC.HEAD: Brando's Son Pleads Innocent to Murder
DOC.TEXT: Marlon Brando's son pleaded innocent to murdering his sister's lover and remained behind bars on $10 million bail. Defense attorney Robert L. Shapiro said he will ask for a reduction in 32-year-old Christian Brando's bail, arguing that an everyday defendant in such a case would be held on $50,000 to $100,000. ``We are going to ask that Christian not be singled out and treated differently than anyone else would be in a similar situation,'' Shapiro said. He said he may propose at a hearing Thursday that the actor's son be released with an electronic monitoring device on his ankle or wrist. Christian Brando pleaded innocent to murder and possession of a machine gun in the slaying of Dag Drollet, the 26-year-old Tahitian lover of his half-sister, Cheyenne Brando, in an argument May 16 at the elder Brando's estate. Marlon Brando did not attend Tuesday's hearing. Prosecutors argued previously for no bail, saying the defendant might flee the country. Two weeks ago, a judge set $10 million as the price for Brando's freedom, taking into consideration his father's vast wealth. Authorities said that was believed to be the highest bail ever set in Los Angeles County. Miss Brando, 20, recently went to Tahiti. Authorities say she is unwilling to return to testify at her brother's trial. Police who arrived at the Brando home in the Santa Monica Mountains said young Brando told them he shot Drollet accidentally ``because he hurt my sister. My sister is pregnant.'' Miss Brando gave birth June 30 in Tahiti.

DOC.HEAD: Worldwide Embargoes Against Iraq Gain Momentum
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hitting Baghdad where it hurts, more countries have joined a U.N.-sanctioned boycott of oil from Iraq and Kuwait. On Tuesday, countries ranging from powerful Japan to neutral Switzerland to tiny Cyprus cut off petroleum imports in an effort to convince the Baghdad government to withdraw its troops that invaded Kuwait on Thursday. Turkey announced it was shut down the twin Iraqi oil pipelines that run through it to the Mediterranean _ carrying half of Baghdad's crude output _ and cutting off trade with Iraq. Baghdad's only other major pipelines exporting crude run through Saudi Arabia, where the flow has been drastically reduced. The U.N. Security Council on Monday voted to impose broad economic sanctions against Iraq for invading small oil-rich Kuwait. The measure forbids loans to Iraq or Kuwait and prohibits any activities, including the transfer of money, that would help the two countries export their goods. Sanctions adopted by the European Economic Community on Saturday froze Iraqi assets and suspended the purchase of oil from the two Arab countries. More than 90 percent of imports from Iraq to the 12-nation EEC are petroleum products. The EEC also suspended arms sales to Iraq. Switzerland, which is not a member of the United Nations, made the unusual move Tuesday of joining the U.N. sanctions and banned all trade with Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. In addition, Switzerland prohibited all payments and other financial transfers to Iraq and Kuwait. Denmark, Norway and Sweden also announced embargoes on all trade with both countries. Japan's participation in the U.N. sanctions was seen as especially key since Tokyo usually has taken a low profile in the Middle East, which supplies much of its petroleum needs. Japan imports 99 percent of its oil. China joined the U.N. decision to embargo arms sales to Iraq, but has been less vocal than other major countries in condemning the invasion. China sold arms to both Iran and Iraq during their eight-year war and is a major Iraqi trade partner. Cyprus' sacrifice in joining the embargo was to give up 70 percent of its oil imports, government spokesman Akis Fantis said. Cyprus has sufficient oil supplies to last until the end of August, he said, but ``we are already in the process of taking steps to secure alternative sources ...'' The worldwide closing of ranks against Iraqi oil imports is likely to lead to even higher petroleum prices, which have already risen dramatically since the invasion and could have a major impact on the world economy. Wholesale oil prices soared to five-year highs in New York on Monday. France will introduce controls Thursday on prices of petroleum products to prevent refiners from using Iraq's invasion of Kuwait as an excuse to raise prices, acting Premier Pierre Beregovoy announced Tuesday. An official with the Petroleum Association of Japan said he was unaware of any increase yet in the price of gasoline for consumers. The official, who refused to be further identified, said it would be at least three months before the sanctions could be expected to force higher gas prices in Japan.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 28,509.14, up 856.07 points or 3.10 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Maimed Protester Settles For $920,000
DOC.TEXT: An anti-war demonstrator whose legs were severed by a Navy munitions train has agreed to settle his lawsuit against the government and train crew for $920,000, his lawyer says. The settlement is subject to approval by the U.S. Justice Department, said attorney Thomas Steel. Brian Willson, 49, had sued for personal injuries and civil rights violations after his legs were cut off below the knee as he sat on the tracks outside the Concord Naval Weapons Station in 1987. He and others were protesting against U.S. weapons shipments to Central America. ``I hope this settlement at least means that the government can't use lethal force to stop demonstrators,'' Willson said in today's San Francisco Chronicle. Lawyers for the defendants _ the U.S. government, the three-member train crew and two supervisors at the Concord base _ agreed to the settlement, Steel said. The lawsuit had been set for trial Sept. 10 in federal court. Steel said that under the agreement, none of the defendants admitted any wrongdoing. Assistant U.S. Attorney John Penrose, who represented the government, said he was barred by a confidentiality order from commenting on the settlement. Willson sued in 1988 after the train crew filed a complaint seeking damages for emotional distress they said he intended to inflict on them by letting them run over him. Their lawsuit was dismissed earlier this year. Willson's lawsuit claimed the Navy had been notified about plans to block the train and that the crew could see him far down the tracks and had time to stop the train before running into him at 17 mph, more than three times the posted 5 mph limit. The Navy accused Willson of causing his own injuries.

DOC.HEAD: Highlights of Voting in Four States
With PM-Primaries Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are highlights of primary balloting in four states Tuesday: GEORGIA= Governor: Lt. Gov. Zell Miller defeated Andrew Young in a runoff for the Democratic nomination for governor. Miller will meet Republican Johnny Isakson. KANSAS= Governor: First-term Gov. Mike Hayden edged real estate executive Nestor Weigand Jr. in a six-way Republican primary. State Treasurer Joan Finney won the Democratic nomination, upsetting former Gov. John Carlin. Senate: GOP Sen. Nancy Kassebaum swamped political unknown Gregory Walstrom to win nomination to a third term. Former Rep. Bill Roy won the Democratic Senate primary. Even though he tried to get off the ballot, he drew more votes than political newcomer Dick Williams of Wichita. MICHIGAN= Governor: Republicans chose Sen. John Engler over General Motors engineer John Lauve to challenge two-term Democrat James Blanchard. Senate: Republican Rep. Bill Schuette defeated lawyer Clark Durant for the right to oppose Democrat Carl Levin, who is seeking a third term. MISSOURI= Rep. Richard Gephardt, the House majority leader, won the Democratic nomination for an eighth term, trouncing Nicholas F. Clement, a newspaper carrier who is a follower of extremist Lyndon LaRouche.

DOC.HEAD: Young Fails in Georgia Bid; Hayden Survives Kansas Scare
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: Andrew Young came up short in his bid to make history as Georgia's first black governor, falling to Lt. Gov. Zell Miller in a Democratic runoff. Kansas Gov. Mike Hayden survived a scare, edging a Republican primary opponent who blamed him for higher property taxes. ``Don't say that I didn't run a good campaign,'' Young, the former Atlanta mayor, congressman and U.N. ambassador, said Tuesday night. ``Say that Zell Miller ran a better campaign.'' With 99 percent of precincts reporting, Miller had 576,226 votes, or 62 percent. Young had 352,159 votes, or 38 percent. The loser called for party unity and termed Miller his ``former opponent, but my friend.'' ``Zell Miller is a people-person whom the people of Georgia feel comfortable with,'' Young said. ``They know Zell Miller better than they know Andy Young.'' Young, 58, had hoped to follow in the footsteps of L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia, who last November became the nation's first black elected governor. He finished 12 points behind Miller in the primary July 17 after a genteel campaign in which race was rarely mentioned. For the runoff, Young went on the offensive, attacking Miller's ties to the banking industry and resurrecting the label ``Zig-Zag Zell'' that was hung on Miller 10 years ago to suggest he changed positions for political expediency. ``Now is the time for reconciliation,'' Miller, 58, said in claiming victory. ``The last two weeks I did not see the Andy Young I had known for the last 20 years. But I also can empathize with him. I've been behind. I've lashed out. I understand that feeling.'' Miller, whose main issue was support for a state lottery, faces Republican Johnny Isakson in November. Democratic Gov. Joe Frank Harris was barred by law from seeking a third consecutive term. In Kansas, Hayden narrowly defeated real estate executive Nestor Weigand Jr., the strongest of five primary challengers. In an upset on the Democratic side, state Treasurer Joan Finney wrecked former Gov. John Carlin's hopes of a comeback. With all precincts reporting, Hayden had 138,025 votes, or 45 percent, Weigand had 130,358 votes, or 42 percent, and four others divided the remainder. Hayden and other Republicans were surprised by Mrs. Finney's victory. ``We certainly don't take her lightly,'' Hayden said. ``I look forward to an aggressive, very straightforward campaign on the issues.'' Weigand, a 51-year-old businessman with no political experience, spent his own money freely in a 10-week TV blitz. He hit hard at the 46-year-old governor's role in property reappraisal and a new classification system that many blamed for big property tax increases in 1989. ``You all have given me more than any candidate could ever expect,'' Weigand told supporters. ``We've come a long way in the last 11 weeks. And we've left an indelible mark on Kansas.'' On the Democratic side, Finney had 80,831 votes, or 47 percent; Carlin had 79,115 votes, or 46 percent; and minister Fred Phelps had 11,612 votes, or 7 percent. ``I have no regrets over the decision I made (to try a comeback) last October, and I have no regrets over the race I ran,'' Carlin said. Mrs. Finney said she attributed her victory to ``a desire by the people to regain control of their government, and have some fiscal responsibility.'' The longtime treasurer ran a shoestring campaign, raising only about $50,000, and few political observers gave her any chance. She received no major newspaper endorsements. Carlin's private life may have cost him votes. He divorced twice while he served as governor from 1979 to 1987, and his second wife drew unfavorable attention by trying to raise money for a swimming pool at the executive mansion while the Kansas economy was in trouble. Here are highlights of other voting Tuesday: MICHIGAN: Republicans picked state Sen. John Engler to challenge Gov. James Blanchard and Rep. Bill Schuette to take on Sen. Carl Levin. Both incumbent Democrats seek third terms. Engler won 87 percent of the vote against General Motors engineer John Lauve, while Schuette defeated lawyer Clark Durant 62 percent to 38 percent. MISSOURI: Rep. Richard Gephardt, the House majority leader, easily captured the Democratic nomination for an eighth term, claiming 82 percent of the vote against Nicholas F. Clement, a newspaper carrier who is a follower of extremist Lyndon LaRouche. KANSAS: Sen. Nancy Kassebaum had no trouble gaining the GOP nomination for a third term, piling up 87 percent of the vote against political unknown Gregory Walstrom. The victor in the Democratic Senate primary was former Rep. Bill Roy, who tried too late to remove his name from the ballot and still outpolled political newcomer Dick Williams of Wichita 57 percent to 43 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwait Crisis Highlights Turkey's Dilemma
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Persian Gulf crisis has put Turkey in a delicate spot, testing both its allegiance to NATO and the West and its commitment to friendly ties with its volatile Arab and Moslem neighbors. Secretary of State James A. Baker III arrives Thursday, and there is speculation the United States wants to enlist Turkey's military against Iraq. Turkey, which considers itself a bridge between Europe and Asia, has been feeling the pull of both East and West more than ever as it tries to take a balanced position in the aftermath of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Turkey doesn't want to isolate itself from the United States and Western Europe by refusing to take strong punitive action against neighboring Iraq. It is hoping for admission to the European Community, which has taken a tough line against Iraq. But predominately Moslem Turkey also fears provoking the wrath of Iraq and angering Moslem fundamentalists who value Arab solidarity. The dilemma was most evident in the way Ankara dealt with the twin pipelines that carry Iraqi oil through Turkey to a terminal on the Mediterranean coast. Turkey came under immediate pressure from the United States to shut down the pipelines, but Turkey refused to act unilaterally. Before long, Iraq shut down one of the pipelines itself and reduced the capacity of the second. Then, on Tuesday, the second pipeline was effectively shut down when Turkey announced it was banning tankers from loading oil from it. But Turkish officials were quick to stress that the decision was taken strictly in line with the oil embargo ordered by the U.N. Security Council on Monday. ``We were not pressured by anyone,'' said the state minister for oil affairs, Mehmet Kececiler. Western diplomatic sources said Turkey stood the most to lose of any NATO country from sanctions against Iraq. Iraq owes Turkey about $740 million, debts which were to be paid off with oil purchases. Turkey was being paid more than $250 million a year to service the pipelines. Now that the United States has intervened militarily in the crisis, Turkey may face tough decisions. The United States would need permission from the Turkish government to use bases on Turkish soil for any operations in the Persian Gulf. U.S. officials in Washington said Tuesday that a multinational force including Egyptians and Morrocans will be deployed in Saudi Arabia to deter an Iraqi attack. Turkish Foreign Ministry spokesman Murat Sungar said early today that Turkey had not received any request to join such a force. There has been speculation that Baker will raise military options when he arrives for talks with President Turgut Ozal and other officials. Western diplomatic sources said, however, that Baker is coming for ``broad consultations on overall strategy'' and not on a military mission. The Turkish media has speculated about the presence of 14 U.S. F-111 figher-bombers at the Incirlik air base in southern Turkey. The same type of aircraft, taking off from bases in Britain, were used in the 1986 U.S. bombing raids against Libya. The U.S. Embassy and the Foreign Ministry said Tuesday that the planes are on a routine rotation in Turkey. While Turkey suddenly finds itself in a prominent position in the Persian Gulf equation, only recently the country was wondering whether its long strategic role on NATO's southern flank was evaporating with the end of the Cold War. A further sense of isolation from the West came when the European Community indefinitely put off consideration of Turkey's bid to join the trading bloc.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Asks End of Antitrust Immunity
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department is calling for an end to the immunity U.S. airlines have from antitrust laws in fixing international air fares. The department's antitrust division made the recommendation Tuesday in comments filed with the Transportation Department, which is considering whether to extend the antitrust immunity for the International Air Transport Association. IATA's members, who include American and foreign airlines, set international air fares under an antitrust immunity that the organization has enjoyed since 1946. The Federal Aviation Act allows the granting of such antitrust exemptions to further ``international comity'' or other foreign policy interests. the Justice Department urged the Transportation Department to review the immunity on a country-by-country basis. ``Immunity for IATA appears particularly unwarranted in those markets where the involved foreign government does not actively support or favor cartel pricing,'' the Justice Department said, noting that European Common Market nations are pushing for increased airline competition. ``Many Americans may not realize that the prices of their airline tickets for travel abroad are set by what is in effect a legalized international cartel,'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said in a statement. Now that airline deregulation has promoted competition on domestic flights, ``there is a strong interest in protecting consumers when they travel on U.S. carriers from the United States to foreign countries,'' said James F. Rill, assistant attorney general for antitrust.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Indicted in Slayings of Three Daughters
DOC.TEXT: A 32-year-old meatpacker who blamed a curse for the deaths of her six children and a niece has been charged with killing three of her daughters to collect on their life insurance. Diane Lumbrera was indicted Tuesday on three counts of murder. Five of Ms. Lumbrera's children died before their fourth birthdays between 1976 and 1984, but the deaths did not arouse suspicion at the time. Authorities in Texas began to investigate after Ms. Lumbrera was charged with murder in Garden City, Kan., where she moved from Bovina in 1985, in the smothering of her 4-year-old son in May. The Texas charges cover the deaths of 3-month-old Joanna Lumbrera in 1976, 3-year-old Melissa Lumbrera in 1978 and 2-year-old Melinda Ann Garza in 1982. Prosecutors did not say how the three youngsters are alleged to have been killed. Hospital and autopsy reports had given the cause of death as choking in two cases and congenital heart disease in the third. Bovina Police Chief Gary Coleman said Ms. Lumbrera told authorities one of her former mothers-in-law put a curse on her that damned all her children to early death. Sheriff's deputy Richard Bonham said he discovered Ms. Lumbrera had attached to her life insurance policy riders for each of her children and had collected a total of about $15,000 for their deaths. Two other sons and a niece also died while under her care between 1978 and 1984. Grand juries are looking into those deaths. After the Kansas death was questioned, authorities in Texas began searching for details on the other deaths in and around Bovina, a town of about 1,400 people 70 miles southwest of Amarillo. District Attorney Johnny Actkinson would not detail the evidence against Ms. Lumbrera.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Rebound From Previous Losses, Dollar Slips
DOC.TEXT: The key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange sharply rebounded Wednesday from the previous day's plunge and posted the eighth-largest gain. The U.S. dollar fell against the Japanese yen. The dollar ended at 150.00 yen, down 0.60 yen from Tuesday's finish. It opened higher at 150.63 yen, and ranged between 149.85 and 150.63. The Nikkei Stock Average recouped 856.07 points, or 3.10 percent, ending the day at 28,509.14. Wednesday's gain was the first since July 31 and the eighth-largest ever, following a 901.75-point increase recorded Nov. 13, 1987. The Nikkei's rebound was helped by index-linked bargain-hunting in reaction to Tuesday's big drop, traders said. They said the index's rebound also reflected stability in bond and currency markets. Masashi Wakabayashi, a trader with Yamaichi Securities Co., said market players began to pick up underpriced issues following the recent drops and adjusted their oversold positions. He said Wednesday's earlier gains in the futures market encouraged investors buying in the spot market. He said, however, very few people participated in the market. Other traders said stability in the bond market also contributed to the Nikkei's gains Tuesday. Since last Thursday, when Iraq invaded Kuwait, the index has dropped 3,184.92 points, or 11.5 percent, topped by Tuesday's 946.46-point loss. The index's 27,653.07-point close Tuesday was the lowest level since Oct. 26, 1988, when the index fell to 27,620.60. Already vulnerable due to higher interest rates, the index has now lost 5,204.88 points since July 20 in 12 losses against one gain in the last 13 trading days. The dollar inched downward against the yen after opening higher. The yen strengthened against major European currencies as a result of a technical correction, dealers said. They said the market is basically bearish toward the U.S. unit but many market players are focusing less on the dollar as a safe haven. In the bond market, the yield of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond slipped to 7.97 percent from Tuesday's close of 8.105 percent. Its price rose to 83.56 points from 82.98 points.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Reserve Test May Be Postponed Because of Real Use
With PM-US-Iraq Bjt
Oil Reserve Test May Be Postponed Because of Real Use
DOC.TEXT: The Energy Department says the Strategic Petroleum Reserve is ready for use if there is a severe energy supply interruption, but that it won't be used just to keep prices low. Congressional Democrats have asked President Bush to tap the reserve now to stop the energy price rise the Iraqi invasion started, but Deputy Energy Secretary Henson Moore says the reserve will not be used to flood the market. However, John Easton, deputy assistant secretary of energy for international affairs and energy emergencies, assured a House panel Tuesday the agency is ready to use the reserve if necessary. The oil reserve was established in response to the 1973-74 Arab oil embargo and built to its current size at a cost of about $20 billion, which includes the cost of the oil, and preparing and maintaining the storage site. It has been tapped only once, when Congress ordered 2 million barrels auctioned to oil companies in 1985. It would take at least 16 days from a presidential request for oil to flow from the reserve, DOE spokesman Phil Keif said. During that time, bids from oil companies would have to be submitted, reviewed and chosen.

DOC.HEAD: Stark Apologizes To Sullivan Over Racial Remark
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Pete Stark has apologized to Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan for calling him a ``disgrace to his race'' last week, according to spokesmen for both men. Neither Sullivan nor Stark's office would release the text of the letter of apology delivered Monday night. ``He did apologize,'' Bob Shemermund, a spokesman for Sullivan, said Tuesday. Stark's remark last week infuriated Sullivan, the only black member of President Bush's Cabinet, who called the statement ``incomprehensibly offensive.'' Stark, who said the intended target of his criticism was Bush administration policies he believes harm blacks and the poor, said on the House floor afterward, ``I blew it.'' Sullivan did not take that as an apology. He did take the letter that way, but did not send a reply, Schmermund said. In a speech Tuesday, Sullivan said ``he accepted the apology and considered the incident closed,'' Schmermund said. Perry Plumart, a spokesman for Stark, refused to discuss the contents of the letter.
DOC.HEAD: Former S&L Chairman Charged
DOC.TEXT: The former chairman of a failed Texas savings and loan association has been charged with embezzling more than $4 million after purchasing a controlling interest in the thrift in 1985. Alan Ross Rothery, a California attorney and former chairman of Trinity Valley Savings and Loan Association of Cleveland, Texas, was accused of bank fraud, embezzlement, self-dealing and giving false information to a federal bank examiner. Each count carries a five-year sentence and a possible $250,000 fine. The indictment, returned Aug. 2 by a federal grand jury in Beaumont, Texas, was unsealed in court Tuesday. It accuses Rothery and two California businessman, Errol Coughlan, of Malibu, and John Coughlan Jr., of Long Beach, of participating in a scheme to fraudulently divert loan proceeds. The Texas thrift was taken over by federal regulators in March 1989 and sold Oct. 6, 1989, to Hibernia National Bank in Texas, regulators said. The loss to the government for insured deposits and speculative loans is expected to reach $33 million, the Justice Department said.
DOC.HEAD: Small Fire Put Out In Pentagon
DOC.TEXT: A smoky fire that broke out in a room at the Pentagon was put out Tuesday night with no one being injured, authorities said. Investigators did not know what caused the fire, and a damage estimate was not available, said Air Force Capt. Sam Grizzle, a Pentagon spokesman. The fire started about 8 p.m. and was brought under control about 20 minutes later, Grizzle said. He did not know what type of work is performed in the room.

DOC.HEAD: Designer of Lever House Dead at 81
DOC.TEXT: Architect Gordon Bunshaft, whose austere, modernist designs included glass and steel office towers in New York and the Hirshhorn Museum in Washington, has died at age 81. Bunshaft, a retired partner at the firmi Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, died of cardiac arrest at his home on Monday. His designs included the Hirshhorn, the Lyndon Baines Johnson Library in Austin, Texas, and his last and most elaborate project, the National Commercial Bank in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, a triangular building 27 stories high with no apparent front or back. His Lever House, built in 1952, introduced the sleek International Style to New York's Park Avenue. The 24-story, blue-green office tower was a marked contrast to the traditional masonry buildings that lined the avenue. Bunshaft designed several other New York office towers, including the Manufacturer's Hanover Trust building, the PepsiCo building and the headquarters of Chase Manhattan Bank, which brought modernism to the financial district. A new generation of architects turned away from Bunshaft's austere modernism. ``The architecture today would have nothing to do with what I like doing,'' he said after his retirement in 1979. ``It's a different world _ and I prefer mine.'' He was awarded the Pritzker Prize for architecture in 1988 in recognition of his early designs. He is survived by his wife, Nina. Funeral arrangements were not disclosed.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``It's a symbolic move to demonstrate to Saddam Hussein that we mean business. It's also a very dangerous and risky move. What do we do if he doesn't back down? I think it's a tripwire force on the hope that he will back down.'' _ Vice Adm. Henry C. Mustin, a recently retired deputy chief of naval operations, on placing U.S. ground forces in Saudi Arabia.

``Don't say that I didn't run a good campaign. Say that Zell Miller ran a better campaign'' _ Andrew Young, the former Atlanta mayor, congressman and U.N. ambassador, after defeat in a Democratic runoff ended his bid to become Georgia's first black governor.

``Many Americans may not realize that the prices of their airline tickets for travel abroad are set by what is in effect a legalized international cartel.'' _ Attorney General Dick Thornburgh after the Justice Department recommended an end to the immunity U.S. airlines have from antitrust laws in setting international air fares.

DOC.HEAD: `Roseanne' Lands in Third Place With Four Other Shows
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs, `Miss Barr ...' to CORRECT date of national anthem performance.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Nielsens-List
DOC.TEXT: The first ``Roseanne'' episode since Roseanne Barr screeched the national anthem finished in a tie for third place in the ratings. NBC's ``Cheers'' was No. 1 and CBS' ``60 Minutes'' was second for the week that ended Sunday, according to figures released Tuesday by the A.C. Nielsen Co. With overall viewership hitting one of its lowest-ever levels, the rerun of ``Roseanne'' was in a five-way tie for third place with a 13.0 rating, compared with 14.6 for the July 31 show. About 1.4 million fewer households tuned in to ``Roseanne'' last week than the previous week. ``Reruns don't matter,'' Miss Barr's husband, Tom Arnold, said Tuesday. ``It's hard to gauge. It doesn't mean much.'' Miss Barr screeched the national anthem at a San Diego Padres baseball game July 25 and was pilloried for it. In the overall ratings, NBC was first with a 9.0, followed by ABC with an 8.9 and CBS with 8.5. Each rating point represents 921,000 households. The audience interest in prime-time entertainment programs dipped to a combined 50 share for the big three networks last week. A share is the percentage of the TV sets in the country turned on and tuned to a show. Preston Beckman, NBC research executive, said the share last week was the lowest ever, except for weeks in which the national political conventions were broadcast. He emphasized that it does not represent a large, sudden decline. The three-network audience is down only two points for June and July compared with the same months last year, he said. Here are the top 10 shows, their networks and ratings: ``Cheers,'' NBC, 14.7; ``60 Minutes,'' CBS, 13.3; (tie) ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC, 13.0; (tie) ``Empty Nest,'' NBC, 13.0; (tie) ``Married ... With Children,'' Fox, 13.0; (tie) ``Roseanne,'' ABC, 13.0; (tie) ``Unsolved Mysteries,'' NBC, 13.0; ``Designing Women,'' CBS, 12.9; ``The Simpsons,'' Fox, 12.8; ``The CBS Tuesday Movie _ Murder Ordained, Part 2,'' CBS, 12.7. In the network evening news ratings, ABC was first with 8.8, followed by NBC with 7.8 and CBS with 7.7.

DOC.HEAD: New President Calls For International Battle Against Drugs
LaserPhoto BOG2
DOC.TEXT: In an inauguration ceremony ringed by tight security, Cesar Gaviria became Colombia's youngest president and called for more international help in fighting his country's drug war. Helicopter gunships circled the city, anti-aircraft guns were aimed at skies over the presidential palace where the inauguration took place Tuesday and thousands of troops backed by armor patrolled the streets. ``No country in the history of humanity has paid such a high price as Colombia in confronting international crime,'' said Gaviria, a demure 43-year-old economist and former treasury minister. ``Drug trafficking is the main threat against our democracy. We will fight it without concessions,'' said Gaviria, who took office for a four-year term, succeeding President Virgilio Barco. The new president called on industrialized countries to lower trade barriers to boost Colombian exports, which would give more Colombians an alternative to participating in the drug trade. Gaviria was catapulted to his nation's highest office a year ago when the then-leading presidential hopeful, Luis Carlos Galan of the governing Liberal Party, was murdered by drug traffickers. That sparked a war between the government and powerful cocaine lords that has left hundreds of people dead. Gaviria, who had served as Galan's campaign manager, became a candidate after the assassination. During the campaigning for May's elections, two other presidential candidates were also murdered. At least one of the slayings was linked to drug lords. During Tuesday's ceremonies, Gaviria, his wife, two young children and visiting presidents were seated behind bullet-proof glass. Gaviria appealed to the United States, which consumes most of the cocaine smuggled out of Colombia, to implement recently announced policies that would favor his country's exports. ``It's not direct economic aid, or military assistance we need most. It's fair treatment. It's free trade,'' Gaviria said. He called on developed countries to attack cocaine consumption within their borders. Gaviria cautioned that extradition of suspected traffickers to the United States _ the fate the drug lords here fear most _ cannot be the only weapon or the main strategy in Colombia's fight against the cocaine cartels. But he didn't rule out continued extraditions. In the last year Colombia has extradited 22 trafficking suspects to the United States and has 15 more waiting to be be extradited. The presidents of Venezuela, Argentina, Ecuador and Haiti attended the ceremonies, which were held outdoors under rainy skies alongside the presidential palace. Vice President Dan Quayle took the occassion to try to build solidarity for world sanctions against Iraq's Saddam Hussein for his invasion last week of Kuwait. ``Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait cannot stand, will not stand,'' Quayle told a news conference in Bogota after meeting with Gaviria. Quayle's security personnel took no chances with the vice president's safety. Several of his muscular bodyguards, wearing dark sunglasses, patrolled the Bogota airport and searched through journalists' bags. Quayle flew from the airport to an army base in a helicopter accompanied by four other Blackhawk helicopters armed with missiles. Despite an apparent cease-fire declared by Colombia's billionaire drug traffickers last month, authorities did not discount the possibility of terrorism. In the past year, drug traffickers have been blamed for exploding some 300 bombs, killing about 500 people. In his remarks, Gaviria promised to further peace talks currently under way with leftist guerrillas, open up the political system to minority groups and promote social programs in Medellin, Colombia's second largest city where much of the drug-related violence takes place. The president's commitment to political pluralism appeared to be confirmed by his choice of Cabinet ministers. The new Cabinet includes five members of opposition parties, including M-19, a former leftist guerrilla group that signed a peace treaty with the government in March. M-19's Antonio Navarro became the first former guerrilla to occupy a Cabinet post in Colombia. He is the minister of health. Barco, who was prohibitied by the constitution from running again, received international praise for launching the government's war against drug traffickers. He will reportedly become Colombia's next ambassador to Britain.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq-Kuwait-At-A-Glance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Bush address at 9 a.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT:
At a glance, the latest developments involving Iraq and Kuwait:
President Bush was addressing the nation today on the Middle East crisis. Tuesday it became known he is sending combat troops and jet fighters to Saudia Arabia to protect the kingdom from Iraqi forces massed in Kuwait.
The administration continued to press for a full economic boycott of Iraq. It asked the Saudis to shut off the flow of Iraqi oil through its territory.

More countries joined the U.N.-sanctioned boycott of oil from Iraq and Kuwait. Among the latest are Japan, Denmark, Norway and Sweden. Turkey shut down the Iraqis' vital oil outlet to the Mediterranean.

Iraqi President Saddam Hussein remained defiant despite the show of force. He declared that the Iraqis ``would rather die than be humiliated'' and threatened to ``pluck out the eyes of those who attack the Arab nation.''

The Washington Post is quoting intelligence sources as saying Iraqi forces appeared to be loading poison gas munitions aboard combat aircraft. Iraq has used chemical weapons during its eight-year war with Iran and against its Kurdish minority.

The American Automobile Association reports gasoline prices at the pump are nearing five-year highs. It said Tuesday that self-service unleaded rose 1.5 cents overnight to $1.201 per gallon, the highest price since the last week of 1985. Based on a survey of 1,400 stations nationwide, it said unleaded fuel has increased 12.6 cents since last Wednesday, the day before Iraq invaded Kuwait.

U.S. officials are worried about the 3,500 Americans in Iraq and Iraq-dominated Kuwait. The State Department is not calling them hostages. But, it says, they're not being allowed to leave the two countries freely.

DOC.HEAD: National Night Out Features Flashlight Marches, Block Parties
DOC.TEXT: Picnics, flashlight marches and neighborhood visits from police marked this year's National Night Out, a 7-year-old effort to get people more involved in preventing crime. Around the country, people were urged to turn on their porch lights and sit outside after dark Tuesday. New York Mayor David Dinkins attended a rally in Harlem, and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., Police Chief Joe Gerwins went to 10 events. ``It's a sad time in the life of this city when little children can't sleep in their parents' homes without risking death from a bullet coming through the window,'' said Dinkins, referring to a recent rash of child slayings in his city. ``It's a sad time, an angry time, a time to come together and fight back.'' Dinkins pledged $250,000 for neighborhood grants to provide activities for young people and $950,000 more for community crime-prevention programs, but spending a lot of public money wasn't the theme of the evening. Night Out founder Matt Peskin said the cost of keeping a 60-watt light in front and behind the average house at night is just $32 a year but a big step toward getting a criminal or vandal to move on. When it started in 1984, the Night Out was mostly people sitting in front of their homes with the lights on, but folks quickly began to throw block parties and invited the police as a way to get to know neighborhood officers. Barbara Landers held a party in Philadelphia. ``The block is running over with people,'' she said. ``We got to introduce people to each other and let them know that there's someone else out here networking with them.'' Peskin had predicted a turnout of 21 million in 8,000 communities in all 50 states and Canada and at U.S. military bases around the world. Participating groups have until the end of August to report on turnout, he said. Elsewhere: _In Charleston, W.Va., at least 25 neighborhood groups held rallies, cookouts, marches, block parties and other events. A senior citizens group marched with flashlights around their high-rise apartment complex. _In Columbus, Ohio, police coordinated activities of 194 community watches. _In Pittsburgh, hundreds of people blocked off streets for potluck dinners, and children paraded down streets. _In Norfolk, Va., walkathons and flashlight vigils were held and office buildings stayed lit into night. City vehicles kept their lights on all day.

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Activist Killed Outside His New York Home
DOC.TEXT: A Colombian immigrant active in his homeland's hard-on-drugs Liberal Party was shot to death in front of his home. Police today would not say whether the attack was believed to be a political assassination. Pedro Mendez, 50, was shot three times Monday night as he walked from his car toward his home, police said. Mendez still had his wallet and other valuables when police found him, said police spokesman Fred Weiner. Mendez, who moved to this country 19 years ago, was treasurer of the New York Chapter of the Colombian Liberal Party, which is considered the leading opponent of Colombia's drug lords. The leader of the party, Cesar Gaviria Trujillo, was inaugurated president on Tuesday. ``It's possible the drug cartels killed him to assert their power with the new president. Isn't it coincidental that (he) was killed on the eve of Gaviria's inauguration?'' said Mendez's brother Hector. Police spokeswoman Sgt. Tina Mohrmann would not comment on whether the attack was believed to be politically motivated. Neighbors told police they heard gunshots and a car speeding away, but no one reported witnessing the shooting.

DOC.HEAD: Peace Corps Worker Returns Home After 50 Days as Captive
DOC.TEXT: A Peace Corps volunteer freed after 50 days as the hostage of anti-American rebels in the Philippines says he hopes to return to his adopted country some day. ``We're definitely going back. I don't know when,'' Tim Swanson said after he arrived in Cheyenne on Tuesday. Swanson, 26, dined on steak and his mother's rhubarb pie after a 24-hour trip from Manila. He was freed by the New People's Army on Thursday after the Philippine military agreed to a three-day truce. He was turned over to the International Red Cross and taken to the U.S. Embassy in Manila, where he was checked by doctors. The Peace Corps sent its volunteers home from the Philippines on June 27 because of reported threats from rebels. U.S. officials said they were unaware of Swanson's kidnapping when the order was issued. Swanson, who is married to a Filipino teacher, said he contemplated escaping but discarded the idea. ``Bbasically I knew I would get out sometime and I wanted ... that when I eventually did get out to have no more problems with the NPA because I wanted to be able to come back to the Philippines without worrying about them anymore,'' he said. Swanson said he had little to do but sit and wait in the rebels' jungle hideout near his Philippine home of Patag. ``They just told me to rest, take it easy,'' he said. ``I paced up and down some. Peeled the bark off the wood that our shelter was built out of. Daydreamed a lot. Sat around doing pretty much nothing quite a bit.'' Swanson said he had a radio for part of the time and listened to reports of the efforts to free him. He also heard from his captors that there had been speculation that he went willingly with them. ``They thought that sounded pretty silly,'' he said. ``I thought it was pretty crazy-sounding myself.''

DOC.HEAD: Mirror Flaw Threatens to Delay Weather Satellite Launching
DOC.TEXT: A mirror design flaw in a new $1 billion series of weather satellites could delay their launch and leave forecasters ``standing in front of blank screens,'' The New York Times reported today. The flaw is in mirrors meant to reflect images from the satellites' telescopes, the newspaper said, citing federal officials and experts. The problem is that the mirrors warp when heated, as sunlight would do in outer space. The trouble is another blow to NASA, which is supervising the satellites' construction. The space agency already is reeling from problems with its shuttle fleet and a defective mirror on its $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope. The two mirror problems are technically unrelated, the Times said. Officials said they have no estimate of how much it will cost to correct the satellite mirror problem or how long the launch of the first advanced satellite might be delayed. It is scheduled for 1992, but the Times said unofficial estimates put the delay at anywhere from two months to more than a year. James R. Greaves, NASA program manager for meteorological satellites, said the ``scary aspect'' is that the nation is now down to one working advanced satellite. ``If that fails, weather people are going to be standing in front of blank screens,'' he said. The United States also has planes, radar and other satellites that contain forecasting equipment, but only this type of satellite gives a comprehensive view of the weather situation at any instant. The five-year lifetime of the current advanced satellite, which beams the weather pictures used in newspapers and on television, ends in February 1992, although it might last longer. Elbert W. Friday Jr., head of the National Weather Service, said that loss of advanced satellite coverage would constitute ``a national emergency,'' with significantly less capability for making forecasts and tracking hurricanes and other storms. The five new satellites are being built by Ford Aerospace under NASA supervision, at a cost of $1 billion. Greaves said the mirrors had been built correctly by the Applied Optics Corp. according to ITT Corp. specifications.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Surge, Dollar Off
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf `Oil prices...' with 1 graf to fix direction of oil prices to down, sted up. Pickup 8th graf ``The stock...''
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index today posted its eighth-largest gain and almost erased the previous day's huge losses that were blamed at least in part on the Persian Gulf crisis. The dollar fell against the Japanese yen. The Nikkei Stock Average recouped 856.07 points, or 3.10 percent, ending the day at 28,509.14 in moderate trading. First section volume was estimated at 580 million shares, compared with Tuesday's volume of 500 million. Today's gain was the first since July 31 and the eighth-largest ever. The Nikkei's rebound was helped by index-linked bargain-hunting in reaction to Tuesday's big drop, traders said. They said the index's strength also reflected stability in bond and currency markets, as well as a drop in oil prices in Tokyo. The yield of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond closed lower at 7.915 percent from Tuesday's close of 8.105 percent. Its price ended at 83.80 points, up from 82.98 points. Oil prices sharply fell in Tokyo. At about 3 p.m. (2 a.m. EDT), Brent for October delivery was valued at about $26.00-26.20 a barrel, down from $27.80-28.00 Tuesday in Asia. ``The stock market has bottomed out with yesterday's plunge,'' said Yoshiro Inoue, an analyst with Nomura Securities Co. ``Market players felt they had sold too much and began picking up underpriced issues to adjust their positions,'' he said. Since last Thursday, when Iraq invaded Kuwait, the index had dropped 3,184.92 points, or 11.5 percent, topped by Tuesday's 946.46-point loss. The index's 27,653.07 close Tuesday was the lowest level since Oct. 26, 1988, when the index fell to 27,620.60. The Tokyo stock market, already vulnerable due to higher interest rates, had lost 5,204.88 points between July 20 and Aug. 7. Inoue said the market will remain nervous until the Iraq-Kuwait dispute starts moving toward a peaceful settlement. He also predicted some more selling for technical adjustment involving option trading. The final day of August option trading is scheduled for Thursday. On the foreign exchange market that reacted nervously to news reports about the Middle East, the dollar ended at 150.00 yen, down 0.60 yen from Tuesday's finish. It opened higher at 150.63 yen, and ranged between 149.85 and 150.63. After its morning slip following dollar-selling for profit-taking by some trading companies, the dollar rose back to the day's high in the afternoon, when the market was swayed by the report that President Bush was sending troops to Saudi Arabia, said Eiichi Seino, a dealer with Fuji Bank. Market players than sold the dollar for position adjustment when a rumor of an important announcement by Bush scheduled later today failed to be confirmed before trading ended, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Detroit Iraqis Have Mixed Feelings About Homeland
DOC.TEXT: The spray-painted words on the wall of an abandoned building express what many in the city's large Iraqi community are afraid to say. ``The Iraqi government continues to torture the Iraqi people,'' reads the message. ``NO to the fascist government in Iraq.'' The graffiti stands out among the businesses and residences owned by Chaldeans _ Christian Arabs, mostly from Iraq _ whose largest community in the United States is in the Detroit area. Most Chaldeans here have relatives in Iraq and refuse to comment on the invasion of Kuwait by Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein's troops, said a gasoline station owner who refused to give his name. ``Some of them like Saddam Hussein. Some of them don't,'' he said. ``People are afraid of him.'' About 45,000 Chaldeans live in the Detroit area, said Father Manuel Boji, the priest at the Chaldean Diocese in suburban Southfield. Chaldeans emerged after Christianity spread to the Middle East, where Islam is the dominant religion. Most Chaldeans in the area come from northern Iraq and few wish to return, Boji said Tuesday. They open grocery stores, selling fruit and vegetables from wooden bins on the sidewalks. They work as dentists, advertising on signs in Arabic and English. They raise their children, worrying about families in Iraq. And they stay quiet about Saddam. ``Some are for him. Some are not,'' said Karim Hakim, a retired grocery store owner in Southfield. Hakim left Baghdad in 1925, returning only to get married in 1937. ``Some of them just left recently within three or four years and they're for him. Lots of them have to be because they're afraid for their people,'' he said. ``Saddam Hussein is No. 1,'' said a teen-ager as he walked in the Chaldean neighborhood. The youth refused to be identified, but he and five friends cheered Saddam's invasion of Kuwait. ``He's doing the right thing for our people,'' he said. Hakim said Chaldeans who left Iraq several years ago have fewer loyalties and less fear of Hussein's government than more recent arrivals. ``I'm not for (the invasion),'' Hakim said. ``I'm American. I've been here all my life mostly, so that's it.''

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer: Vicki Long Secretly Married to Archbishop
DOC.TEXT: The woman whose intimate relationship with Roman Catholic Archbishop Eugene Marino led to his resignation claims she was secretly married to him nearly two years ago, her lawyer says. Vicki R. Long and Marino exchanged what she considered wedding vows in December 1988 during a trip to New York, attorney Anthony Fontana said Tuesday. Fontana said he was not sure of the details ``but I do know that she says that at one point in time he got her to perform vows and I think it's a further indication of the tremendous amount of control that he had over her.'' Archdiocese spokesman Peter Dora denied Marino and Ms. Long had wed. ``There is no marriage that would be recognized by the state or by the church,'' he said. Marino, 56, resigned earlier this year because of what archdiocese officials said last week was an intimate relationship with Ms. Long, 27, of Riverdale. Marino had been the nation's highest ranking black Catholic. Ms. Long also claims she was seduced by a nun during a trip to Pittsburgh when she was 19, The Atlanta Constitution reported today, citing two unidentified sources familiar with an account Ms. Long gave church officials. The newspaper did not give the nun's name. Ms. Long's allegations about the nun surfaced in her 1987 paternity suit against the Rev. Donal Keohane of Columbus, who she claimed fathered her 4-year-old daughter, the newspaper said. Blood tests showed that Keohane was not the father, but the archdiocese is paying child support. The Rev. Michael Woods, a Sandy Springs priest, resigned Saturday after admitting he, too, had an intimate relationship with Ms. Long. Ms. Long has denied she had a sexual relationship with Woods. She has not said whether she had a sexual relationship with the archbishop. Marino, whose whereabouts have been withheld by the church, has not commented publicly on his relationship with Ms. Long.

DOC.HEAD: Showers Along East Coast; Thunderstorms and Heat in Southwest
DOC.TEXT: Showers were scattered along the Atlantic seaboard from Maine to the Carolinas today, and extreme heat lingered in the Southwest. Today's forecast called for thunderstorms in the deserts of Southern California and Arizona and in Florida, Georgia and South Carolina. Showers were expected along the East Coast. Hurricane Diana was expected to bring flooding to Mexico. On Tuesday, temperatures dropped to record lows across the nation's midsection, and heavy rain caused flooding in the Northeast. Record lows mostly in the 50s and 60s were reported in Texas, New Mexico, Illinois, Ohio, Indiana, Arkansas, Kansas, West Virginia, Alabama, Missouri, Kentucky, Michigan, Tennessee and Colorado. Billings, Mont., warmed to a record high of 103. Temperatures along the northern half of the Rockies were as much as 15 degrees higher than normal. The high temperature for the nation Tuesday was 120 at Death Valley, Calif.
