DOC.HEAD: Scientists Send Radioactive Jam to Governor, Energy Secretary
DOC.TEXT: Ruby-red mulberry jam made from fruit grown near the Hanford nuclear plant has been sent to Energy Secretary James Watkins and Gov. Booth Gardner. They should have no problem recognizing the gifts. They're labeled ``Radioactive. Do not eat.'' Two scientists said they made the jam during the weekend from mulberries gathered along the banks of the Columbia River beside the Hanford complex in south-central Washington. They say the jam is contaminated with strontium 90, a deadly isotope present in radioactive fallout. Oceanographer Norm Buske and his wife, mathematician Linda Josephson, said they wanted to alert state and federal officials that contamination of vegetation near the closed N Reactor could pose a safety hazard. Battelle Pacific Northwest Laboratories, which has been contracted by the government to monitor the plant, said researchers have known for years that vegetation in ``no trespassing'' areas near the reactor is contaminated. Strontium 90 ``has not been reported in mulberries before, but it's been documented in other vegetation in the area for several years,'' said Battelle Pacific spokesman Jerry Holloway. The isotope is a byproduct of nuclear weapons production and was knowingly and legally released around the riverside N Reactor, he said. Buske and his wife, who operate an independent laboratory about 75 miles northeast of the reservation, said they were concerned that strontium 90 is present in edible plants accessible by boat. The isotope travels through underground springs to the river, Buske said. The jam, which Buske said was shipped Monday by Federal Express, arrived at the governor's office Tuesday, said Dick Milne, Gardner's press secretary. It was not known if Watkins' office received the jam. ``The mulberry jam with the little extra something'' has been sent to a state radiation lab for further analysis, Milne said. The jam's contents were not revealed to Federal Express, Buske said. Under federal standards, the jam contains 80 to 90 times the strontium 90 levels allowed in daily consumption in drinking water, Buske wrote in an accompanying letter. But the jam would only pose ``a minimal risk'' if it was eaten, he said. The couple also gathered curly dog, an edible green, along the riverbank, which is posted with ``no trespassing'' signs, but opted not to deliver it because it could be harmful if handled. ``This is not a hollow exercise,'' Buske said. ``We are convinced that some of their radiation pathways are dangerous to the public.'' Most of the plutonium used in U.S. nuclear weapons was made at the 600-square-mile plant near Richland, Wash. It is considered the most severely polluted site in the federal weapons complex. Technology to handle some of the hottest radioactive wastes does not exist. The full cleanup is expected to take more than 30 years and cost more than $100 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Metabolism Rebounds After Extremely Low-Calorie Diets, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: The crash diet that gave Oprah Winfrey her svelte new figure does not permanently lower the body's metabolism, a study says. Many people have worried that crash dieting permanently lowers a person's metabolism _ the rate at which the body at rest burns calories _ making it harder and harder to shed more pounds and to keep the weight off. Today, a study in the Journal of the American Medical Association found that the Optifast liquid diet caused women's metabolism to plunge, but it rebounded after they began eating normal food. The study was funded in part by Optifast. The diet helped the women lose almost 50 pounds in four months, the study said. ``The good news is that the study showed dieting, when combined with exercise, does not result in a long-term reduction in metabolic rate,'' said lead researcher Thomas A. Wadden. ``The bad news is that it's still a struggle to maintain weight loss.'' Wadden, associate professor of psychology at the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine and clinical director of its Obesity Research Group, said in a telephone interview Tuesday that for every 25 pounds of weight loss, a dieter must eat 100 fewer calories a day than in pre-diet days to maintain the loss. Wadden also is a consultant to the Sandoz Nutrition Co., maker of Optifast. Miss Winfrey shed 67 pounds on the Optifast diet. The study compared nine women who went on the 420-calorie-a-day Optifast program with nine women who went on a diet of conventional food totaling 1,200 calories a day. The metabolism of the Optifast women dropped 22 percent over 16 weeks, when they were consuming only the liquid diet, while the metabolism of the others fell about 13 percent. Metabolism rates of the Optifast group rose to within 11 percent of initial rates during the following six weeks, when the women were gradually switched from to about 1,100 calories of normal food a day, the study found. Metabolism in the 1,200-calorie group rose to within 8.6 percent of original levels during that period. Exercise _ walking up to 20 minutes at a time, three times a week _ was an important part of the program for both groups, said Wadden. ``We're not sure why that is,'' he said. ``It may have some long-term effect on metabolic rates. More importantly, it simply burns up calories.'' Over the entire 48 weeks of the study, women in the Optifast group lost about 48 pounds each; women on the 1,200-calorie diets lost about 40 pounds each. Subjects weighed an average of 216 pounds at the beginning of the study. Dr. Peter D. Vash, assistant clinical professor of medicine at the medical school of the University of California at Los Angeles, said the study will not be news to researchers in the field. ``I concur with Dr. Wadden's conclusion, that diet will not adversely permanently affect the metabolic rate,'' he said in a telephone interview. Vash emphasized that such extremely low-calorie diets are appropriate only with proper supervision and only for the obese. Optifast, which costs about $3,000 and requires at least a year's commitment, is supervised through hospitals.

DOC.HEAD: Chaplain Who Claimed Vietnam Heroism is Dismissed, Fined
DOC.TEXT: An Army chaplain who faked a heroic record with the elite Green Berets and Rangers in the Vietnam War was dismissed and fined $10,000 after pleading guilty during a court-martial. Maj. Gary Probst, who joined the Army in the 1980s, was ordered Tuesday to pay $1,000 a month for 10 months, said a Fort Lewis base spokesman, Maj. Martin Eckert. Probst's sentence will automatically be reviewed. In the meantime, he has been assigned to administrative duties. He pleaded guilty to five violations of the Uniform Code of Military Justice. Probst wore 15 insignia he never earned, including the Bronze Star and the Vietnam campaign ribbon, ruled Lt. Col. Richard Mann, a military judge. Probst, 37, also admitted making false statements in his list of career duties and decorations, disobeying an order by returning to the 1st Special Forces Group complex after being ordered to stay away, putting in a false claim of about $100 in motel bills and taking a government-owned chair for personal use. Probst, a Mormon chaplain who worked at the 1st Special Forces Group, could have been given a dishonorable discharge and up to 20 years in prison. He indicated in an interview before his court-martial that he wore the insignia to gain the trust of soldiers. Probst served at Fort Gordon, Ga., and Schofield Barracks, Hawaii, before coming to Fort Lewis in 1987, Eckert said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Longtime Navajo Foes Winners in Primary Election
DOC.TEXT: Suspended Navajo tribal leader Peter MacDonald survived a hard-fought primary and will face longtime foe Peterson Zah in November for the tribe's highest office. Zah, tribal chairman from 1983 to 1987, was the top vote-getter Tuesday, with 13,785 votes, or 30 percent. MacDonald was next in the 15-candidate field with 10,322 votes, or 22.7 percent, edging interim President Leonard Haskie. In a restructuring, the president will replace the tribal chairman as leader of the 172,000-member reservation in Arizona, New Mexico and Utah. About half the more than 95,000 eligible voters on the reservation turned out for the election. Zah, 53, defeated MacDonald in 1982, but MacDonald regained the post in 1986. The Tribal Council placed MacDonald on paid leave in 1989 following U.S. Senate testimony that MacDonald had accepted bribes and kickbacks. MacDonald, 61, is awaiting three trials in tribal court on charges of bribery, fraud and election violations. His first trial is scheduled for Sept. 18. He has denied any wrongdoing.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Generally Higher, Gold Also Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was generally higher in nervous European trading late this morning as dealers positioned themselves for a possible war in the Middle East. Gold prices were also higher as the market continued to be buffeted by rumors and counter-rumors regarding rising tension from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait last week, dealers said. News that Iraq planned an ``important announcement'' later today raised tension in the currency markets. President Bush sent troops to Saudi Arabia ``and the dollar's a few points higher,'' said one trader at a major West German bank in Frankfurt. ``At such times one has to buy a few dollars. It's purely a precaution.'' But one Milan dealer said room for the dollar to move higher is limited because the U.S. currency ``seems to have lost its role as a safe haven.'' ``The market is discounting a possible intervention by the U.S. in the Middle East,'' the dealer said. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell 0.50 yen to a closing 150.00 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 150.15 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Tuesday: _1.5905 West German marks, up from 1.5763 _1.3350 Swiss francs, up from 1.3315 _5.3293 French francs, up from 5.2995 _1.7858 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7785 _1,164.00 Italian lire, up from 1,155.37 _1.1511 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1495 In London, the dollar fell against the British pound and was quoted at $1.8733, compared with $1.8765 late Tuesday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $383.00 a troy ounce, down from $383.25 bid late Tuesday. But at midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a higher recommended price of $384.75. In Zurich, the bid price was $385.25, up from $383.15 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 87 cents to close at a bid $382.65. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $4.88 a troy ounce, from Tuesday's $4.89.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Bodyguard Of Mrs. Mandela Sentenced To Death
DOC.TEXT: A former bodyguard of Winnie Mandela was sentenced to death today for murdering a 14-year-old black activist who had been kidnapped and held at Mrs. Mandela's house. Supreme Court Justice Brian O'Donovan rejected arguments from the defense that 37-year-old Jerry Richardson's desire to gain Mrs. Mandela's favor was a mitigating factor in the killing. ``It is difficult to see how kidnap and murder can be mitigated by the desire to please anybody,'' said O'Donovan. He also sentenced Richardson to 18 years' imprisonment for kidnapping, assault with intent to do grievous bodily harm and attempted murder. James ``Stompie'' Seipei Moeketsi was found stabbed to death in January 1989 after Richardson led him away from Mrs. Mandela's house in the black township of Soweto. According to the testimony, Stompie was accused of being a police informer. Black leaders later criticized the group surrounding Mrs. Mandela, saying they had engaged in a ``reign of terror'' in Soweto and that the community should shun Mrs. Mandela. She began to reappear at anti-apartheid rallies a few months before her husband Nelson Mandela, deputy president of the African National Congress, was released from prison in February. O'Donovan said the evidence indicated Mrs. Mandela was at her home at the time of the beatings. Mrs. Mandela has not been charged in the case, and declined a request by Richardson's lawyers to testify on his behalf. Her driver and other associates are scheduled for trial on kidnapping and assault charges in September. Only Richardson was tried for Stompie's murder. President F. W. de Klerk suspended all hangings in February, but courts still have the option of imposing the death sentence in murder cases when the judge finds there are no mitigating factors.

DOC.HEAD: Bus Kills 95-year-old Murder Defendant
DOC.TEXT: A 95-year-old man awaiting trial for murder was struck by a bus and killed after receiving special permission to leave his apartment for a hospital visit, police said. ``This is more than ironic, it's Kafkaesque,'' said Manhattan Supreme Court Justice Rose Rubin, the judge who was to preside at Barre's trial. Oliver Barre was hit by a city bus as he walked across the street with a companion Tuesday morning on his way to a Veterans Administration hospital about a block away, police said. He died two hours later at Bellevue Hospital, hospital spokeswoman Brenda Rivera said. Helen Carroll, 90, described by Rivera as Barre's girlfriend, suffered head injuries and was listed in serious condition this morning at Bellevue, said hospital administrator Robert Frazier. The bus driver, Basil Pesce, was cited for failing to yield to pedestrians, police said. He was not injured in the accident, and the bus carried no passengers. Barre was charged with second-degree murder in the metal pipe bludgeoning of an elderly neighbor June 16. He pleaded innocent and was due in court Oct. 4. Barre claimed his victim, Norma Marks, 88, had tried to strangle him and poison other people in his building. More than 140 residents of Barre's apartment building petitioned to have him jailed after the murder. However, Rubin allowed him out on bail provided he only leave his apartment from 2 to 4 p.m. On Monday, his lawyer got special permission for Barre to go to the VA hospital Tuesday morning.

DOC.HEAD: Heart Valve Manufacturer Reports Defects To Patients
DOC.TEXT: A heart valve manufacturer bowed to the demands of consumer activists and agreed to inform thousands of implant patients of potential defects. Shiley Inc. of Irvine, a subsidiary of New York-based Pfizer Inc., said Tuesday it will identify and notify 21,000 patients in the United States of product defects that could prove dangerous. Its notices will advise patients about the warning signs of mechanical valve failure and what steps to take should the device fail, company officials said. The announcement affects those patients who received the Bjork-Shiley 60-degree ``convexo-concave'' heart valve. The company voluntarily pulled the valves from the U.S. market in 1986 following reports of valve fractures. Roger Sachs, vice president and medical director at Shiley, said the firm was determining how patients will be notified. He said Shiley was negotiating with another company to compile a registry of implant patients. The decision comes after Public Citizen Health Research Group, a Washington, D.C.-based consumer organization, filed a lawsuit against Shiley and Pfizer to force Shiley to warn patients about the defects. A judge dismissed the suit in May after ruling that the U.S. Food and Drug Administration had sole authority to issue such an order. ``If the company does what it says it is going to do, there is no question that some people who otherwise would die will live,'' said Public Citizen's director, Dr. Sidney Wolfe. ``I think they (Shiley) saw the handwriting on the wall and yielded to something they should have done a long time ago,'' he added. Originally, Shiley had cautioned only surgeons about the valve's problems, replying upon them to notify their patients. In March, the company mailed warnings to surgeons, cardiologists, primary physicians and emergency room practitioners. A statement issued Tuesday by Shiley said the decision to notify patients directly came in response to FDA concerns that physicians may not have effectively communicated the product's defects to implant patients. Shiley officials added they will ask the FDA to review the notices it will send to patients. FDA spokeswoman Susan Cruzan said the agency could decide by early next year whether to require valve manufacturers to notify patients directly of any potential product defects.

DOC.HEAD: State Tax Collections Up 7.5 Percent
DOC.NOTE: EDs: RECASTS lead; SUBS 7th graf bgng, Alaska, New..., to define severance taxes
DOC.TEXT: State tax collections rose by 7.5 percent in fiscal 1989 over the previous year, the Commerce Department says. The agency said Tuesday that state tax collections totaled $284 billion in 1989, up from $264 billion a year earlier. Eight states reported increases of more than 10 percent including Oregon, up 22.5 percent, and California, up 14.2 percent. Other increases above 10 percent included 13.4 percent in Delaware, 12.7 percent in Alaska, 11.5 percent in Idaho, 11.1 percent in Indiana, 10.8 percent in Iowa and 10.2 percent in Kentucky. Only Utah and South Dakota reported decreases in state tax collections. Utah was down 11.4 percent while South Dakota dropped 1.7 percent. The Commerce Department said the national average per capita state tax ranged from a high of $2,675 in Alaska to $554 in New Hampshire. Alaska, New Hampshire and Wyoming have no state income or sales taxes. The severance tax, which applies to oil and other minerals extracted from the earth, is the primary source of state income in Alaska and Wyoming, while the corporate net income tax is the largest source in New Hampshire. Other states ranking at the top of the per capita list were: Hawaii, 1,994; Delaware, $1,679; Massachusetts, $1,534; Connecticut, $1,485; New York, $1,481; Minnesota, $1,470; California, $1,418; Washington, $1,367, and New Jersey, $1,357. In addition to New Hampshire, other states at the end of the per capita list were: South Dakota, $655; Texas, $822; Tennessee, $823; Utah, $832; Colorado, $875; Mississippi, $882; Alabama, $889, Nebraska, $900, and Arkansas, $903. More than half of the state tax revenues were collected by just nine states: California, $41.2 billion; New York, $26.6 billion; Texas, $14 billion; Pennsylvania, $12.6 billion; Florida, $12.5 billion, Illinois, $11.8 billion; Michigan, $11.1 billion; Ohio, $10.8 billion, and New Jersey, $10.5 billion. As usual, general sales and gross receipts taxes were the largest source of state taxes in 1989, up 7.3 percent to $93.4 billion. Individual income taxes gained 10.7 percent to $88.7 billion, while corporate net income taxes rose 4.8 percent to $23.9 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Bush's Speech Only His Third From Oval Office
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS last graf to CORRECT that address was to all schools
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's televised speech today on the Kuwait crisis was only the third time he has addressed the nation from the Oval Office. The other two occasions were both last year: his Sept. 5, 1989, nighttime address unveiling his strategy for the war on drugs, and his Dec. 20, 1989, morning speech on the U.S. invasion of Panama. Bush also gave a Sept. 12, 1989, noontime talk to students about drugs that was telecast by satellite to the nation's schools.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Makes Indirect References to Hitler
DOC.TEXT: President Bush didn't mention Adolf Hitler or World War II today in his speech on the Iraq crisis, but they clearly were on his mind as he described Saddam Hussein and the tactics needed to stop him. ``As in the case of the 1930s, we see in Saddam Hussein an aggressive dictator threatening his neighbors,'' Bush said. ``Twice we have seen what his promises have meant. His promises mean nothing,'' the president said, apparently referring to Thursday's invasion of Kuwait and Saddam's offer Friday to withdraw his troops. ``Appeasement does not work,'' Bush said. ``If history teaches us anything, it is that we must resist aggression or it will destroy our freedoms,'' he said. ``This is not an American problem or a European problem or a Middle East problem _ it is a world problem.''

Here is the text of President Bush's address Wednesday on the Iraq crisis: In the life of a nation we're called upon to define who we are and what we believe. Sometimes these choices are not easy. But today as president I ask for your support in a decision I've made to stand up for what's right and condemn what's wrong all in the cause of peace. At my direction, elements of the 82nd Airborne Division, as well as key units of the United States Air Force, are arriving today to take up defensive positions in Saudi Arabia. I took this action to assist the Saudi Arabian government in the defense of its homeland. No one commits America's armed forces to a dangerous mission lightly, but after perhaps unparalleled international consultation and exhausting every alternative, it became necessary to take this action. And let me tell you why. Less than a week ago in the early morning hours of August 2nd, Iraqi armed forces, without provocation or warning, invaded a peaceful Kuwait. Facing negligible resistance from its much smaller neighbor, Iraq's tanks stormed in blitzkrieg fashion through Kuwait in a few short hours. With more than 100,000 troops, along with tanks, artillery and surface to surface missiles, Iraq now occupies Kuwait. This aggression came just hours after Saddam Hussein specifically assured numerous countries in the area that there would be no invasion. There is no justification whatsoever for this outrageous and brutal act of aggression. A puppet regime imposed from the outside is unacceptable. The acquisition of territory by force is unacceptable. No one, friend or foe, should doubt our desire for peace, and no one should underestimate our determination to confront aggression. Four simple principles guide our policy. First, we seek the immediate, unconditional and complete withdrawal of all Iraqi forces from Kuwait. Second, Kuwait's legitimate government must be restored to replace the puppet regime. And third, my administration, as has been the case with every president from President Roosevelt to President Reagan, is committed to the security and stability of the Persian Gulf. And fourth, I am determined to protect the lives of American citizens abroad. Immediately after the Iraqi invasion, I ordered an embargo of all trade with Iraq, and together with many other nations, announced sanctions that both froze all Iraqi assets in this country and protected Kuwait's assets. The stakes are high. Iraq is already a rich and powerful country that possesses the world's second largest reserves of oil and over a million men under arms. It's the fourth largest military in the world. Our country now imports nearly half the oil it consumes, and could face a major threat to its economic independence. Much of the world is even more dependent upon imported oil and is even more vulnerable to Iraqi threats. We succeeded in the struggle for freedom in Europe because we and our allies remain stalwart. Keeping the peace in the Middle East will require no less.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: ... no less.
DOC.TEXT: We're beginning a new era. This new era can be full of promise, an age of freedom, a time of peace for all peoples. But if history teaches us anything, it is that we must resist aggression or it will destroy our freedoms. Appeasement does not work. As was the case in the 1930s, we see in Saddam Hussein an aggressive dictator threatening his neighbors. On 14 days ago, Saddam Hussein promised his friends he would not invade Kuwait and four days ago he promised the world he would withdraw. And twice we have seen what his promises mean. His promises mean nothing. In the last few days, I have spoken with political leaders from the Middle East, Europe, Asia and the Americas and I have met with Prime Minister Thatcher, Prime Minister Mulroney and NATO Secretary General Woerner. And all agree that Iraq cannot be allowed to benefit from its invasion of Kuwait. We agree that this is not an American problem or a European problem or a Middle East problem. It is the world's problem. And that's why, soon after the Iraqi invasion, the United Nations Security Council, without dissent, condemned Iraq, calling for the immediate and unconditional withdrawal of its troops from Kuwait. The Arab world, through both the Arab League and the Gulf Cooperation Council, courageously announced its opposition to Iraqi aggression. Japan, the United Kingdom and France and other governments around the world have imposed severe sanctions. The Soviet Union and China ended all arms sales to Iraq. And this past Monday, the United Nations Security Council approved, for the first time in 23 years, mandatory sanctions under Chapter 7 of the United Nations Charter. These sanctions now enshrined in international law, have the potential to deny Iraq the fruits of aggression while sharply limiting its ability to either import or export anything of value, especially oil. I pledge here today that the United States will do its part to see that these sanctions are effective and to induce Iraq to withdraw without delay from Kuwait. But we must recognize that Iraq may not stop using force to advance its ambitions. Iraq has massed an enormous war machine on the Saudi border capable of initiating hostilities with little or no additional preparation. Given the Iraqi government's history of aggression against its own citizens as well as its neighbors, to assume Iraq will not attack again would be unwise and unrealistic. And therefore, after consulting with King Fahd, I sent Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney to discuss cooperative measures we could take. Following those meetings, the Saudi government requested our help. And I responded to that request by ordering US air and ground forces to deploy to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia. Let me be clear, the sovereign independence of Saudi Arabia is of vital interest to the United States. This decision, which I shared with the congressional leadership, grows out of the longstanding friendship and security relationship between the United States and Saudi Arabia. U.S. forces will work together with those of Saudi Arabia and other nations to preserve the integrity of Saudi Arabia and to deter further Iraqi aggression. Through their presence, as well as through training and exercises, these multinational forces will enhance the overall capability of Saudi armed forces to defend the Kingdom. I want to be clear about what we are doing and why. America does not seek conflict, nor do we seek to chart the destiny of other nations. But America will stand by her friend. The mission of our troops is wholly defensive. Hopefully, they will not be needed long. They will not initiate hostilities, but they will defend themselves, the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia and other friends in the Persian Gulf. We are working around the clock to deter Iraqi aggression and to enforce UN sanctions. I'm continuing my conversations with world leaders. Secretary of Defense Cheney has just returned from valuable consultations with President Mubarak of Egypt and King Hassan of Morocco.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says He'll Explore Using Oil Reserves, Urges Conservation
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Incorporates material from a0468, PM-Oil Reserve
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today said he will ask other oil-producing nations to replace embargoed Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil on world markets and explore whether to dip into the nation's strategic reserves to bolster supplies. The president also asked Americans to conserve energy and called on oil companies to ``do their fair share'' and try to hold the line on prices. Bush did not name the countries he planned to call on to increase production. The president of Venezuela said Tuesday his nation would try to increase production, according to an official traveling with Vice President Dan Quayle, who met with the Venezuelan leader. Bush's sanctions against Iraq for invading Kuwait include a trade embargo that bans import of either Iraqi or Kuwaiti oil. Although supplies are said to be high, prices for gas and other petroleum products have increased in the days since the invasion, prompting criticism from Congress and administration officials. ``I'm asking the oil companies to do their fair share,'' Bush, himself a former oilman, said in his nationally televised address from the Oval Office. ``Conservation measures also can help,'' the president said. ``Americans everywhere must do their part.'' Bush said he and the leaders of other nations boycotting Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil were exploring whether it would be necessary to draw from oil reserves. In the meantime, Bush said he was asking ``all producing nations to do what they can to increase production'' in order to minimize the effect of the boycott. On Tuesday, the Energy Department said the Strategic Petroleum Reserve is ready for use in the event of severe oil shortages but would not be used just to keep prices low. Some in Congress have called on Bush to tap the reserve to push prices back down. The oil reserve was established in response to the 1973-74 Arab oil embargo and built to its current size at a cost of about $20 billion, which includes the cost of the oil, and preparing and maintaining the storage site. It has been tapped only once, when Congress ordered 2 million barrels auctioned to oil companies in 1985. It would take at least 16 days from a presidential request for oil to flow from the reserve, Energy Department spokesman Phil Keif said. During that time, bids from oil companies would have to be submitted, reviewed and chosen.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: ... of Morroco.
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State Baker has consulted with his counterparts in many nations, including the Soviet Union, and today he heads for Europe to consult with President Ozal of Turkey, a staunch friend of the United States. And he'll then consult with the NATO foreign ministers. I will ask oil producing nations to do what they can to increase production in order to minimize any impact that oil flow reductions will have on the world economy. And I will explore whether we and our allies should draw down our strategic petroleum reserves. Conservation measures can also help. Americans everywhere must do their part. And one more thing. I'm asking the oil companies to do their fair share. They should show restraint and not abuse today's uncertainties to raise prices. Standing up for our principles will not come easy. It may take time and possibly cost a great deal. But we are asking no more of anyone than of the brave young men and women of our armed forces and their families. And I ask that in the churches around the country prayers be said for those who are committed to protect and defend America's interests. Standing up for our principles is an American tradition. As it has so many times before, it may take time and tremendous effort, but most of all, it will take unity of purpose. As I have witnessed throughout my life in both war and peace, America has never wavered when her purpose is driven by principle. And on this August day, at home and abroad, I know she will do no less. Thank you and God bless the United States of America.
DOC.HEAD: END TEXT
Jury Reaches Verdict on One Count, But Won't Reveal Decision
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with jury resuming deliberations. Picks up 9th graf pvs `The panel ...'
DOC.TEXT: The jury in Marion Barry's drug and perjury trial resumed deliberations today after refusing to reveal its verdict on one of the 14 counts. On Tuesday, the mayor's lawyer conceded for the first time that Barry may be convicted on some counts. Jury foreman Edward Eagles sent a note to U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson late Tuesday indicating the jury had ``reached a verdict on count 12,'' Jackson said. That count stems from the testimony of former Carter administration aide Doris Crenshaw, who said that she and Barry had snorted cocaine together in her Washington hotel room between Nov. 7 and Nov. 10, 1988. ``Have you reached a verdict?'' Jackson asked Eagles. ``I would prefer that you poll the jury,'' the foreman replied. After a moment, Jackson asked whether the jury wanted to reveal its decision. ``Not at this time,'' said a woman juror. A male juror shook his head. Jackson then dismissed the panel of nine women and three men for the day after answering a routine evidentiary question. Deliberations resumed this morning. The panel last Thursday began deliberating the 14 charges against Barry _ three felony counts of perjury, one misdemeanor count of conspiracy and 10 misdemeanor counts of cocaine possession. Meanwhile, chief defense attorney R. Kenneth Mundy speculated Tuesday that Barry could be convicted on some counts. ``You're going to get some hung counts ... some acquittals ... you might get one or two convictions,'' Mundy said. ``My opinion is they've passed the perjury ... (and) ...he's going to be acquitted'' of those counts. Allen Palmer, a former federal prosecutor who now works as a criminal defense attorney, speculated that Eagles declined to reveal the jury's decision because one or more jurors became uncertain about their conclusion. ``Obviously someone was a little shaky in their resolve during the 20 minutes or so it took to assemble people in the courtroom,'' Palmer said in an interview. ``One or two people indicated to the foreman that they may not be willing to go along with their prior vote,'' he theorized. ``That's why the foreman wanted the judge to ascertain from the jurors themselves what their individual votes were.'' The maximum penalties for conviction on all 14 criminal charges against the mayor are 26 years in prison and $1.85 million in fines. Under federal sentencing guidelines, however, any sentence would be far less than the maximum. The defense has acknowledged the mayor was an occasional user of cocaine but has contended the government has not proven charges concerning use at specific times and places. Witnesses at the trial testified that Barry snorted and smoked cocaine and smoked opium and marijuana some 200 times. Thirteen witnesses said they saw Barry use cocaine between 1983 and last January when the mayor was videotaped by the FBI smoking crack. Three other witnesses said they saw Barry smoke marijuana. Admitted cocaine dealer Lydia Pearson said she sold crack to the mayor about 25 times in a three-month span.

DOC.HEAD: Bhutto: Army Threatened to Impose Martial Law
DOC.TEXT: Former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto said today the army had threatened to impose martial law as a way of forcing the president to dismiss her 20-month-old government. On Monday, President Ghulam Ishaq Khan dissolved Ms. Bhutto's government, citing widespread corruption among senior officials, misuse of power and the failure to control ethnic violence in her home province of Sindh. He named a caretaker government and called for elections on October. ``The president's speech was prepared by the military headquarters,'' Ms. Bhutto claimed at a news conference. That charge has been denied by both the military and Ishaq Khan. ``The caretaker government is temporary,'' she added. ``Within a few weeks, the army will take over.'' An army spokesman said Ishaq Khan had consulted the army chief of staff, Gen. Mirza Aslam Beg, before making his decision to dismiss the government, but he denied the president was pressured by Beg. ``It was in the offing for a very long time,'' the army spokesman said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``Even they (Ms. Bhutto's government) were aware of it.'' He also rejected Ms. Bhutto's claim that the military was considering the imposition of martial law. The spokesman said with tensions high on the border with neighboring India, the army would be unable to declare martial law and deploy large numbers of troops to patrol in cities. Ms. Bhutto's critics and even members of her own Pakistan People's Party said she had been warned repeatedly to reform her government. Ms. Bhutto told reporters she had no differences with the army until May, when disputes emerged over the conflicts in neighboring Afghanistan and in Kashmir, the disputed territory divided between India and Pakistan. ``Until May there were no differences between me and Gen. Beg, but when the process of repatriation started, major differences developed,'' she said. Ms. Bhutto claimed the army opposed the repatriation of 3.8 million Afghan refugees living in Pakistan, saying it would give legitimacy to the Soviet-backed government in Kabul that U.S.-supplied guerrillas have been fighting to overthrow. Ms. Bhutto also claimed the army wanted to go to war with India over Kashmir, where a Moslem uprising for independence from mainly Hindu India has claimed more than 900 lives since late January. Ms. Bhutto said she opposed a war with India. An army spokesman dismissed those allegations.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Lists His Reasons
With PM-US-Iraq Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush listed ``four simple principles'' today that he said guided U.S. policy as he dispatched American forces to Saudi Arabia: ``First, we seek the immediate, unconditional and complete withdrawal of all Iraqi forces from Kuwait. ``Second, Kuwait's legitimate government must be restored to replace the puppet regime. ``And third, my administration, as has been the case with every president from President Roosevelt to President Reagan, is committed to the security and stability of the Persian Gulf. ``And fourth, I am determined to protect the lives of American citizens abroad.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Mexicans to Discuss Cross Border Issues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Baker, Solana remarks. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Mexican Foreign Secretary Fernando Solana joined forces today in condemning the Iraqi conquest of Kuwait and demanded an immediate withdrawal of Iraqi forces. The occasion was a gathering of more than 150 American and Mexican officials, including nine cabinet members from each side, to discuss such issues as energy supplies, drug trafficking and immigration. One U.S. official said the assemblage constituted perhaps the largest bilateral discussion in diplomatic history. The meetings are held annually under the auspices of the Mexico-U.S. Binational Commission. Minutes after President Bush addressed the nation on the Persian Gulf crisis, Baker stood before the delegates and condemned Iraq's ``outlaw act of blatant, illegal aggression.'' Baker reaffirmed the administration's call for the ``immediate withdrawal of Iraqi forces and the return of Kuwait's legitimate government.'' In a similar vein, Solana said Mexico condemns the Iraqi invasion. ``We call for the immediate withdrawal of the invading troops.'' he said. Shortly after the opening ceremony ended, Baker headed for Turkey for consultations on the Gulf crisis. The Iraqi invasion added a new dimension to this year's Mexican-American conclave because of the destabilizing impact it's having on the price and supply of oil worldwide. Mexico exports about half of its 2.5 million barrel daily production of oil and stands to benefit substantially from the recent sharp increases in oil prices. It was expected the two sides would discuss the possibility of an increase in Mexico's production capacity in the event of a significant drop in the international supply of oil. In his remarks, Baker said completion of a free-trade agreement and continued progress in the war against narcotics trafficking are two of the major challenges the United States and Mexico face. He said cooperation in combatting the drug trade has been better this year than at any time in history. For his part, Solana said: ``Mexico is willing to multiply its economic contacts with the United States. We believe that a fair, free-trade agreement would be a major step in that direction.'' Solana touched only briefly on the drug issue in his remarks. According to U.S. officials, the priority Mexico has given to the issue is reflected in increased cocaine seizures: an estimated 12,000 kilos (26,500 pounds) over the last six months, most as a result of joint Mexican-American operations. In addition, Mexico is pleased that the United States is increasingly accepting Mexico's view that the U.S. government should do more to reduce demand for narcotics.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
Iraq Says Kuwait is Part of Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi state television declared today that Kuwait is part of Iraq and called for ``full unity between Kuwait and Iraq.'' The statement stopped short of saying Iraq has annexed Kuwait, but strongly suggested that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has no intention of giving up the emirate, which his troops seized in a lightning raid on Thursday. ``Our fellow citizens, history has proved that Kuwait is a part of Iraq,'' said the statement, read by an unidentified announcer. ``In order to make our banners the banners of freedom and unity...we are appealing for all Iraqis...we are appealing to all principles of honor, to go with their heroic leader, Saddam Hussein,'' the announcement said. The statement also called for Arab unity in the face of outside threats, an apparent reference to a multinatinal force being sent to Saudi Arabia. Earlier, Iraqi radio had said there would be an important announcement today, fueling speculation that Baghdad intended to say it had annexed Kuwait. The statment came less than two hours after President Bush told the American people that U.S. troops were taking up ``defensive positions'' in oil-rich Saudi Arabia to guard against a possible attack by Iraq. Bush again demanded an immediate Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Gets Congressional Backing on Deploying Combat Troops
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers today praised President Bush's decision to send U.S. combat forces to Saudi Arabia to deter further aggression by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, whose troops overran neighboring Kuwait last week. But members of Congress cautioned that the United States should not go it alone in protecting other Arab nations and U.S. oil interests in the Persian Gulf region. ``It's important that this be a joint operation. I hope other Arab states can get involved,'' Rep. Ike Skelton, D-Mo., a senior member of the House Armed Services Committee, said in a telephone interview. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., stressed during a campaign swing for Democratic candidates in Georgia that it would ``be important if we could obtain greater and greater international cooperation and coordination in these efforts not only on the ground but in terms of any potential blockade.'' ``The international support is important, I think, to American public feeling that we're not in this alone and that we represent a broader concern,'' Foley said in an interview on NBC's ``Today'' show. In an Oval office address this morning, Bush announced that U.S. troops were taking up defensive positions in oil-rich Saudi Arabia to guard against a possible attack by Iraq. Bush described the makeshift Saudi defense force as ``multinational,'' but he did not identify the participants and there was considerable confusion about its makeup. Egypt and Morocco denied they were involved. ``I think that the policy the president is following is one that's very, very important to our national security interests, and I think he has strong support in the Congress,'' Foley said of the decision. Rep. Dante Fascell, D-Fla., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said in a CNN interview from Miami that he endorsed Bush's actions but emphasized the need for participation from other countries. ``I certainly support the concept of other nations being involved in this matter besides just simply air and naval power, essential as that might be,'' he said. ``I'll just feel a lot better when I see some other troops on the ground joining those U.S. troops in defense of Saudi Arabia,'' Fascell said. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said on CBS's ``This Morning'' program that the battle ``is to really prevent one rather demented soul, this fellow Saddam Hussein, from gaining control over the bulk of the world's oil reserves.'' Rep. William S. Broomfield of Michigan, ranking Republican on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said the United States should ``make an example of Saddam Hussein.'' ``It's important that other regional powers understand that the world will not put up with naked aggression,'' Broomfield said in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: Mubarak Denies Egypt Will Join Multinational Force
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 12th graf ``I call...' to UPDATE with 9 Arab nations agreeing to attend summit, inserts 1 graf after 21st graf, ``He said...' to UPDATE with Italy and Spain giving U.S. permission to use bases on their territory. Pickup pvs 22st graf, `France has...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt today denied U.S. reports that his country has agreed to send troops to join the multinational force to defend Saudi Arabia and other threatened states in the Middle East. Mubarak made the comment in a nationally televised speech in which he did not rule out sending Egyptian troops as part of an Arab force. Earlier today, Britain announced it would join the multinational military effort to help prevent Iraq from expanding its invasion. U.S. officials in Washington, speaking on condition of anonymity, had said on Tuesday that Egypt and Morocco, close allies of the United States, had agreed to send troops to join the U.S.-led multinational force. But both countries today denied those reports. The question of Egypt's and Morocco's participation in the force is important because Saudi Arabia reportedly has insisted that other Arab nations join with the United States in sending troops to counter Iraq. Egypt has a large arsenal of U.S.-supplied weapons and is the second-largest recipient of U.S. economic and military aid _ currently receiving $2.3 billion a year. Since 1981 the United States has conducted biannual joint maneuvers with Egypt. But Mubarak said intervention by foreign troops could worsen the crisis, which began Thursday when tens of thousands of Iraqi troops overran Kuwait, then massed along the Saudi border. ``We have no troops there (in Saudi Arabia). We are not preparing troops and there is no talk about this,'' Mubarak said. ``But if we are asked to participate with Arab troops, I do not think Egypt would refuse,'' he said. Mubarak called for an emergency Arab summit within 24 hours and offered to hold it in Egypt. Shortly before Iraq invaded Kuwait, Mubarak had tried to ease tensions between the two countries and had thought he had succeeded. ``I call for an urgent Arab summit within 24 hours. It would be better than having a solution forced on us by foreign powers,'' the Egyptian leader said. Egypt's Middle East News Agency reported that Saudi Arabia, Algeria, Libya, Tunis, Morocco, Jordan, Oman, Yemen and Syria had agreed to attend the summit. There were no details on when the proposed summit would be held. Mubarak said he had no personal knowledge that foreign powers would strike Iraq but said he feared such an attack was coming. ``I have told our brothers in Iraq, I am afraid that Iraq will be struck by a harsh strike from the outside. Don't think that the fleets are just going to sit there sleeping,'' Mubarak said of naval forces being sent to the region by the United States, France and Britain. Morocco also indicated today that it was not willing to join the multinational force. The official Moroccan news agency MAP quoted an official source as saying, ``We deny all military participation'' in the force. Morocco's King Hassan II receives millions of dollars a year in U.S. military aid. The moderate Arab country has U.S.-made tanks. There was hope that a multinational defense of Saudi Arabia would deter President Saddam Hussein's million-man Iraqi army from crossing the border and seizing the kingdom's rich oil fields. Secretary of State James A. Baker III made plans to meet Friday in Brussels with the foreign ministers of the 15 U.S. allies in Europe after a quick consultation trip to Turkey. The move appeared to be an effort to enlist Western Europe in the Saudi defense effort. The announcement by British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd today that Britain would participate in the multinational force followed a conversation between Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and Saudi Arabia's King Fahd. Hurd said the Saudis asked for British help, and Britain was in contact with the United States and other allies on the best contribution it could make. He said it was too soon to specify which forces Britain would send, but he added: ``We are essentially talking about naval and air forces.'' Also today, Spain and Italy agreed to let the United States used bases on their territory to help transport U.S. troops and equipment sent to gulf. France has said it has not been asked to take part in the multinational force and that participation was not ``envisaged at this stage.'' Turkey, which closed twin Iraqi oil pipelines to the Mediterranean on Tuesday, also was not asked to join such a force, said Turkey's Foreign Ministry spokesman, Murat Sungar. Bonn today signaled readiness to allow the U.S. military to use American facilities in West Germany as a ``basis for operations'' for soldiers headed to Saudi Arabia to defend that nation against Iraq. But the West German government said late Tuesday that there were no plans for German troops to join the multinational force, noting that the West German Constitution bars the use of German troops outside the country. Taizo Watanabe, spokesman for the Japanese Foreign Ministry, also said his country's constitution would bar it from joining any international military effort in the Persian Gulf. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney returned to Washington today after visiting Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Morocco in a two-day trip to drum up support for U.S. pressure on Iraq. He met with King Hassan in Morocco on Tuesday. A handful of British and French navy vessels were also in the region. A Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman said a Soviet anti-submarine ship and destroyer were dispatched from the Indian Ocean toward the area, but only to ``ensure safety of navigation of Soviet civilian vessels.'' Diplomats said the U.N. Security Council's resolution Monday ordering an international trade embargo against Iraq could be used as justification by the United States and other nations to act unilaterally, or in concert apart from the United Nations, to enforce the boycott.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Bush Commits US Forces to ``Defensive'' Position in Saudi
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, inserts material on supply ships. Editing throughout. 1st Add should stand as background.
DOC.TEXT:
President Bush announced today that U.S. troops were taking up ``defensive positions'' in oil-rich Saudi Arabia to guard against a possible attack by Iraq. ``They will not initiate hostilities but they will defend themselves,'' he said. At least 5,000 ground troops were involved, along with 140 sophisticated fighters and bombers and naval supply ships, according to government sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. Cruise missiles programmed to hit specific Iraqi sites were aboard a battleship that set out on a week's journey to the Middle East. In a televised Oval Office address, Bush sharply condemned Iraqi aggression in invading Kuwait last week. He demanded ``immediate, unconditional and complete'' withdrawal and the restoration of the Kuwaiti government to power. The president conceded that the Saudi defense mission ``may take time and be costly'' and said he would consider tapping the nation's strategic petroleum reserves to assure a ready supply of oil. He called on the oil companies not to engage in unnecessary price hikes to take advantage of the international uncertainty and urged that other oil-producing nations boost production. Bush committed American forces as the second part of an international effort to force an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. The United Nations voted earlier in the week to impose a complete trade embargo against Iraq, and Bush and other world leaders have been considering how to implement the sanctions, including a possible naval blockade. Bush described the make-shift Saudi defense force as a ``multi-national'' one, but he did not identify the participants and there was considerable confusion about its makeup. Egypt and Morocco denied they were involved. The reaction from Iraq was defiant. State television declared that ``history has proved that Kuwait is a part of Iraq.'' One Pentagon official, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, said the nation's military leadership was settling in for what could be a lengthy operation. ``This whole thing isn't easy. You don't deploy forces and they suddenly show up in another part of the world. There are a hell of a lot of logistical problems that go into moving people around the world, particularly in the extreme conditions of the Middle East,'' he said. Members of Congress offered immediate backing for the president's moves. Said House Speaker Thomas Foley, ``I think the people and the Congress will support him.'' Expressions of concern blended with support. Democratic Rep. Les Aspin, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said the nation was in for ``a couple of very, very tense days.'' The president provided no estimate of the number of troops involved in the Saudi deployment _ deliberately so, according to Pentagon sources who said Bush did not want to tip off Iraq. U.S. sources had said Eqypt and Morocco would participate in the multi-national force, but only Britain said it would take part. ``We have no troops there,'' said Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak. ``We are not preparing troops and there is no talk about this. But if we are asked to participate with Arab troops, I do not think Egypt would refuse. The USS Wisconsin departed Tuesday night on a week-long voyage for the Mediterranean Sea, armed with 32 Tomahawk cruise missiles programmed with targeting information about specific Iraqi positions, the sources said. It would escort the carrier Saratoga to the Mediterranean. Two other carriers are in the region, along with their escort ships. The president continued his diplomatic maneuvers as the military deployment unfolded. White House officials said Bush was meeting during the day with Kuwait's ambassador in a gesture that reflected continuing American support for the exiled Kuwaiti government. Secretary of State James A. Baker was departing for Turkey and a later visit to Brussels for a meeting with NATO leaders on Friday. Sources who spoke on condition of anonymity said Turkey was seeking compensation of as much as $2 billion in exchange for shutting down the Iraqi oil pipeline that crosses its territory. ``There is no justification whatsoever for this outrageous and brutal act of aggression,'' Bush said of Iraq and its leader, Saddam Hussein, a man he described as ``an aggressive dictator threatening his neighbors.'' ``A puppet regime imposed from the outside is unacceptable. The acquisition of territory by force is unacceptable. No one, friend or foe, should doubt our desire for peace, and no one should underestimate our determination to confront aggression.'' Pentagon sources, who spoke on condition of not being identified, said Army units heading for Saudi Arabia included elements of the 82nd Airborne Division from Fort Bragg, N.C.; the 24th Division (Mechanized) from Fort Stewart, Ga., and the 101st Airborne Division from Fort Campbell, Ky. The 82nd and the 101st make up the 18th Airborne Corps. As well, several Marine supply ships based at the super-secret U.S. facility on the island of Diego Garcia have set sail for the region, the sources said. ``This first movement is of light infantry and airborne troops. But these ships have the heavy tanks, M1-A1 Abrams and M-60s, that are needed for heavy-duty ground fighting,'' the source said. The source said the Tomahawk cruise missiles would overmatch the French-made Exocet missiles that Iraq has used so successfully in other conflicts. Sources said Navy supply ships have departed Guam, the strategic Pacific Island base manned with 8,000 U.S. airmen and sailors, for the Arabian Sea to back up the Independence and the Eisenhower carriers.
more

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Lists Naval Forces Deployed in Mideast Crisis
With PM-Iraq-US Military
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon offered this breakdown today of the U.S. Navy forces that have been deployed to the Mediterranean and Middle East region: Persian Gulf: Nine ships, including the command ship LaSalle, two cruisers, a destroyer and five frigates. Mediterranean: Eleven combat ships and six auxiliary ships. Four ships from the Marine Amphibious Readiness unit normally deployed to the Mediterranean are on duty off the coast of Liberia. Red Sea: The aircraft carrier Eisenhower has completed its transit of the Suez Canal. Pentagon sources report that five other ships are accompanying the carrier en route to the Arabian Sea. Atlantic Ocean: Ten ships of the aircraft carrier Saratoga battle group and five Marine amphibious ships are transiting the Atlantic for deployment to the Mediterranean. Indian Ocean: The aircraft carrier Independence and six ships.
Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers in the United States and abroad.

Aug. 3 The Providence (R.I.) Journal-Bulletin on Iraq-Kuwait: Let us hope that anyone who believes history ended with the decline of the Cold War is aware of the Iraqui invasion of Kuwait. This remarkable event has come as a shock, but no surprise: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq had been hinting about such action for some time, and had bullied Kuwait with the threat of force at the recent OPEC conference in Geneva. ... President Bush has vowed that the United States will ``take whatever steps necessary'' to defend American interests in the Persian Gulf. ... We take President Bush's comments to mean that oil supplies to the West will not be interrupted _ and we trust that he will not hesitate to guarantee those supplies. If this means a resumption of our earlier policy of reflagging and escorting tankers in danger, then that earlier policy should be swiftly resurrected.

Aug. 3 The Register-Guard, Eugene, Ore., on Iraq-Kuwait: Iraq has a huge army, massive debts and ambitions that are out of proportion to its size. At its doorstep lies Kuwait, a virtually undefended country with $2 trillion worth of oil. In retrospect, it's surprising that Iraq waited until now to grab its rich little neighbor. ... Iraq's invasion has also confirmed that its president, Saddam Hussein, is one of the world's most dangerous men. Under his leadership Iraq has launched an eight-year war against Iran, used chemical weapons more extensively than any nation since World War I, attempted to buy nuclear weapons triggers on the international black market, and threatened Israel with annihilation. Now, with Kuwait's resources at his disposal, Hussein controls 20 percent of the output of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, putting him in a position to cause economic mischief on a global scale. Iraq must be forced back within its borders, but armed force _ particularly American military intervention _ should not be the instrument. The United States does not have enough at stake to justify a war with Iraq over Kuwait. ... Hussein is undeterred by world opinion. He will, however, respond to economic pressure. ... President Bush has already cut off trade with Iraq, frozen Iraqi funds and protected Kuwaiti assets in the U.S. from Iraqi seizure. Other countries should respond with sanctions of their own. The Soviet Union and France, Iraq's two main suppliers of military equipment, have a special responsibility to end arms shipments. Japan and Western Europe, the main consumers of Iraqi oil, should seek supplies elsewhere. Oil exporters in the Mideast and elsewhere should increase production to facilitate the boycott.

Aug. 4 Orange Coast Daily Pilot, Costa Mesa, Calif., on Iraq-Kuwait: It's time to act like a superpower. The United States needs to use its military force to dislodge Iraq from its occupation of Kuwait and to cripple the million-man, renegade Iraqi army. The reason is simple: other methods of retaliation are too risky. From all accounts, Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein is the Hitler of the 1990s, the Butcher of Baghdad, a madman who wants to rule the Middle East. If we put an international economic knife to Hussein's throat, he might lash out in defense. Remember, this is a man who has built a Third World country into a first-rate military power, liberally used chemical weapons in his war with Iran and, some analysts fear, may have a nuclear surprise up his sleeve. Why sweat an outlaw like this? The United States has spent $300 billion per year to build up its military; let's put it to use. ... As Iraqi troops sit just miles from the Saudi Arabia border, the time for the U.S. to draw the line has passed. Hussein obliterated the line as soon as his army crossed the border of Kuwait. The world community has unanimously condemned Iraq for its lightning takeover of Kuwait. We encourage the United States to lead the world and bring this outlaw country to justice.

Aug. 2 The Brainerd (Minn.) Daily Dispatch on Justice Marshall: Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall (made) malicious comments concerning President Bush's nomination of David Souter to replace Justice William Brennan on the court. In an interview on ABC television, the 82-year-old justice scoffed at Souter as a nobody who couldn't hope to fill the shoes of Brennan, an esteemed liberal. But Marshall's pique didn't end there. He also blasted the president. ``It's said that, if you can't say something good about a dead person, don't say it,'' Marshall said of Bush. ``Well, I consider him dead.'' This statement is not only shockingly rude but also totally inappropriate from the mouth of a supposedly dignified Supreme Court justice. The fact that he has a lifetime appointment and is largely insulated from public scrutiny doesn't excuse such callousness.

Aug. 2 Athens (Ohio) Messenger on S&Ls and student loans: The savings and loan scandal is actually having one beneficial side-effect: It is making Washington nervous about the federal government's vast and miscellaneous liabilities. Federal insurance on thrift deposits is the reason the public must pick up the tab for hundreds of insolvent S&Ls around the country. The cost to the taxpayers: $300 billion over 30 years. But deposit insurance is only one form of public guarantee. Numerous other programs shift risk and potential losses from private parties to the citizens at large. The administration is starting to take a close look at the public's exposure in areas like home mortgages, farm credit _ and that perennial invitation to abuse, student loans. Federally guaranteed student loans worth $13 billion will be made this year. Those loans help millions of young people pay for college or vocational training. Unfortunately, they also line the pockets of con artists who set up fly-by-night trade schools that exploit unsophisticated, often semiliterate clients and feed off federal loans. The default rate, just 9 percent at four-year colleges, averages 40 percent at for-profit trade schools. Loan deadbeats are costing taxpayers $2 billion this year. ... Together, these agencies will have more than $1 trillion in liabilities outstanding by 1991. The taxpayers, reeling from the savings and loan bailout, have a right to insist that these enterprises be financially sound.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Study Says Kids Shouldn't Ride in Backs of Pickups
DOC.TEXT: Children riding in the back of pickup trucks risk severe injury and death even if the vehicle is not involved in a crash, researchers report. The study in today's Journal of the American Medical Association examined data on 290 children up to age 14 who had been injured or killed in pickups from 1980 to 1989 in Orange County, Calif. The researchers found that 24 percent of those injured in the back of the truck were hurt in non-crash events _ such as a sudden stop or turn _ compared with 9 percent of those in the cab. And 47 percent of the children riding in the back were injured when ejected from the vehicle, while only 11 percent of those riding inside were ejected, the researchers said. ``The ultimate goal should be a legislative intervention eliminating travel in the back of a pickup truck where no opportunity for restraint exists,'' wrote the authors, led by Dr. Phyllis F. Agran of the University of California at Irvine's pediatrics department. ``It goes against every principle of child safety that you could imagine,'' said Dr. Mark Widome, chairman of the American Academy of Pediatrics' Committee on Injury and Poison Prevention. The authors noted that National Highway Traffic Safety Administration statistics show that in 1987, 127 children under age 20 were killed nationwide while riding in the back of pickups. About 1,000 children were injured in such instances that same year, the authors said. In 1989, 103 youths aged 21 and under died while riding in pickup beds, federal statistics show. Only eight states have measures restricting travel in the back of pickups, said the study's authors.

DOC.HEAD: Antibiotics Head Off Urinary Tract Infections In Women After Sex
DOC.TEXT: Taking a tablet containing antibiotics after sex can give women who suffer frequent urinary tract infections a reprieve from that common and frustrating problem, researchers report. Such an approach is better than taking the same antibiotics daily or three times a week to prevent infections, since continual antibiotic therapy can be costly and can promote antibiotic-resistant bacteria, the researchers reported in today's Journal of the American Medical Association. The drugs they used in a new study _ trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole, marketed in combination under the trade names Bactrim and Septra _ seem to work regardless of how often a woman has sex, the researchers said. The drugs also are highly effective in women who use diaphragms for contraception, an important finding since diaphragms have been blamed for contributing to urinary tract infections in sexually active young women. The researchers compared 16 infection-prone women who took the antibiotics after sex with 11 similar women who were given an inert drug. The women were an average of 23 years old, and each had suffered at least two urinary tract infections in the previous year. Only two of the 16 women taking antibiotics developed infections during the 180 days of the study, compared with nine of the women taking placebos. The researchers were led by Dr. Ann Stapleton of the Department of Medicine at the University of Washington in Seattle. The infection rate in study subjects who took antibiotics after sex _ 0.3 per patient-year _ compares favorably with rates reported previously for patients who took the same drugs daily or three times per week _ zero to 0.15 infections per patient-year, the researchers said. Taking antibiotics after intercourse is something many physicians already prescribe for such women, but the Seattle study is the first scientific support for the strategy. ``It is an important study, even though the idea is not new,'' Dr. Arieh Bergman, chief of gynecology and urology at the University of Southern California Women's Hospital, said in a telephone interview Tuesday from Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: worth considering.
DOC.TEXT: Aug. 4 Asahi Shimbun, Tokyo, on Iraq-Kuwait: There are mounting international calls for economic sanctions against Iraq as a result of its invasion of Kuwait. ... More than anything else, we wish to see the conflict resolved in the United Nations from the standpoint of the Kuwaitis whose country has been invaded. There were not a few cases where economic sanctions invoked in the Cold war years tended to become half-baked and did not function in an effective manner. Given this tendency, Japan used to be rather passive on economic sanctions. ... Having an increasingly bigger say in the world community, Japan ought to extricate itself from its conventional passive posture of following other countries and act positively so that economic sanctions against Iraq may be effective. ... The best option for making economic sanctions effective is to respond to the Iraqi-Kuwaiti situation in an imperturbable manner, instead of being carried away by immediate market trends.

Aug. 5 Turkiye, Istanbul, Turkey, on Iraq-Kuwait: Iraq has destroyed peace in the region. ... There is little doubt that Turkey should not enter into deplorable actions on behalf of the superpowers. But on these days when a vacuum has been created in the region couldn't (Turkey) raise its voice a bit louder and make it heard by the masses calling for law and justice? ... It must be admitted that Iraq has committed this very unjust action extremely successfully and gotten the highest grade. ... Neither the CIA, nor the KGB nor anyone else had the slightest idea of what was going to happen. (But Iraq) may get used to that. ... Turkey must place its helmet and top hat of diplomacy (on the table) and think about it.

Aug. 4 Sovetskaya Rossiya, Moscow, on Iraq-Kuwait: The conflict in relations between Iraq and Kuwait erupted more than a fortnight ago when Baghdad accused Kuwait authorities of exceeding OPEC production quotas and thereby bringing down world prices of oil and harming the Iraqi economy. ... But the roots of this bloody conflict go much deeper. They lie in the hegemonistic nature of the Iraqi leadership's foreign policy over the past decade. Tensions in the Persian Gulf continue unabated. This, as the Soviet government justly said in its statement, is directly at odds with the interests of Arab countries, means extra obstacles to settling conflicts in the Middle East, and runs counter to positive trends of recovery in the international economy.

Aug. 6 The Guardian, London, on Iraq-Kuwait: Frustration in the Gulf leads temptingly to the invocation of task forces and tactical bombing, but the military option is no option at all. The emergence of a potential hostage problem of vast dimensisons only emphasized that this is far too vast a crisis for gunboat diplomacy. Loose talk of ``carpet-bombing'' Baghdad should be put back in the bottle of theoretical but unacceptable scenarios. ... For the West to use force now would only compound its enormous historical error which has allowed the monster we helped create to thrive. ... Nothing would do more to convince the Arab world that Saddam Husseein is the Nasser of the '90s. And nothing would more quickly undermine the new harmony of the post-cold war world than unilateral action by the United States and its allies.

Aug. 2 Straits Times, Singapore, on Trinidad and Tobago: The coup attempt (in Trinidad and Tobago) is to some extent a manifestation of a nation's unhappiness with grinding poverty and a worsening economy. ... Exploiting this, the rebels claimed that they staged the coup because of government corruption and austerity measures. Whether or not they are to be believed, corruption at the highest level and further economic pain through austere _ and necessary _ measures are the ingredients that could turn a contented people against their government. ... What made matters worse in Trinidad and Tobago was that the frustration also took on a religious and racial slant. Moslems, mainly converts, form six percent of a population which is predominantly Christian. ... Another sinister aspect of this highly combustible situation was the allegation that some of the rebels were trained in Libya, dubbed by many Western governments as a sponsor of terrorism. If Libya did indeed help pull the trigger, then clearly Trinidad's troubles have far wider implications, especially for small countries who suffer from a triple dosage of economic woes and a racial minority which is also a religious minority.

Aug. 6 Jakarta (Indonesia) Post on normalizing relations between China and Indonesia: As we begin to conduct full diplomatic relations with China in the continuously changing setting of the Asia-Pacific region, therefore, we must from the outset have a clear vision and retain concrete ideas of what the actual purposes of maintaining such relations are. ... Although we will be developing our bilateral relations with China on different levels _ trade, culture, sports, science and technology and so forth _we should prevent ourselves from developing sentimental views that could fog our clear view on the aspirations of China as a major Asian power. That is why it is important to convey to China, in no uncertain terms and precisely at this initial stage of normal diplomatic relations, that the efforts to restore peace in Cambodia have by now become a crucial test case of whether it has the intention of playing a constructive role in Southeast Asia. Certainly the majority of countries in the world, as well as we in Indonesia, find it difficult to understand how a major power such as China ... persists in using such a despicable group as the Khmer Rouge as its policy instrument on mainland Southeast Asia. ... In that fundamental sense, the resumption of normal diplomatic relations between ... Indonesia and ... China could have a beneficial impact on the stability and the dynamic development of East Asia.

Aug. 1 Trouw, Amsterdam, Netherlands, on Liberia: The end of the Liberian president, Samuel Doe, is near, although he himself doesn't seem to think so. With a few hundred faithful followers he has barricaded himself in his palace in the besieged capital, Monrovia, and feels strengthened by his belief in ``juju,'' the magic powers that should make him invincible. ... Doe did not turn out to be the champion of emancipation of suppressed ``natives.'' He established a new ethnic supremacy, of his Krahn tribe over other ethnic groups. Under his corrupt rule the country was impoverished. But the Americans stayed. They had economic interests (rubber), maintained the radio station Voice of America and an important military communication center, and the Monrovian airport was of military significance. It would be nonsense to say that the Americans bear guilt for the current violence in Liberia. But Washington could have protested earlier against Doe's misbehavior, and it could have thrown in its economic and political power. ... Now the European Community and the United States have distanced themselves from the violence of Doe, and from the rebels who are fighting him. ... Not siding with the rebels is nice. ... But waiting (until) things get better is the worst position possible. Tens of thousands of refugees are floating into the Ivory Coast and other poverty-stricken neighboring countries. Help has to be given there. Efforts of West-African countries to mediate in order to break through this deadlock merit support. ... However, the most important thing is that it is made clear to the ``victors'' in this horrible conflict, from the start and in every possible way, that human politics pay and draconian politics do not.
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Rdp
ABA House of Delegates Votes to Repeal Abortion Rights Stand
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The American Bar Association's policymaking body today withdrew its formal support of abortion rights, heeding a plea from a majority of members who took part in an earlier forum here. The ABA's House of Delegates, by a vote of 200-188, approved a so-called neutrality proposal to repeal its ``pro-choice'' policy adopted in February. The vote followed nearly two ours of spirited, at times impassioned debate over an issue that has divided the nation's largest lawyers' group as have few issues in its history. Supporters of the pro-choice stance vowed to fight on and said future ABA conventions could be dominated by the abortion issue. ``Nobody here has the illusion we're going to put our tails between our legs and go home,'' said Estelle Rogers of Washington, D.C., a leader of those who wanted the ABA to remain on record in support of abortion rights. Anthony Palermo of Rochester, N.Y., who led the drive for repeal, said he hoped the matter now is resolved. ``It would be a grave mistake if we kept dominating each meeting with this issue,'' he told reporters. During the debate among the delegates, Sally Determan of Washington, D.C., urged rejection of the repeal resolution. Adopting it, she said, would send a signal the ABA was abandoning its support of ``women's right to choose, to control our own bodies'' and was bowing to a well-financed campaign by a vocal minority. Barbara Howard of Cincinnati said she supported the repeal proposal because views on abortion reflect deeply held individual religious and moral beliefs. ``Abortion is not a legal issue,'' she said. ``It's a political issue, a moral issue.'' Lawyers attending the ABA's Assembly on Monday voted 885-836 to urge the delegates to rescind the February policy. Abortion opponents joined forces with those who support neutrality to narrowly approve the recommendation. Neither side said it had any plans for a referendum on the issue among all 360,000 ABA members nationwide. The split within the ABA was underscored by two speakers today, its new president, John J. Curtin Jr. of Boston, and his designated successor, Sandy D'Alemberte of Tallahassee, Fla. Curtin urged repeal. D'Alemberte pleaded with his colleagues to stand fast behind the pro-choice policy, which he said defends ``the principle of liberty.'' ``I am forced to ally myself with one set of friends against another,'' Curtin said. On Tuesday, he told a news conference the issue has caused wounds within the ABA he hopes to help heal. Regardless of the outcome of today's debate, Curtin said, ``There will be some disappointed people and I'll speak to the healing process. We're not a single-issue organization.'' Curtin had said he would refuse to sign any legal briefs in which the ABA advocates abortion rights if the pro-choice stance were retained. Palermo, in urging repeal of the February policy, said, ``If current policy is not altered, the ABA will be accurately portrayed as an advocate of one extreme position in the debate, thus forfeiting its potential role as a constructive arbiter of the debate.'' Monday's Assembly: 12th graf pvs. Monday's Assembly vote was open to any of the 12,000 association members attending this week's annual convention who paid a $250 registration fee. The resolution adopted by the House of Delegates in February said government should not interfere ``with the confidential relationship between a pregnant woman and her physician'' in deciding on abortions. The policy prompted criticism by some who said it creates an impression the ABA may be biased when it decides whether to support judicial nominees. But Curtin said Tuesday that the ABA will continue to evaluate judicial appointees, including Supreme Court nominee David H. Souter, based on competence, integrity and judicial temperament. More than 1,500 members have quit the ABA since February in protest over the pro-choice stance, costing the association about $300,000 in annual fees.
