With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp
DOC.NOTE: Eds: These quotes are suggested for use as a package or separately for layout purposes.
DOC.TEXT:
Here are some of Wednesday's quotes on the Iraq-Kuwait crisis:
``I want to be clear about what we are doing and why. America does not seek conflict, nor do we seek to chart the destiny of other nations. But America will stand by her friend. The mission of our troops is wholly defensive. Hopefully, they will not be needed long. They will not initiate hostilities, but they will defend themselves, the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia and other friends in the Persian Gulf.'' _ President George Bush.

``We have no troops there (in Saudi Arabia). We are not preparing troops and there is no talk about this. But if we are asked to participate with Arab troops, I do not think Egypt would refuse.'' _ Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak.

``Our fellow citizens, history has proved that Kuwait is a part of Iraq. In order to make our banners the banners of freedom and unity...we are appealing for all Iraqis...we are appealing to all principles of honor, to go with their heroic leader, Saddam Hussein.'' _ From a statement read on Iraqi radio.

DOC.HEAD: No More Goose Step, Defense Minister Says
DOC.TEXT: East German soldiers will no longer march the goose step because it is out of step with the country's new democratic ways, East Germany's defense minister announced Wednesday. The goose step, widely linked to Germany's militaristic past, no longer fits the armed forces' image, Defense Minister Rainer Eppelmann said, according to the ADN news agency. The goose step was a trademark of Adolf Hitler's Third Reich. After Germany was divided, the West dropped the goose step, but the East retained it.

DOC.HEAD: Man Convicted of Holdup With Infected Syringe
DOC.TEXT: A heroin addict and who is infected with the AIDS virus was convicted Wednesday of attempting to hold up a jewelry store with an infected syringe. The Lugano jury court found the 28-year-old Italian guilty of armed robbery and sentenced him to three years in prison. He was also barred from Switzerland for 15 years. The defendant's name was not given as is custom for first offenders in Switzerland. He threatened to stab the saleswoman of a store at Ponmte Tresa, near the Italian border, with the infected syringe. AIDS is caused by a virus that damages the body's immune system, leaving victims susceptible to infections and cancer. One way in which it is spread is through needles or syringes shared by drug abusers.

DOC.HEAD: Tokyo Receives First Measurable Precipitation in Four Weeks
DOC.TEXT: Showers fell in the parched Tokyo area Wednesday, the first measurable precipitation in nearly four weeks, but the rain missed the city's dwindling water source in the northern mountains, weather officials said. The capital's Waterworks Bureau said the city of 12 million people has enough water for only 15 days. A hot, dry summer has left seven reservoirs serving the capital and part of five surrounding states at just 25 percent of capacity. The 4.8 million households in Tokyo have been urged to cut their water use by 10 percent. The water bureau said it will have to ask residents to further cut their water use if the situation worsens. The water bureau said the water shortage was the worst since the long drought in the summer of 1987. A high pressure system touched off intermittent showers in the Tokyo area, dropping up to 2.8 inches of rain Wednesday. It was the first rain in Tokyo to amount to more than 0.4 inches since July 13.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Lists His Reasons
With AM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush listed ``four simple principles'' Wednesday that he said guided U.S. policy as he dispatched American forces to Saudi Arabia: ``First, we seek the immediate, unconditional and complete withdrawal of all Iraqi forces from Kuwait. ``Second, Kuwait's legitimate government must be restored to replace the puppet regime. ``And third, my administration, as has been the case with every president from President Roosevelt to President Reagan, is committed to the security and stability of the Persian Gulf. ``And fourth, I am determined to protect the lives of American citizens abroad.''

DOC.HEAD: Family Walks Out As Prosecution Sums Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs with prosecution summation, courtroom walkout; Picks up 8th graf pvs., `They are ...'
DOC.TEXT: Family and friends of three defendants in the Central Park jogger case walked out of the courtroom this morning as a prosecutor told the jury the teens were guilty of raping and nearly killing the woman. The closing argument by Assistant District Attorney Elizabeth Lederer was interrupted about 10 minutes after it began when a dozen of the defendants' supporters stood up and left. Lederer continued speaking, imploring the jury to convict Yusef Salaam, 16, Raymond Santana, 15, and Antron McCray, 16, in the April 19, 1989, brutalization of the jogger during a gang rampage through Central Park. ``These three youths had gone into the park ... with 30 or more people. They went to rob people, to beat people, and to assault people. And that is what they did. They robbed, beat and assaulted anyone they could catch,'' Lederer said. Lederer made reference to the courtroom appearance of the woman who authorities said was beaten, bludgeoned, raped and left for dead by her assailants. ``The fact that she could even come to this courtroom is a miracle. ... (The jogger) will never be the same as she was,'' Lederer said. The jury was expected to begin deliberations later today. Defense lawyers made their final appeals to the jury on Tuesday, with one attorney suggesting the victim was not gang-raped and others accusing detectives of lying about how admissions were obtained from the three defendants. Robert Burns, lawyer for Salaam, said in closing statements that unanswered questions raise doubts about whether she was raped. ``Nobody in his right mind would dispute the seriousness of her injuries,'' said Burns, ``but this brave young lady did not, and cannot, shed any light on what happened to her on April 19, 1989.'' Burns said semen found inside the jogger's body did not match that of the three defendants, her boyfriend or any person known to prosecutors. ``How can one conclude beyond a reasonable doubt that the sperm found inside her arose out of the criminal assault?'' Burns asked. Salaam, Santana and McCray are accused of raping and nearly killing the jogger and assaulting two male runners in the north end of Central Park. They are on trial in state Supreme Court in Manhattan on charges of attempted murder, rape, sexual abuse, riot, assault and robbery. The 30-year-old woman is back at work as a vice president at Salomon Brothers investment bankers, but she testified that she still suffers from impaired sight, balance and smell as a result of the attack. The principal evidence against McCray and Santana are statements they gave police. Salaam did not give police a statement but a detective testified he took notes of admissions Salaam made during questioning. All the lawyers said police lied on the witness stand about how the admissions were obtained. Michael Joseph, McCray's lawyer, charged that detectives used threats and promises to extract statements from his client. Peter Rivera, Santana's lawyer, told the jury, ``Raymond was not involved in any way, shape or form in the events he confessed to.'' Burns also criticized prosecutors for putting the jogger on the stand and for showing the jury color photographs of her injuries. ``I believe the district attorney has made an attempt to appeal to your emotions,'' Burns told the jury. ``When the prosecutor waves all those ghastly pictures at you, those are attempts to catapult you into a spirit of vengeance.''

DOC.HEAD: Chronology of Key Events in Dispute Between Iraq and Kuwait
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of the dispute between Iraq and Kuwait: July 17 _ Iraqi President Saddam Hussein accuses Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates of flooding the oil market and driving prices down, and that the move cost Iraq $14 billion in lost oil revenue. He further charges that Arab states in the Persian Gulf are conspiring with the United States and Israel to weaken Iraq's economy and undermine its military buildup. July 18 _ Iraq accuses Kuwait of stealing $2.4 billion worth of oil from wells along the disputed border with Iraq and of seeking to wreck Iraq's economy by overproducing oil and thus pushing down prices. July 20 _ Kuwaiti officials suggest Iraq's sudden outburst of belligerence is aimed at getting its creditors _ including Kuwait _ to write off billions of dollars in debts from the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. July 24 _ The U.S. Defense Department announces that U.S. Navy warships and aircraft are holding a ``short-notice exercise'' in the Persian Gulf with the United Arab Emirates, about 600 miles southeast of the Kuwait-Iraqi border. Kuwait reinstates a state of alert it declared July 16 and canceled after three days of tension between the two oil-producing countries. July 25 _ The Iraqi government says that it will not be intimidated by U.S. pressure in its oil dispute with neighboring Kuwait, and Saddam summons the U.S. ambassador for talks. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt says Iraq and Kuwait plan to meet in Saudi Arabia in an effort to resolve their dispute. July 26 _ OPEC ministers in Geneva agree to halt overproduction in hopes of pushing up the price of crude oil. Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates pledge to abide by the agreement. Analysts say Saddam clearly influenced the outcome of the meetings. July 31 _ Kuwaiti and Iraqi delegations meet in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, to negotiate the oil and border dispute. Diplomats say Iraq has massed 100,000 troops on Kuwait's border, more than triple the number originally estimated. That number dwarfs the Kuwaiti army, which has a total of about 20,000 troops. Aug. 1 _ Iraq pulls out of talks on the 2-week-old border, oil and money dispute with Kuwait shortly before it sends its forces to invade the oil-rich sheikdom. Aug. 2 _ Iraq's army overruns Kuwait before dawn; tank-led troops quickly seized the ruler's palace and other government buildings. Aug. 3 _ Shelling and gunfire shakes portions of Kuwait's capital, indicating a last-ditch attempt by Kuwaiti forces to hold out against the Iraqis. Iraqi troops push to within 5 to 10 miles of the Saudi Arabian border. The State department also said 14 Americans are now known to be missing in Kuwait and are believed to be in Iraqi hands. Aug. 4 _ Baghdad announces a new military government for Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. The 12-member European Community imposes an embargo against imports of Kuwaiti and Iraqi oil. It also bans exports of weapons to Iraq, suspends that country's preferential trade status and freezes Iraqi assets. Aug. 5 _ Kuwait's new Iraqi-installed government claims that Iraqi troops begin pulling out of Kuwait; the United States says it doubts withdrawal is really under way. Aug. 6 _ The U.N. Security Council orders worldwide embargo on trade with Iraq to punish that nation for its invasion of Kuwait. In Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and other U.S. military leaders confer with Saudi leaders about how to defend the oil kingdom against any attack by Iraq. Aug. 7 _ President Bush orders the deployment of U.S. combat troops and warplanes to Saudi Arabia; a U.S. Navy task force sets sail for the region. Turkey shuts down the Iraqi pipeline to the Mediterranean, honoring a U.N. trade embargo. Aug. 8 _ Iraq declares that Kuwait is part of Iraq and calls on Iraqis to rally behind President Saddam Hussein. Britain agrees to join a multinational force in the Persian Gulf.

Here is the text of President Bush's news conference Wednesday on the Iraq crisis: Bush: Terry? Q: Mr. President, how many American troops have you sent to Saudi Arabia? How long are you committed to keeping them there? And why not use them to drive Iraqi forces out of Kuwait? Bush: There will be a military briefing at the Pentagon, I think it's within an hour, and so I will leave the numbers to them. I would expect there would be some reluctance to give out specific numbers at this point for very obvious reasons. What was the last part of your _ Q: The other parts, sir, were how long will you keep American forces in Saudi Arabia, and why not use them to drive the Iraqi troops out of Kuwait? Bush: Well, as you know from what I said, they're there in a defensive mode right now. And therefore, that is not the mission, to drive the Iraqis out of Kuwait. We have economic sanctions that I hope will be effective to that end, and I don't know how long they'll be there. They just got there _ are just getting there. Q: Is this an open-ended commitment? I mean, could this drag on for years? Bush: Nothing is open-ended, but I'm not worrying about that there at all; I'm worrying about getting them there and doing what I indicated in our speech in there is necessary: the defense of the Saudis and the trying, through concerted international means, to reverse out this aggression. Q: Mr. President, are we in a war? And what other nations have agreed to join our forces in defending Saudi Arabia? And I take it you also have included other Gulf nations in that umbrella. Bush: We're not in a war. We have sent forces to defend Saudi Arabia. Other nations _ I will leave announcements about what other nations will be participating to the Saudis. But I believe Margaret Thatcher, after talking to King Fahd, has announced that forces will be going in, and then I think you'll see other such actions, but I'd much prefer to leave that to Saudi Arabia, who _ indeed, it's their country. Q: But was Cheney's mission successful in rallying support with Egypt and Morocco? Bush: Well, I _ I, having talked to Mubarak a couple of times myself, feel that we are in very close agreement with him. Who was your other country you asked about? Q: Morocco, Yemen. Bush: Morocco _ very, very supportive of the Saudis and of our overall position on the Mideast. So, they're _ I was very pleased with the Cheney mission in that regard. Brit? Q: Mr. President, there are several dozen Americans in Baghdad apparently not able to leave (inaudible) and perhaps hundreds more in Kuwait, and perhaps elsewhere in Iraq as well. In view of the extreme political sensitivity of Americans toward this whole question of hostages, why should not Saddam Hussein feel that he holds very high cards now in dealing with the United States? Bush: Well, I've been encouraged that there had been _ have been actually announcements, I believe, saying people were free to leave. So I'm not going to speculate or hypothecate beyond that. I want to see them out of there obviously. But what he does, that's a bit unpredictable. But I'm not going to heighten tensions in this regard by responding to hypothetical questions that might go beyond your question. Q: Well, what _ I just wonder what assurances you might be able to provide so that our policy in this instance will not become, as it has in the past, hostage-driven?
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Free Foreign Hostages, West African Nations to Send Troops
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 18th graf, ``The West...' with 1 graf to CORRECT that Togo sted Gambia contributing forces. Pickup pvs 19th graf, `The West...'
DOC.TEXT: EDITORS: The following is based in part on a pool report from journalists in Monrovia. AP correspondent Michael Goldsmith was among them.

Rebel leader Prince Johnson today freed foreign hostages his forces had kidnapped to provoke international intervention in Liberia's bloody civil war. The British Foreign Office said Johnson released all the hostages seized Monday and Tuesday, but said it was unclear how many people were freed. On Tuesday, Johnson had presented 22 hostages from eight countries to reporters at a news conference. A Foreign Office spokesman in London said Britain was waiting for the hostages to come to Monrovia from the nearby town of Caldwell, where they were being held. Only eight of the hostages have been identified. They are an American, an Argentinian, three Britons, a Dutchman and two West Germans. A fourth Briton has been freed but not identified. In Beirut, an official said 10 Lebanese were among those kidnapped. The American hostage was identified as Chris Mende, 27, a mining contractor from Sacramento, Calif. U.S. Marines were airlifted into Monrovia on Sunday, one day after Johnson threatened to begin rounding up foreigners in an effort to force foreign powers to intervene and end the civil war. The Marines evacuated Americans and other foreigners and took up defensive positions within the walled U.S. Embassy compound. Neighboring West African nations agreed Tuesday to send troops to stop the civil war. Diplomats based in Sierra Leone, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said 2,000 West African troops will soon be sent by sea to Monrovia from Freetown, Sierra Leone. Most of the troops would be from Nigeria. Earlier reports had said Nigeria was planning to airlift 500 soldiers to Monrovia. Johnson had said the hostages would not be freed until the United States or West African nations intervene militarily to halt the 7-month civl war to oust President Samuel Doe. Johnson said his forces would attack the Marines if no troops came. Some 5,000 people, mostly civilians, have been killed in the civil war. ``What this country really needs is the peaceful intervention of the United States'' or other African nations, said Johnson. ``If they don't intervene I will attack the American Marines.'' Nigerian President Ibrahim Babangida said today the peacekeeping troops would be deployed soon in Monrovia. Babangida said he hoped they would meet no resistance but added that they would be prepared to impose a truce if necessary. Street battles continued to rage in the Liberian capital, where rival rebel armies loyal to Johnson and former bureaucrat Charles Taylor are fighting each other and soldiers of the beleaguered Doe, who remains holed up in his fortified mansion. Heavy fighting also broke out near the U.S. Embassy. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said the Marines will protect the embassy and ``will do that with force if necessary.'' The State Department said the U.S. Embassy has taken steps to evacuate all Americans who can reach the embassy in Monrovia. The U.S. government also has agreed to evacuate some other foreign nationals. Ms. Tutwiler said a representative of Johnson's group had informed U.S. officials on Tuesday that the hostages were all well and would not be harmed. The Economic Community of West African States, meeting in Banjul, Gambia, did not say when the soldiers would go to Liberia. The West African leaders said in a communique at the end of their two-day summit Tuesday that a five-nation group led by a Ghanaian commander would go to Liberia. The other nations sending troops are Guinea, Nigeria, Sierra Leone, and Togo. The West African force would impose a cease-fire that would allow the establishment of a broad-based interim government charged with organizing free and fair elections, the announcement said. None of the warring parties would be permitted to participate in the interim government. No members of the interim government would be allowed to stand for election, the communique said. The beleagured Doe, who has repeatedly called for international intervention, welcomed the West African initiative in a telephone call Tuesday to the British Broadcasting Corp. The West African have asked the international community to help pay the cost of the operation and elections estimated at $50 million.

DOC.HEAD: Advice From Parents to College Students Doesn't Change Over Time
DOC.TEXT: Some things never change. A 1904 letter found at the University of Montevallo sounded two familiar themes of parent-child correspondence: money and letters. The letter was found by a remodeler under a window molding in the Main Hall basement, which was once a cafeteria. The letter was in its original envelope, addressed to Clyde Merrill, a student at the university in the early 1900s. Bill Plott, UM's director of information services, said the letter was from Miss Merrill's father, J.B. Merrill of Edwardsville. In his closing remarks, Merrill wrote: ``I will send check in day or two. Will carry my check book with me ... P.S. write to your ma.'' Ed Booth, a history buff who owns Central Construction, was thrilled with his find. ``I have a collection of arrowheads that I've found on construction sites before, but never anything like this,'' said Booth.

DOC.HEAD: New Beach Law: Boas Allowed Only If They're the Feathery Kind
DOC.TEXT: Sunbathers wearing a boa that isn't made of feathers are subject to a ticket. The City Commission passed a law Tuesday prohibiting boa constrictors and all other reptiles on city beaches. Another ordinance barring animals didn't include cold-blooded creatures such as snakes or lizards. ``We've had several people try to bring boa constrictors to the beach and when they were asked to leave, they argued that a reptile isn't an animal,'' said Lt. Matthew McShane. ``It's younger guys using snakes as a come-on for girls _ a `look at me' kind of thing,'' the police officer said. ``The people were asked to leave but we can't enforce a law that doesn't exist. We didn't anticipate this problem when the original ordinance was passed,'' said Mayor Marvin Frederich. Frederich said the slithery creatures go to the beach wrapped around their owner's neck or arm. ``What's a police officer supposed to do _ cuff them over the snake?'' he asked.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor's Mansion Going Against Water Conservation
DOC.TEXT: Most city residents are going along with the mayor's call for water conservation because of a drought, but water use is way up at the mayor's official residence. Mayor Tom Bradley has lobbied for a mandatory water conservation program that would impose rationing if residents fail to reduce their consumption by 10 percent below 1986 levels. By that standard, the mayor's official residence, Getty House, passes muster. During June and July, water use at Bradley's residence was 26 percent below 1986 levels, although in April and May, the decrease was less than 1 percent, according to Department of Water and Power records. But compared to last year, the faucets at Getty House are gushing. Water consumption from April through July at Getty House was an average 2,079 gallons per day, up nearly 27.5 percent over the same period last year, according to the records cited by the Daily News of Los Angeles. City residents cut their water use by 9.5 percent over the same period last year, the newspaper reported Wednesday. A Bradley spokesman blamed unseasonably high temperatures this year and more official receptions at the residence. ``The mayor held three times as many receptions this year than he did during the same four months last year,'' Bill Chandler said. ``If you know how much water is used at a reception with a hundred people, it's clear where much of the water went.'' City Councilwoman Joan Milke Flores, chairwoman of a council committee on water issues, said the Getty House water bill could dampen the mayor's credibility on conservation matters. ``People look to public officials for good examples,'' Flores said. The City Council rejected Bradley's conservation proposal last month in favor of a voluntary plan.

DOC.HEAD: WASH: hostage-driven?
DOC.TEXT: Bush: I can provide only the assurance that I consider the protection of American life fundamental to my job and responsibilities as president. Yes? Q: Mr. President, the question of chemical weapons. There are reports that the Iraqis were seen loading airplanes with chemical weapons. How concerned are you that he would use these over our troops that are there? Bush: Well, I think any time you deal with somebody who has used chemical weapons on the battlefield, you are concerned about it, and I would think that he'd know that, given the way the world views the use of chemical weapons, that it would be intolerable and that it would be dealt with very, very severely. So I would hope that there would be no use of chemical weapons. Q: Mr. President, I am being told in my ear that there is a report or a rumor out of Jedda that Saddam Hussein is dead. Have you heard anything of this? Bush: I've not heard anything of that. Q: Do you know if the Saudis will _ do you know if the Saudis will follow _ do you know if the Saudis are going to follow the Turks' lead in shutting off an Iraqi pipeline, the one (inaudible)? Have you had any promises from the Saudis or any other oil-producing countries that they will increase production to make up for this shortfall? Bush: Well, I'm convinced _ I believe that the Venezuelans have announced a significant increase, and I expect you'd find others to follow. And what was the first part, John? Q: Are the Saudis cutting off the pipeline to _ (inaudible)? Bush: That matter will be discussed, I'm sure, and I know that the Saudis are fully in accord with the action taken by the United Nations in terms of Chapter 7 sanctions. And so I _ but we have no deal with them in that regard. Q: Sir, it's difficult for us to get information from Saudi Arabia, one reason being the American news media were not permitted to accompany American troops into Saudi Arabia. Was that your decision or King Fahd's? Bush: That decision didn't come to me. But there's plenty of reporters in Saudi Arabia right now. Q: Well, do you think there should be a Pentagon pool, as there was for example in Panama? Bush: Well, I'd have to discuss that with the Secretary of Defense. I'm glad that the matter _ that that many forces could be moved with not too much advance warning, and with not too much, therefore, risk to Saudi Arabia or to these troops. Yeah? Q: Mr. President, was there any one single thing that tipped your hand into deciding to send U.S. troops and aircraft into Saudi Arabia? And secondly, how supportive have the Soviets been about your decision? Bush: There was no one single thing that I can think of, but when King Fahd requested such support we were prompt to respond. But I can't think of an individual specific thing. If there was one, it would perhaps be the Saudis (sic) moving south when they said they were withdrawing. Q: You mean the Iraqis, sir? Bush: I mean, the Iraqis _ thank you very much, it's been a long night _ moving _ the Iraqis moving down to the Kuwait-Saudi border when indeed they had given their word that they were withdrawing. That heightened our concern. Q: How supportive have the Soviets been to your decision, sir? Bush: The Soviets have been very responsible, in my view. They have joined the United Nations on that resolution, and Jim Baker, as recently as yesterday afternoon or evening, was in touch with Shevardnadze again, and you know, I can't ask for a more favorable response than he received. Yes, Jerry. Q: Mr. President, is it your intention to let economic pressure alone provide the force that drives Iraq out of Kuwait? Are you prepared to wait several months, which is how long it might take for the economic sanctions to really bite? Bush: Well, we've taken this first significant step to defend Saudi Arabia. The economic sanctions should begin to bite pretty soon. There will be further steps taken to ensure that they are fully effective, and then we'll wait and see where we go from there. But I have no _ we're not _ we're not _ I'm not beyond that in my thinking. There, obviously, is a lot of contingency planning that always goes on and prudently should go on. Charles, then Ann.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Worried About Americans in Iraq, Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Bush comments; EDITS throughout to conform. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With PM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he was encouraged by suggestions that 3,500 Americans in Iraq and Kuwait may be allowed to leave, but added that their safety still cannot be assured. Bush told a news conference that one concern was the ``unpredictable'' nature of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Bush spoke after an Iraqi Airways passenger jet arrived from Iraq in Amman, Jordan, today with more than two dozen Americans as well as other foreigners, a Jordanian security official said. But a U.S. Embassy spokesman in Amman said he was unaware of any evacuees arriving in Jordan. It would be the second commercial flight carrying out foreigners stranded after Thursday's invasion of Kuwait. An Iraqi airliner arrived in Cairo Tuesday carrying 78 foreigners, mostly Japanese. Bush told reporters: ``I want to see them (the Americans) out of there, obviously. But what he (Saddam Hussein) does, that's a bit unpredictable.'' He said protection of American life was ``fundamental to my job and responsibilities as president.'' U.S. officials have been concerned since the Iraqi invasion took place about the fate of the 3,000 or so Americans in Kuwait and the 500 in Iraq. The officials spoke of their concerns Tuesday as Bush ordered U.S. troops and combat planes to Saudi Arabia to protect that country against a potential attack by Iraq. While declining to refer to the Americans as hostages, the State Department said Tuesday they were not being permitted to leave the two countries freely. Part of the confusion stems from contradictory signals Iraqi authorities have been sending concerning whether Americans who wish to leave will be allowed to do so, said the officials, who asked not to be identified. A group of Americans, most of them bused from Kuwait to Baghdad by Iraqi authorities, were not allowed to leave their hotel in the Iraqi capital, causing some officials to worry about Iraq's intentions. ``It is our hope that circumstances will permit Americans to depart Iraq by road within the next few days and eventually that Baghdad airport will reopen so that all foreigners may depart,'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said. ``This depends, obviously, on the government of Iraq opening its borders.'' She said Assistant Secretary of State John Kelly raised the issue of the Americans' safety with the Iraqi ambassador on Monday but received no immediate reply. Turkey and Jordan, both neighbors of Iraq, are logical destinations for Americans who want to leave the country by land. Jordanian authorities have promised to help any Americans who cross into their country by land. A senior Iraqi official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Tuesday that Iraq is considering allowing foreigners, including U.S. Embassy staff and dependents, to leave by land through Jordan. Ms. Tutwiler said Americans in Kuwait have been advised to leave the country as soon as possible and a few have managed to leave by various routes. She said it was not clear when Americans and other foreigners will be allowed to depart freely. About 39 Americans are at the Rashid Hotel in Baghdad, many taken there by bus from Kuwait by Iraqi authorities. Ms. Tutwiler said they have been interviewed by U.S. consular officials and appear to be in good shape. Among the 39 is Penelope Nabokov, a 10-year-old girl from Albany, Calif., whose family said she was among 367 passengers taken from a British Airways jetliner in Kuwait while the invasion was under way last week. The girl was traveling alone from London to India, where her mother was doing research.

DOC.HEAD: British Man Takes Cab to Border; More Evacuees Arrive in Jet
DOC.TEXT: A British businessman believed to be the first foreigner to travel by road from Baghdad to Jordan since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait said Wednesday he had ``no problem.'' ``I just took a taxi and went,'' said Bryan Hume, who manages a freight business based in Amman. It was only after he arrived late Tuesday, after a 19-hour journey, that Hume was informed other foreigners had not been allowed to leave Iraq. Iraq began flying foreigners out later that day. The second Iraqi Airways passenger jet arrived in Jordan on Wednesday carrying foreigners, a security official reported. The first Iraqi airliner arrived Tuesday carrying 78 foreigners, mostly Japanese. It was the first commercial flight carrying people who were stranded in Kuwait and Iraq after Iraq invaded its neighbor. Hume, 52, of Southampton, said he was in Erbil, in northern Iraq, when Iraqi forces invaded Kuwait one week ago. Movement out of Iraq was barred, but the country has since begun allowing foreigners to leave. ``When I returned to Baghdad, I spent some time with friends and then simply took a cab and asked to be driven to the border. It was as simple as that,'' he said. ``When I arrived at the Iraqi border post of Rutbah, a surprised Iraqi civilian told me `How did you get here? Foreigners are not allowed to leave,''' he said in an interview in his office. ``But the Iraqi border officials gave me no trouble. They stamped my passport and waved me on.'' Hume said he apparently became the first foreigner to cross the border after the Iraqi government decided to allow foreigners to leave. Rutbah is 490 miles west of Baghdad and 75 miles east of the Jordanian border. Hume said it was only after he arrived in Amman that he realized there was an international crisis. ``Everything was perfectly normal in Baghdad, no excitement, no fear or anything,'' he said. ``Of course there is a lot of cheering and patriotic songs on (Iraqi) TV,'' he said. Hume said traffic on the desert highway from Amman to Baghdad ``appeared normal'' and that there was no military presence on the highway. Meanwhile, a Jordanian airport official said a ``preliminary passenger list'' listed eight French citizens and 32 Britons on the flight that arrived in Amman on Wednesday. He said some Americans also were aboard the Boeing 747 jetliner, but a U.S. Embassy spokesman said he was unaware of any American evacuees aboard the plane.

DOC.HEAD: WASH: then Ann.
DOC.TEXT: Q: Mr. President, I can understand the need for individual countries to announce their own attentions with regards to the multinational force, but it's our understanding that the Saudis wanted an Arab component in that force. Is that in fact the case, and will there be one? Bush: They didn't tell us that, but it would not be at all surprising if there was an Arab component in that force, not at all. Q: But you do not have one at this point? Bush: Well, I'm not going to comment on _ on _ because I think announcement of all components really should come from the participating countries. Yeah, Ann? Q: Not even broader, to define it as Arab, if not by nation? Bush: No, I told you I wouldn't be surprised if that happened, but I think that I'd much prefer to have that _ the announcements of that come from others. This _ I think it is important that the focus be on Saudi requests and on the defensive nature of the move we've made with these forces. Yes, Ann? Q: Mr. President, you've told us several times of Saddam Hussein's lies in his dealings with other leaders and with the United States on his intentions. Why do you now believe the Iraqi government's statements that they will let Americans go if there are no _ if there is no evidence of an American being let go? Bush: I'm not sure I totally believe them. I hope they're telling the truth. Q: Do you have assurances from any intelligence source, any other source, that indicates movement by those Americans, or any _ Bush: Well, I've had a source of movement by some foreigners, so I would hope that this would then apply to Americans. Yes? Q: Mr. President, you said in your speech this morning that the puppet regime in Kuwait was unacceptable, and so was the acquisition of territory. At the same time, though, you said that the _ that the deployments are wholly defensive. The question is, how do you actually expect to force Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait? Bush: Economic sanctions in this instance, if fully enforced, can be very, very effective. It is a rich country in terms of oil resources. They're a poor country, in a sense, because he squandered much of the resource on military might, and there are some indications that he's already beginning to feel the pinch. And nobody can stand up forever to total economic deprivation. Yes? Q: If I could follow that up _ if I can just follow real quickly. Could you _ will you rule out preemptive strikes against Iraq? Bush: I am not going to go into hypothetical situations. We've been very careful not to do that, and I'm simply not going to respond. Maureen; and then we'll go to the aisle. Q: Mr. President, could you share with us the precise military objective of this mission? Will the American troops remain there only until Saddam Hussein removes his troops from the Saudi border? Bush: I can't _ I can't answer that because we have _ we have a major objective with those troops, which is the defense of the Soviet Union. So I think it's beyond _ (Cross talk.) Bush: (Laughing) _ a defense of Saudi Arabia _ so I think it's beyond the _ I think it's beyond just the question of the tanks along the border. Q: Sir, are you preparing for a prolonged ground _ Bush: A lot of air power, for example. Q: Are you preparing for a prolonged ground war in the Persian Gulf? Bush: I'm not preparing for a long ground war in the Persian Gulf. There's not a war going on there right now. Q: But, I'm just saying, could you just tell the American people what your specific military objective is? Bush: My military objective is to see Saudi Arabia defended _ that's the military objective. Our overall objective is to see _ see Saddam Hussein get out and go back and to have the rightful regime of Kuwait back in place. Yes?

DOC.HEAD: Bush Flubs Follow `Long Night'
With AM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The ``thank you'' that ended President Bush's news conference Wednesday came not from the press corps but the president, thanking reporters for correcting several mistakes. Bush verbally confused Iraq and Saudi Arabia and also said the main U.S. objective in sending troops to the Persian Gulf area was ``the defense of the Soviet Union.'' Asked at one point what persuaded him to send U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia, Bush replied, ``If there was one it would perhaps be the Saudis moving south when they said they were withdrawing.'' As reporters murmured ``the Iraqis,'' Bush said, ``I mean the Iraqis moving south. Thank you very much. It's been a long night.'' Later, Bush said, ``We have a major objective with those troops, which is the defense of the Soviet Union.'' As reporters chorused ``Saudi Arabia,'' Bush laughed and corrected himself. Bush also spoke of the pre-invasion substantial ``boycott'' of Iraqi troops on the Kuwait border. He caught the mistake himself, changing the word to ``buildup.'' He ended the brief news conference with these words: ``Thank you all very much and let me just say this on a personal basis. I screwed up a couple of times here, and I'm very grateful for your assistance in straightening it out. ``God, I'd hate to have had some of those answers stand,'' Bush added.

DOC.HEAD: Broadway Musical Canceled After Union Bans British Actor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs with production canceled. Picks up 9th graf pvs., `Mackintosh and ...' Deletes outdated 16th graf pvs., `the matter ...'
DOC.TEXT: The Broadway production of ``Miss Saigon'' was canceled Wednesday after Actors' Equity refused to allow a white British actor to play the role of a Eurasian in the musical. ``The debate is no longer about the casting of `Miss Saigon' but the art of acting itself,'' producer Cameron Mackintosh said in a statement issued on behalf of the creative team for the hit London musical. The show, scheduled to open in March at the Broadway Theater, had a more than $25 million advance sale, the largest in Broadway history. The money, according to Mackintosh, will be refunded. The producer said an estimated $600,000, already spent on pre-production work for the show, has been lost. The union Tuesday denied Englishman Jonathan Pryce permission to repeat his award-winning performance as a brothel owner when the London hit comes to New York in March. ``The casting of a Caucasian actor made up to appear Asian is an affront to the Asian community,'' said Alan Eisenberg, the union's executive secretary. ``The casting choice is especially disturbing when the casting of an Asian actor in this role would be an important and significant opportunity to break the usual pattern of casting Asians in minor roles.'' The union has jurisdiction over all performers appearing on Broadway and must give its approval to actors from foreign countries who appear there, except for British ``stars.'' But the definition of ``star'' is hazy. ``We did not deal with the issue of whether this man is a star or not,'' Eisenberg said. Mackintosh said he would not take the matter to arbitration, a process Equity suggested Tuesday might be the next step. ``The inaccurate and inflammatory statements which Equity made concerning `Miss Saigon' have served only to craete a poisonous atmosphere in which creativity and artistic freedom cannot function or survive,'' Mackintosh said. ``Arbitration cannot clear this atmosphere.'' Mackintosh and other producers have argued that the ban is an infringement on their right to choose the performers they want. ``When my production team cast the noted black actor Robert Guillaume to replace Michael Crawford as the Phantom in the Los Angeles company of `Phantom of the Opera,' we did so purely on the grounds of talent and suitability,'' Mackintosh said last week. ``Ironically, in the current Broadway production of `Phantom' we have an Amerasian actor of tremendous ability playing the lead role of the Vicomte de Chagny. Why is it quite proper for him to play a European artistocrat and not for Jonathan Pryce to play a Eurasian?'' Robert Stigwood, who produced the musical ``Evita,'' said in a letter to Equity earlier this week that he is casting the film version of the show. ``Does the view of Actors' Equity concerning ethnic casting preclude my consideration of an American-Italian female star to play the title role?'' he asked. ``Will I incur the wrath and condemnation of Actors' Equity for casting a non-Hispanic in the role of Che?'' Eisenberg said the union's decision was made ``in full awareness that many jobs may be lost to actors of Asian background'' if ``Miss Saigon'' is canceled. According to Variety, the musical would employ 182 people, including 50 actors and stage managers, 26 musicians and 34 stagehands. Non-traditional casting has been more common off-Broadway, particularly at the New York Shakespeare Festival, where black actor Morgan Freeman recently played Petruchio opposite Tracey Ullman, who is white, in a Central Park production of ``The Taming of the Shrew.'' The festival has used black, Hispanic and Asian actors in almost all its recent Shakespeare productions. It even cast actress Diane Venora in the title role in ``Hamlet'' several years ago. ``You do non-traditional casting whenever possible, but it depends,'' said Alan Coleridge, a casting director. ``You look at the text. Does the text support it?'' The controversy over ``Miss Saigon'' began with a complaint filed by playwright David Henry Hwang, author of ``M. Butterfly,'' and actor B.D. Wong, who starred in the play. ``There is no doubt in my mind of the irreparable damage to my rights as an actor that would be wrought if ... Asian actors are kept from bringing their unique dignity to the specifically Asian roles in `Miss Saigon,''' Wong said in a letter to Equity President Colleen Dewhurst. In London, Pryce won the Olivier Award as best actor in a musical for his performance in ``Miss Saigon.'' He won praise on Broadway in 1976 for his performance in ``Comedians,'' which earned him a best-actor Tony Award. About 300 to 400 of Equity's 40,000 members are Asian, Eisenberg said. ``We are talking here about color and this union responding to the wishes of its membership,'' Dewhurst said Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: WASH: in place. Yes?
DOC.TEXT: Q: Mr. President, can you tell us what U.S. and Saudi forces will be up against? You mentioned surface-to-surface missiles, you've spoken previously of the chemical warfare capability of the Saudis (sic: may mean Iraqis). What are they up against? And the second question is _ the second part of the question is, did we misread Saddam Hussein? A couple of months ago, your people were up on the _ the administration was up on the Hill deflecting a move to put sanctions on _ on _ on _ Bush: Let me _ let me ask you _ I'm not going to take the question on the exact military problem there because we're going to have a thorough briefing at the Pentagon _ I think they're much better equipped to handle that kind of detail. On Saddam Hussein, look, we have tried very hard to see if there wasn't a way to have somewhat improved relations _ there's no question about that. But _ and I have no regret about having tried to have discussions that might have led to a better relationship. But that had to stop the minute you have this _ this kind of aggression. But I don't think having _ having tried tentatively to have a little better relationship with a person over the last couple of years _ we've still been very, very wary all along of his _ of his intentions. Q: But did our intelligence let us down or _ or did you know that what has happened _ when did you get an indication of _ (inaudible) _ as far as moving into Kuwait and that sort of thing? Bush: No, I don't _ I don't feel let down by the intelligence at all. When you plan a blitzkrieg-like attack that's launched at 2:00 in the morning, it's pretty hard to stop, particularly when you have just been given the word of the people involved that there wouldn't be any such attack. And I think the intelligence community deserves certain credit for _ for _ for picking up what was a substantial boycott _ (correcting himself) a substantial buildup and then reporting it to us. So _ and this information was relayed properly to interested parties, but the move was so swift that it was pretty hard for them to stop it. I really can't blame our intelligence in any way _ fault them in this particular _ in this particular go-round. Yeah, Ellen? Q: Mr. President, you said this morning that our troops will also defend our other friends in the Gulf. Do we view the American troops there as peacekeepers throughout the Gulf? Bush: We view them there to defend Saudi Arabia, and hopefully their presence there will deter adventurism against any of the other Gulf countries. Yes? Q: What other countries, sir, are we prepared to defend in the Gulf region? Bush: Well, I'm not going to give you a list, but _ but we're certainly interested in the freedom and the independence of all those countries in the GCC, just for openers. Yeah? Q: Mr. President, do you see any domestic impact on the budget talks or deficit from this situation in the Middle East, impact on the gasoline tax possibility or in any other way? Bush: Well, an operation of this nature has considerable expense associated with it. But I've asked for some estimates now as to what that _ what that price may be, but whatever it is, we're going to have to pay it. But I don't have the exact figures yet. John? Q: Mr. President, the national security analysts say that this crisis demonstrates once again the vulnerability _ constant vulnerability of the oil fields in the Middle East. Doesn't this suggest that this force that you've sent over there may be there for some time, or at least fragments of it will be there to make sure that there is a steady flow? Bush: Well, you might interpret it that way. I'm not prepared to say that I think that's what the outcome will be, because I think if there is this pull-back that the world is calling for, and if the sanctions are effective, I think you would reduce the risk of future adventurism.

DOC.HEAD: Israelis Stone Arab Cars, Riots Sharpen Divisions of Jerusalem
DOC.TEXT: Israelis hurled stones at Arab-owned cars Wednesday as an unprecedented wave of anti-Arab rioting in Jerusalem entered its third day. The riots erupted Monday after the discovery of the bodies of two Jewish teen-agers who had been stabbed to death, apparently by Palestinian militants. Thousands of Israelis took to the streets, injuring dozens of Arabs in stoning attacks. Mayor Teddy Kollek, a champion of coexistence in this mixed Arab-Jewish city, said the riots were ``the most effective attempt to re-divide the city.'' ``It will remain a unified city, but the question is, what kind of city? Will it be a pleasant city like in the last 20 years or a hard city like in the last 2{ years?'' Kollek said, referring to the 32-month-old Palestinian uprising. For Israel, unity of Jerusalem, its declared eternal capital, has been a matter of prestige since it captured Arab east Jerusalem from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war and annexed it to west Jerusalem. Palestinians demand east Jerusalem, home to 140,000 Arabs, be the capital of their would-be state. Israel refuses to negotiate on the unity of the city. Invisible barriers, strengthened by the Palestinian uprising, now crisscross the city, dividing Arab and Jewish neighborhoods. Most of Jerusalem's 354,000 Jews are afraid to visit the city's eastern sector, fearing stonings, stabbings or firebomb attacks. Of the 47 Israeli victims of the uprising, eight have been killed in Jerusalem. At least nine Palestinians have been killed by Israeli security forces. Until recently, anti-Arab rioting was rare, but now fear has gripped the Arabs. ``I have a car with blue plates which means I'm an Arab, and frankly speaking I don't feel safe to drive to the western part of the city,'' said Ziad Abu Ziad, a pro-PLO newspaper editor. Arabs from the occupied territories have blue license plates, while Israeli citizens, Arabs and Jews, have yellow license plates. Israeli officials, such as district police commander Rahamim Comfort, acknowledged that ``such a situation never existed in the past.'' Kollek described Tuesday as ``the hardest day Jerusalem ever had.'' That was after riots broke out following the funeral for the slain teen-agers. Thousands of Israelis, many chanting ``Death to the Arabs,'' thronged the funeral. Dozens of Arabs were injured in the ensuing rioting. One of the wounded was in critical condition Wednesday. The violence continued Wednesday as Jewish mobs stoned Arab-owned cars and taxis. Several windshields were smashed, but there were no reports of injuries. Israel radio said that by late Wednesday police had arrested some 35 Jews for stoning Arabs and their property over the past two days. Many West Bank Palestinians stayed away from Jerusalem for fear of attack. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's adviser, Avi Pazner, insisted that the city is not divided. ``This is nonsense. I heard the same two months ago when there were disturbances in (Arab villages of) Silwan and A-Tur,'' Pazner said. ``The key is that the Arabs have to understand that this is one city, that they have to live in peace with us. Any action like such a horrible murder ...will make tensions rise.''

DOC.HEAD: Precede POZA RICA
Tropical Storm Batters Mexico's Sierra Maestra Mountains
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE death toll, detail on conditions. Pick up 7th graf pvs, `Red Cross...'
DOC.TEXT: Hurricane Diana weakened to a tropical depression today and moved inland from the Gulf of Mexico, battering northeastern mountains after triggering mudslides and flooding. Two deaths were reported in the Gulf city of Tuxpan and one in Veracruz after the worst of the storm passed Tuesday. At 6 a.m. EDT, the storm had winds of 35 mph and its center was located 100 miles northeast of Mexico City and moving west at 12 mph, the U.S. National Weather Service said. The Weather Service said it expected rainfall of up to 8 inches over the next day, which could produce flash flooding and mudslides. About 500 Tuxpan residents spent the night in local schools, and Mayor Perecles Namorado Urruita said some 4,000 homes were wrecked by the hurricane, which local officials said packed winds of up to 120 mph at the height Tuesday afternoon. The Federal Highway Police said scores of cars and other vehicles were stranded for hours by flash floods on the Tampico-Altamira highway, which in some places was under more than six feet of water. On Tuesday, Diana packed winds of 90 mph in the Gulf of Mexico after sweeping by the Yucatan Peninsula and Campeche state. The storm knocked down power and telephone lines in Veracruz and Tamaulipas states. Large areas were without telephone service or electricity, dozens of roads were blocked by fallen trees and mudslides and hundreds of people were flooded out of their homes. Red Cross spokesman Rosario Romero Hernandez in the port city of Veracruz said one man was killed by a falling tree Monday night. About 800 families were flooded out of their homes in Tampico, a port in neighboring Tamaulipas state, the government news agency Notimex reported. It said another 70 families lost their homes in Ciudad Madero and 500 people were flooded out in Altamira. The Federal Highway Police said scores of cars and other vehicles were stranded for hours by flash floods on the Tampico-Altamira highway, which in some places was under more than six feet of water. Tropical storms have sustained surface winds of between 39 and 74 miles per hour, while a hurricane is at least 74 mph.

DOC.HEAD: WASH: future adventurism.
DOC.TEXT: Q: In your call to the producing countries to pick up the slack, do you expect that to begin immediately? Bush: Well, I think it will start very, very soon. I don't know about today, by any _ Q: Mr. President, with the economy tipping close to the edge of a recession, do you think we still can afford to raise taxes or cut spending, or won't that increase the risk of a (inaudible) recession? Bush: I still think it's absolutely essential to get a budget agreement, and that's going to require a lot of compromise and it's going to require a lot of principle. But you know, what I want to do is separate out my feelings about the budget now that I feel uninhibited by an agreement not to say anything, because I want to tell you exactly how strongly I feel about it. But I don't want to do it here today. I don't want to mix it into this briefing that is largely, you know, dominated by the world concern about the Middle East. But I feel like a liberated human being now. I don't feel bound by _ Q: Why not? Bush: _ by _ may I finish what I'm saying here? (Laughs.) I don't feel bound by an agreement that I've told the congressional leaders is no longer in effect. And we've been getting one side of that, mainly from the Democrats in the Congress. And now you're fixing to get the other, but not this minute; you have to stay tuned. Q: Mr. President, to follow up, do you think the spike in oil prices which has occurred significantly at home as a result of the Persian Gulf problem could edge the economy into a recession? Bush: I have not been advised of that. I hope that is not the case, and what I hope to do is see a reduction in oil prices once a _ once it becomes clear that there will not be shortage. There's an overhang now of oil in the marketplace, thank God. We have a Strategic Petroleum Reserve that we can draw from. Other countries have the same _ a couple of other countries have SPRs themselves. And I hope that this rapid spike on oil prices will not be permanent, and I think if we _ if the world begins to see assurances, that there will not be a dramatic cutoff _ or cutdown on oil, that then things will return much more to normal in the market. Yeah? Q: Mr. President? Q: Mr. President, assuming that _ Bush: One more after this. Q: _ assuming that we achieve the goal of Iraqi forces out of Kuwait, Saddam Hussein is still going to be sitting there on top of a million-man army _ (inaudible). What happens in the long run after that, and can you contain that with _ short of removing Saddam Hussein from power? Bush: I would think that if this international lesson is taught well, that Saddam Hussein would behave differently in the future. And that's what has been so very important about this concerted United Nations effort, unprecedented you might say or certainly not enacted since 19 _ what was it? 23 years ago? _ 19 _ 23 years ago. So, I _ I _ I don't think we can see that clearly down the road, but a line has been drawn in the sand. The United States has taken a firm position, and I might say we're getting strong support from around the world for what we've done. I've been very, very pleased about that. Large countries and small countries. The world reaction has been excellent. And I would hope that all of this would result in Saddam Hussein or some calmer heads in Iraq understanding that this kind of international behavior is simply unacceptable, and we see where we go. Q: Mr. President? Bush: Yes, Sarah? Q: Sir, would you please _ Bush: This is the last question. Q: I understand that we provide most of the food for Iraq and have done so on the long term and short term and subsidy payments, credit (inaudible) for some time. That means that we've been letting them have a lot of food and a lot of other products from our farmers at probably low rates, arranged by the Department of Agriculture. Now, do you _ would you please discuss the effect of your embargo; and how much do you think that the Iraqis already owe us for food? Bush: Well, I don't know what they owe us for food, but I know that this embargo, to be successful, has got to encompass everything. And if there are _ you know, if there's a humanitarian concern, pockets of starving children or something of this nature, why, I would take a look. But other than that, this embargo is going to be all encompassing, and it will include food. And I don't know what Iraq owes us now for food. Generally speaking, in normal times we have felt that food might be separated out from _ you know, grain, wheat, might be separated out from other economic sanctions. But this one is all encompassing and the language is pretty clear in the United Nations resolution. Thank you all very much. And let me just say this, on a personal basis. I've screwed up a couple of times here and I'm very grateful for your assistance in straightening it out. God, I'd hate to have had some of those answers stand. Thank you.

DOC.TEXT: A deeply divided American Bar Association rescinded its 6-month-old endorsement of abortion rights Wednesday and leaders immediately called for healing among the orgbers. The ABA's policy-making House of Delegates voted 200-188 to repeal aanization's mem resolution that the nationwide lawyers' group had adopted in February by a more than two-to-one margin. Repeal proponents said Wednesday's about face returned the organization to a neutral position on the explosive issue. But abortion rights forces said the fight was far from over. ``Nobody here has the illusion we're going to put our tails between our legs and go home,'' said Estelle Rogers of Washington, D.C., who opposed the repeal. Anthony R. Palermo of Rochester, N.Y., who led the repeal drive, said a continuing feud over abortion rights could hurt the ABA's reputation. ``It would be a grave mistake if we keep dominating each meeting with this issue,'' he said. DOC.HEAD: U.S. Forces Taking Up Positions to Block Iraqis
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs, raising reference to AWACs and adding Powell quote on Iraqi forces; edits to shorten
DOC.TEXT:
American ground and air forces fortified Saudi Arabia's defenses against Iraq today, with two powerful aircraft carriers positioned to block vital sea routes and protect troops rushing into the desert kingdom. Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staffs, said the first U.S. military aircraft dispatched from the United States have arrived in Saudi Arabia and `taken up position.'' Powell said five AWACs reconnaissance planes were arriving today. In addition, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said the United States had granted a Saudi request to waive the cap on the number of F-15 jetfighters the kingdom is allowed. At a Pentagon briefing, Powell and Cheney refused to provide many specific details of the U.S. troop movements or describe the size of the sudden deployment. ``You can be sure that for the mission we have been given we will put in adequate forces,'' Powell said. Of the battle-tested Iraqis, Powell said: ``They are not invincible. They are not 10-feet tall.'' Powell, using a map of the Gulf area, demonstrated where the aircraft carrier USS Independence and its support ships have taken up positions just outside the Persian Gulf and the carrier USS Eisenhower in the Red Sea _ not far from the end point of an Iraqi oil pipeline and within range for its aircraft and other weapons to engage Iraqi forces. On the ground already in Saudi Arabia are the first arrivals among the warplanes and ground forces ordered into the oil-rich country on Tuesday, the Pentagon officials said. Powell said the troops brought with them protective clothing and medical supplies to be used in the event Iraq uses its sizeable stores of chemical weapons against the American forces. Powell and Cheney briefed reporters four hours after President Bush delivered a nationally televised address in which he confirmed his decision to send U.S. forces into the tense Persian Gulf region. Cheney described the deployment as ``a major commitment of U.S. forces'' but said he could not provide specific details for strategic reasons. ``Our purpose in sending forces at this time into the gulf region and to Saudi Arabia in particular is to deter any further Iraqi aggression,'' Cheney said. He said he expected other nations to join the U.S. forces in the area, but with the exception of Great Britain, he refused to name other nations expected to participate in the multinational effort. Pentagon sources said earlier that the U.S. arsenal will include heavy tanks for possible ground battles and sophisticated cruise missiles programmed to destroy specific Iraqi targets. Thirty-two Tomahawk cruise missiles are aboard the battleship Wisconsin, which was sent from the United States to the gulf area Tuesday night, according to sources, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. The sources also said today that a second Navy cruiser had been added to the gulf, bringing the number of U.S. ships in the strategic waterway to nine. At the Pentagon briefing, Powell said the carrier Eisenhower, accompanied by five other warships, today completed its transit of the Suez Canal enroute to the gulf. President Bush, in his speech this morning, said the U.S. forces were on a ``wholly defensive'' mission, and added: ``They will not initiate hostilities, but they will defend themselves.'' Should it come to that, one of the sources today said the Tomahawks would be a crucial part of the U.S. arsenal. ``They are sophisticated, terrain-following cruise missiles programmed with special software packages that allow them to hone in on specific targets, such as Iraqi oil refineries,'' the source said. ``You sit off beyond the range of the Iraqis and fire in.'' The sources also said several of the Marines' prepositioned supply ships based at the super-secret U.S. facility on the island of Diego Garcia have set sail for the region, the sources said. ``This first movement is of light infantry and airborne troops. But these ships have the heavy tanks, M1-A1 Abrams and M-60s, that are needed for heavy-duty ground fighting,'' one source said. It will take the Wisconsin, which is escorting the carrier Saratoga, at least a week to reach the eastern Mediterranean, the sources said. U.S. forces were ordered into Saudi Arabia and the gulf region Tuesday as the Bush administration, with fresh intelligence on Iraqi troop activities in Kuwait, declared the Saudi kingdom under ``imminent threat'' of attack. Under the Saudi desert lie the largest oil reserves in the world. Cheney, as Bush had earlier, declined to speculate on the possible length of the historic U.S. presence in the volatile region. ``We don't know how long it will last,'' Cheney said. Among the dangers facing U.S. troops in a conflict with Iraq is Saddam's arsenal of chemical arms and his track record of using them as a weapon of mass destruction. Powell said it was unclear whether Iraq was preparing its chemical weapons for use, ``but we attribute them with that capability.'' The Army units facing duty in Saudi Arabia are part of the nation's rapid deployment .'' The reaction from Iraq was defiant. State television declared that ``history has proved that Kuwait is a part of Iraq.'' In his remarks, the president conceded that the Saudi defense mission ``may take time and be costly'' and said he would consider tapping the nation's strategic petroleum reserves to assure a ready supply of oil. He called on the oil companies not to engage in unnecessary price hikes to take advantage of the international uncertainty and urged that other oil-producing nations boost production. Bush sidestepped a question about what other countries would be joining a multi-national force in Saudi Arabia. ``I'd prefer to leave that to'' the Saudis to announce, he said. He noted that British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher had said she would commit forces. Egypt and Morocco had said they were not participating in the Saudi defense buildup, contrary to reports from some U.S. sources. Bush said encouraging things about both nations, but did not claim their involvement. Bush said ``It wouldn't be at all surprising'' if there were an Arab component in the force that eventually took shape in Saudi Arabia. Bush also said he was concerned with the possibility that Iraq might use chemical weapons, since it has employed them in the past. ``It would be intolerable and it would be dealt with very, very severely.'' Powell said the American forces were equipped with masks, clothing and medicine to thwart the chemical weapons. He expressed confidence about the mission, saying of the battle-tested Iraqis, ``They are not invincible. They are not 10 feet tall.''
