DOC.HEAD: No War Fever, But Expatriates Apprehensive
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: , RIYADH, Saudi Arabia (AP) _ Hundreds of expatriates flooded airports Wednesday, hoping to leave Saudi Arabia following news of the military escalation resulting from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Transister radio sales boomed as nationals and expatriates tuned in to hear the latest news of U.S. military intervention and Arab reaction. They had to find foreign stations. The state-run radio and television maintained regular programs, which consist mainly of religious discussions and chanting of verses from the Koran. ``We are calm, because we trust in God,'' said Atiya al-Anzi, a shopkeeper in Dammam. ``We will be afflicted only if God wills it this way. Otherwise, God will protect us and grant victory to our leaders. But I must admit that households (families) are a bit scared.'' The U.S. troop deployment to the kingdom increased apprehension among expatriate communities, especially in the Eastern Province, home of the world's largest oil fields. Some U.S. and other expatriates were reported sending away their dependents. Arab, Indian and other workers stood in long lines requesting exit and re-entry visas, so they can return when calm is restored. The management of the Arabian-American Oil Company, or Aramco, was reported to be weighing the advisability of evacuating some of its 38,000 expatriate employees or dependents. They live mainly in Dhahran, Sanajib and Khafji, in the Eastern Province near the crisis area on the Saudi border with Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. About 28,000 Americans live and work in Saudi Arabia. They make up the largest American community overseas. The U.S. Embassy in Riyadh recommended that American citizens depart. ``Due to the Iraqi military invasion of Kuwait and continuing unstable conditions in the region, the Department of State advises all Americans to defer all travel to the (Saudi) Eastern Province, Qatar, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates,`` the U.S. Embassy told members of the American community. ``The department is permitting dependents of U.S. government officials to depart the area on a voluntary basis. The department advises other Americans to consider doing the same.'' There were no symptoms of war fever, but civil servants operated in an air of emergency. They arrived at offices earlier and staying much later than usual. The government-guided newspapers had front-page editorials in support of Kuwait against Iraq, stressing that the Saudi government would spare no effort to protect its people and seek an honorable way out of the crisis. ``Our government has been serving Moslem and Arab brethren with sincerity and honesty, and as such will never fail to crush these devils,'' said Abdul-Rahman Salem, a merchant in Jiddah. ``The Iraqis have done themselves no good by hurting Kuwait, whose ruler is a kind and honest man. (Iraqi President) Saddam Hussein has sown the seeds of mischief and he can only reap the fruits of evil.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Report Five Deaths in Violence in Suburbs
DOC.TEXT: Police said Wednesday that five people have been shot to death in three days of looting, burning and battles between police and mobs in mixed-race suburbs of Port Elizabeth. Police headquarters in Pretoria said four of the dead were shot by officers. Police roamed the northern suburbs in armored vehicles, firing birdshot and tear gas at stone-throwing groups Wednesday, said a journalist. The violence began Monday and spread to numerous suburbs of the eastern port city. Members of the Northern Areas Action Committee said police fired tear gas at them as they left a meeting Monday. Police said they fired tear gas, stun grenades, birdshot, and finally pistols after crowds repeatedly attacked a police bus Monday night. The Northern Areas Action Committee is allied with the African National Congress, but there was no evidence either organization was controlling the crowds. Journalists said much of the mob violence was directed at people connected with the local council structures set up by the white-run provincial government. The Evening Post newspaper quoted an unidentified ANC member as saying the violence would stop when the local government management committee resigned. Police and officials of the Northern Areas Action Committee and the ANC said the mobs were running wild. ``It is out of control to a great extent, but we are trying our hardest to keep our people disciplined,'' said Ronald Niegaardt, chairman of the Northern Areas Action Committee. ``Some criminal elements have become involved and they are looting all over the place for their own benefit.'' The journalist, who did not want to be identified, described the scene Wednesday: ``They are looting, they are stoning police, they are putting up roadblocks, using tires and refuse. There are lots of onblookers standing by and the police are riding around in Casspirs (armored vehicles). They are shooting with birdshot and tear gas. ``From the air you can see fires in quite a few places. A large number of shops have been broken into and the goods looted,'' said the journalist. Cliff Foster, a reporter for the Newscape news agency, said, ``The northern areas are cut off from the outside world by burning barricades erected at all entrance and exit routes as police and mobs continued to battle in the street.'' Barricades and stonethrowers kept ambulances from entering the suburbs. They circled the perimeters, picking up wounded when notified by police, but there was no estimate of how many people had been injured. Pupils and teachers were unable to get to schools, and most people were prevented from getting to work.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Mubarak and King Hussein Call For Arab Summit
DOC.TEXT: The government announced today that an Arab summit on the Iraqi invasion will be held in Cairo on Thursday. King Hussein of Jordan said the meeting will be the ``last change'' to resolve the crisis peacefully. In a nationally televised speech, President Hosni Mubarak spurned a U.S. plan for multinational forces under its leadership in Saudi Arabia, opting instead for a purely Arab force. Mubarak called for an emergency Arab summit ``within 24 hours'' to discuss the crisis and offered to host the summit. At a news conference in Amman, Jordan, King Hussein of Jordan said he would attend the conference. ``We are trying to resolve the problem in an Arab context,'' the king said. He described the meeting as the Arab world's ``last chance'' to solve the problem without resorting to further violence. He said he could understand the anger of Arabs over the inability of Arab states to resolve the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait by themselves. ` ``I have no plan to present,'' Hussein said. ``The plan will be presented by the Arabs themselves. It will be a good and open meeting.'' Mohammed Abdel-Moneim, Mubarak's press secretary, told reporters that the summit will convene in Cairo Thursday evening. ``Arab leaders will begin arriving for the summit in a matter of hours,'' he said. ``This quick response reflects a sense of the gravity of the situation which President Mubarak stressed in his speech.'' Abdel-Moneim did not give the exact number of Arab countries that accepted Mubarak's summit proposal. But he said they included Saudi Arabia, Syria, Algeria, Djibouti, the United Arab Emirates, Yemen, Libya and Qatar.

DOC.HEAD: Bush: No Longer Bound by Vow of Silence on Budget Talks
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Wednesday he's no longer bound by his vow of silence with the Democrats on the deficit talks, making him ``feel like a liberated human being.'' Bush, at a news conference on his decision to send U.S. troops and warplanes to Saudi Arabia, did not unburden himself of his feelings on the long sputtering talks. But he left no doubt that he soon will. ``I still think it's absolutely essential to get a budget agreement, and that's going to require a lot of compromise and it's going to require a lot of principle,'' Bush said. He said he would like ``to tell you exactly how strongly I feel about it, but I don't want to do it here today. I don't want to mix it into this briefing ... dominated by the world concern about the Middle East. ``But I feel like a liberated human being now. I don't feel bound by an agreement that I've told the congressional leaders is no longer in effect,'' Bush said. ``We've been getting one side of that mainly from the Democrats in the Congress,'' Bush said. ``And now you're fixing to get the other, but not this minute. You have to stay tuned.'' The president indicated earlier that he would feel free to speak out against the Democrats because they failed to come forward with a plan of their own. The budget talks, begun in May, came to a temporary halt last week when lawmakers left town on a one-month summer vacation. Bush and congressional leaders Congress plan to take another crack after Labor Day at whittling down the nearly $170 billion deficit looming for 1991. Bush said that sending U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia entails ``considerable expense.'' ``I've asked for some estimates now as to what that price may be, but whatever it is, we're going to have to pay it,'' he said. The White House said Tuesday that it has given the initial order to federal agencies to prepare for deep, automatic spending cuts in October if the budget talks fail. Without an agreement, the Gramm-Rudman law will require across-the-board cuts in many programs of roughly $100 billion. That's not counting the cost of the savings-and-loan bailout, which could push the actual 1991 deficit from $169 billion to $231 billion or more. Gramm-Rudman requires a 1991 deficit no larger than $64 billion. Bush in late June backed off his ``no-new-taxes'' campaign promise and acknowledged that solving the deficit will require tax revenue increases. Both sides agreed at the outset to try to conduct the bargaining with no private preconditions. A Republican proposal to raise taxes on alcohol and limit state and local income tax deductions subsequently came to light, while the Democrats refused to put any package of their own on the table. The negotiators were aiming at reducing the deficit by $50 billion in 1991 and $500 billion over five years. With the sluggish economy already veering dangerously close to a recession even before the recent spike in oil prices, some economists predict the budget negotiators will be forced to adopt a more modest goal for reducing next year's red ink.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Many Americans Can't Afford Necessities After Housing Costs
DOC.NOTE: For Release 6:30 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: A third of Americans are ``shelter poor,'' spending so much of their incomes on housing that they can't afford other necessities, a study released Wednesday said. The report by the Economic Policy Institute, a liberal economic research organization, said 27 million households ``are unable to meet their non-shelter needs at even a minimum level of adequacy'' because of high housing costs. Those households contain 78 million people, or 32 percent of the population, the organization said. The study said 42 percent of all who rent their homes were ``shelter poor'' in 1987, the last year of the study. Twenty-two percent of homeowners were in that category, it said. The number of ``shelter poor'' households increased from 18.7 million in 1970 to 26.5 million in 1987, a 42 percent increase, the study concluded. The study's author, Michael E. Stone, professor of community planning at the University of Massachusetts in Boston, used an index that assumes a family pays its rent or mortgage first, then uses what income is left to pay for basic needs such as food, clothing, transportation and medical care. He concludes that people are ``shelter poor'' if their household has too little left after paying the housing costs to afford the minimum basic necessities, as defined by the federal government's bureau of labor statistics low budget standards. Stone's index differs from conventional rules of thumb that families have housing affordability difficulty if they pay more than 25 or 30 percent of their income for housing. He instead used a sliding scale of affordability, varying with income and size of household. ``Some households can afford less than the traditional 25 percent of income,'' Stone said. ``Indeed, some can afford nothing for housing while others can pay more than 25 percent and even 30 percent without hardship.'' His report contends that growth in one and two-person households since 1970 has concealed an increase in housing affordability problems experienced by families with children. The ``shelter poverty'' rate for one and two-person households declined from 32 percent to 26 percent during the period, while the rate for households with three or more people rose from 29 percent to 34 percent. The problem is worst among the poorest one-third of households, but also affects some middle-income households, particularly renters, the study said. The study said the average ``shelter poor'' household faced a gap of $290 a month between what they were paying and could afford for housing. ``Shelter poverty is in part a problem of worsening income inequality and declining real incomes among those at the bottom of the distribution,'' the study said. ``But it is also a problem of escalating housing costs... .''

DOC.HEAD: L-Tryptophan Outbreak Linked to Manufacturing Change
With AM-Marijuana-Brain, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For Release at 6 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: The recent outbreak of a potentially fatal disease linked to L-tryptophan probably came from an impurity introduced by a change in how the dietary supplement was made, according to a report. Disease experts in several states have traced the mysterious illness to supplements made by one Japanese chemical company that produces L-tryptophan in bulk. Now, doctors have tracked down the specific batches responsible for the outbreak and conclude that changes in the way they were made, including less filtering of possible toxic contaminants, were the most likely cause. ``We believe that some of the (toxic) agent has been getting into L-tryptophan for years,'' said Dr. Michael T. Osterholm. ``But there was a series of circumstances that may have increased the agent in the product in late 1988 and at the same time resulted in lowering the amount removed in the finished product.'' Osterholm, the Minnesota state epidemiologist, said researchers are now trying to pinpoint the poisonous substance that apparently contaminated the supplements. All L-tryptophan was ordered off the market in the United States in March after it was linked with an outbreak of eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome that has struck more than 1,500 people, killing 27. The painful blood disorder can cause high fever, rash, weakness and shortness of breath, among other symptoms. L-tryptophan, an amino acid, has been used to treat insomnia, depression and other disorders. It is made in bulk by six companies, but the outbreak was linked to the Showa Denko K.K. firm of Japan. Osterholm was senior author of the latest report, along with other researchers from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control, the Mayo Clinic and the Minnesota Department of Health. It was published in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine. While most of the cases of the blood disease associated with L-tryptophan were spotted during 1988 and 1989, Osterholm said others occurred in the early 1980s. L-tryptophan is made in fermentation vats by the bacteria Bacillus amyloliquefaciens. The researchers found that the problems began after Showa Denko started using a new strain of the microbe and cut in half the amount of carbon used to filter out impurities. ``What we were able to demonstrate without a doubt was that there were changes that occurred that let more of it (the toxic substance) be in there,'' said Osterholm. Alan Wachter, a spokesman for Showa Denko, said, ``The company has acknowledged that there was a statistical profile that pointed to their product'' as the cause of the outbreak. However, he said it is still uncertain whether the fault lies in changes in its manufacturing process.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Pete Rose Arrives at Federal Prison
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with comment from warden, background on expected release date. Picks up 7th graf pvs., `During his ...' Version also moved on sports wire.
DOC.TEXT: Former Cincinnati Reds manager Pete Rose arrived at a federal work camp today to begin serving a five-month sentence for filing false tax returns, prison officials said. Baseball's career hit leader reported to the prison at about 1 p.m., according to a statement released by warden John Clark. ``Mr. Rose will have all the rights and obligations as all prisoners and will receive no special privileges,'' Clark said. ``We will have his term pass as uneventfully as possible for him and the other prisoners.'' Rose said he did not want to talk to reporters, and Clark's statement said the prison will respect his request for privacy. Rose, 49, was facing a Friday deadline to enter the minimum security Federal Prison Camp. He was convicted on two counts of filing false income tax returns for failing to report more than $350,000 in income from gambling, autograph signing and baseball memorabilia sales. He delayed reporting to prison while he recovered from knee surgery he underwent July 20, the same day he was sentenced by U.S. Distict Judge S. Arthur Spiegel. His release is scheduled for Jan. 7, 1991. Rose has said he hoped to be home for Christmas, and authorities have said he could knock 15 to 20 days off his sentence for good behavior. During his first two weeks at the camp, Rose will stay in a building apart from the main dormitory while he is oriented to prison life, authorities said. Prison officials will interview him to match his skills to one of about 35 prison jobs. He will not be permitted to give interviews during the orientation period. Rose's attorneys have said he will not grant interviews during his entire term, said assistant warden Randy Davis. Prison guards have been prohibited from seeking Rose's autograph. Camp inmates have been eagerly awaiting his arrival and have said they hope he will play on a prison softball team. Rose also will have use of the camp's basketball, tennis, handball and boccie ball courts, and a weight room. He originally was ordered to a federal camp in Ashland, Ky., but that facility was still under construction, so he was reassigned to Marion.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Ready for Battle, While Families Settle in to Wait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf pvs, `Pentagon sources...' to UPDATE with details of divisions; SUBS grafs 18-20 pvs beginning `The U.S ...' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with nine U.S. ships in gulf, battleship and planes en route. Picks up 21st graf pvs, `I hope...' ^With PM-Iraq-US Military, Bjt
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOR1,JV1,JV2
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers held their children tight, military wives shopped with tears in their eyes and at least one bride was left at the altar as U.S. troops were mobilized to help Saudi Arabia defend a possible attack by Iraq. Pfc. Mark Ohmer, a member of Fort Bragg's 82nd Airborne Division's chemical unit, was to marry Angela Nelson, 19, on Saturday in suburban Detroit. The $6,000 wedding was postponed when he was called back to the North Carolina base to prepare to leave for Saudi Arabia. ``It's scary _ not just for my wedding, but for the country and for all the soldiers who might have to go over there and fight,'' Nelson said. ``It happened so fast. I'm so upset.'' In North Carolina, convenience store clerks said brisk sales of chewing tobacco, batteries and insect repellent to somber soldiers and their wives were sure signs Fort Bragg soldiers were ready to go. ``A lot of fathers are coming in with their kids, holding them real tight'' and many wives are in tears as they make their purchases, said Effie Parsons, a clerk at the Short Stop convenience store near the base. ``They are definitely going. There is no doubt in my mind that this is another war,'' said Ms. Parsons, 23. President Bush ordered U.S. forces to Saudi Arabia to repel a potential Iraqi attack. Iraq invaded neighboring Kuwait last week. ``At my direction, elements of the 82nd Airborne Division, as well as key units of the United States Air Force, are arriving today to take up defensive positions in Saudi Arabia,'' Bush said today. ``I took this action to assist the Saudi Arabian government in the defense of its homeland.'' Pentagon sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that besides that division from Fort Bragg, they expected deployment of the 24th Division (Mechanized) from Fort Stewart, Ga. and the 101st Airborne Division from Fort Campbell, Ky. Elements of those three units would be deployed with the 18th Airborne Corps, a control unit at Fort Bragg that directs the combat divisions, the sources said. Bush provided no estimate of the number of U.S. troops involved in the deployment. But government sources who spoke on condition of anonymity said at least 5,000 ground troops were involved, along with 140 sophisticated fighters and bombers. About 2,000 troops temporarily stationed at Fort Chaffee, Ark., for training were headed back to their home base at Fort Bragg ``because of the activities in Iraq,'' said base spokesman Cecil Green. A task force of the 82nd Airborne Division had been participating in a mock war scheduled to end Sunday, but the exercise was cut short, he said. At Fort Campbell, a base spokesman said today that the 101st Airborne had not been deployed to Saudi Arabia, but soldiers were tensely awaiting word. ``I'm sure everybody that had access to a TV was watching closely, or if they did not, listening to the radio,'' said public affairs officer Bill Harralson. Soldiers on leave from the 24th Infantry Division at Fort Stewart were summoned back Tuesday, but base officials refused to say whether they were being sent to the Middle East. Spec. 4 Norman Aimes, 24, part of the infantry division, said he was called back from leave in Utah. ``They called and said there is a 99 percent chance that we are going,'' Aimes said Tuesday. Pentagon sources said today that a second Navy cruiser was added to the Persian Gulf, bringing to nine the number of U.S. ships in the strategic water way. The sources said the battleship Wisconsin, carrying cruise missiles, was deployed Tuesday night and that President Bush planned to send F-15 and F-16 fighter aircraft. Already deployed were five AWACs reconnaisance planes, government officials said. Navy and government officials downplayed the possibility of a blockade or military involvement for sailors aboard the USS Saratoga, which set out Tuesday from the Mayport Naval Station near Jacksonville, Fla. But the possibility of action was on the minds of many family members as the huge aircraft carrier set out. ``I hope we get involved. I hope so. Maybe we can straighten out the situation out there. Maybe they need us to go in and kick butt,'' said Wendy Hunter, holding her 8-month-old son, Jonathan. Her husband, Paul, is aboard the Saratoga, which was joined by a small support flotilla that included the guided missile cruiser Philippine Sea, the destroyers Spruance and Sampson, and the frigate Elmer Montgomery. In Washington state, four Navy squadrons with more than 950 men from Whidbey Island Naval Air Station were aboard the three aircraft carriers in or heading for the gulf, said base spokesman Howard Thomas.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Swiss Hostage Released After 10 Months of Captivity
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines bulletin series. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Kidnappers freed a Swiss Red Cross worker in Lebanon today and handed him over to Syrian authorities, a Syrian official said. Reporters were summoned to the Foreign Ministry in Damascus for the imminent handover of the hostage to Swiss officials. There was no immediate word on the identity of the hostage, one of two Red Cross workers kidnapped 10 months ago in Sidon in southern Lebanon. It was the first breakthrough in the hostage situation since April, when two American hostages were freed. A group calling itself the Palestinian Revolutionary Squads had said in a statement released late Tuesday that it would free the two hostages within 24 hours. It was not known why only one hostage was expected in Damascus. The statement, delivered to the independent newspaper An-Nahar and a Western news agency, came with a photograph of captive Emanuel Christen. He appeared with short hair, a clipped beard and a mustache and looked straight into the camera. Christen, 33, was kidnapped Oct. 6 along with Elio Erriquez, 24, outside the artificial limbs center in south Lebanon's port city of Sidon, where the two worked as orthopedic technicians. Sidon is 25 miles south of Beirut. It was the first claim of responsibility for the kidnapping of the two Swiss men by a group since their abduction. Police in Sidon had blamed their abduction on the Libyan-financed Fatah-Revolutionary Council faction, led by Palestinian terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal. But the group had denied the charge. The Fatah-Revolutionary Council faction has reportedly been undergoing bloody internal purges over the past year. The statement said the decision to free the Red Cross captives came in response to the wishes of Syrian President Hafez Assad, Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi and Algerian President Chadli Bendjedid. Christen and Erriquez have been among 16 foreigners held hostage in Lebanon since March 1985. The others are six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, an Irishman and an Italian. Two American hostages were released within a week of one another in April. The statement also said the group had guarantees that their demands would be met, but did not specify what the demands were. The longest held foreign hostage is Terry Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Says Mirror For Weather Satellite Warps In Sunlight
DOC.TEXT: Mirrors being built for a $747 million series of weather satellites have been found to warp and become useless in the temperature extremes of space, NASA officials said Wednesday. The problem marks the second time in recent months that a NASA project has been seriously affected by failed mirror technology. Engineers found in June that a mirror aboard the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope was ground to the wrong specifications and produces only a blurred visual image. A spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said the new flaw was discovered by ITT Aerospace, a subcontractor for the project, and that the planned weather satellites can not be completed and launched until a solution is found. ``The visual images from these mirrors would be pretty close to useless,'' said Bryan Dunbar, a space agency spokesman. The mirrors are being built for a satellite to be launched in February, 1992 as the first of five in a series of robot weather observers. Dunbar said engineers for NASA, ITT and Ford Aerospace, the prime contractor, are scrambling to correct the problem in time for the 1992 launch and it is possible that there could be no delay if a solution is found quickly. Managers of the NASA program were not available for comment, Dunbar said. Officials said the problem occurs only when the 12-by-20-oval mirrors are exposed to the intense light of the sun in space. Dunbar said tests in a vacuum chamber showed that intense sunlight, such as experienced by satellites in orbit, can warp the mirrors. That distorts images that the mirrors reflect into instruments aboard the satellite. NASA is supervising construction of the weather satellites for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, said Frank Lepore, a NOAA spokesman. He said the space agency builds and launches the satellites and that the weather bureau takes over the operation once the craft are at geostationary orbit 22,300 miles above the Earth. The weather craft scheduled for launch in 1992 is to supplement the single satellite that NOAA now has for cloud cover observations over the United States. Lepore said that the current satellite, called GOES 7, was moved over the center of the U.S. after GOES 6 failed last year. He said the weather bureau prefers to have satellites over both coasts so the craft can observe ocean storm fronts far from U.S. shores. The weather satellites take pictures of the cloud cover that are commonly published in newspapers and broadcast on television. Dunbar said that the mirrors for the new series of weather satellites are made of berylium metal coated with nickel. The reflective surface is then coated with aluminium and silicone dioxide. He said that after two mirrors were made, ITT discovered in a computer simulation that the mirrors would warp when exposed to direct sunlight in space. ITT then tested the computer model in a vacuum chamber and confirmed the problem, Dunbar said. The new weather satellites are to have two of the 12-by-20-inch mirrors. One will be used to reflect cloud cover images in visible light to a camera. The other will be reflect light to an infrared detector which can then determine temperatures in the lower 10 miles of the atmosphere.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
East German Lawmakers Favor Unification in October
DOC.TEXT: East German lawmakers on Wednesday voted against immediately unifying with West Germany but said the historic merger should take place on Oct. 14. Under the proposal, the first united German elections in almost 60 years would be held on that date and formal unity would take place either immediately before or after the balloting. The vote sets the stage for a pivotal showdown Thursday in the West German Parliament, which must approve the constitutional changes needed to allow elections to take place so quickly. Opposition Social Democrats in West Germany have vowed to block those changes, which require a two-thirds majority in the lower house of Parliament, the Bundestag. The Christian Democrats of East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl want unification and united German elections on Oct. 14. Social Democrats, the second-largest parties in both nations, want unification alone on Sept. 15 and elections on Dec. 2. Kohl needs the approval of the Social Democrats to substantially shorten the constitutional timetable for holding elections. DOC.HEAD: Excerpts of Mubarak Statement
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait-Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from President Hosni Mubarak's nationally televised speech Wednesday on Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Brothers, our country and the Arab nation are passing through very difficult and complicated circumstances. You are used to me talking with you with complete honesty about any internal or external event which affects Egypt or Arab national security... Today, I find myself obliged to warn of the extreme danger... We have to consider with concern and extreme care the disastrous effects that it could have if it continues... I am neither biased to this side or that. I do not want it misunderstood that I am biased to the Kuwaiti side against Iraq. it is a matter of principles. Egypt has its principles and positions and these positions cannot be sold for money ... The problem started with the border problem between Iraq and Kuwait. This border dispute goes back long years ... Kuwait should have moved and tried to resolve it... I held long talks with our brother President Saddam (Hussein of Iraq). I asked him outright if his troops were moving toward Kuwait, and his told me these were just routine movements and that the troops were 70 kilometers (about 40 miles) away from the border. I asked him if he intended to attack, and he told me no, he told me that he had had enough, and I said good, then we can work on finding a compromise... (Later) They told me Iraq had invaded Kuwait and that paralyzed my thoughts. I am a military man and know how these things develop. I woke up , still finding it hard to believe it was happening to two Arab sisters ... I was dazed .... (The day of the invasion) King Hussein said he would pass by me. We sat and talked and I told him the situation was very serious. We decided that no one wants an Arab summit because we would only sit and curse each other. I said to him, King Hussein, ``I am afraid of the consequences of this. It will be destructive and will put the Arab nation on the spot and our position will be very bad.'' I told him to go to talks with President Saddam, and stress two points ... 1. The necessity for the immediate withdrawal from Kuwait and 2. The necessity for Iraq to stop overthrowing other regimes by force because it is not its responsibility. It is the right of the people... I told him if the need arises, Egypt will join in forming an Arab force to serve as a buffer zone between the two sides ... The crisis has become internationalized. The Arab League Council condemned the invasion ... the Organization of Islamic Conference also issued a similar condemnation, as did the Gulf Cooperation Council. We were here, snapping at each other, while the Security Council met and condemned the Iraqi invasion and demanded the withdrawal of the Iraqi troops. The Security Council was ahead of us as though the crisis was not Arab, as though the Arabs are a dead body which does not want to move. After that, the Security Council met again and issued a more severe statement, banning the exports of any Iraqi or Kuwaiti products and banning the sale of anything to Iraq and Kuwait. It was like a seige ... and if this siege does not produce any results, they move to article number 42 which is a military siege and the use of military force. And we were still sitting and watching... The Canadian prime minister and the American President Bush and French President Mitterrand and Turkey and Britain, they all contacted me and said a siege is inevitable. I tried to convince them to give us a chance. I told President Bush to give us a chance, but he said he would issue the sanctions ... The issue is grave. The situation is grave and the European countries are moving. You (Saddam) said you would not strike and you struck. And now you are turning to Saudi Arabia and saying ``I will not strike.'' They will not believe you. Do you think they will wait until disaster strikes them too? We can see in the world news, American planes and British vessels. The world is moving freely in the region. I told our brothers in Iraq and I will tell you, this is not a secret, this is my estimation of the situation... I tell you my point of view as a former military man. I am afraid that Iraq will be struck by a harsh strike from different sides. Don't think that the fleets are just going to sit there sleeping. This is just my personal point of view. I have not received any information that there is an attack coming. It is clear to me that there is an attack coming, and it could be destructive and frightening... You (Saddam) are not accepting the Arab umbrella. Well, you are getting the foreign umbrella. American and French and British and other forces are being forced on you. ... Isn't it more honorable for us to solve our problems in the framework of an Arab umbrella. Isn't it more honorable for us to listen to the sound of reason between each other. I think the situation is very grave. Today, fighter bombers went to an Arab country. An aircraft carrier passed (through the Suez Canal.) Someone might ask me to stop the aircraft carrier, but I cannot stop it. According to the (international) agreement ... I cannot stop anyone from passing through the canal except if I am at war with him. You (Saddam) cannot put me in a bind like this. You cannot commit such a crime and then ask me for the impossible. Don't embarrass me. Just like you have interests, I have interests. I am trying as much as possible to protect Arab honor ... Everyone will ask for foreign troops after this. There is talk that Egyptian forces went to protect there (Saudi Arabia.) We have no troops there. We are not preparing troops and there is no talk about this. But, I tell you honestly, if we are asked to participate with Arab troops as a safeguard, I do not think Egypt would object to this. Arab joint troops. I am not participating with foreign troops. We hope to resolve this crisis with an Arab solution. In all truth, the picture I see is black... The picture is frightening and if we do not contain the situation and move very quickly, we will no longer have a standing and we will be dead bodies and military powers will force things on us and will have their own way ... From this stand, I call on President Saddam and the Iraqi leadership to respond to an Arab umbrella and withdraw its forces from Kuwait and restore the legitimacy of Kuwait. It is also possible to have joint Arab forces to stand between the two sides until negotiations start to resolve the issue. I am sure that the Arab leadership will reach a solution to this problem. At the same time, time is running out very quickly and events are happening quicker than our movements. I call for an emergency Arab summit within 24 hours, or even within a few hours. It would be better than having a solution forced on us by foreign powers. I hope Arab presidents and kings will respond to this appeal and I am ready in this case to host the Arab summit in Egypt, hoping that we reach a solution before something we do not like or accept happens. National security is in danger and Iraq is in danger. They may say no, but this is my point of view ... It will not be an Arab summit to exchange curses or tear each others clothes. But it will be to solve our problem in the Arab framework which is more honorable to the Arab nation.

President Bush will nominate Samuel B. Kent of Galveston, Texas, to be a federal judge, the White House said Wednesday. Kent, 41, would succeed Hugh Gibson Jr. as the U.S. district judge for the Southern District of Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Takes a Gamble, Pushed by US Oil Needs
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, driven by America's thirst for oil, has undertaken the riskiest gamble of his administration by sending U.S. forces to a faraway faceoff with one of the world's most dangerous leaders. Other American presidents have painfully learned that the Middle East can become a graveyard for U.S. servicemen, a prison for hostages and a sand trap for politicians. Bush acknowledged that the United States may have to pay a big price to stop Iraq's Saddam Hussein from plundering Saudi Arabia and its vast oil reserves. ``Standing up for our principles will not come easy,'' Bush cautioned the nation in a speech Wednesday from the Oval Office. ``It may take time and possibly cost a great deal.'' Bush, politically strong at home, has received strong international support for his campaign to drive Saddam's troops from Kuwait and keep them out of neighboring Saudi Arabia, the largest single supplier of U.S. oil. In contrast to his normal caution, Bush decisively imposed U.S. economic sanctions and an oil boycott against Iraq and then rallied other world leaders to do the same. So far, so good. In times of crisis, ``Americans are quick to support a president and rally around the flagpole in a nationalistic way,'' said Colorado College political scientist Tom Cronin. ``However, Americans find fault with a president when casualties occur, when hostages are taken and when maneuvers seem to backfire or are inept,'' Cronin added. ``The risk is even greater (in the Middle East) because we are under severe limitations of weather, language, distance and because of Arab animosity toward the United States.'' The danger of hostage-taking is real. There are an estimated 3,000 Americans in Kuwait and 500 in Iraq who are vulnerable to Saddam's whims. ``What he does, that's a bit unpredictable,'' Bush acknowledged. Even for a superpower like the United States, Saddam is a formidable foe. His million-man force, hardened by eight years of war with Iran, is the fourth largest army in the world. It is armed with more than 5,600 tanks, over 500 combat aircraft and a horrifying arsenal of chemical weapons that Saddam has been willing to use, even against his own countrymen. Ruthless and unpredictable, Saddam has proven his willingness to fight, not only with helpless neighbors such as Kuwait but with well-armed adversaries such as Iran. ``It's not a country that bluffs,'' said Judith Kipper, a Middle East expert at the Brookings Institution. ``There's no subtlety here. He's (Saddam) not somebody who puts troops on a border to wink and blink.'' Despite the hazards, Bush's hand was forced by America's addiction to foreign oil, which accounts for 50 percent of the petroleum used in the United States. Iraqi control of Saudi Arabia would give Saddam the unacceptable power to control oil supplies and prices. Bush said Iraq's aggression could pose a major economic threat to the United States, which already has been edging toward a recession. If a recession comes now, Bush at least can blame Saddam. Even while confronting the Iraqi leader, Bush said U.S. troops would be used solely to prevent an invasion of Saudi Arabia, not to drive Iraqi troops out of Kuwait. For now, that second step is just too big, Bush judged. He expressed hope that global economic sanctions would impel Saddam to bring his troops home. The crisis in the Persian Gulf puts a spotlight on Bush's reluctance in recent months to try to restrain Saddam despite many warning signs of menacing intentions. The White House opposed congressional efforts to impose sanctions on Iraq and argued it could win Saddam over by diplomacy. ``The fact is, it didn't work,'' conceded White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. ``We did the best we could.'' There also are lingering questions about the effectiveness of Bush's policy toward the Middle East, where the president has been frustrated time and again in efforts to win a broad peace agreement. ``We have not had a regional policy,'' said the Brookings' Kipper. ``We have tended to always look at this through the prism of the Arab-Israeli conflict.'' Suggesting a broader perspective, she said, ``We ought to look at it through an aerial view, a satellite view. ... That's been our failure, the failure of the Bush administration.''
EDITOR'S NOTE: Terence Hunt has covered the presidency since 1981 and is the AP's chief White House correspondent.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Annexes Kuwait; U.S. Forces Move in, But Without Arab Allies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 20 grafs to UPDATE with Arab summit to be held Thursday evening, nine nations to attend. Pickup 22nd, `Reports today...'
DOC.TEXT:
Iraq today annexed Kuwait, the emirate it overran six days ago, and defied ``all the fleets and squadrons of aircraft'' of a U.S.-led force. Arab nations balked at challenging Iraq militarily, opting instead for more diplomacy. U.S. troops were deployed to protect Iraq's neighbor, Saudi Arabia, in what Washington calls a multinational effort. But so far only Britain has agreed to send troops, though other nations have agreed to provide support. The Arab states of Egypt and Morocco declined to participate, despite U.S. reports that they would. An Arab summit meeting on the crisis was scheduled for Thursday in Cairo. President Bush, in a nationally broadcast speech, confirmed U.S. forces were dispatched to the troubled region. But he said: ``We're not at war.'' Meanwhile, the economic and military noose slowly tightened around Iraq. Turkey shut down the Iraqis' vital oil outlet to the Mediterranean, honoring a U.N. trade embargo ordered to punish Iraq for its takeover of Kuwait. One published report said the Saudis had agreed to boost their oil output. Diplomats were working to arrange for the evacuation of foreigners stranded in Kuwait and Iraq, including thousands of Americans. It was unclear whether the Iraqis would allow all who wanted to leave. Iraq, in a statement by its official Iraqi News Agency monitored in Cyprus, said its formal takeover of Kuwait came at the request of the provisional government it installed in the emirate last week. ``The Revolutionary Command Council has decided to return the branch, Kuwait, to the whole and to the Iraq of its origins in a comprehensive and eternal merger,'' the statement said. Iraq has long laid claim to Kuwaiti territory, and cited those claims as among the reasons for its invasion. Earlier, an announcement on Iraqi radio and television indicated the annexation was imminent, calling Kuwait ``part of Iraq.'' The later Iraqi statement warned that outside military intervention would be useless. ``All the evil and all the conspirators, all the fleets and squadrons of aircraft, all the centers of brute force inside or outside the Arab homeland will not shake a single palm frond in Basra ... Kuwait or Ahmadi,'' the Iraqi statement said. Mina al-Ahmadi is Kuwait's main oil-loading terminal. Basra is a key port on the Shatt-al-Arab in southern Iraq. Saudi rulers have never before allowed U.S. troops onto their soil, and sources had said Arab participation in the multinational effort was a Saudi condition for doing so. But Morocco and Egypt denied U.S. reports their troops would participate. The fact that the Saudis are allowing in U.S. forces and warplanes indicates they consider Iraq's president, Saddam Hussein, to harbor further expansionist intentions. Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak called in a nationally televised speech for an emergency Arab summit. His spokesman, Mohammed Abdel-Moneim, later said the meeting will be held in Cairo on Thursday evening. Abdel-Moneim did not give the exact number of Arab countries that had accepted Mubarak's summit proposal. But he said they included Saudi Arabia, Syria, Algeria, Djibouti, the United Arab Emirates, Yemen, Libya and Qatar. Bush provided no estimate of the number of U.S. troops involved in the deployment. But government sources who spoke on condition of anonymity said at least 5,000 ground troops were involved, along with 140 sophisticated fighters and bombers. Cruise missiles programmed to hit specific Iraqi sites were aboard a battleship that set out on a week's journey to the Middle East. Today's Iraqi announcement said the Baghdad-backed provisional government of Kuwait yearned ``to achieve complete unity between Kuwait and Iraq, and for the hero Saddam Hussein to be our leader and protector.'' Iraq says it invaded to support a new government by ``revolutionary youth'' who had toppled Kuwait's rulers, but diplomats have called that a farce. Iraq had already announced that Kuwait's currency was being linked on a one-to-one basis to the Iraqi dinar, in another sign of imminent annexation. On Tuesday, Saddam said his people ``would rather die than be humiliated'' and threatened to ``pluck out the eyes of those who attack the Arab nation.'' ``No one should underestimate our determination to confront aggression,'' Bush said in a nationally broadcast address on the crisis. ``If history teaches us anything, it is that we must resist aggression or it will destroy us.''
Reports today by The Washington Post, The New York Times, CNN and others quoted intelligence sources as saying Iraqi forces appeared to be loading poison gas munitions aboard combat aircraft. That was said to have sealed the decision to deploy U.S. troops. Iraq did not hesitate to use chemical weapons during its eight-year war with Iran and against its Kurdish minority. U.S. troops and warplanes, ordered on Tuesday to guard oil-rich Saudi Arabia against Saddam's million-man army, would be part of a multinational force, which sources said was a condition set by the Saudis. In addition to Mubarak's denial that Egypt was participating, the Morocaan news agency MAP said Morocco would not participate in the multinational effort. Mubarak said Egypt would consider acting in an Arab force. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney returned to Washington today after a two-day swing to Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Morocco. After Cheney's visit to Saudi Arabia, Bush administration officials said the Saudis had agreed to increase oil production by 2 million barrels a day, The New York Times reported today. Such a move would help offset the reduction in world supplies. Meanwhile, Britain announced today that it will send unspecified naval and air force units to join the multinational force. ``The multinational effort is designed to deter Hussein. If Iraq compounds this with a fresh act of aggression, it will be extremely expensive, damaging and destructive to Iraq,'' Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said in London. The multinational force would be far outnumbered by the estimated 100,000 Iraqi soldiers reported to have massed on Kuwait's southern border, but is seen as a symbol of U.S. commitment to Saudi defense. As part of the Bush administration's mobilization of forces to the tense region, a U.S. carrier group passed through the Suez Canal en route to the Red Sea today and a new U.S. Navy task force set sail from Florida. Iraq overran Kuwait after threatening its small neighbor for weeks over a border dispute. Baghdad also said Kuwait's violation of OPEC oil-production quotas amounted to economic war because overproduction kept oil prices down. The conquest of Kuwait drove oil prices up by about 30 percent and gave Iraq control of 9 percent of world daily oil production. If Iraq were to conquer Saudi Arabia, it would raise its share of world oil production to almost 20 percent. But oil prices sank today in London in what traders said reflected confidence that there would be enough world oil production to make up for supplies lost in the wake of the Iraqi invasion. Meanwhile, many governments were drawing up regulations to enforce the anti-Iraq trade embargo ordered Monday by the U.N. Security Council at Washington's urging. If fully enforced, the boycott could cripple Iraq, which depends heavily on its oil exports for economic survival. In Saudi Arabia, the Iraqi oil flow was reported slowing to a trickle through a pipeline on Saudi territory because of the drop in demand due to the embargo. But the Saudis did not immediately announce a shutoff of the pipeline, apparently not wanting to give Saddam a pretext to invade.

DOC.HEAD: Tamil Raid Kills 54 Civilians, Military Says
DOC.TEXT: Tamil rebels opened fire on a bus Wednesday, killing at least 27 civilians, and hacked to death 27 other people in a village raid, military officials said. The rebels, battling for an independent homeland, raided Bandaraduwa village in eastern Ampara district late Tuesday and killed 27 villagers, said the officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity. First report of the killings came from four injured villagers who arrived at a military camp in Ampara seeking medical help. The town is is 135 miles east of Colombo. In the other attack, Tamil rebels stopped a bus Wednesday and gunned down at least 27 Sinhalese at Mahadivulkewa village in northeastern Trincomalee district, said the officials. The area is 125 miles northeast of Colombo. It was the fourth massacre by Tamil rebels since Friday, when they stormed two mosques and killed 140 Moslem worshippers in eastern Batticaloa district. On Sunday, at least 50 Moslems were hacked and shot to death by the rebels in three separate villages in Ampara district. It was not immediately known if the village and bus victims were also Moslems. The militants accuse Moslems of backing the government in the civil war. Moslems, who account for about 7 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, claim neutrality. The rebels say their minority Tamil community is discriminated against by the majority Sinhalese. Tamils form 18 percent the population of Sri Lanka, while Sinhalese make up 75 percent. At least 14,000 people have been killed in the 7-year-old ethnic conflict in this nation.

DOC.HEAD: What Happened To Andy? More To It Than Just Race
DOC.TEXT: Andrew Young's crusade to become the Georgia's first black governor foundered in a tidal wave of white votes. But there was almost certainly more to it than that. Young was late to go on television, late to articulate his message, late to give Georgia Democrats a good enough reason to turn their backs on Lt. Gov. Zell Miller, a populist they'd been electing and re-electing for 16 years. Miller buried Young _ 68 percent to 32 percent _ in Tuesday's Democratic primary runoff and will meet Republican state Rep. Johnny Isakson in November. Democratic Gov. Joe Frank Harris was barred by law from seeking a third consecutive term. ``American politics is complex,'' Young said Wednesday. ``It's an insult to try to break it down as racial. It's not as simple as that.'' Young's campaign manager, Hobby Stripling, a white small-town mayor from southern Georgia, conceded Wednesday that Miller had effectively zoomed past the field before anyone figured out quite what was going on. ``Zell ran a very good campaign,'' he said. Miller declared his candidacy two years out, immediately dominating the race. His television advertising was clever and sharply focused. He said he'd bring Georgia a state lottery to benefit education. He said he'd put drug criminals in boot-camp prisons. Young, the former Atlanta mayor, congressman and ambassador to the United Nations, didn't announce until January. He didn't go on TV until June. His first ads were bland and inoffensive, mostly scenes of Young in an integrated classroom telling Georgians that, yes, he was pro-education. He spent much of the time leading up to the July 17 primary in white, rural southern Georgia, preaching his message of economic development. In two terms as mayor, he had brought jobs and prosperity to Atlanta, and he would do it for Thomasville and Moultrie and Waynesboro. ``He believes very strongly in the economics of the world,'' Stripling said. ``It was very hard for him not to deal with that issue. He likes that issue. ``But the average voter just didn't give a damn.'' Some black leaders grumbled that Young was taking his base _ the black vote _ for granted, while pushing a traditional white pro-business campaign. He hit snags cultivating what politicians call ``free media,'' too. Reporters following Young swapped stories about how many times they were unable to reach his press staff. The day before the runoff, Young's plane was filled with four staff members and two reporters, while Miller hauled at least three TV crews around the state. Young insisted more than once that his money was going to get-out-the-vote efforts, rather than TV advertising. But in black neighborhoods, his historic campaign failed to turn out as many voters as Jesse Jackson did in 1988. And finally, Young came as close Wednesday as he will likely ever come to conceding that yes, there was a little bit of racism involved. ``I don't think there'll ever be a colorless campaign,'' he said. ``I think we can be comfortable enough with our differences to not let that influence us too much.'' Young polled 80 or more of the black vote, according to the votes from some key precincts. But in some white counties, he lost by a margin of nearly 20-to-1. In other elections Tuesday, Kansas Gov. Mike Hayden, seeking a second term, edged real estate executive Nestor Weigand Jr. in a six-way Republican primary. State Treasurer Joan Finney won the Democratic nomination, upsetting former Gov. John Carlin. Michigan Republicans chose Sen. John Engler over General Motors engineer John Lauve to challenge two-term Democrat James Blanchard for governor. In a race for the Senate, Republican Rep. Bill Schuette defeated lawyer Clark Durant for the right to oppose Democrat Carl Levin, who is seeking a third term. In Missouri, Rep. Richard Gephardt, the House majority leader, won the Democratic nomination for an eighth term, trouncing Nicholas F. Clement, a newspaper carrier who is a follower of extremist Lyndon LaRouche.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Abortion Group Targets American Express for Boycott
DOC.TEXT: Anti-abortion activists said Wednesday they would boycott American Express and 43 other companies that donate funds to Planned Parenthood. Leaders of the Christian Action Council said the move follows a letter-writing campaign in which companies were asked to withdraw support from Planned Parenthood because abortions are performed at its clinics. The organization said the businesses should ``stay out of and keep out of the abortion business.'' The Christian Action Council said it was focusing its first boycott attempt on American Express because that company is widely known, not because it donated the most money. American Express spokeswoman Toni Maloney said the firm has not taken a stand on abortion. ``We give to a lot of various projects that basically meet the themes of community service and education,'' she said. ``We gave two modest grants to Planned Parenthood projects in 1989 and we felt that both of those fell into those categories.'' Maloney said American Express had not yet made a 1990 grant to Planned Parenthood. ``But this year is only half over and last year's donations were made late in the year,'' she said. David Andrews, vice president of Planned Parenthood of America, said of the boycott threat, ``American Express is a very sophisticated corporation and they're not going to be pushed around by the CAC.'' The Christian Action Council had been pursuing a letter-writing campaign asking companies to withdraw support from Planned Parenthood because abortions are performed at its clinics. The group said its actions led American Telephone & Telegraph Co. to withdraw its support for Planned Parenthood, beginning in 1991, and that at least 10 other companies had followed AT&T's lead. ``Letters were sent pointing out to AT&T that it was, in a sense, shooting itself in the foot by supporting an agency that kills its future customers,'' said Joe Scheidler of the Pro-Life Action League. Andrews said he knew of no other businesses that had withdrawn financial support from Planned Parenthood. ``I think that AT&T's withdrawal of support backfired not only on AT&T but also on the CAC. We got thousands of new donors after that,'' he said. ``Most corporations don't appreciate any interest group like the CAC trying to dictate their corporate support.'' Maloney said American Express was concerned about card holder complaints. ``We have received calls both for and against our support of Planned Parenthood,'' she said. ``We know that we cannot please everyone all the time.'' The CAC says companies will be removed from its boycott list once they pledge to withdraw support or if support has not been given for more than five years.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Patti Davis, a frequent critic of her father's government, blames the Reagan administration for the slaughter of thousands of dolphins. In a report for the syndicated television series ``A Current Affair,'' Davis traces the slaughter of dolphins _ many caught in tuna nets _ to among, other things, her father's administration. ``My sense of grief and helplessness increased when I learned that the Reagan administration had allowed 20,500 dolphins a year to be killed, contrary to the intent of the Marine Mammal Protection Act,'' she said. Davis, 37, the daughter of Ronald and Nancy Reagan, has been an actress, singer, writer and environmental activist, clashing with her parents on many issues. The report is to air Friday.

Singer Bonnie Raitt donated her concert fee to a group fighting to keep a low-level radioactive waste dump out of western New York, a group official said Wednesday. Raitt also promised that her road manager would match her $2,000 contribution, said James Weiss, co-chairman of Citizen's Against Radioactive Dumping. Two sites in Cortland County were under consideration for the dump. Raitt, who won a Grammy last year for her album ``Nick of Time,'' turned over her performance fee from Friday's show at the Finger Lakes Performing Arts Center in Canandaigua. ``Don't ever allow the state to dump radioactive waste in any of your counties,'' Raitt told an audience of 9,000. Weiss said the singer spoke with CARD members who had set up a table outside the arts center and gave them a check after the show.

Actor William Shatner, the unflappable Capt. James T. Kirk of the Starship Enterprise, says bad reviews shake him up. Critics castigated last year's ``Star Trek V,'' blaming the film's creative and box office failure on Shatner's direction, so he was apprehensive about literary reviews of his first book. ``In this business, we all want to be loved, and when someone says they don't like your work, they're saying, in effect, that they don't like you, so you suffer for it,'' he said in a recent interview. Reviews of Shatner's futuristic cop thriller ``Tekwar,'' published late last year with the paperback released a week ago, were generally favorable. He decided to ``throw caution to the wind'' and write the book because he was familiar with science fiction and police work, Shatner said. He starred in the ``T.J. Hooker'' cop series. ``So I took a cop I've played and put him in the future. Then, I took a subject that was in the news, drugs, and put it in the book. Then, to keep costs down in case it's made into a movie, I set most of the action in the forests of Mexico.''

New York Gov. Mario Cuomo may be a magician with language, but not with linguine. ``Do I cook?'' said Cuomo, responding to a television interviewer who inquired Wednesday about the governor's culinary skills. ``I eat.'' Then Cuomo, known as a deft speaker, said he cooks ``occasionally, but very clumsily.'' Did he have one favorite dish that he liked to whip up, such as lasagna or meatballs? ``Are you kidding? For me to make lasagna would be a desecration of a great Italian dish,'' the Democrat said. ``I let my mother make lasagna. I let my mother-in-law make lasagna. I let (wife) Matilda make lasagna. I don't mess with sacred things.'' The television reporter, from New Jersey station WWOR, said she asked the governor as a lead-in to a segment on food.

Film star Gerard Depardieu was fined $1,800 and his license was suspended for six months for driving while drunk. He was arrested after a car accident that injured two people. Depardieu, who won best-actor award at the Cannes Film Festival this year for his title role in ``Cyrano de Bergerac,'' also was sentenced Wednesday to a two-month suspended prison sentence. Depardieu, 41, did not attend the court proceeding in Riom. His lawyer, Serge Teillot, said the actor ``fully acknowledged his responsibility'' but felt the proceedings would be more calm if he did not attend. Prosecutors said Depardieu's blood contained twice the legal alcohol limit of 0.08 percent after the July 20 accident, which occurred as the actor drove to a hotel after shooting scenes for a new movie. His car collided with another on a country road near Puy-de-Dome, slightly injuring the wife and daughter of the other driver. Depardieu told police he was trying to answer a call on his car telephone and was blinded by the setting sun when the crash occurred.

DOC.HEAD: Brady: Higher Oil Prices Needn't Cause Recession
DOC.TEXT: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said Wednesday that oil price shocks need not topple the economy into a recession, but he called on the Federal Reserve to stimulate growth with lower interest rates. ``We are not contemplating recession,'' Brady said after a luncheon speech to the National Press Club. ``Certainly the events of last week, where the price of oil has gone up, are going to impose additional hardships on the country,'' he said. ``But I don't think we should come to judgment quickly.'' However, Brady said he and President Bush want the Federal Reserve to give economic growth a boost by lowering interest rates. He said strong growth was particularly important now, when the United States was responding to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait ``Everybody wants lower interest rates. ... At this point in time in the United States, economic growth is very important,'' he said. He expressed confidence that Federal Reserve policy makers, who meet next on Aug. 21, would lower rates in response to sluggish growth. The economy, as measured by the gross national product, grew at an anemic 1.5 percent annual rate in the first half of 1990. ``We look for lower interest rates. ... The fact that the country is faced with slower growth will almost certainly produce lower interest rates,'' Brady said. Meanwhile, the Federal Reserve reported that economic growth was slackening even before the price of crude oil soared from $20 a barrel before last week's invasion of Kuwait to $28 after. In a July 27 survey of the Federal Reserve's 12 district banks, ``most noted that the pace was slow or had slackened recently,'' the central bank said in a report known as the ``beige book.'' Richard W. Rahn, chief economist of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, said a recession is now unavoidable. The economic impact of turmoil in the Persian Gulf is exacerbating the effects of the Federal Reserve's tight money policy, he said. ``We anticipate that the economy will grind to a virtual standstill during the third quarter of this year and actually contract by 1.4 percent in the fourth quarter,'' he told a news conference. ``Our forecast shows the economy continuing to experience negative real growth in the first quarter of 1991 and practically no growth in the second quarter.'' On other topics, Brady said: _He did not know if oil companies were taking advantage of consumers by raising gasoline prices so quickly after the invasion of Kuwait, but said, ``If people are gouging ... those that are doing the gouging will hear from the president.'' _Budget deficit negotiations with Congress may produce a number different from the $50 billion reduction goal, but that reducing the deficit was more important now that the United States was trying to exert its influence in the Persian Gulf. _The staggering cost of the savings and loan bailout ``frightens politicians into finger-pointing and blame-avoiding.'' The administration will ``rise above the political blame game,'' he said, while ``the line in the political world goes, `Since I don't make mistakes, someone else must be making them.''

DOC.HEAD: Company Suspected of Working on Second Chemical Weapons Plant
DOC.TEXT: A West German company involved in the construction of a Libyan plant alleged to produce chemical weapons may have supplied plans for a second such facility, prosecutors said Wednesday. Juergen Hippenstiel-Imhausen, the head of the Imhausen-Chemie company, was found guilty in June of shipping materials for the Libyan plant. He was sentenced to five years in prison. Mannheim prosecutor Peter Wechsung said 80 police officers raided various homes and offices Wednesday, seeking clues about the latest suspicions regarding Imhausen-Chemie. Wechsung told The Associated Press that ``at the end of 1988, when there were the first signs of the company's involvement in the Libyan affair, the firm had already been at work on the second facility.'' According to prosecutors, the Imhausen company delivered the plans for the second plant in violation of West Germany's export laws. Wechsung, whose office has jurisdiction in the case, added that Imhausen is suspected of having used federal research funds to pay employees involved in the second project. The prosecutor did not say how far the second project may have gotten, or where it was to have been located. He also did not say what led officials to suspect that plans for a second plant were under way. Suedwestfunk, the state radio station in southern Baden-Wuerttemberg, said Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi planned to build it in Sabhah deep, in the desert. The first plant was built in Rabta, about 50 miles from Tripoli. Disclosures about German involvement in the Rabta plant strained relations between Washington and Bonn for several months starting in December 1988. The United States alleged the plant was intended to produce chemical weapons. Gadhafi denied it and said the plant was making pharmaceuticals. On June 27, a Mannheim superior court found Hippenstiel-Imhausen guilty of violating export laws and tax evasion in connection with the plant at Rabta. Chief Judge Juergen Henniger said that based on the testimony of expert witnesses, the court concluded that the Rabta plant ``was clearly intended for the production of chemical warfare agents.'' Henniger said the plant was capable of producing mustard gas and other poison gases, and that Hippenstiel-Imhausen was aware of its intended purposes. Hippenstiel-Imhausen, 49, confessed in June to helping in construction but said he did not know the plant was intended to make poison gas. The Rabta plant was reportedly damaged by fire under mysterious circumstances earlier this year. The United States initially said the blaze caused heavy damage to the plant, but later news reports said U.S. officials believed the fire was a hoax.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Iraq-Kuwait Merger
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait-Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from an announcement carried by Baghdad radio and attributed to the Iraqi-installed government of Kuwait on Wednesday. The announcement called for a merger of Kuwait and Iraq. They are followed by excerpts from the Iraqi government's announcement, also broadcast by the state-run radio, that the merger had taken place. The announcements were monitored by The Associated Press in Nicosia.

The following was attributed to the ``provisional government of free Kuwait'' Honorable citizens of Kuwait, dear kinfolk in great Iraq, O sons of the glorious Arab nation: When the uprising in Kuwait took place on August 2, the objective of the uprising was not just to remove a regime, although it was a corrupt agent regime, and replace it with a new national system. The objective from the very beginning was a big and historic goal, a dear pan-Arab goal, through which we would rectify comprehensively, eternally and radically what colonialism had imposed on our country. Dear brothers, the crystal-clear historic fact is that Kuwait is a part of Iraq. Its people are Iraqis, and throughout their history they drank the waters of the Tigris and Euphrates rivers; they grew up on the shores of the Shatt-al-Arab. The colonialism that partitioned the Arab homeland to secure itself a foothold in the land of the Arabs, to exploit their resources, and weaken them forever, is what created an artificial entity called the state of Kuwait.... The free provisional Kuwaiti government has decided to appeal to our kinfolk in Iraq, the valiant men of al-Qadissiyah (a 7th century Arab victory over the Persians), the honorable, generous, chivalrous guards of the eastern gateway of the Arab homeland _ led by the knight of the Arabs and the leader of their march, President Field Marshal Saddam Hussein _ to agree that their sons should return to their large family, that Kuwait should return to great Iraq, the mother homeland, and to achieve a complete merger and unity between Kuwait and Iraq, and for the hero Saddam Hussein to be our leader and protector of our march as the president of the Republic of Iraq, as he is the chairman of the (Iraqi) Revolutionary Command Council.... We look to your decision and your heed to our call so the festival can be complete and so that jubilation may spread throughout Iraq and the land of Arabism. We have relied on God; let the faithful put their trust in God. Brothers in proud Iraq, this is our appeal and our decision.

Here are excerpts of an Iraqi government announcement, also broadcast by Baghdad radio, announcing that the merger has taken place. In the name of God, the merciful, the compassionate. O great Iraqi people from the land to the sea; O zealous Arabs everywhere; scarce are the days when the Arabs are jubilant, when they are joyous because of the meanings these days carry, and when they look forward to the days to come.... One of the most egregious criminal acts of colonialism was its partition of the homeland, which was a single homeland the day Baghdad was the capital of all Arabs. And following the independence which Arab countries won, imperialism started intensifying its malicious actions.... Thus, the spiteful pencil and scissors of imperialism began to draw up maps.... In all cases, while drawing up geographic and sovereign boundaries for all states, Western colonialism sought to make all states weak and to ensure that partition, with the passage of time, would prevent these states from closing ranks and demonstrating a unified stance. Thus, colonialism achieved its objectives. The strongest evidence to show its success is that it turned the Arab homeland into 22 states ... by pursuing these methods, colonialism divested the Arabs of not only the components of material capabilities, but also of the components of spiritual progress. What has befallen other states in the Arab lands befell Iraq when colonialism divested it of a dear part of it; namely Kuwait, and kept Iraq away from the waters to prevent it from acquiring part of its tactical and strategic abilities, and thus kept part of its people and part of its wealth away from the origin and the wellspring.... Because the gates of the sky open up to the active and those of goodwill and to the determination of the believers who reject oppression, tyranny, and injustice, the gates of the sky opened up to Iraq before the day of the call on 2nd August (the day of the invasion of Kuwait) and to its detached part, Kuwait.... Woe be to us from God's torture if we are late in performing our duties toward him. Some of our duties to him and on his land are struggle and jihad (holy war) for the sake of a deep pan-Arab awakening which rectifies affairs and retrieves for the Arab individual his status and leading role in the message of God and life.... Based on all this .... in view of what the situation has resulted in after the Croesus entity (previous Kuwaiti government) was shaken and after the earth under its feet and the feet of its collaborators collapsed; with the objective of weakening the hopes of the traitors and evildoers inside and outside the Arab homeland; the Revolutionary Command Council has decided to return the branch, Kuwait, to the whole, to the Iraq of its origins in a comprehensive and eternal merger.

In a separate report from the Iraqi News Agency, the Revolutionary Command Council was quoted as saying in a statement: All the evil and all the conspirators, all the fleets and squadrons of aircraft, all the centers of brute force inside or outside the Arab homeland will not shake a single palm frond in Basra ... Kuwait or Ahmadi. Mina al-Ahmadi is Kuwait's main oil-loading terminal. Basra is a key port in southern Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures Sink, U.S. Stocks Get A Mild Boost
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to RECAST lead, UPDATE with Saddam speech, UPDATE oil prices, Dow Jones index; picks up 8th graf, `Prices had ...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Oil Boom, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Oil futures prices fell and stocks built on early gains today as speculators reacted to the movement of U.S. forces into Saudi Arabia to defend against Iraqi threats to oil-producing nations beyond Kuwait. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the cost of key West Texas Intermediate crude for September delivery fell $2.35 to settle at $25.96 a barrel. The contract had risen 26 cents in volatile trading Tuesday to settle at its highest level since Dec. 6, 1985. Prices for unleaded gasoline and home heating oil were down by more than 6 cents a gallon. Analysts said word that Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and other major oil-producing nations would increase their output also worked to suppress crude prices. Iraqi state television declared today that Kuwait is part of Iraq and called for ``full unity between Kuwait and Iraq.'' An unidentified announcer suggested that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has no intention of giving up the emirate, which his troops seized in a lightning raid on Thursday. Crude futures fell further following the announcement. The Iraqi statment came less than two hours after President Bush told the American people that U.S. troops were taking up ``defensive positions'' in oil-rich Saudi Arabia to guard against a possible attack by Iraq. Bush said he will ask other oil-producing nations to replace embargoed Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil on world markets and explore whether to dip into the nation's strategic reserves to bolster supplies. Oil prices also sank in London. The spot price of Brent Bend, the most widely traded international crude oil, fell $1.90 to $25.50 a barrel. On Wall Street, stock prices inched higher as investors picked over marked-down issues. The Dow Jones industrial average, which lost 5.70 points on Tuesday for its sixth straight loss, rose 24.26 points to close at 2,734.90. Prices had plunged Monday and the Dow fell more than 93 points, its worst one-day slide since the mini-crash of last October. In Japan, the Tokyo Stock Exchange rebounded today and posted its eighth-largest gain as traders taking advantage of the Persian Gulf crisis went bargain hunting. But Persian Gulf war rumors depressed stock prices in London. The Nikkei Stock Average recouped 856.07 points, or 3.10 percent, ending the day at 28,509.14. It was the first gain since July 31. Since Thursday, when Iraq invaded Kuwait, the index has dropped 3,184.92 points, or 11.5 percent. The Nikkei's rebound was helped by bargain-hunting in reaction to Tuesday's big drop of 946.46 points, traders said. They said the rebound also reflected stability in bond and currency markets. But stock prices turned lower at midday on the London Stock Exchange as rumors swirled about hostilities in the Persian Gulf. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 8.6 points, or 0.4 percent, at 2,227.2. In the currency markets, the U.S. dollar was down against the Japanese yen but up against most European currencies. The dollar fell 0.60 yen to 150.00 yen in Tokyo but was quoted in London at 150.15 yen and still higher in early New York trading at 150.33. The currency also rose against the German mark, the British pound and the Swiss franc. In New York on Tuesday, war rumors sent jolts through U.S. stock and bond markets and lifted oil prices to almost $29 a barrel, their highest level in nearly five years. Each suggestion of a conflict sent oil prices higher and stocks and bonds lower on the theory that oil-shock inflation would wallop the already weak U.S. economy. Conversely, rumors that the situation was easing weakened oil prices and sent money back into the stock and bond markets. ``It's an emotional, volatile market,'' said William Veronda, a strategist at the Denver investment firm Financial Programs Inc. Prices also fell Tuesday in the bond market, a barometer of interest rates and economic health. The weakness especially affected long-term bonds, reflecting fear that higher inflation would erode their value. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond fell about $6 per $1,000 face amount, while its yield rose to 8.86 percent from 8.80 percent late Monday.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: the Gulf.
DOC.TEXT: On Wednesday, Bush again addressed fears for the safety of the stranded Americans _ 3,000 in Kuwait and 500 in Iraq. Protection of their lives is a fundamental responsibility of the president, he said. American officials, declining to refer to the Americans as hostages, said they received conflicting signals from the Iraqis about whether they would be allowed to leave. More than two dozen Americans were aboard an Iraqi Airways jetliner that arrived in Jordan from Iraq Wednesday, a Jordanian security official said.
