But a group of Americans earlier bused from Kuwait to Baghdad by Iraqi authorities had been ordered to stay in their hotel in the Iraqi capital, U.S. officials said. Back home, families waited nervously. ``She's still there, somewhere in Baghdad,'' Kevin York of Mount Prospect, Ill., said of his wife, Faye, visiting relatives in Iraq. ``I want her to get out of there and get home, and then President Bush and the rest can deal with it as they see fit. At that point, I don't care.'' Tens of thousands of Kuwaiti refugees have poured into Saudi Arabia from their homeland, bearing tales of looting by Iraqi soldiers and food shortages. In Baghdad, by contrast, the mood appeared calm. ``Everything was perfectly normal ... no excitement, no fear or anything,'' said British businessman Bryan Hume, who simply took a taxi from Baghdad to Jordan late Tuesday. Some calm returned to world markets after days of distress. Stock indexes in Tokyo, London and New York were higher Wednesday. Oil prices, which have shot up by one-third, fell for the first time since the invasion of Kuwait. Governments were scrambling, meanwhile, to replace Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil supplies cut off by the U.N. embargo. Willing sellers abounded. Venezuela, Nigeria and Iran all said they would boost production to make up for any shortfalls. Although they did not announce it _ possibly to avoid antagonizing Iraq _ the Saudis were reported ready to boost production by 2 million barrels a day, equal to almost half of combined Iraq-Kuwait production.

DOC.HEAD: American Troops Supplied with Injectable Antidote to Chemical Agents
With AM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. soldiers in Saudi Arabia are carrying medical supplies to counter the effects of a possible Iraqi chemical weapon attack, officials said Wednesday. There is no single antidote for all chemical warfare agents, but the Army's Mark I kit issued to combat soldiers includes an injectable antidote that counters the effects of nerve gas. The antidote is atropine, a common drug with a variety of medical uses, said Mickey Morales of the Army's Chemical Warfare Office at the Aberdeen Proving Grounds, Md. Iraq is believed to have blister agents and nerve agents. Mustard gas, which Iraqi forces used on villagers during the Iran-Iraq war of 1980-88, is a blister agent that kills by chemically burning the skin and lungs and causing blisters to arise. Morales said combat soldiers also are issued an M17 kit, which includes protective garments and some decontamination and detection equipment. These garments cover the entire body. The kit includes a mask designed to prevent inhalation of chemical, gas and biological agents. There is also a March 258 kit, said Morales, that is used to decontaminate skin and equipment. It can remove nerve and blister agents. The Army also issues a hand-held device that can detect nerve or blister gas, the concentration and the type of chemical. There are also detectors that work from a distance and a vehicle device that can sniff for chemical agents while the vehicle is in motion.

DOC.HEAD: Police Battle Hundreds of Anti-Government, Anti-U.S. Protesters
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of radical students in Seoul shouted ``Crush Yankees blocking national unification!'' and hurled stones and firebombs at police Wednesday. There were no reports of injuries or arrests at the demonstration. But in two southern cities, police arrested 21 youths at anti-American demonstrations in front of U.S. facilities. The protesters were demanding the withdrawal of the 43,000 U.S. troops stationed in South Korea. Also Wednesday, South Korea invited North Korean officials to a meeting to exchange the names of the more than 56,000 people who have asked to cross the common border when visits are permitted next week. The clash in Seoul erupted when 700 students began hurling stones and firebombs at police and attempted to march from Korea University into eastern Seoul. About 1,000 riot police, armed with shields and clubs, sealed two access roads to the school and fired tear gas at the students. The students claim that the U.S. troops in South Korea are an obstacle to the reunification of South Korea and communist North Korea. They also accused President Roh Tae-woo of manipulating the issue of national unification to prop up his declining popularity. In Kwangju, an opposition stronghold 150 miles south of Seoul, riot police arrested 11 student radicals and dissidents for trying to storm a U.S. cultural center, the Yonhap News Agency reported. In another southern city, Pusan, police arrested 10 students for illegally demonstrating in front of a U.S. military base, the South Korean news agency reported. The agency said the students were shouting `Yankees go home!'' Protesters in both cities, identifying themselves as members of a ``suicide squad for peaceful unification of the fatherland,'' demanded an end to the U.S. military presence in South Korea. Korean radicals have been calling for an end to the U.S. military presence in South Korea and the signing of a peace treaty to replace an armistice agreement that ended the 1950-53 Korean War. In a telephone message sent to his North Korean counterpart on Wednesday, South Korean Prime Minister Kang Young-hoon suggested that liaison officers from the two nations meet Thursday and Friday at the border village of Panmunjom to discuss details of the border crossings. South Korea has said it would open its border next week and allow South Koreans to cross if their safe return is guaranteed. Seoul also said North Koreans would have virtually unlimited access to travel in South Korea during the trial exchange. If the border opening occurs, it would be the first border crossing since a small family exchange program in 1985. The two Koreas have not met to discuss procedures for the proposed border opening and most observers doubt it will take place. Both sides have charged the other with using the border opening as propaganda.

DOC.HEAD: Stark Says Sullivan Above Reproach
DOC.TEXT: A California congressman says that Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan, far from being a disgrace to his race as the congressman said last week, is above reproach. Rep. Fortney ``Pete'' Stark, D-Calif., delivered an apology in a letter to Sullivan dated Monday. The existence of the letter was known Tuesday, but its contents were not revealed. Neither Stark's office nor that of Sullivan would release copies of the letter, but its text was made available Wednesday by government sources who insisted on anonymity. ``I apologize to you for the inaccurate, inept, indefensible and totally uncalled for remarks regarding you as a human and as a professional,'' Stark wrote. ``On both counts you stand above reproach. I hope you accept my apology.'' Stark, chairman of the health subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee, created a furor last Thursday when he said Sullivan, who is black, was a disgrace to blacks because of his support for Bush administration policies that Stark contended have harmed minorities and the poor. Sullivan demanded an apology, saying, ``I don't work on Pete Stark's plantation.'' Stark told the House a day later that ``I blew it'' by referring to Sullivan's race, but he stood by his complaint about Sullivan's support for administration policies on abortion, discrimination, health insurance and other issues. Sullivan declined to construe those remarks as an apology. Sullivan referred to Stark's apology in a speech Tuesday to the Southern Christian Leadership Conference in Richmond, Va. He said ``there is a rich, deep and vital diversity within the black community. This diversity is one of our strengths, and we don't need other people to tell us what to think.'' Sullivan called Stark's remarks a ``public insult.'' But he said that after receiving the apology, ``I consider this unfortunate matter closed.''

DOC.HEAD: Recluse Lived Simply But Left Money to Help Children
DOC.TEXT: An elderly recluse who couldn't make much money growing apples found he had a green thumb in the stock market. He left more than $812,000 in his will to help Washington children. Stanislas Dumas, who never married and lived most of his life in a ramshackle farmhouse, spent little and treated his stock earnings like Monopoly money, his stock broker said Tuesday. Dumas left $812,295 to two hospitals and a trade school, said Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. broker Bruce Heiser, who also served as Dumas' guardian. ``For him it was Monopoly money,'' Heiser said. ``He never took a withdrawal from here.'' ``He lived a very simple kind of life,'' said Heiser, who said he became Dumas' best friend after they met in 1979. At the time of his death, Dumas owned only a few clothes, mostly overalls, a rocking chair and bedroom set and a television sitting on top of two apple boxes, Heiser said. ``He bought new cars and drank champagne,'' Heiser said. ``That was the extent of his spending money.'' Dumas would sock the meager earnings from his apple orchard into stocks, and rode the bull market of the 1980s to huge profits, Heiser said. Dumas died at age 85 in November 1988. The money from his will was distributed last September. He left $325,000 to Yakima Valley Memorial Hospital's neonatal unit, $162,295 to the Shriners' Hospital for Crippled Children in Spokane and $325,000 to Perry Technical Institute in Yakima, Heiser said. ``The different thing about this story is that the money didn't end up under his mattress,'' said Heiser, 39. ``It ended up doing something magnanimous.'' Heiser said Dumas was born and died on a 30-acre apple farm outside of Selah, just north of Yakima. Because Dumas never changed the farming techniques he learned from his father, the small farm was never very profitable, Heiser said. But because the farmer spent so little, he was able to save money to purchase stocks beginning in 1921. Most of his life Dumas handled his stock transactions by telephone with brokers in Seattle. The Seattle office passed the account to Heiser in Yakima in 1979, when the portfolio was worth $79,000 and mostly in South African gold stocks. They later switched to oil stocks, then high-tech stocks, Heiser said. Dumas' investments are still coming in. Heiser recently located $1,500 in a savings account that Dumas had forgotten, and checks come in from a revolving fund at a fruit packing warehouse. That money also goes to the institutions in Dumas' will.

DOC.HEAD: King Hussein Says Arab Summit Last Chance To Avert War
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: King Hussein warned Wednesday that a planned Arab summit is ``the last chance'' to avert war over the Kuwait crisis. The king of this Iraqi-aligned nation was asked at a crowded news conference whether there would be a risk of war if the summit, set for Thursday in Cairo, fails. ``There is a very rapid escalation and a very rapid deterioration of the situation and we are very concerned over what might happen. We will do our best so that the Arab world can stop the slide,'' Hussein answered. Asked if he saw the summit as ``a last chance,'' he responded somberly and without hesitation: ``Yes, I see it as a last chance.'' Earlier in the news conference at Basman Palace, Hussein said ``the escalation of action and reaction could lead us to the verge of disaster.'' The king, who is not related to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, was dressed in a blue business suit and blue tie and spoke slowly in English. His voice sounded tired. He kept repeating that Arabs themselves should settle the crisis created by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait without outside intervention. Asked if he approved of U.S. troops being sent to Saudi Arabia to shield the oil-rich kingdom from Iraqi attack, he said ``Saudi Arabia is a sovereign state that can accept or seek any kind of assistance that it believes it needs. ``It is not for me to say whether this is right or not. Time will tell whether it was, or otherwise.'' Referring to Iraq's announcement Wednesday of the merger of Kuwait with Iraq, the Jordanian monarch said, ``Jordan is against the acquisition of territory by war or any change as a result of external pressure.'' Jordan ``still recognizes the emirate regime in Kuwait,'' he added. Saddam has declared that Kuwait's royal family wuld never be allowed to return. The king made it clear that as a member of the United Nations, Jordan would abide by the principles and decisions of the world body. He did not specify, however, whether Jordan would implement the mandatory sanctions against Iraq decreed by the Security Council this week. He said the region was passing through ``a most dangerous situation,'' adding that Jordan's army has been on partial alert since the crisis began. ``This country is facing a danger, and I think this applies to other Arab countries,'' he said. The king said he did not know how many Arab leaders would attend the Cairo summit. Asked what Jordan would do ``in the final worst-case scenario where war breaks out,'' he again expressed hope that the Arabs will manage to settle the crisis themselves. He said he did not believe any danger existed of anti-American riots breaking out in Jordan. ``I believe that the Jordanian people have confidence in their leadership,'' he said. The Moslem Brotherhood Movement, the strongest bloc in Jordan's Parliament, called on Arabs Wednesday ``to stand firmly against American interests.'' Commenting on reports that if threatened, Israel might use Jordanian space to attack Iraq, he said, ``Jordan is not a passage for anybody and if this happens we shall defend ourselves.''

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaiti Diplomat Asks Arabs To Support U.S. Efforts Against Iraq
With AM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Kuwaiti diplomat appealed to Arab countries Wednesday to rally behind the United States-led effort to force Iraqi invaders from his homeland. Sheik Saud Nasir al-Sabah, the Kuwaiti ambassador to the United States, charged that his people are suffering ``brutal atrocities'' at the hands of Iraqi forces occupying Kuwait. Saud met with President Bush at the White House after Bush's nationally televised address to explain why he had sent U.S. troops, ships and warplanes to defend Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf. The ambassador, a member of the deposed royal family, said he conveyed to Bush ``a message from the Emir expressing our gratitude and thanks to him, to the American people and to all those countries that have rallied behind us in our day of need.'' He said he told Bush of the reports of atrocities from refugees who have fled Kuwait since last Thursday. ``I urged our friends around the world, with the leadership of the United States ... and our brothers in Saudi Arabia and the Gulf countries and also in the Arab world to rally and not to waste time to put an end to these atrocities,'' Saud said. Asked if he had hoped for even more aggressive action from the United States to liberate Kuwait, Saud said Bush was ``adamant'' about forcing the Iraqis to withdraw. ``The situation is in good hands, and we are reassured of this,'' he said. Standing before a bank of cameras on the White House driveway, he said, ``I would like from this forum to reassure my people in Kuwait and my people around the world that ... Kuwait will be back under the leadership of his highness the Emir.'' ``Be patient. Keep collected and patient,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq-Kuwait at a Glance
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
Here, at a glance, are Wednesday's developments in the Iraq-Kuwait crisis:
Iraq annexed Kuwait, the emirate it overran six days ago, and defied ``all the fleets and squadrons of aircraft'' of a U.S.-led force. Arab nations balked at challenging Iraq militarily, opting instead for more diplomacy.

President Bush demanded an ``immediate, unconditional and complete'' Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, and later told reporters U.S. forces would not try to drive the Iraqis out of that country. The GIs are there primarily to defend Saudi Arabia, he said, and he hoped the global U.N. trade embargo ordered Monday would pressure Iraq President Saddam Hussein into a Kuwait pullout.

Hundreds of Americans and other foreigners streamed to airports in Saudi Arabia to get out of the country. American officials again expressed concern about more than 3,000 U.S. citizens stranded _ and possibly detained _ in Iraq and Kuwait. Dozens of oil tankers, their masters fearful of conflict, stood anchored outside the Persian Gulf.

The six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council, an alliance of emirates, issued a statement condemning the Iraqi aggression, raising the possibility the smaller emirates might join the U.S.-led force. Egypt's President Hosni Mubarak also hinted at a future Egyptian role.

Venezuela, Nigeria and Iran all said they would boost production to make up for any oil shortfalls. Although they did not announce it _ possibly to avoid antagonizing Iraq _ the Saudis were reported ready to boost production by 2 million barrels a day, equal to almost half of combined Iraq-Kuwait production.
Oil prices sank in London in what traders said reflected confidence that there would be enough world oil production to make up for supplies lost in the wake of the Iraqi invasion.

DOC.HEAD: Vicki Long Claims She Was Seduced by Nun, Newspaper Says
DOC.TEXT: The woman whose romantic involvement with the archbishop of Atlanta led to his resignation claims she was seduced by a nun when she was 19, a newspaper reported Wednesday. Two anonymous sources say Vicki Long, 27, claims the seduction occurred during a weekend trip to Pittsburgh, the Atlanta Journal-Constitution reported in a story Wednesday. Ms. Long has refused comment since her relationship with former Archbishop Eugene Marino became public last week. Her attorney, Anthony Fontana, did not return phone calls Wednesday. Atlanta Archdiocese officials confirmed last week that Marino, who resigned his office citing health reasons, had an ``intimate relationship'' with Ms. Long, a former lay minister. Marino has not commented publicly. The Rev. Michael Woods, a Sandy Springs priest, resigned Saturday, citing an intimate relationship with Ms. Long. Ms. Long has denied a sexual relationship with Woods, but an archdiocese spokesman, the Rev. Peter Dora, said Woods ``did make it clear ... that they had a sexual relationship.'' Fontana has said Marino sexually manipulated Ms. Long, who is considering filing a lawsuit against the archdiocese. The nun allegation first surfaced in Ms. Long's August 1987 paternity lawsuit against the Rev. Donal Keohane of Columbus, who she claimed fathered her 4-year-old daughter. Blood tests showed Keohane was not the father, but the archdiocese is paying her child support. The lawsuit claimed Keohane developed a priest-counselor relationship with Ms. Long and ``through this relationship learned the details of (Ms. Long's) previous traumatic, demoralizing and frightening experience.'' That experience, the newspaper reported, was with a nun Ms. Long worked with at St. Francis Hospital in Columbus. Pittsburgh is the site of the home convent of the Franciscan Sisters of Millvale, which furnishes nuns to St. Francis Hospital. The nun, who was transferred from Columbus, has not been identified.

DOC.HEAD: Winnie Mandela's Bodyguard Sentenced to Death
DOC.TEXT: A former bodyguard of Winnie Mandela was sentenced to death Wednesday in the killing of a teen-age political activist, and officials said Mrs. Mandela's alleged involvement in the case will be reviewed. The Supreme Court sentenced Jerry Richardson, 37, ex-bodyguard and coach of the Mandela United soccer team, in the killing of James ``Stompie'' Seipei Moeketsi, 14. There will be an automatic review by an appeals court. The South African Press Association quoted Witwatersrand Attorney-General Klaus van Lieres as saying he now will consider the role in the case of Mrs. Mandela, wife of Nelson Mandela, deputy president of the African National Congress. Mrs. Mandela has not been charged. Her driver and other associates face trial next month on kidnapping and assault charges. The judge held during Richardson's trial that Mrs. Mandela was at her home when Moeketsi was assaulted there. Moeketsi was killed after being held at the house. Supreme Court Justice Brian O'Donovan rejected defense arguments that a need by Richardson to gain Mrs. Mandela's favor, and a desire to do whatever he thgought would please her, was a mitigating factor in the killing. ``It is difficult to see how kidnap and murder can be mitigated by the desire to please anybody,'' O'Donovan said. He also sentenced Richardson to 18 years imprisonment for kidnapping, assault with intent to do grievous bodily harm, and attempted murder. Moeketsi was found stabbed to death in January 1989, after Richardson took him from Mrs. Mandela's house in the black township of Soweto. Richardson lived at the house with other young men who called themselves the Mandela United Soccer Team and acted as Mrs. Mandela's bodyguards. Last February, a group of South Africa's most prominent black leaders said the soccer team engaged in a ``reign of terror'' in Soweto. They urged the community to shun Mrs. Mandela. She began to reappear at anti-apartheid rallies, however, a few months before her husband was freed from prison. According to trial testimony, Richardson and other associates of Mrs. Mandela abducted the boy and three young men from a Methodist Church-run home in Soweto in late December 1988. The three men testified that Mrs. Mandela, Richardson and other bodyguards beat and whipped them in a room at her house. Moeketsi was accused of being a police informer, according to the testimony, and the three men were accused of having homosexual relations with a Methodist minister who ran the church home. O'Donovan ruled that no evidence emerged to support the allegation against the minister. Only Richardson was tried for the murder. Referring to trial testimony, defense lawyer H. Joubert said Mrs. Mandela had said Moeketsi and the three abducted men were ``not fit to be alive,'' and that she began the beatings. President F. W. de Klerk suspended hangings in February, but courts may still impose the death sentence in murder cases when the judge finds no mitigating factors.

DOC.HEAD: Groups Go To Court To Protect Lab Rats, Mice and Birds
DOC.TEXT: Two animal welfare groups have sued the U.S. Department of Agriculture to try to force officials to regulate treatment of laboratory rats, mice and birds. In a lawsuit filed Tuesday in U.S. District Court, the Humane Society of the United States and the Animal Legal Defense Fund claim that the department misused its discretion in excluding rats, mice and birds from the protection of the Animal Welfare Act. The two groups filed a petition with the department last year, formally asking for regulations to cover rats, mice and birds. It was denied in June on the grounds that Agriculture Secretary CLayton Yeutter has legal responsibility to decide which animals are covered, aside from those specified in the text of the law: dogs, cats, monkeys, guinea pigs, hamsters and rabbits. Kelly Shipp, spokeswoman for Yeutter, said she was aware of the groups' concerns but could not comment on the lawsuit because she had not seen it. Martin L. Stephens, the Humane Society's director of laboratory animals, said rats, mice and birds make up nearly 85 percent of all animals used in research, testing and experimentation in the United States. ``If these animals are needed in research, surely they deserve minimum standards of care,'' Stephens said.

DOC.HEAD: List of Westerners Held Hostage in Lebanon
DOC.TEXT:
Here is a list of the six Americans and other non-Lebanese kidnap victims still missing in Lebanon:
1. Terry A. Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, kidnapped March 16, 1985.
2. Thomas Sutherland, 59, acting dean of agriculture at the American University of Beirut, abducted June 9, 1985.
3. Joseph James Cicippio, 59, acting comptroller at the American University in Beirut, kidnapped Sept. 12, 1986.
4. Edward Austin Tracy, 59, west Beirut resident. Revolutionary Justice Organization claimed on Oct. 21, 1986, to have abducted him. 5. Alann Steen, 51, a communications instructor at Beirut University College, kidnapped Jan. 24, 1987.
6. Jesse Jonathan Turner, 43, professor of mathematics and computer science at Beirut University College, kidnapped Jan. 24, 1987. Non-Americans: 1. Terry Waite, 51, British envoy of the Anglican Church, disappeared Jan. 20, 1987.
2. Alec Collett, 68, British journalist, kidnapped March 25, 1985. 3. John McCarthy, 33, British television journalist, kidnapped April 17, 1986.
4. Alberto Molinari, 70, Italian businessman who lived in Beirut, kidnapped Sept. 11, 1985.
5. Brian Keenan, 39, an Irish teacher of English at the American University of Beirut, kidnapped April 11, 1986.
6. Jack Mann, 76, British missing in west Beirut since May 12, 1989. 7-8. Heinrich Struebig, 49, and Thomas Kemptner, 28, West German relief workers, kidnapped May 16, 1989.
9. Elio Erriquez, 24, Swiss Red Cross worker abducted Oct. 16, 1989.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Swiss Hostage in Lebanon Freed, Officials Say
LaserPhoto ZUR1
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to update with witnesses saying Christen handed to Swiss officials. Pickup 8th pvs, `Christen and...
DOC.TEXT: A Swiss Red Cross worker who had been held hostage in Lebanon for 10 months was freed Wednesday and handed over to Swiss authorities, officials and witnesses said. It was the first release of a Western hostage in more than three months. Reliable eyewitnesses said they saw Emanuel Christen being handed to Swiss authorities shortly after midnight in front of the Syrian Foreign Ministry. Syria had said the handover would not occur until later Thursday. Christen, 33, was kidnapped Oct. 6 along with fellow Red Cross worker Elio Erriquez, 24. A group calling itself the Palestinian Revolutionary Squads said in a statement released Wednesday he had been freed. The Syrian Foreign Ministry and Red Cross in Geneva confirmed the release. The witnesses, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Christen was handed to Swiss Charge d'Affaires Fritz Kuehni. They said Kuehni and Christen were then driven to the Swiss Embassy. The eyewitnesses said they were too far away to tell whether Christen appeared to be in good health. The statement from the Palestinian Revolutionary Squads did not explain why only one of the Swiss men was released. It had said in a statement Tuesday night they both would be freed within 24 hours. That was the first time since the abductions a group had claimed to hold Christen and Erriquez. ``After we have promised yesterday night to release the two delegates of the International Red Cross in Lebanon within 24 hours, one of them, Emanuel Christen, has been set free and handed over to a representative of Brig. Gen. Ghazi Kenaan at 6 p.m. this evening,'' said the text in full. It was handwritten in Arabic. The statement was delivered to the Beirut office of a Western news agency at 11:30 p.m. Kenaan is the chief of Syrian Army intelligence in Lebanon. The statement was accompanied by an instant photograph of Christen. It showed him from the waist up, wearing a dark T-shirt. It was similar to the photograph that accompanied Tuesday's statement, which was delivered to a Western news agency and the independent An-Nahar newspaper. Christen and Erriquez were abducted outside an artificial limbs center in Sidon, a port city 25 miles south of Beirut, where they worked as orthopedic technicians. Police in Sidon had blamed their abduction on the Libyan-financed Fatah-Revolutionary Council faction, led by Palestinian terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal. The group denied the charge. The statement Tuesday said the decision to free the Red Cross captives came in response to the wishes of Syrian President Hafez Assad, Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi and Algerian President Chadli Bendjedid. The statement also said the group had guarantees that their demands would be met, but did not specify what those demands were. There are now 15 Westerners held hostage in Lebanon. They include six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, an Irishman and an Italian, in addition to Erriquez. The longest held foreign hostage is Terry Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. The two most recently freed hostages were Americans Frank Herbert Reed, 57, and Robert Polhill, 55. Both were freed in April.

DOC.HEAD: Garbage Collectors Get Breakfast In Alley
DOC.TEXT: It was one man's tribute to workers with a dirty job. Todd Crittenden prepared and served breakfast Tuesday for four employees of Clark Brothers Sanitation in the alley behind his garage. A small hand-written sign said, ``The First Annual Sanitation Engineers' Sunrise Breakfast.'' The host said the meal was to still his guilt for a mound of trash from a recent cleaning of his basement. ``This is about 10 years worth of accumulated junk, the memorabilia of failed do-it-yourself projects,'' he said. ``I thought the poor sanitation engineers are going to hate me for this, so why don't I feed them breakfast?'' Crittenden got up at 5 a.m. to prepare the TV tray settings. He wore a tuxedo and served the workers sweet rolls with coffee, orange juice and milk. Small wicker baskets held the rolls on each tray, next to jelly jars with a cigarette in each. Crittenden was armed with a lighter to do the bidding of any worker who cared to smoke. ``Each setting has an individual floral centerpiece in an antique cream bottle,'' Crittenden pointed out. ``Surprising, very surprising,'' said Rick Homolka, one of the workers. Ray Wooten has collected garbage on the same route for 10 years. As he smoked the complimentary cigarette he said he has never been served breakfast in an alley before. ``Well fellas, let's get to work,'' Wooten said after taking about five minutes to enjoy the rolls and beverages. Wooten's colleagues rose, thanked Crittenden and started loading the junk.

DOC.HEAD: Man Convicted of Printing Millions Worth $316
DOC.TEXT: Joseph T. Hill would have been better off printing wallpaper than counterfeiting 3 million Polish zlotys, federal agents say. That amount of Polish currency is worth $316. ``The guy could have printed a boxcar full of them and not have enough to buy an expensive suit,'' said Rick Johnson of the U.S. Secret Service office in Orlando. A U.S. District Court jury convicted Hill, 61, on Tuesday of counterfeiting the bogus bills plus an unspecified amount of U.S. currency. He faces 20 years in prison and $500,000 in fines. Hill, a former building contractor who traveled to Poland earlier this year, testified he obtained a $19,000 laser copy machine to duplicate greeting cards and make wallpaper. Secret Service agents investigated after police in nearby Longwood arrested a man passing two counterfeit $20 bills. He led authorities to Hill. ``We can only speculate that he was going to return to Poland and live like a king,'' Johnson said.

DOC.HEAD: Despondent Man Sets Self Afire, Blaze Kills Mother
DOC.TEXT: A man distraught over marital problems set himself on fire and ran into his mother's house, which also became engulfed in flames. He survived but his mother was killed. Evidence indicates Samuel Taylor, 30, doused himself with a flammable liquid and set himself afire in ``a possible suicide attempt,'' said homicide detective Belinda Weldon. ``He was despondent over his marital situation,'' she said. Police found what they called a suicide note in the charred remains of the house. Details about the note and Taylor's marriage were not disclosed. Police and witnesses said Taylor was aflame from head to toe when he ran into his mother's house and screamed for help. ``I tried to stop it, but I couldn't put it out,'' said a relative, George Davis. ``Fire was spreading everywhere.'' He said Taylor ran out of the house after seeing flames race across furniture and up curtains. Neighbors wrapped blankets around Taylor to put out his flames. Davis said he tried to save 51-year-old Clara Taylor, a stroke victim, but the heat forced him and his wife outside. Taylor was in critical condition Wednesday in the burn unit of University Hospital.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Trucks Stuck at Iraqi-Turkish Border
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of trucks are stuck on both sides of the border following Turkey's decision to cut trade with Iraq, and local Turkish and Iraqi officials conferred Wednesday on what to do about it. Only buses and private cars have been allowed to cross the border since Wednesday morning, a local official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. He said later that the two sides agreed to allow thousands of tankers and trucks on the Iraqi side of the border to enter Turkey. Turkey in effect closed an Iraqi oil pipeline, banned all exports to Iraq except food and medicine, and stopped Iraqi imports Tuesday in compliance with U.N. economic sanctions. On Wednesday, 30 Turkish workers crossed into Turkey from the Habur border post, Anatolia news agency reported. It said 22 Japanese tourists arrived from Iraq via the same route Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Silence: A Veiled OK For US Buildup
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union kept conspicuously silent Wednesday about the U.S. military buildup in the Middle East in what appeared to be a tacit endorsement of the moves against Iraq, Moscow's former ally. Moscow, along with Washington, has strongly condemned the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. On Wednesday, the Kremlin did not go so far as to offer immediate ships, troops or moral support for President Bush's announcement of a multinational force to deter any Iraqi attack on Saudi Arabia. But the Soviet silence came in stark contrast to the past, when Moscow routinely denounced U.S. military operations in Libya, Panama, Grenada and Lebanon. The Soviet Foreign Ministry held no briefings Wednesday, and no commentaries on the U.S. moves appeared immediately in the state-run press. Factual accounts of Bush's speech announcing the deployment of U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia appeared on Soviet television and in the official news agency Tass. The only hint of Soviet reaction was anchorman Igor Fesunenko's remark on the television news program Vremya about ``the most alarming news'' from the Middle East. Introducing a report on Iraq's announcement it had annexed Kuwait, Fesunenko said, ``I wouldn't take it upon myself to predict the consequences of this event.'' During the crisis, the Soviets have acted in unprecedented cooperation with the United States, despite their previous alliance with Iraq. They issued a joint statement with Washington calling for the Iraqis to withdraw, and they backed the U.S. plan approved by the United Nations for a worldwide embargo on Iraqi oil and other goods. They also cut off all military supplies to Iraq. Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri Gremitskikh said Tuesday the Soviets were adopting a ``wait and see'' attitude toward the U.S. naval presence in the region.

DOC.HEAD: East Germans Vote for October Unification
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with new material and editing, UPDATING with rejection of Sept. 15 unification, de Maiziere quote, other. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: East German lawmakers, pressed by a sinking economy, voted on Wednesday to merge with West Germany in less than 10 weeks. The vote set the stage for a political showdown in West Germany's Parliament over the date of unification. Under the East German proposal approved Wednesday, the first united German elections in almost 60 years would be held Oct. 14. Formal unity would take place either immediately before or after the balloting. The West German Parliament would have to approve constitutional changes needed to allow elections to take place that quickly. Opposition Social Democrats in West Germany have sworn to block those changes, which require a two-thirds majority in the lower house of Parliament, the Bundestag. The left-of-center Social Democrats believe early unification but a later election date would hurt conservative West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, because he would be blamed for East Germany's deteriorating economy. Kohl's Christian Democrats, also the party of East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere, want unification and united German elections on Oct. 14. The Social Democrats, the second-largest parties in both nations, want unification alone on Sept. 15 and elections for a united government on Dec. 2. Kohl needs the approval of the Social Democrats to shorten the constitutional timetable for holding elections. East German lawmakers on Wednesday voted 187-148 in favor of the Oct. 14 proposal for both joint elections and unification. There were 11 abstentions. Oct. 14 is also the date East Germany will hold elections for the state governments it will create to match West Germany's federal system. Wednesday's vote was a victory for de Maiziere, but he has nearly destroyed his governing coalition over the issue. The Social Democrats in his coalition voted against the proposal. ``Unity must be completed quickly and well,'' de Maiziere said in urging approval of his party's proposal. He said that splitting unity and elections would force East Germany, plagued by rising joblessness, to endure too long a political campaign. Kohl is believed to want elections as fast as possible. The prolonged dispute over unification has led to political bloodletting that could hurt him. Earlier Wednesday, East German lawmakers voted overwhelmingly for a proposal that the merger take place only after major international and domestic questions on unity are resolved. That vote blocked an attempt by a small conservative party to seek an instant merger so West Germany could assume immediate responsibility for East Germany's faltering economy. Under the adopted resolution: _A political treaty on merging the German states must first be concluded, expected before September. _The final round of unification talks must be concluded between the four World War II allies _ the Soviet Union, the United States, Britain and France. The last session is set for Sept. 12 in Moscow. _Progress must be made on building the five states to which East Germany will be reduced when it merges with West Germany. Some lawmakers expressed embarrassment over the increasingly harsh debate that lawmaker Christian Schultze characterized as an ``unrestrained pre-election campaign.'' ``We politicians have not cut a good figure in the quarrel over this question,'' said Richard Schroeder, parliamentary leader of the East German Social Democrats. The West German Bundestag meets Thursday. All the parties say they are motivated by East Germany's rising jobless rate and worsening economic situation since the July 1 economic merger of the two nations.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms, Heavy Rains And A Very Cool Morning
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms spread rain across parts of the East on Wednesday, and a third day of record low temperatures cooled the central part of the nation. Strong thunderstorms developed in the Southeast in the hot, moist air ahead of a slowly moving cold front. Thunderstorms produced winds gusting to 55 mph in Atlanta, and hail as large as golf balls in Marion County, Fla. The same cold front produced showers and thunderstorms along much of the Atlantic Coast. Elsewhere, a few showers and thunderstorms fell over coastal Texas and the southern Appalachians. There were a few showers over parts of Upper Michigan. Hot weather continued in the West, with temperatures approaching 90 degrees in Washington state by midday, and nearing 100 in the desert Southwest. Fresno, Calif., hit 111 and the temperature reached 120 at Death Valley, Calif. It was unseasonably cool across the south-central part of the nation Wednesday morning. Sixteen cities reported record low temperatures for the date. Those records were: Alamosa, Colo., 37; Austin, Texas, 69; Baton Rouge, La., 64; Birmingham, Ala., 60; Camden, Ark. 57; El Dorado, Ark., 56; Hot Springs, Ark., 50; Houston, 68; Kansas City, Mo., 57; Lake Charles, La., 64; Lubbock, Texas, 58; Meridian, Miss., 58; Pine Bluff, Ark., 57; Port Arthur, Texas, 69; South Bend, Ind., 50; Texarkana, Ark., 58; Waco, Texas, 61. North of that region, afternoon temperatures were in the upper 80s in the northern High Plains and in the lower 90s in western South Dakota and western Nebraska. Wednesday's low in the Lower 48 states was 34 degrees in Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Leader Frees Hostages; West African Nations Sending Troops
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Washington saying hostages back at hotel, more evacuations, international force reported near Liberian border, TRIMS pvs; no pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto ABJ3
DOC.TEXT: EDITORS: The following is based in part on a pool report from journalists in Monrovia. AP correspondent Michael Goldsmith was among them.

Rebel leader Prince Johnson on Wednesday freed foreign hostages, and Liberia's West African neighbors prepared to send in peacekeeping troops to try to bring a halt to the bloodshed. Savage street battles raged in the Liberian capital of Monrovia, where rebel armies loyal to Johnson and his rival, Charles Taylor, were fighting each other and soldiers of the beleaguered President Samuel K. Doe. Johnson seized the hostages Monday and Tuesday in a bid to provoke foreign intervention in Liberia's bloody 7-month-old civil war. Earlier in the week, the rebel leader presented 22 hostages from eight countries to reporters at a news conference. The British Foreign Office said Johnson released all the remaining hostages Wednesday, but said it had no total number. However, one official in London said four Britons were among those freed. In Washington, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said the freed foreigners were back at a hotel. He said they include one American whom he identified only as Chris Mendez. He said the fighting prevented U.S. officials from contacting Mendez. The other hostages included an Argentinian, a Dutchman, two West Germans and 10 Lebanese. Diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Wednesday that 2,000 West African troops were being sent to Monrovia by sea from Freetown, the capital of neighboring Sierra Leone. They said most of the troops would come from Nigeria, the most powerful West African nation. Nigerian President Ibrahim Babangida said Wednesday the troops would try to impose a truce, and he hoped they would meet no resistance. He did not say when the force was being dispatched but said it would be ``very soon.'' In the past, Babangida has been a strong ally of Doe. Taylor claimed earlier this week that the force was being sent to keep Doe and his corrupt administration in power. He had threatened to attack such an army. Military sources in Freetown said troops of the force were on standby at the Sierra Leonean coastal village of Sulina, 10 miles from the Liberian border. Reports from the Nigerian capital, Lagos, said troops also might be airlifted into Monrovia. The five-nation African force was to be led by Lt. Gen. Arnold Quainoo of Ghana, a Cabinet minister who used to command the army, according to Ghana's government. Other nations sending soldiers are Guinea, Sierra Leone and Togo. Babangida, arriving in Lagos from a two-day emergency summit of the West African Economic Community in Gambia, suggested the West African leaders hoped for some form of U.S. intervention. ``I believe the United States shares our desire to bring peace to Liberia and halt the daily carnage there, especially around Monrovia, urgently and we are hoping that this operation will get the support of America,'' he said. The 16-nation West African Community, of which Liberia is a member, has asked the international community to help pay costs of the peacekeepers and proposed general and presidential elections, estimated at $50 million. Leaders at the summit of the Economic Community of West African States said the troops were being deployed ``in the interest of the African people as a whole and for the maintenance of international peace and security.'' The announcement said the troops would impose a cease-fire that would allow for the establishment of a broad-based interim government charged with organizing free and fair elections. It said none of the warring parties would be permitted to participate in the interim government, and no members of the interim government would be allowed to stand for election. Doe welcomed the West African initiative, and Taylor's envoys told the Gambia meeting they might accept such a force. France appealed Wednesday for its citizens in the Liberian capital to make their presence known to the U.S. or French embassies in case they needed to be evacuated. A Foreign Ministry spokesman in Paris said there are about 20 French nationals in Liberia. Other nations trying to evacuate their nationals include Nigeria, Ghana and India. The U.S. State Department said a skeletal staff would remain at its embassy in Monrovia. The U.S. government also has agreed to evacuate some other foreign nationals who can reach the embassy compound. Some of the 235 Marines who were airlifted into Monrovia to pluck out Americans and other foreign nationals have taken up defensive positions within the walled U.S. Embassy compound. About 2,100 Marines were sent in ships off Liberia. State Department spokesman Margaret Tutwiler said the Marines will protect the U.S. Embassy ``with force if necessary.'' Boucher said evacuation flights were continuing and that eight more people, including four Americans, were flown out of the country Wednesday. In all, 125 people have been evacuated in the U.S. operation, including 91 Americans, he said.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Arms Magellan Rocket As Spacecraft Speeds Toward Venus Orbit
DOC.TEXT: NASA armed Magellan's rocket Wednesday, preparing the spacecraft to orbit Venus for a $744 million mission to take the best radar pictures yet of the surface of the cloud-covered planet. The agency has recently been embarrassed by a mirror defect that crippled the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope and hydrogen leaks that temporarily grounded the space shuttle fleet. So engineers at Jet Propulsion Laboratory are intent on making sure the unmanned Magellan successfully fires its rocket Friday to go into near-polar orbit around Venus. If all goes well, engineers will spend most of the month testing Magellan's radar and making adjustments. Sometime between Aug. 26 and Sept. 1, Magellan will start formal use of its radar to peer through thick Venusian clouds and map the planet. ``I'm able to sleep as long as I don't drink caffeine, but I suspect I'm going to be very nervous'' until Magellan is safely in orbit, said Magellan project manager Tony Spear. ``It's like your life can go either one direction or another, so I don't plan after Friday right now.'' The 3.7-ton Magellan was released from the cargo bay of the shuttle Atlantis on May 4, 1989, then fired an inertial upper-stage booster rocket to launch it on a looping, 948-million-mile trip to the second planet from the sun. Engineers received a radio signal from Magellan on Wednesday indicating the spacecraft successfully completed an electronic circuit to arm a solid-fuel Star rocket, Spear said. At 9:32 a.m. PDT Friday, a computer program will automatically order the rocket to fire for 83 seconds. The rocket, firing forward, will reduce Magellan's speed from 24,600 mph to about 18,600 mph. That will allow Magellan to be captured by Venus' gravity into an orbit ranging from 171 miles to almost 5,000 miles above the planet. The spacecraft will be behind Venus when the rocket ignites, and won't emerge from Venus' shadow until about 9:54 a.m. Radio signals from Magellan take almost 13 minutes to reach Earth. So it will be about 10:07 a.m. PDT when engineers receive a radio signal indicating Magellan is in orbit. If they receive the signal five minutes early, that will mean the rocket didn't fire and Magellan is speeding past Venus in another major failure for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. But Spear is optimistic the mission will work. ``We trust our spacecraft,' he said. ``It's demonstrated it knows how to take instructions.'' At midmorning Wednesday, Magellan was 519,095 miles from Venus and 143 million miles from Earth. It was traveling at 10,189 mph, increasing speed as it was tugged by Venusian gravity. Magellan will be able to detect Venusian surface features larger than the length of about 2{ football fields. So its pictures will be about 10 times more detailed than the best pictures obtained by radars on Earth or aboard some of the two dozen spacecraft that have visited the planet before. Venus is Earth's nearest neighbor other than the moon, and the two planets are similar in size and density. Magellan may reveal whether the two planets also have similar geological processes, including movements of gargantuan plates of shifting crustal rock. It also may detect evidence of ``Venusquakes,'' determine if any of the planet's tens of thousands of volcanoes are erupting, and learn if Venus had oceans before a runaway ``greenhouse effect'' raised its surface temperature to 900 degrees Fahrenheit. Magellan's prime mission is to map 70 percent to 90 percent of the planet during the first 243-day cycle, equal to one Venus day. NASA is expected to approve continued operation. Three 243-day mapping cycles are needed to map the entire planet. NASA's comptroller's office says the total cost of the Magellan mission is $744 million, including $413 million for the spacecraft and its instruments.

DOC.HEAD: Israelis Jittery That Saddam Will Make Good on Threats
DOC.TEXT: Israelis are becoming increasingly jittery about Iraq's military expansion, worrying that Saddam Hussein will try to make good on threats to use chemical weapons against the Jewish state. Some Israelis are stockpiling canned goods in their attics, since the Persian Gulf conflict has triggered memories of being under siege by Arab armies. Others are trying to purchase gas masks. Most are glued to their radios and eager to see their superpower ally, the United States, put an end to the invasion. Defense Minister Moshe Arens warned Wednesday that an Iraqi attack on Israel ``is not impossible.'' ``We have heard his (Saddam's) threats and we know he carries out his threats, as he did with Kuwait,'' Arens said. ``But I'm sure he knows that Israel is not Kuwait and not Saudi Arabia, therefore I think that the chance he will do such a thing is not very high.'' Arens said Israel has not been asked to help in the U.S.-led multinational force to deter Iraqi aggression. But he said Israel would respond positively if the United States asked to use its landing facilities. Arens, of the right-wing Likud bloc, has repeatedly warned that Israel will take action if Saddam sends forces into neighboring Jordan. He has called Saddam a ``little Hitler.'' Even dovish legislators have thrown their support behind Arens. ``Iraq's action has surprised many and people talk about it all the time,'' said Benjamin Beit-Hallahmi, a psychologist at Haifa University. ``It is clear this has made many fear there could be a war. He's got missiles and planes. Everyone would love to see this whole crisis come to an end.'' Iraq, which boasts a 1-million-strong army, is Israel's most formidable Arab foe. It has a powerful air force and weapons arsenal that includes non-conventional arms. On Wednesday, Iraq's military command claimed Israeli warplanes had been painted in American colors and readied for an attack on Iraq. The Iraqi command warned that Iraq would respond to ``any aggressive act by Israel ... wherever Iraq's long arm may reach to strike its targets.'' Four months ago, Saddam said he would torch half of Israel with binary chemical weapons if Israel attacked his country. Israeli officials denied the Iraqi allegations. ``This is another lie that the President Saddam Hussein of Iraq is using to advance his aggressive aims,'' the Israeli military command said in a statement. An army spokesman refused to say whether the army has been put on alert following the Iraqi announcement. Most Israeli observers agreed that the Iraqi announcement was aimed at winning sympathy in the Arab world while deterring the United States from attacking Iraq. Adding to Israel's concern is the alliance Saddam has forged with King Hussein of Jordan, the Arab country with the longest common border with Israel. Israeli reports say Hussein recently allowed Iraqi warplanes to fly menacingly close to Israel's frontier. The invasion of Kuwait last Thursday made Iraq's threat loom larger, compounding the Israelis' preoccupation with security that is fueled daily by the Palestinian uprising. Israeli generals held an emergency meeting last weekend and decided to step up the distribution of gas masks nationwide, Israeli media reported. But some Israelis are too anxious to wait for army-issued equipment. Miriam Sterman, a Jerusalem homemaker and mother of four, told a reporter she would try to buy her own masks. Ms. Sterman reacted to reports that Iraq was loading chemical weapons onto warplanes in response to a U.S. military buildup in Saudi Arabia. Hannah Ilan, another Jerusalem resident, has asked her husband to buy cartons of flour, sugar, canned milk, and a sesame paste called tehina, which is a popular Middle East food. Mrs. Ilan explained that she survived two sieges of Jerusalem. One was in the 1948 Middle East war when Palestinian fighters choked all supplies to the city for weeks. The other was in 1967, when she spent most of the weeklong war in a shelter with three children, including an infant. ``Those memories haunt me. I hear there's a war going on around here so all I worry about is having enough in the house,'' Mrs. Ilan said. Many feel consoled that the military action is happening far from Israel's borders. Kuwait is 800 miles away. Analysts also note that Israel's military strength would likely deter Saddam from attacking the Jewish state. But there is also some disappointment at seeing the United States unable to put a swift end to the crisis, said Mark Heller, an expert on Iraq at Tel Aviv University. ``There is this hope, expectation that the U.S. will give them (the Iraqis) a slap in the face,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says `Line Drawn in the Sand' as US Forces Deployed
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Wednesday he dispatched American troops on a dangerous mission to the Persian Gulf to protect Saudi Arabian oilfields and ward off a threat to America's ``economic independence.'' He warned Iraq's Saddam Hussein: ``A line has been drawn in the sand.'' Bush said, ``We're not in a war.'' And he called the U.S. effort ``wholly defensive.'' He offered no guess as to when the operation might end. He demanded Iraq's ``immediate, complete and unconditional'' withdrawal from Kuwait, the little oil state Saddam's armies overran last week. Laying out reasons for the largest deployment outside this hemisphere since the Vietnam war, Bush said America imports half its oil from abroad and ``could face a major threat to its economic independence'' if Saddam, ``an aggressive dictator,'' manages to take over the oilfields of the Persian Gulf. The president reached out to unlikely international partners in his bid to squeeze Iraq. Secretary of State James Baker told reporters the Soviet Union had dispatched naval forces to the Persian Gulf for use in any international blockade to enforce a UN trade embargo. Baker also said he was dispatching an aide to Syria ``to see if we can coordinate'' and added the United States has been in touch with Iran ``through third party contacts.'' Both nations are bitter foes of Iraq _ but Syria is on the official State Department list of states supporting terrorism, and Iran has long been accused of pulling the strings behind the holders of American hostages in Beirut. The president's decision won quick support from members of Congress, but some worried whether other countries would join in the stop-Iraq action. ``I hope we will not be the `Lone Ranger' like we were in Vietnam,'' said Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif. Bush's appeals to other nations to commit their armies to a multinational defense of the Saudis met a tepid public response. Only Britain joined in wholeheartedly. However, congressional sources who asked not to be identified said several hundred soldiers from other Persian Gulf countries, already in Saudi Arabia under the auspices of the Gulf Cooperation Council, had been moved into position to cooperate with U.S. and Saudi forces. Rep. Ike Skelton, D-Mo., said following a briefing by Defense Department officials ``it appears this is a very strong multi-national effort.'' But he declined to be more specific about the origins of the force. As a tense president spoke to the nation, government sources said at least 5,000 paratroopers from the 82nd Airborne and other units were en route or already taking positions on Saudi soil _ backed by an armada of air and seapower, armed to the hilt. By evening, one Pentagon source said the military movement was expected to last ``several days, at least.'' The source said the troop movements had encountered no difficulties. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, peeled away some of the secrecy from the operation _ while keeping quiet about the size of the U.S. commitment. Powell told reporters ground forces had ``taken up position'' on Saudi soil. And he said the aircraft carrier USS Independence and its support ships were stationed just outside the Persian Gulf, in position to choke off Iraqi trade lines. The U.S. contingent included 140 jet fighters and bombers as well as battleships that carried 32 Tomahawk Cruise missiles programmed to destroy specific targets in Iraq, military sources said. ``You can be sure that for the mission we have been given we will put in adequate forces,'' Powell said. The battle-tested Iraqis, he said, ``are not invincible. They are not ten feet tall.'' Diplomatic sources in the Mideast reported that hundreds of U.S. Marines were airlifted early Wednesday to near Khafji, an oil-terminal Saudi town near the Kuwaiti border. Khafji is the site of the Japanese-owned Arabian Oil Co. There was no immediate confirmation in Washington. Bush seemed tense when he went on television at 9 a.m. EDT for a 10-minute speech, but he appeared more relaxed _ although tired _ three hours later at a news conference. He stumbled over his words occasionally. ``No one commits America's armed forces to a dangerous mission lightly,'' he said. The American forces ``will not initiate hostilities but they will defend themselves,'' he said. Instead of trying to evict Iraqi forces from Kuwait by military action, Bush expressed hope that a U.N.-directed worldwide trade embargo of Iraqi oil could force Saddam into submission. He hinted that a blockade of Iraqi ports _ usually considered an act of war _ might be forthcoming if the embargo proves ineffective. ``The stakes are high,'' the president said. ``Iraq is already a rich and powerful country that possesses the world's second largest reserves of oil and over a million men under arms. It's the fourth largest military in the world.'' Baker, who flew to Turkey, said he was carrying assurances of financial and military support for its ``forthright closing of an Iraqi oil pipeline and for freezing Iraqi assets.'' Earlier, government sources said the Turks were seeking $2 billion to compensate them for revenue lost by cutting off Iraq's oil exports.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Asks Convictions; Defendants' Families Walk Out
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 5-7, ``About 10 ...,'' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with end of final argument, deliberations to begin Thursday; picks up 8th graf, `Lederer asked ...' INSERTS 3 grafs after 9th graf pvs, ``These defendants ...,'' with additional prosecutor comments.
DOC.TEXT: Denouncing three teen-age defendants as rapists and would-be killers, the prosecutor in the Central Park jogger case summed up the case Wednesday by asking jurors to imagine the victim's terror. Assistant District Attorney Elizabeth Lederer, stressing charges of rape and attempted murder, repeatedly referred to the woman who was gang-raped and bashed repeatedly with a brick the night of April 19, 1989, while out for her nightly run. ``After they finished beating and raping her, they left her bleeding and unconscious in the most desolate part of the park,'' Lederer said. ``They weren't satisfied with raping her. They demonstrated an intent to kill her.'' She asked the jury to convict Yusef Salaam, 16; Raymond Santana, 15; and Antron McCray, 16, in the attack on the jogger and attacks on two male joggers during a gang rampage through Central Park. The three are charged with attempted murder, rape, sexual abuse, riot, assault and robbery. After Lederer's final argument, Justice Thomas Galligan began his charge to the jury. Deliberations were to begin Thursday. Earlier, about 10 minutes into Lederer's summation, about a dozen relatives and supporters of the defendants walked out of the courtroom together. Lederer continued speaking, and the jury showed no reaction as the group exited. The supporters then stood humming a spiritual and praying in a circle outside the courtroom. Galligan subsequently banned them from the courtroom. Lederer asked jurors to ``imagine what went through the mind of (the jogger) as the attackers surrounded her and started ripping off her clothes. ``These defendants wanted her to die, and they took the steps to make that happen,'' the prosecutor said. ``These defendants had every reason for not wanting her to survive.'' Lederer challenged each defendant's claim that his statement was improperly taken and that police lied about interrogation procedures. Referring to Yusef Salaam's contention that he was tricked into confessing the crime, Lederer noted his confidence when he testified. ``This is not a person who is manipulated. This not a person who has words put in his mouth,'' Lederer said. Lederer disputed a defense argument that a lack of blood on the teen-agers' clothing indicated they had nothing to do with the attack. The jogger lost at least three-fourths of her blood in the assault. Lederer said the jogger was found a short distance from where her assailants left her to die. ``The defendants dragged her into the cover of darkness,'' about 78 feet into the woods off a paved drive, where they beat and raped her, Lederer said. Still thrashing because of neurological reflex, ``She lost that blood while rolling down to the path. ``There was no reason their clothes should be bloody,'' Lederer said. ``She was bleeding from her head. These defendants didn't come into contact with her head. ... They were raping her.'' Defense lawyers made their final appeals to the jury on Tuesday, with one attorney suggesting the victim was not gang-raped, while another accused detectives of lying about how incriminating statements were obtained from the three defendants. Those statements are the prosecution's chief evidence. Salaam's attorney, Robert Burns, said unanswered questions about the woman's sex life raised doubts about whether she was raped at all. The 30-year-old jogger is back at work as a vice president at the Salomon Brothers investment banking firm. She testified that she still suffers from impaired sight, balance and smell as a result of the attack.

DOC.HEAD: Leukemia-Stricken Ambassador Reported Improving
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakia's ambassador to Washington, hospitalized with acute leukemia 20 days ago, is much improved, her embassy said Wednesday. Ambassador Rita Klimova ``is recovering and the doctors are very optimistic,'' said Czechoslovak Embassy press officer Daniel Veseley. ``The chemotherapy is working, it is the best news we could have,'' he said a reporter. ``She is feeling quite well and optimistic for recovery,'' he added. Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, where Klimova was taken Aug. 20 for examinations and chemotherapy treatment, has referred queries on her condition to the embassy. Leukemia is cancer of the white blood cells treated by pharmaceuticals or bone marrow transplant or a combination of the two. The disease was first diagnosed at Walter Reed U.S. Army Medical Center in Washington, where President George Bush's personal physician arranged for her to be examined, Embassy Charge d'Affaires, or acting ambassador, Miroslav Chrobok said last month. Doctors at Walter Reed were quoted by Chrobok as saying radioactive fallout from the 1986 Soviet nuclear accident at Chernobyl could be the cause of Klimova's leukemia.

DOC.HEAD: Mexico To Boost Oil Exports To the United States
DOC.TEXT: Mexico said Wednesday it plans to increase oil exports to the United States by 100,000 barrels a day for two months to help compensate for the the loss of U.S. imports from Iraq and Kuwait. Mexican Foreign Secretary Fernando Solana said the gesture was being made in the interests of benefiting ``an important and friendly client.'' Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady said the action ``exemplifies the spirit of relations between the two countries.'' Solana and Brady spoke to reporters at the conclusion of day-long discussions between Mexican and American officials held under the auspices of the U.S.-Mexico Binational Commission. After the Iraqi military takeover of Kuwait, President Bush imposed an embargo on imported oil from both countries. According to U.S. government figures, the United States imported about 600,000 barrels a day from Iraq and about 117,000 from Kuwait. Total daily U.S. imports average an estimated 8 million barrels a day. Solana indicated that the Mexican increase would have been higher but that oil production in Mexico is running virtually at capacity. Last year, Mexico exported 763,000 barrels a day to the United States out of total production of more than 2.5 million barrels. About half Mexico's production is exported. ``This aid by Mexico is much appreciated at this time,'' Brady said. While the U.S. stands to benefit from increased supplies, Mexico, in turn, will receive increased revenues from the expanded oil exports, as well as a bonus from the higher prices that have resulted from the international embargo of Kuwaiti and Iraqi oil. At the ceremonial opening of Wednesday's discussions, Secretary of State James A. Baker III joined forces with Solana in condemning the Iraqi conquest of Kuwait and they demanded an immediate withdrawal of Iraqi forces. Baker said completion of a free trade agreement and continued progress in the war against narcotics trafficking are two of the major challenges the United States and Mexico face. Trade officials from both countries recommended to President Bush that the two countries open negotiations on a free-trade agreement. Bush was pleased by the recommendation, said spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Fiztwater said in a statement such an agreement ``could create a more prosperous trade and investment relationship'' between the two countries. The United States and Canada negotiated a similar agreement in 1988, removing almost all trade barriers between the two countries. Baker said cooperation in combatting the drug trade has been better this year than at any time in history. For his part, Solana said, ``Mexico is willing to multiply its economic contacts with the United States. We believe that a fair, free trade agreement would be a major step in that direction.'' Solana touched only briefly on the drug issue in his remarks. According to U.S. officials, the priority Mexico has given to this issue is reflected in increased cocaine seizures, an estimated 26,500 pounds over the last six months, most as a result of joint Mexican-American operations. In addition, Mexico is pleased that the United States is increasingly accepting Mexico's view that the U.S. government should do more to reduce demand for narcotics. More than 150 representatives from the two countries attended this year's meeting of the Binational Commission. The size of the delegations reflects the broad array of cross border issues on the bilateral agenda.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Solicits Syrian, Iranian Aid in Anti-Iraqi Campaign
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 4th graf: ``Before stopping,'' to CORRECT Iran to Iraq
DOC.TEXT: The United States turned to two of its long-time Middle East adversaries, Syria and Iran, seeking potential partners to counter Iraq's aggression in the Persian Gulf. The dramatic moves were announced by Secretary of State James A. Baker III as he flew to Turkey with assurances to that nation of financial and military support for its ``forthright closing'' of two Iraqi oil pipelines and for freezing Iraqi assets. U.S. government sources said Turkey was seeking $2 billion to compensate it for revenue it will lose by closing the pipelines. Before stopping at a Portugese air base in the Azores for refueling, Baker also said he had received new assurances of Soviet support in enforcing an economic boycott of Iraq ordered by the United Nations Security Council. Baker told reporters traveling with him he would send John H. Kelly, assistant secretary of state for the Near East, to Damascus from Ankara ``to see if we can coordinate with the Syrians'' on collective efforts against Iraq. At the same time, Baker verified reports that the United States also has been in touch with Iran through ``third party contacts.'' The enmity between the Syrian and Iraqi governments is intense, with the only possible greater enmity being that between Iran and Iraq. Syria helped Iran in Iran's long and bloody eight-year war started by another invasion of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein in 1980. Syrian President Hafez Assad and Saddam Hussein are longtime rivals within the Arab world. The two nations are ruled by rival Arab socialist parties, each considering the other an outcast. Apart from that conflict, Syria's relationship with the United States has been as bad as U.S. reations with Iraq. In fact, Syria is one of six countries listed by the State Department as sponsoring terrorists acts. Iraq was removed from that list several years ago. Terrorist groups believed to be under the influence of Iran are holding six Americans hostage in Lebanon, the longest since 1985. Baker declined to say what `` collective efforts'' Syria and the United States might undertake against Iraq. ``I really don't want to get into the specifics of that,'' he said. Baker talked for about a half hour by telephone with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, their third conversation in two days. The secretary then said, ``They continue to support enforcement of the U.N. resolution. We can look toward continued Soviet cooperation to carry out the resolution.'' Baker said Moscow had dispatched naval forces to the Persian Gulf for use in any international blockade to enforce the sanctions approved unanimously Monday by the U.N. Security Council. Kelly, who was flying to Turkey with Baker, will go on to Saudi Arabia, whose oil fields the U.S is protecting with thousands of troops dispatched Wednesday. Kelly will meet with ousted leaders of the Kuwaiti government who were given sanctuary in Saudi Arabia, and with Saudi officials. A senior U.S. official who demanded anonymity said was up to Saudi Arabia to decide whether Syria and Iran could participate in defense of the kingdon against Iraq. Iran has mounted terrorist operations against Saudi Arabia in the past, according to Saudi officials.

DOC.HEAD: GIs Take Up Position in Saudi; Iraq Dismisses U.S. `Fleets and Squadrons'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads thruout to UPDATE with Bush reason for deployment; Iraqi statement on embargo; Baker says Syria and Iran have been approached for cooperation, help, SUBS last graf to change ``said'' to ``signaled'' re oil production increases. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX14
DOC.TEXT: By sea and air, American paratroopers, seamen and fighter pilots plunged into the gathering storm of the Middle East on Wednesday to defend the Saudi oil kingdom against any attack by a powerful, expansionist Iraq. Just six days after invading Kuwait, the Iraqis proclaimed they had annexed that wealthy Persian Gulf nation, and Iraq's President Saddam Hussein sounded unafraid of the U.S. superpower. ``All the fleets and squadrons of aircraft ... will not shake a single palm frond'' in Iraq, said a statement by Saddam's ruling council. In Washington, President Bush warned the Iraqis that ``a line has been drawn in the sand'' in Saudi Arabia, where the first aircraft and ground forces of a U.S. expeditionary force took up positions Wednesday. The United States also turned to two of its longtime Middle East adversaries, Syria and Iran, seeking partners to counter Iraq's aggression. Egypt announced that an emergency Arab summit would convene in Cairo Thursday to discuss the crisis. The potential for further explosions in the Arabian desert sent new tremors through the Middle East and around the world. Hundreds of Americans and other foreigners streamed to airports in Saudi Arabia to get out of the country. American officials again expressed concern about more than 3,000 U.S. citizens stranded _ and possibly detained _ in Iraq and Kuwait. Dozens of oil tankers, their masters fearful of conflict, stood anchored outside the Persian Gulf. As GIs packed up for the 5,000-mile journey to the Persian Gulf and the uncertain days ahead, Americans wondered whether they were headed into war. Angela Nelson was to wed an 82nd Airborne Division soldier on Saturday in Michigan, but he was recalled for duty in Saudi Arabia. ``It's scary,'' she said. ``Not just for my wedding, but for the country.'' Saddam said his 100,000-man invasion force seized Kuwait last week because the emirate had wronged Iraq _ by overproducing oil, driving down world prices and Iraqi revenues, and by demanding repayment of huge loans it made to Iraq. He also reasserted longstanding Iraqi territorial claims on Kuwait. In announcing the abrupt annexation Wednesday, the Iraqis claimed that ``history has proved that Kuwait is a part of Iraq.'' But Bush, in a White House address televised to the nation, declared that history had instead proven that ``we must resist aggression or it will destroy us.'' Saddam disclaims any design on vast Saudi Arabia, which borders both Kuwait and Iraq. Refugees filtering out of Kuwait say the dug-in Iraqi troops are in seemingly defensive positions. American officials said, however, they considered the Iraqi army an ``imminent threat'' to Saudi Arabia, and said intelligence reports indicate the the Iraqis are in offensive formations. The United States rushed to Saudi Arabia's side, Bush said, because the American economy, heavily dependent on imported oil, would be threatened if Saddam, ``an aggressive dictator,'' took over Gulf oilfields. Bush, who demanded an ``immediate, unconditional and complete'' Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, later told reporters U.S. forces would not try to drive the Iraqis out of that country. The GIs are there primarily to defend Saudi Arabia, he said, and he hoped the global U.N. trade embargo ordered Monday would pressure Saddam into a Kuwait pullout. American officials provided few public details of the strength and timetable of the U.S. military deployment in Saudi Arabia. At least 5,000 ground troops were involved, U.S. sources said, along with 140 F-15s, F-16s and other jet fighters and bombers. Besides the 82nd Airborne, Pentagon sources said Bush ordered elements of the 101st Airborne Division and the 24th Infantry Division (mechanized) to duty in Saudi Arabia. The 101st is equipped with attack helicopters that could be launched against advancing tanks. In addition, 4,000 U.S. Marines were flown to Saudi Arabia and some units were deployed near the oil-terminal town of Khafji, which abuts the border of Iraqi-occupied Kuwait, Mideast diplomatic sources said. And five U.S. Air Force AWACs reconnaissance planes were arriving Wednesday in Saudi Arabia, said Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. The Bush administration called the intervention a ``multinational'' effort, but few other governments climbed aboard immediately. Egypt and Morocco denied reports by U.S. sources that they had agreed to send troops to Saudi Arabia. Only the British said they would send unspecified military forces. But Egypt's President Hosni Mubarak said Egyptians might later take part in an all-Arab force. Meanwhile, the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council, an alliance of Arab emirates, condemned the Iraqi aggression, raising the possibility that the smaller oil states might join the U.S.-led force. A brigade of troops from the emirates was already in Saudi Arabia. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, flying to Turkey with assurances of financial and military support for Ankara's closing of two Iraqi oil pipelines, told reporters he would send John H. Kelly, assistant secretary of state for the Near East, to Damascus ``to see if we can coordinate with the Syrians'' on collective efforts against Iraq. At the same time, Baker verified reports that the United States also has been in touch with Iran through ``third party contacts.'' The enmity between the Syrian and Iraqi governments is intense, with the only possible greater enmity being that between Iran and Iraq. Not all Arabs condemn Iraq's takeover of Kuwait. In Iraqi-aligned Jordan, for example, the Moslem Brotherhood Movement, the strongest bloc in the Parliament, called on Arabs ``to stand firmly against American interests.'' Gen. Powell said in Washington that the Iraqis, hardened by a recent eight-year war with Iran, ``are not invincible. They are not 10 feet tall.'' But the several thousand U.S. troops reported being deployed in the 100-degree heat and blowing sands of Saudi Arabia would be no match for the large Iraqi invasion units in Kuwait, or the million-man Iraqi army that backs them up. The best immediate U.S. weapon appeared to be the economic embargo, which had already cut off much of Iraq's all-important oil exports. Global solidarity looked unlikely, however. Two examples: Indonesia said it would continue trading with Iraq; the Netherlands, a U.S. ally, said it would allow a Dutch dredging company to continue work to enlarge an Iraqi port on the Gulf. Bush said ``additional steps'' might be needed _ an allusion to a naval blockade of Iraq orchestrated by the United States. The necessary U.S. warships were assembling. Nine U.S. Navy vessels are now patrolling the Persian Gulf, Iraq's only direct sea outlet, and a 15-ship task force led by the aircraft carrier USS Independence was just outside the mouth of the strategic waterway. In addition, the carrier Eisenhower, accompanied by five other warships, passed through the Suez Canal on Wednesday en route to the gulf.
