DOC.HEAD: Bourbon, Not Champagne, To Splash Across Bow Of Submarine Kentucky
DOC.TEXT: The Trident submarine USS Kentucky will be christened Saturday _ with a special blend of Kentucky bourbons instead of the traditional bottle of bubbly. Eight distilleries donated their most seasoned bourbon for the event, according to a news release from U.S. Rep. Larry J. Hopkins, R-Ky. Twelve Kentuckians assigned to the submarine will bottle the whiskey during a special ceremony on land Thursday. Hopkins' wife, Carolyn, is to break the commemorative bottle over the bow of the 560-foot, 18,750-ton submarine. The christening will take place at the Electric Boat division of General Dynamics. Electric Boat is the sole builder of the Trident submarine, which is designed to serve as an undersea missile-launching platform. Electric Boat has already delivered 10 Tridents to the Navy. The boat will be the third Navy vessel named in honor of the Bluegrass State, but it's the first to be christened with Kentucky spirits, the release said.

DOC.HEAD: Precede NICOSIA
U.S. Marines Are Deployed at Khafji, Near Kuwait Border
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with 4,000 U.S. Marines deployed inside Saudi Arabia. Picks up 7th graf, English said .. .
DOC.HEAD: With Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: About 4,000 U.S. Marines were flown to Saudi Arabia and Marine contingents were deployed Thursday near Khafji, close to the kingdom's border with Iraqi-occupied Kuwait, according to diplomatic sources. The sources, speaking on condition they not be identified, said the Marines reached the area early Thursday morning. They did not say how they were flown in or give other details of the airlift. The sources said no U.S. military planes had been landing at Dhahran's international airport on Thursday but could be landing at other air strips. Pentagon sources in Washington had reported that the American planes and men would be flown to Riyadh, the capital, and Dhahran on the Persian Gulf coast. The diplomatic sources said they did not know how far the Marines were from the Khafji oil terminal, site of the Arabian Oil Co., a Japanese concern. Executives in Khafji said that from their location they were not aware of any extraordinary activities. The oil terminal lies 18 miles south of town and the border. The report of a Marine deployment in the oil-rich northeast corner of Saudi Arabia was not immediately confirmed in Washington, where President Bush announced Tuesday he had ordered ground and air forces to Saudi Arabia to defend the kingdom against any Iraqi aggression. American sources in Washington said about 5,000 ground troops and 140 warplanes would be involved. But one diplomatic source in the region said two U.S. army divisions, about 30,000 troops, were on their way to Saudi Arabia. The U.S. sources had said elements of three divisions _ not necessarily the entire divisions _ would be sent to Saudi Arabia. But the discrepancy in reports could not otherwise be immediately reconciled. Associated Press photographer Greg English reported after flying over the Strait of Hormuz that about 30 oil tankers were anchored outside the strait, about double the number over the weekend. English said few vessels ventured into the Persian Gulf itself. ``The whole of the southern gulf seemed like it had been deserted overnight,'' he said. During an extensive morning overflight of the southern gulf, English reported sighting only one Norwegian-flagged tanker sailing out and one French warship. Shipping executives said that only ships with very strict schedules or those that had been there already were inside the gulf. They said those outside were the ones that were told they could wait for further instructions. Loading at the main Saudi oil terminal of Ras Tanura was normal, but one executive pointed out that the vessels were moving cautiously and more slowly than usual. Loading was canceled, however, at Dubai's Jebel Ali terminal, where ships were told that ``due to situation in gulf, loading will not continue,'' the executives said. Jebel Ali cargo includes stored Iraqi oil products.

DOC.HEAD: Motorcycle Mamas, Papas, The Whole Gang, Descend on Black Hills Town
DOC.TEXT: A quarter-million motorcyclists have converged on this small Black Hills town to enjoy races, tours and general good times. The weeklong 50th Black Hills Motor Classic has turned the town of 7,000 on the edge of western South Dakota's Black Hills into a motorcycle mecca. ``It's great, mind blowing,'' Marguerite McNeill of Queensland, Australia, said Tuesday. ``It seems to have all ages. It doesn't matter what or who you are.'' Motorcycles are parked on the six blocks of Main Street that have been blocked off to other traffic. Bikes are parked on both sides of the street and in double rows down the middle of every block. The visitors included lawyers, bankers, police officers, doctors and housewives. ``This is just unreal to see this many people,'' said Burt Trumbower, wearing leather and a diamond stud in his left ear, as he surveyed Main Street. Trumbower, 45, a postal inspector from St. Paul, Minn., was attending his 17th rally. Two wedding parties zoomed up and down the streets, and another couple was observed taking vows in a nearby park with a bearded, leather-clad man officiating. Some attending the rally belong to established groups, such as Hell's Angels, Banditos and Sons of Silence. The rally started small in 1940, and was dedicated to tours and races. The races are still held, but over the years the parties have taken precedence. ``I bet most people don't know the races go on,'' said Bruce Hubbard, president of the Black Hills Motor Classic Board, which is part of the local Chamber of Commerce. ``They just come to ride their bikes, maybe drink a couple of beers and talk to their buddies.'' The gathering officially began Monday, but bikers began arriving last week _ along with extra law enforcement offiicers. The rally runs through Sunday. The rally's relatively mellow mood was broken Tuesday night when police shot and killed a man who'd broken into a home after pounding a knife blade about 2 feet through a door, authorities said. The man also had threatened at least one other person and caused other disturbances, said Mike Jackley, Meade County state's attorney. Authorities would not release the man's name. ``This is a very isolated incident,'' said Jackley. ``There's no good rational explanation for it. I'd say from the reports I've seen he definitely was not acting rationally.'' For the most part, the crowd is friendly, said Harold Sykora, chairman of a task force of state agencies providing support services for the rally. ``They seem to be polite. If you bump into someone on the street, they'll say `Excuse me' and be on their way. People come here to have a good time,'' Sykora said.

DOC.HEAD: North Says He Has No Political Aspirations _ For Now
DOC.TEXT: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf to include reference to previous North statement.

Oliver North, a major figure in the Iran-Contra arms scandal, says he has no political aspirations _ for now. North told the Loudoun (Va.) Times-Mirror in an interview published Wednesday that he's formed an educational foundation that will deal with politics on a grass-roots level. But the retired Marine lieutenant colonel told the newspaper, ``I have no political aspirations of my own.'' He added, however, ``My daddy used to tell me, `Never say never.'' North has made similarly vague statements about his political plans before, and that last remark is similar to one made in March to USA Today. North also is a walking advertisement for one of his companies, Guardian Technologies International Inc., which manufactures bulletproof vests. ``I wear one every time I'm out in public,'' he said. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Washington last month set aside all three of North's convictions in the Iran-Contra case. The court said there needed to be a hearing on whether there had been improper use of testimony North gave Congress under a grant of partial immunity. The court dismissed outright one count, citing faulty instructions from the judge.

DOC.HEAD: Airline Promotion Puts Comics, Business Talks on Detroit-Cleveland Flights
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Last name `Aprill' in 8th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Take my flight, please, says a commuter airline, which is putting comedians in the cabin to lighten up the short hop between Cleveland and Detroit. On a flight too quick for work or napping, comedian Don Tersigni reminded the crowd Wednesday on Continental Express' 50-minute flight to Detroit, ``If you don't like my act, where are you going to go?'' The Detroit entertainer then launched into Sylvester Stallone and Elvis Presley impersonations, with a bit of improvising. ``I couldn't hear myself, really,'' he said. ``Especially doing impressions. I was just sort of winging it.'' Said Boston businessman William Stadler, ``At least it wasn't boring.'' ``It's a good way to spend a short flight,'' said Robert Anderson, an architect from the Detroit suburb of St. Clair Shores who flies to Cleveland weekly. The commuter airline on Monday launched a week of in-flight business talks and comedy to publicize the Detroit route it started in February. Detroit is one of 15 cities the airline serves from Cleveland. But for stand-up comics, some flights force a change of style. Comic Al Aprill did sit-down comedy when Flight 4454 en route to Cleveland experienced turbulence Monday night. ``I was told our comedian does a real good job,'' said Capt. Bill Daly. ``I'm sorry I can't let him stand up.'' Earlier Wednesday, most of the 17 passengers on the 30-seat plane stayed awake to hear Detroit Free Press assistant business editor Nunzio Lupo give a 20-minute talk on the labor negotiations going on between the Big Three automakers and the United Auto Workers union. Passengers applauded Lupo after the flight, and, perhaps more importantly, listened to the airline's emergency instructions. ``In the morning it's really hard. They'll sleep, or read their paper. They don't listen to my demo,'' said flight attendant Lisa Lyons of Erie, Pa. Detroit dentist Frank Markie said Lupo's talk ``shortens the time'' and that flights are ``usually pretty boring.'' The morning airborne business briefings and evening flights with comedians have been popular enough that the Continental Airlines commuter-feeder line may try them on other routes, spokeswoman Nancy Compel said. ``It's a lot different than entertaining a nightclub crowd,'' Tersigni said.

DOC.HEAD: Quebec Asks Military Help in Mohawk Standoff
DOC.TEXT: Quebec has asked the federal government to send in soldiers ``to ensure public security'' in a month-long armed standoff between Mohawks and provincial police, Premier Robert Bourassa said Wednesday. In another development, the Mohawks and the federal government announced agreement on a mediator to bring the parties back to the bargaining table. Bourassa had given the Mohawks a 48-hour ultimatum that ran out Wednesday to either resume talks or face unspecified consequences. The dispute has polarized Canadians, spurring both sympathy protests by other Indians and anti-Indian demonstrations. At his news conference in Quebec City, Bourassa said he wants the military's role to be peaceful. ``There's no question at this stage of an armed assault,'' he said. He did not say when or how many soldiers would move into the town of Oka, where police and Mohawks have faced each other behind barricades since a gun battle July 11. A policeman was killed during that fight, which broke out when police stormed a barricade erected by Mohawks to stop the expansion of a local golf course on land the Mohawks claim as ancestral. Blame in that killing has not been established. Bourassa said the soldiers will back up provincial police because ``for the last month, they've had a very difficult job that they've done very courageously.'' Calling in the army to Oka, 18 miles west of Montreal, does not mean that civil liberties are being curtailed, Bourassa said. He said the military will take its orders from provincial police. Loran Thompson, a Mohawk spokesman, said he was not surprised nor overly concerned about the military's arrival. ``We're hoping the army just stays out there and tries to maintain peace,'' he said. Asked if the Indians fear an assault, Thompson said,``That's always possible, but we're advised that our men are ready if it comes to that.'' There was no immediate comment on the military role from federal officials. In separate remarks, Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said the negotiator in the dispute will be Alan B. Gold, chief justice of Quebec Superior Court. He said Gold's job will be to ``clarify any pre-conditions, and having addressed these matters, he will take steps for the commencement of substantive negotiations.'' Mohawk negotiator Joe Deom said in a statement that the Indians had agreed to Gold's role. But he added that ``nothing has changed'' in the Mohawks' demands. The talks bogged down over the Mohawks' conditions: free movement of food and Mohawk advisers across the barricades, and the presence of international observers. Deom said the Mohawk barricades will remain during the talks. Federal officials plan to buy the disputed land to block the golf course addition.

DOC.HEAD: Pakistan's New Leader Pledges Elections
DOC.TEXT: Pakistan's new leader said Wednesday he will hold elections in October, but ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto raised doubts about that promise and the future of democracy in the country. After Ms. Bhutto's government was abruptly dismissed Monday, President Ghulam Ishaq Khan set new elections for Oct. 24. He accused the government of corruption and nepotism. On Wednesday, acting Prime Minister Mustafa Jatoi, the former opposition leader, said he intends to carry out the plan for October voting. ``Elections is our priority,'' said Jatoi, speaking to reporters for the first time since taking office. ``I unequivocally declare that I will fulfill this promise.'' He said an election commission had been formed and had begun to set the timetable for the balloting. However, Ms. Bhutto said she doubted elections would be held. She predicted the military that has ruled Pakistan for much of its 43-year history would soon seize power. ``The caretaker government will not last. Within a few weeks, the army will take over,'' Ms. Bhutto said at a news conference in her hometown of Karachi. She also said the military had threatened to take over unless the president dismissed her government. The army denied her allegations, and Jatoi told reporters he was ``astonished'' by the former prime minister's remarks. ``The army has played a positive role in helping to restore democracy,'' he said. ``This is her expression of gratitude.'' Ms. Bhutto inherited the political mantle of her father, the late Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto. He was ousted by Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq in a 1977 coup and hanged two years later. Zia himself was killed in a mysterious plane crash on Aug. 17, 1988. His death led to the first democratic elections after more than a decade of military rule. When Ms. Bhutto led her party to victory and took office in December 1988, she pledged to restore democracy. Diplomats and political analysts also voiced skepticism Wednesday about the date of elections, pointing out that the interim administration is comprised largely of Ms. Bhutto's fiercest critics. They also cited the threat of war with neighboring India over the disputed territory of Kashmir. The U.S. ambassador to Pakistan, Robert Oakley, said October elections were not certain. ``I agree there is a question mark,'' Oakley said at a seminar. ``I retain the same feeling at the moment that the chances are reasonably good.'' But he added, ``There's always the impact of whether a government is true to its words.'' The president dismissed Ms. Bhutto's government, citing a long list of charges ranging from official greed to misuse of power. She has repeatedly denied the allegations, saying anyone with proof should take it to court. Corruption is endemic in Pakistan, but Jatoi said it had flourished at unprecedented levels during Ms. Bhutto's administration. ``Rampant corruption and the complete breakdown of law and order necessitated the president's constitutional action,'' he said. ``The priorities of my government are going to be to continue the democratic process while cleansing our society of the negative influences of the past 20 months.'' ``Accountability in accordance with law is the demand of the people and will also be initiated,'' he said. ``Those who looted and plundered the economy of the nation and the treasury cannot go scot-free.'' He said tribunals would be set up to investigate the charges and empowered to disqualify candidates from election and assess punishment. However, he said there would be no witch hunt against the former government.

DOC.HEAD: Trial of 2 Live Crew Members Set For October
DOC.TEXT: A state judge on Wednesday set Oct. 9 for the obscenity trial of three members of the rap music group 2 Live Crew. Broward County Circuit Judge June Johnson set the date after rescinding bench warrants issued earlier in the day because the defendants' attorneys didn't appear for a docket hearing. The attorneys, contacted by the court, appeared later and told the judge they hadn't been notified of the hearing. County sheriff's deputies arrested 2 Live Crew leader Luther Campbell and member Chris Wongwon after a June concert in Hollywood, Fla., at which the rappers sang sexually explicit lyrics from their ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' album. The record had been ruled obscene U.S. District Judge Jose Gonzalez. A third member, Mark Ross, was charged later in the case. The group has four members. Each of the three defendants is charged with one count of misdemeanor obscenity, and faces up to a year in jail and a $1,000 fine. The album has stirred the debate on obscenity and free speech. An Indiana judge last week ruled that the million-selling album violates standards of decency and should not be sold to minors, and Dallas prosecutors filed charges against two store chains for selling it. The record has also been banned from record stores in San Antonio.

DOC.HEAD: Hurricane Diana Passes, Leaves Mexican Coast Town a Wreck
DOC.TEXT: Hurricane Diana was well inland and appeared to be blowing itself out Wednesday after wrecking this coastal oil town of 120,000. Mexico's National Meteorological Service said Diana, now downgraded to a tropical depression, was over Central Mexico heading west, but could still cause heavy rains there and as far south as the Valley of Mexico. Tuxpan had long been lucky. The hurricanes that sweep the Gulf of Mexico always seemed to veer away and spin north toward Texas. ``It was as if we had divine protection,'' said Mayor Perecles Namorado. The luck ran out Tuesday when Hurricane Diana smashed this city head-on with winds estimated at up to 120 mph, killing at least two people, injuring eight and leaving thousands homeless. Two other fatalities were reported in the Veracruz area to the south. High tides and flooding in Veracruz, Tampico, Tuxpan and elsewhere forced thousands to flee. The U.S. National Hurricane Center near Miami meanwhile reported that a tropical depression gained strength off Africa on Wednesday and headed toward the Azores as tropical storm Edouard. It is the fifth named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season, which runs through the end of November. Tuxpan was cut off from the rest of the world when Hurricane Diana peaked. Telephone lines to the outside were down and radio contact was lost. Mayor Namorado said power was cut, partly to prevent danger from downed power lines, which ran through smashed roof tiles, tree trunks and bent sign boards in the darkened streets. Downed trees surrounded the bandstand in the city's Benito Juarez Plaza. The mayor said more than 4,000 houses in Tuxpan were damaged too badly to occupy. Police Commander Jorge Ramos Mundo said a 12-year-old girl died when a power line fell on her home and a 52-year-old woman was killed by a collapsing wall. Thousands of Tuxpan residents returned home from shelters at daylight Wednesday to find their houses smashed or damaged. ``Everything is drenched,'' moaned Alejandra Castan, whose wood slat house lost its corrugated metal roof. ``We didn't have time to remove anything.'' ``We had confidence in Tuxpan that the hurricanes would never come,'' fisherman Bartolo Gomez said, and then waved toward wrecked houses nearby. ``Roofs began to fly. Trees fell. The lights went. We lost communication.'' Residents said the storm hit twice. In between, for about an hour, Tuxpan was in the eye of the storm. ``It was totally calm. There was no rain. There was no wind. The sun even came out,'' Ramos said.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Backs Multinational Force, Egypt and Morocco Refuse
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout with new material and editing, UPDATES with U.S. approach to Iran, Syria to help, Kuwaiti exile government to attend Cairo meeting, other details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Britain pledged military backing Wednesday for a U.S.-led multinational force to deter Iraqi aggression. West Germany, Italy and Spain offered bases, but Egypt and Morocco _ considered the likeliest Arab participants _ refused to join. Secretary of State James A. Baker III made a surprise announcement that the United States also is turning to Syria and Iran as potential partners to rein in Iraq, though U.S. relations with both have long been hostile. The enmity between Syria and Iraq is possibly surpassed only by that between Iran and Iraq. En route to Turkey, Baker told reporters he was sending an envoy to Syria and confirmed the United States has been in touch with Iran through ``third party contacts.'' British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, responding to a direct appeal from Saudi Arabia's King Fahd as well as U.S. requests, was the only leader to offer ships and planes for the multinational force. Despite leaks by U.S. sources at the Pentagon that Egypt and Morocco were potential members, both countries denied any agreement to participate. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt spurned the U.S.-led multinational force, whose first troops and aircraft landed in Saudi Arabia on Wednesday. But he said Egypt would consider committing troops to an Arab force that would act as a buffer between Iraq and Kuwait. Mubarak will act as host at an emergency Arab summit on Thursday in Cairo to discuss the crisis sparked by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait last Thursday. Saddam proclaimed Wednesday he had annexed Kuwait. Mubarak spokesman Mohammed Abdel-Monein on Wednesday listed the countries that would attend as Saudi Arabia, Syria, Algeria, Djibouti, the United Arab Emirates, Yemen, Libya and Qatar. Egypt's Middle East News Agency also listed Morocco and Jordan. Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi arrived in Egypt Wednesday night. The Kuwaiti news agency Kuna said it was told by Sheikh Sabah Al-Ahmed Al Jaber, deputy prime minister and foreign minister in the exiled Kuwaiti government, that the exiled administration accepted an invitation to attend. Kuna quoted exiled government sources as saying Crown Prince Sheikh Saad Al-Abdullah Alsalim, prime minister in exile, would lead the delegation. ``I am afraid that Iraq will be struck by a harsh strike from the outside,'' Mubarak said in a nationally televised speech. ``The picture I see is black. I call on President Saddam to respond to an Arab umbrella and to withdraw his force.'' Military units of the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council _ Saudi Arabia, Oman, Qatar, Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates and Kuwait _ already are in Saudi Arabia and could become part of the multinational force. The council's force, called ``Peninsula Shield,'' consists of two infantry brigades, one Saudi and one comprising units from the other countries. With an estimated 3,000 troops and 100 U.S.-made tanks, the brigades are currently at Hafr el-Baten in northeast Saudi Arabia. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd offered British military forces, but said it was too soon to say which countries would contribute to the multinational force. ``The essential point is Saddam Hussein now knows an attack on Saudi Arabia, were he to contemplate one, would not be an attack on Saudi Arabia alone,'' Hurd said. Other members of the 16-nation NATO military alliance and the 12-nation European Community appeared to be holding back on military commitments for now. Italy said it agreed to let bases be used to help facilitate transport of troops and equipment and for logistical support, Premier Giulio Andreotti's office announced. Spain, whose Premier Felipe Gonzalez opposes outside intervention in the Persian Gulf, nonetheless agreed to allow the United States to use four jointly operated military bases to support U.S. troops. Bonn signaled readiness to allow the U.S. military to use American facilities in West Germany as a ``basis for operations'' for soldiers headed to Saudi Arabia. West Germany said Tuesday its constitution bars use of German troops outside the country. Greece said nine U.S. support planes were granted permission to pass through Greek airspace on their way to the Persian Gulf. France, which has two ships in the Gulf of Oman and a frigate with Exocet missiles en route, said Wednesday ``no participation is envisaged at this stage'' in the multinational force. The Soviet Union offered no immediate military or moral support, but its silence was seen as a tacit endorsement of the U.S. moves. The Soviets have condemned the Iraqi invasion and pledged their full commitment to the U.N. economic embargo against Baghdad. Chinese Premier Li Peng said in Jakarta, Indonesia, that China would respect Saudi Arabia's decision to allow U.S. troops on its soil. Japan expressed support for the U.S. decision to send troops into Saudi Arabia as a defensive measure.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Forces Dig in to Block Any Iraqi Push Into Saudi Arabia
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS lede, 4th graf: ``About 5,000,'' 6th graf: ``Gov. Jim,'' 8th graf: ``Diplomatic sources,'' to raise higher Marine presence and note second National Guard unit called up. Please note a0756 should have bheen slugged 2nd Ld.
DOC.TEXT: U.S. warplanes and combat troops, backed by an armada of Navy ships, have taken up defensive positions in and near Saudi Arabia, U.S. military officials said Wednesday. Some Air National Guard units were called up for active duty. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney described the deployment as ``a major commitment of U.S. forces'' that included elements of the 82nd Airborne Division and F-15 fighter jets. He declined to provide specifics, citing security concerns. Terming the military situation ``uncertain'' after Iraq President Saddam Hussein's ``act of infamy'' in invading Kuwait, Cheney indicated American forces could be in the region for months. About 5,000 ground troops and more than 100 F-15 fighter planes were ordered to the region, congressional and Pentagon sources reported, and 4,000 Marines were said by diplomatic sources to have been moved close to the Saudi-Kuwait border. Nearly 40 warships and escort vessels _ some armed with sophisticated cruise missiles programmed to destroy specific Iraqi targets _ will be in Mideast waters by next week, the sources said. What was announced in Washington was evidently only part of the story. Reports of other troop movements arrived throughout the day. Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey announced in Trenton that the 170th Air Refueling Group of his state's Air National Guard had been called up. Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York said his state's 105th Military Airlift Group, which flew transport missions in the invasion of Panama, had been called to active duty with his agreement. Rep. John Spratt, D-S.C., said A-10 air-to-ground attack jets from Myrtle Beach Air Force Base had left for Saudi Arabia. Unlike the F-15, an ``air superiority'' fighter designed to tangle with other planes, the A-10 was designed to attack ground targets, and its six-barrelled 30mm anti-tank cannon has been described as the best anti-tank weapon in the world. Diplomatic sources in Saudi Arabia said 4,000 U.S. Marines had been deployed at Khafji, a Saudi oil-terminal town on the border with Kuwait. It was not known where they came from, though Marines had been based at Diego Garcia, the U.S. island bastion in the Indian Ocean about 1,500 miles away. One of the diplomatic sources said the U.S. ground commitment would be 30,000. The movement of troops, ships and planes will take ``several days at least,'' said one Pentagon source early Wednesday evening. This source, speaking on condition of anonymity, noted that most of the 82nd Airborne Division was still in the United States. He did not, however, say how much of the division would be moved to Saudi Arabia. The build-up appeared to be going well without major difficulties, the source said. At present, two aircraft carriers bristling with 80 to 90 aircraft each are within striking distance of Iraqi targets. Another is on the way. ``Our purpose ... is to deter any further Iraqi aggression,'' Cheney said. He said he expected other nations to join the military effort but declined to name any except Britain. ``The mission of the armed forces is to take up defensive positions,'' said Gen. Colin Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Powell expressed confidence American sailors, soldiers and airmen were prepared for battle in the hostile, desert environment if called upon. ``We've trained for it, we've exercised in it,'' he said. And while Iraq's million-man army has been hardened by its eight-year war with Iran, he said, ``They are not invincible. They are not ten feet tall.'' Cheney and Powell briefed a packed room of reporters in the Pentagon, standing in front of a map of the Saudi region that identified some of the major U.S. units that had been deployed, but not all of them. Asked for information on U.S. troop movements or the size of the sudden deployment, Powell replied simply: ``You can be sure that for the mission we have been given we will put in adequate forces.'' Cheney and Powell said the aircraft carrier USS Independence and its support ships have taken up positions just outside the Persian Gulf and the carrier USS Eisenhower is in the Red Sea _ not far from the end point of an Iraqi oil pipeline and within range for the carrier's aircraft and other weapons to engage Iraqi forces. Powell said the troops brought with them protective clothing and medical supplies to be used in the event Iraq uses chemical weapons against the American forces. The briefing came after President Bush delivered a nationally televised address announcing his decision to send U.S. forces into the tense Persian Gulf region. Pentagon sources said the U.S. arsenal will include heavy tanks, dispatched aboard Marine supply ships from the secret U.S. facilities on the Indian Ocean island of Diego Garcia. Other supplies were en route from Guam, in the Pacific, the sources said. The battleship Wisconsin, steaming across the Atlantic with the aircraft carrier Saratoga, had 32 Tomahawk cruise missiles programmed to destroy specific Iraqi targets, sources said. And a second Navy cruiser has been added to the Navy's task force in the Persian Gulf, bringing the number of U.S. ships in the strategic waterway to nine. Powell and Cheney added that the aircraft carrier Eisenhower, accompanied by the warships Scott and Ticonderoga, had gone through the Suez Canal on its way to the scene. Five AWACs, Airborne Warning and Control aircraft, sold to the Saudis in the late 1970s, had been put on station in central Saudi Arabia, they said. Cheney said his discussion with the Saudis on a quick visit earlier this week had also resulted in Bush's waiver of a congressional limit on the transfer of F-15 fighter jets to Saudi Arabia, permitting a dozen of the sophisticated aircraft to be shipped to the kingdom.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Woman Granted Residency After Deportation Case Dropped
DOC.TEXT: A federal immigration judge on Wednesday granted permanent U.S. residency to a Soviet woman who was involved in a highly publicized custody battle with her American husband. After a one-hour hearing, immigration officials agreed to drop efforts to deport Inna Yurevna Carver to the Soviet Union. The U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service in January denied Ms. Carver's request that it waive certain requirements for permanent residence. ``First it was my love and dream to live here,'' Ms. Carver, 27, said after the hearing. ``But I had also burned my bridges with Russia. I feel wonderful _ I love this country.'' Ms. Carver drew attention two years ago when she battled to gain custody of her 14-month-old son, Tristan. The baby and her estranged husband, John Paul Carver, were found in Mexico in 1989, a year after he took the baby. Carver was arrested in Texas in March 1989 and given a one-year deferred sentence last December for abandoning his wife and taking the baby. A psychologist testified during custody proceedings that Carver believed his former wife was involved in Soviet espionage. During Wednesday's testimony, Ms. Carver said the only reason she came to the United States was her love and devotion to Carver. The two met and married in the Soviet Union in 1986. Their son was born there in 1987 before the family moved to Edmond, Okla., later that year. They were divorced in June. She said her reasons for seeking divorce included physical and mental abuse. ``I was never treated like this in my life,'' Ms. Carver said. U.S. Immigration Judge John Duck denied several attempts by INS general counsel James Reynolds to continue the hearing until Carver could be present. Duck said he had reviewed past claims by Carver and found them ``completely uncredible.'' ``I'm not going to give a great bit of weight to what that man says,'' Duck said. Reynolds then agreed to drop the deportation case, and told Ms. Carver's attorney no appeals would be made. Ms. Carver said she will stay in Norman, work toward an education degree at the University of Oklahoma and seek U.S. citizenship. ``I really feel a lot of relief,'' she said. ``I thought it would be a little more vicious.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Interior Minister Wants Weapons Confiscation Deadline Extended
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Interior Minister has recommended that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev extend his Thursday deadline for militants to disarm and disband. Vadim Bakatin told the official news agency Tass Wednesday he was making the suggestion because new leaders have come to power in Armenia, which hosts the country's biggest and most defiant force of militants. Gorbachev, trying to quell ethnic violence that has shaken this multinational country, declared July 26 that militants nationwide have 15 days to turn in their weapons. But many militants, especially those in Armenia which is locked in a territorial dispute with neighboring Azerbaijan, have refused to comply with Gorbachev's decree. More than 200 people have been killed in ethnic clashes between Armenians and Azerbaijanis over control of the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh, which Azerbaijan has held since 1923. Soviet officials have warned that force would be used to confiscate any illegal weapons they can find after the deadline expired. There was no immediate word whether Gorbachev, who is vacationing, had agreed to Bakatin's recommendation. The Interior Minister did not say how long the deadline should be extended. The Communist Party daily Pravda said Wednesday that only a handful of the militants' estimated thousands of weapons have been turned in. ``The appeal to humanness and reason, inherent in the demand to hand over arms and stop bloodshed, did not find support among those who heighten criminal tensions in the country,'' Pravda said. Bakatin said about 1,600 firearms and more than 100,000 rounds of ammunition were voluntarily handed in or confiscated from July 25 through Wednesday. In Armenia, 6,700 firearms, including 1,200 submachine guns, have been stolen this year, Pravda said. The Armenian parliament rejected Gorbachev's order as interference in the republic's internal affairs, and has begun debating an independence declaration. But Bakatin appeared hopeful because of the election of a new president of Armenia. The president, Levon Ter-Petrosyan, arrived in Moscow on Wednesday for two days of talks with Soviet and Russian Federation leaders on the weapons decree and other issues, Tass reported. Bakatin, who met Ter-Petrosyan on Wednesday, told Tass, ``Until recently, republican authorities did not take a constructive attitude. However, there are grounds to maintain that the political situation in the republic is changing. ``Hope has appeared that Armenian authorities can resolve, within a short period and on their own, all tasks concerning ... the stabilization of the socio-political situation in the republic.'' Bakatin said the Interior Ministry consulted with Armenia's new leaders and that they agreed on ``the need to strengthen law and order, protect citizens and rule out the unlawful bearing of arms.'' Ter-Petrosyan, a leader of the Armenian National Movement, told his republic's parliament on Tuesday that Armenia could handle its own problems _ a response to Kremlin threats to send in troops to enforce order if Gorbachev's decree on weapons is ignored. But it was unclear whether he would directly ask the militants to give up their weapons and if he did, whether they would comply. The Soviet Interior Ministry faced a problem with another southern republic, Georgia. Georgian President Givi Gumbaridze told Tass his republic would not enforce Gorbachev's order until the republic's parliamehnt ends its session on Aug. 17.

DOC.HEAD: Producer Cancels `Miss Saigon' After Union Ban on Actor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 7th graf, `The Shubert ...' to UPDATE with comment from actor Jonathan Pryce. Pick up 8th graf, `Mackintosh's action ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LON12
DOC.TEXT: The Broadway production of the hit London musical ``Miss Saigon'' was canceled by its producer Wednesday after an actors' union refused to let a white British actor play the role of a Eurasian. ```Miss Saigon' is dead for this season,'' said Richard Maltby Jr., co-lyricist of the musical. ``It would be hard to crank up again.'' The decision by producer Cameron Mackintosh came after the union's council voted Tuesday to bar English star Jonathan Pryce from repeating his portrayal of an amoral brothel owner. ``The debate is no longer about the casting of `Miss Saigon' but the art of acting itself,'' Mackintosh said in a statement issued on behalf of the show's creative team. The show, which had been scheduled to open in March at the Broadway Theater, is a love story set during the closing days of the Vietnam War. It had an advance ticket sale of more than $25 million, the largest in Broadway history. Mackintosh said the money will be refunded. He said an estimated $600,000 spent on pre-production work for the show has been lost. ``The Shubert Organization has turned down bookings of other productions in order to reserve the Broadway Theater for `Miss Saigon,' and now has incurred a substantial loss as well,'' Mackintosh said. Pryce said he was shocked to learn the union had turned him down for the role. ``Once the shock has worn off, I think I'm going to feel pretty angry about it,'' he said. Mackintosh's action came after the council of Actor's Equity voted on whether Pryce, a respected British performer who has appeared on Broadway twice before, should star in the American production of ``Miss Saigon.'' ``The casting of a Caucasian actor made up to appear Asian is an affront to the Asian community,'' said Alan Eisenberg, the union's executive secretary. Eisenberg said the union's decision was made ``in full awareness that many jobs may be lost to actors of Asian background if the production is canceled.'' ``The issue of lost money was really not a factor in discussions,'' he added. The economic impact could be enormous. The trade newspaper Variety calculated that the New York production of ``Miss Saigon'' alone would have employed about 182 people, including 50 actors and stage managers, 26 musicians and 34 stagehands. The show-business weekly said payroll benefits would total more than $200,000 a week. ``I think Actors' Equity misjudged Cameron Mackintosh,'' Maltby said. ``They didn't understand that if the show wasn't done to Cameron's standards, he just as soon not have it done.'' Mackintosh declined to take the matter to arbitration, a process Equity suggested Tuesday might be the next step. The controversy arose several weeks ago after Actor's Equity received letters of complaint from playwright David Henry Hwang and actor B.D. Wong about the casting of Pryce. ``Ten days ago, I informed Actors' Equity that I would support whatever decision they determined to be in the best interests of their membership,'' Hwang, author of the Broadway hit ``M. Butterfly,'' said Wednesday. ``It has certainly never been my intention to see a show canceled; I simply felt that an important point had to be made, and this has clearly been achieved.''

DOC.HEAD: Indonesia and China Resume Ties after 23 Years
DOC.TEXT: China and Indonesia formally resumed diplomatic relations Wednesday after a 23-year suspension. Indonesia suspended ties in 1967 after accusing Beijing of complicity in a Communist coup attempt two years earlier. China never acknowledged involvement. President Suharto and Chinese Prime Minister Li Peng looked on as their foreign ministers, Ali Alatas of Indonesia and Qian Qichen of China, signed the documents at Merdeka (Freedom) Palace. In a speech at a state dinner honoring Li Tuesday night, Suharto called the signing a milestone that ``marks a new era in the relations of our peoples and nations.'' After the signing, Li stressed that China had no intention to support any underground Coummunists in Indonesia. ``For more than 23 years our relations have been suspended. But now both countries have resumed diplomatic relations and so we are now moving toward developing better understanding and we both agreed to let bygones be bygones,'' Li said. Under terms of the memorandum of understanding signed Wednesday, Indonesia recognizes only one China and that Taiwan is an integral part of China. It says Indonesia maintains only economic and trade relations of a non-governmental nature with Taiwan. The Nationalist Chinese government on Taiwan still claims to be the legitimate government of all China. A trade pact also was signed Wednesday under which the two countries will grant each other most-favored-nation status with respect to customs duties and other taxes.

DOC.HEAD: Americans At Iraqi Hotel Remain Under Armed Guard
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS lede and 2nd graf to raise higher girl's transfer and name: SUBs grafs 10-12 ``Boucher spoke,'' to remove redundancies
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: As President Bush dispatched U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia, Iraq turned over a 10-year-old girl to U.S. diplomats in Baghdad but kept 38 other Americans confined to a hotel under armed guard in what one official described as a ``potentially scary'' situation. The girl, Penelope Nabokov of Albany, Calif., was taken from the hotel to the U.S. embassy by agreement with Iraqi officials, State Department officials said Wednesday night. While the U.S. concern was focused on the Americans sequestered at the Hotel Rashid in Baghdad, the State Department also was worried about the thousands of other Americans in Iraq and in Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. Some Americans reportedly have been the target of threats by Iraqi forces in Kuwait. A week after the Iraqi conquest of Kuwait, with borders in both countries and airports closed, the Americans were still not free to leave. This raised concern in Washington that Iraqi authorities might find them politically useful at a time of escalating military tensions with the Bush administration. The State Department has refused to call them hostages. There are an estimated 3,000 Americans in Kuwait and 400 in Iraq, 100 fewer than previous estimates. Bush told reporters that there had been some encouraging signs concerning the Americans, apparently referring to statements by Iraqi officials that all would be allowed to leave. But none of the statements have proved to be authoritative, and U.S. officials expressed frustration over the their inability to obtain a firm commitment from the Iraqis to allow the Americans to leave. Asked about the status of the 39, State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said, ``Their status is that they cannot leave the hotel grounds, but they have full use of the facility. There are armed guards located at the hotel, but the Americans have not been threatened.'' Boucher spoke before Penelope was moved to the embassy. The girl had been flying alone from her grandmother in France to join her mother in India when she and other passengers on a British Airways plane were caught during a refueling stop by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait last Thursday. One of the officials who disclosed her transfer to the embassy said he did not know where she would go next or when. This official spoke on condition that his name not be used. The top U.S. diplomat in Baghdad, Joseph Wilson, as well as other consular officials, have met with the Americans at the hotel. That group includes the 11 oil workers who were taken from the border region in Kuwait a few days ago, 25 people brought by bus from Kuwait City, and three who were already at the hotel. Boucher said the Iraqis have given contradictory statements concerning the Americans in Iraq and Kuwait. One explanation given for their lack of permission to leave is that the airport and the borders have been closed for security reasons, said one official, asking not to be identified. American envoys also have been told that the granting of exit visas takes time, the official said. As for the reports of Iraqi forces threatening people, Boucher said there is no evidence that Americans or other foreigners are being singled out. ``We're certainly concerned about the incidents which have occurred and we have raised these with the Iraqi government,'' Boucher said. ``We have repeatedly reminded the Iraqi government of their responsibility for the safety of Americans and other foreigners, and we expect the Iraqi government to carry out its pledges to ensure the safety of foreigners and the security of diplomatic premises.'' Bush told reporters that he was concerned about the Americans because of the ``unpredictable'' nature of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. He said protection of American life was ``fundamental to my job and responsibilities as president.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Kills Ex-Wife's Daughter, Shoots Self, Police Say
DOC.TEXT: A man who abducted his ex-wife and her 13-year-old daughter bludgeoned the girl to death, then shot himself in the head when police stormed his home Wednesday, authorities said. Ed Sugg, whose age was unknown, was in critical condition at a Paris hospital, officials there said. His ex-wife, whose name was not released, also was beaten, and was in stable condition with head injuries. Police Chief Karl Louis said Sugg apparently used a baseball bat to beat the woman and her daughter at the woman's Paris home, then took them to his home early Wednesday morning and bound them. ``At one point, the suspect then left to clean up the crime scene _ there was blood all over the woman's home and porch _ and in that time, the woman managed to free herself and escape,'' Louis said. ``She realized her daughter was dead and made her way to a nearby home where she called the sheriff's department,'' he said. Louis said Sugg apparently returned to his home without going back to his ex-wife's home. State, Lamar County and city law-enforcement officers surrounded Sugg's home at mid-morning but got no response from him. A tactical unit stormed the home late in the afternoon, and Sugg fired one shot into his head, Louis said.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit by Former Chicago-Philadelphia Agent Against FBI Settled.
DOC.TEXT: The FBI settled a lawsuit filed against it by a black agent who complained he had been a victim of racial discrimination, the bureau said Wednesday. The FBI statement announcing the agreement did not give details, including whether any payment was made to Donald Rochon, a special agent who sued over alleged discrimination against him in the bureau's Chicago office. In January the FBI settled racial discrimination complaints by two other employees, Leadell Lee, a Chicago agent, and Gertie Armstrong, a clerk in Omaha. Rochon's lawsuit in U.S. District Court in Washington alleged he was the butt of racial jokes and death threats in the Chicago office. Rochon also had worked in Omaha and complained of racial harassment there. That complaint was upheld in administrative proceedings and was not part of the lawsuit. The lawsuit accused FBI supervisors of tolerating racial harassment against Rochon and his family and retaliating against him for complaining. Rochon had been assigned to the Philadelphia office, but the FBI statement Wednesday said part of the settlement provided that he ``will not return to active duty with the FBI.'' It did not say when he left active duty. FBI officials were unable to answer questions about the case Wednesday night. The FBI agreed to settle the case to ``avoid the disruption to the FBI's operations and the drain on its resources which I believe would have resulted from a bitterly contested trial,'' FBI Director William Sessions said in the statement. In January, Rochon's attorney, David Kairys, said his case was strengthened by settlement of the complaints by Lee and Ms. Armstrong.

DOC.HEAD: Security Council Discusses Iraqi Annexation of Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. Security Council on Wednesday night discussed a proposed resolution condemning the Iraqi annexation of Kuwait. The talks followed the council's vote Monday to impose a global embargo on Iraqi products, including its oil. The 15-member council formally denounced the Aug. 2 invasion hours after it began. U.S. Ambassador Thomas Pickering said after Wednesday's closed-door talks that he expects a unanimous vote Thursday to condemn the annexation. ``In the informal consultation, I was impressed by the degree of unanimity,'' Pickering said. ``Everybody in there is ready to go ahead and condemn the annexation.'' Mohammad Abulhasan, Kuwait's U.N. ambassador, called the annexation ``bullying of a whole country by force and annexing it without the will of the people.'' Iraq's U.N. ambassador, Amir al-Anbari, said the annexation was declared at the request of Kuwait's new government, which Iraq installed after its invasion. Al-Anbari said Kuwait's government had asked in a letter to Iraqi officials ``that Iraq and Kuwait merge together into one state.'' The U.N. resolution under consideration declares ``null and void'' the annexation and any other attempts to ``alter the status of Kuwait.'' The proposed measure also calls on all U.N. member nations and international groups ``to refrain from any action or dealings that might be interpreted to be an indirect recognition of the annexation.'' The draft resolution also reaffirms the Security Council's ``determination to bring the invasion and occupation of Kuwait by Iraq to an end and to restore the sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of Kuwait.'' The Security Council is the U.N. body that handles issues relating to international peace and security. Its resolution are legally binding on all U.N. members, although past council resolutions have often been ignored or flouted. The United Nations has no enforcement mechanism.

The deployment of U.S. warplanes and lightly armed Army battalions to Saudi Arabia provides a strategic, but highly risky, toehold against Iraq's menacing million-man army, private military analysts say. The Bush administration said it views the 100,000 Iraqi soldiers near the Saudi border as an ``imminent threat'' to Saudi security after the forces of President Saddam Hussein conquered tiny Kuwait and its vast oil riches last week. Under the Saudi desert lie the largest oil reserves in the world. Military experts interviewed Tuesday said placing American ground forces in Saudi Arabia, even in relatively small numbers, could be the start of a protracted and dangerous U.S. commitment.

The cutoff of oil from Iraq is putting smiles on the faces of those in the struggling U.S. oil industry. Houston, America's energy capital, has been crawling toward recovery after prices plunged in the 1980s. Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and the U.N. embargo on Iraqi oil could speed things up. U.S. oil companies began last year to increase exploration budgets, and new drilling and exploration techniques have brought about regional booms. But a sustained increase in oil prices because of the Persian Gulf crisis could spur domestic drilling and attract investors scared off in the 1980s, observers said. ``There is an air of expectancy,'' said John Faulkinberry, chief financial officer of Paramount Petroleum Co., an oil and gas exploration and production company. ``This one event could really heat things up. It could drive up drilling activity and bring capital back into the industry.''

Andrew Young came up short in his bid to make history as Georgia's first black governor, falling to Lt. Gov. Zell Miller in a Democratic runoff. Kansas Gov. Mike Hayden survived a scare, edging a Republican primary opponent who blamed him for higher property taxes. ``Don't say that I didn't run a good campaign,'' Young, the former Atlanta mayor, congressman and U.N. ambassador, said Tuesday night. ``Say that Zell Miller ran a better campaign.'' With 99 percent of precincts reporting, Miller had 576,226 votes, or 62 percent. Young had 352,159 votes, or 38 percent. In Kansas, Hayden narrowly defeated real estate executive Nestor Weigand Jr., the strongest of five primary challengers. In an upset on the Democratic side, state Treasurer Joan Finney wrecked former Gov. John Carlin's hopes of a comeback.

The gaily painted carousel on the National Mall is still taking tourists on a gentle musical swing through yesteryear, but officials at the Smithsonian Institution's nearby headquarters are bracing for a bumpy financial ride into the future. Anticipating a new era of austerity after a quarter-century of extraordinary expansion, the Smithsonian is delaying the start of several major construction and renovation projects and searching for ways to trim its costly payroll of 6,600 employees. At the moment, Robert McC. Adams, secretary of the Smithsonian, is gratified that a House subcommittee recently voted to boost his federal appropriation next year by nearly 18 percent, from $267 million to $313 million, even more than he had requested. Nevertheless, Adams is worried about ominous portents of a long-term budget squeeze, including economic disruptions from the Persian Gulf crisis and the threat of ``almost unbelievably devastating'' automatic spending cuts in mid-October under the Gramm-Rudman deficit reduction law.

Actors' Equity has barred a white actor from playing a Eurasian in the Broadway musical ``Miss Saigon,'' stirring debate over color-blind casting and minority opportunities on stage. The union Tuesday denied Englishman Jonathan Pryce permission to repeat his award-winning performance as a brothel owner when the London hit comes to New York in March. ``The casting of a Caucasian actor made up to appear Asian is an affront to the Asian community,'' said Alan Eisenberg, the union's executive secretary. Cameron Mackintosh, producer of ``Miss Saigon,'' has threatened to cancel the show, the most anticipated musical of the coming theater season, if Pryce is not allowed to perform. The musical, set in the final days of the Vietnam War, already has a $24 million advance, the largest in Broadway history. Mackintosh was vacationing Tuesday in France and could not be reached for comment, said spokesman Marc Thibodeau.

DOC.HEAD: Watergate Burglar Now Scene-Stealer
DOC.TEXT: In 1972, G. Gordon Liddy played a key role in the Washington production of The Gang That Couldn't Break In Straight. But he has come a long way from that effort, which earned him bad reviews and 52 months in prison for masterminding the break-in at Democratic National Committee's offices at the Watergate Hotel. The former intelligence chief for the committee to re-elect then-president Richard Nixon, Liddy now has become an occasional actor, among other things. He's usually cast as a steely-eyed villain. But he recently finished his first role in comedy _ yes, comedy. It's in a NBC movie for next season that the network says will co-star Sherman Hemsley and be called ``Lights Out'' or ``Camp Cucamonga.''' ``It's a comedy of mistaken identity,'' said Liddy, a former FBI agent with a crisp, precise way of speaking. ``I play a summer camp inspector ...'' His TV series credits include ``Beans Baxter,'' ``MacGyver'' and ``Airwolf,'' and six TV or theatrical movies, including one called ``When Nature Calls.'' Next month, he'll be seen as an archvillain named Satori in the two-hour premiere of ``Super Force,'' a futuristic police series syndicated to 160 stations. He doesn't know if he'll be a recurring character in it. Liddy, whom Robert Conrad once played in an NBC movie about Liddy's arrest, conviction and time in prison, made his acting debut in 1985. He played Capt. Real Estate, an industrial-strength villain on NBC's ``Miami Vice.'' He originally was to be killed, he said, but the ending was ordered changed and he survived even the second episode. Acting was not a quantum leap in a different direction, he said: ``You've got to remember, I once was a trial lawyer. I haven't met a trial lawyer who was any good who wasn't also something of an actor.'' He speaks truth. Fred Thompson, former minority counsel for the Senate Watergate committee, also now emotes, most recently in ``Days of Thunder'' and ``Die Hard 2.'' Such is Hollywood that Liddy and Thompson even were on the same side of the law as FBI agents in the recent movie, ``Feds.'' Did they talk between scenes about old Watergate times? ``No, that's ancient history,'' said Liddy, who now is 59. ``And we've all gone on to so many different things.'' In his case, different things have included nightclub debates on life and such with the likes of Timothy Leary, the ex-professor with the acid wit, and Hunter S. Thompson, the only national affairs analyst in America who doesn't appear on ``Washington Week in Review.'' This year, there was to be ``The Liddy Show,'' a syndicated debate show. Alas, it didn't pan out. But there still is Miami-based G. Gordon Liddy & Associates, a private investigation and guard company. Liddy also still lectures on security. His second novel,``The Monkey Handlers,'' a new action-adventure novel, is due out in October. And he soon will write a column about home-and-office security as a contributing editor for Forbes' ``FYI,'' a new quarterly magazine that will make its debut in September. Yes, it's his debut in journalism. He sardonically advises those in that line of lunacy: ``I'm starting to break you guys' rice bowl. You made a living off me for so long I figured, what the hell...'' Liddy, whose post-Watergate activities have yielded enough for him to buy hia Maryland home facing the Potomac River and a winter home in Arizona, is unrepentant, defiantly so, about the break-in that made him famous. He has no regrets about the Watergate caper in which Nixon repeatedly has denied any involvement. ``Let me put it this way,'' Liddy said. ``I did that for Nixon. I had fun doing it. I'd do it again for (president) Bush if he called.'' __ Elsewhere in television... NBC PUMPS TWICE: NBC has said it will ``double pump'' the premiere episodes of six new series, or show them twice before the new season officially starts on Sept. 17. Now, NBC is getting down to cases. It says three pumpees, ``Hull High,'' ``Parenthood'' and ``Lifestories,'' will get their first showing on Aug. 20, then again on different nights before their official premiere. ``Working It Out'' will be pumped first on Aug. 22, ``Ferris Bueller'' on the next night, and ``Law and Order'' on Sept. 13. Each also will have another pre-premiere shot later on, ``Law and Order'' on Sept. 27 at 11:30 p.m. EDT. Three other newcomers, ``Fresh Prince of Bel Air,'' ``American Dreamer'' and ``The Fanelli Boys'' get a single-pump preview between Sept. 8 and Sept. 20. When will these series officially premiere? NBC, obviously trying to keep the excitement going, says this will be announced later. End Adv PM Thurs Aug.9

DOC.HEAD: Quayle's Latin American Trips Are Better Than Funeral Duty
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Vice presidents sometimes wind up on funeral duty, but so far, Dan Quayle's specialty has been presidential inaugurations _ openings, not endings. Maybe it reflects the generation gap. Quayle, 43, represented the United States on Tuesday at the inauguration of Cesar Gaviria, 43, as president of Colombia. ``I am here for his inauguration to show the strong importance that the United States places on our continuing partnership with Colombia,'' Quayle said. Change the country and the theme can work most anywhere. In 18 months, Quayle has been at the inaugurations of six newly elected leaders in Latin America. All of them won free elections, on a continent once dotted with dictatorships. Most are youthful, a new generation of Latin leadership. That prompted Quayle to remark in a Dallas speech that his Latin American travels sometimes made him feel like an elder statesman. His still-sagging approval ratings in the public opinion polls don't make him look like one at home. Quayle is returning to Washington tonight from Colombia, Peru, Bolivia and Haiti, the stops on his seventh vice presidential trip to Latin America and the Caribbean. Those travels have taken him to 17 Latin nations, among 29 he has visited as vice president. His inaugural contacts sometimes prove valuable. In Bogota, he met again with President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela, whose second inauguration Quayle attended just after his own. They crossed paths at two other inaugurals since. At the Venezuelan Embassy in Bogota, Perez told Quayle on Tuesday that he would do everything he could with Venezuelan oil and other OPEC producers to make up the shortfall left by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. The emphasis on Central and South America wasn't designed for Quayle; he was no specialist, and he does not speak Spanish. It took shape trip by trip as events required high-level U.S. representation. At a time of upheaval in eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, the president and the secretary of state were focused elsewhere. They still are. Quayle left a U.S. capital gripped by the Persian Gulf crisis, to fly to Bogota in a show of support for Colombia's strong stand against the cocaine cartel and against drug terrorists. And Bush had just postponed indefinitely a five-nation South American trip of his own in mid-September. It was called off because of budget deficit negotiations and other business at home. So Quayle has become the administration's point man in Latin America. ``It's not a spectacular assignment, but it is a valuable one for the administration,'' said his spokesman, David Beckwith. The low profile was evident when Quayle visited Bogota and spent nearly three hours at an outdoor inauguration in a plaza by the national Congress building. Before Bush went into Cartagena, Colombia, under heavy military guard for the Feb. 15 drug summit at an isolated naval base, he said he wasn't doing anything ``stupid or macho.'' Quayle's appearance in Bogota obviously carried greater risks, but nobody made much of it. He was there for about eight hours, touchdown to takeoff Tuesday night, in a capital that has seen violence lthough drug terrorism has centered elsewhere. The vice president's Latin American missions clearly have been a plus, although it's not the kind of work likely to repair his domestic political image. More people probably associate his travels with the false story _ that he'd said he wished his knowledge of Latin was better _ than with the favorable reviews he has drawn, even from some Democrats. And it certainly beats funeral assignments. Quayle represented the government at one, in Central America. As vice president, Bush led U.S. delegations to the funerals of six foreign leaders, three of them in Moscow. Bush made the count seem higher with periodic bits of funereal humor. ``You die, we fly,'' he said. He also said that the funerals were useful. ``You do get to meet firsthand these leaders and form a close personal relationship,'' he said at one dinner during his vice presidential days. ``Many of these dead leaders have stayed in touch over the years. ``It's known as quiet diplomacy.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: A Recession Caused By The Fed
DOC.TEXT: Millions of words have been written and spoken in praise of the Federal Reserve's determination to conquer inflation and save the American economy from destruction. Those words are wasted on Richard Rahn. Though generally not outspoken, economist Rahn has declared himself forcefully on the subject, testifying before Congress that the central bank is inflation's cause, not its cure. ``The central bank, and only the central bank, causes inflation,'' he told Congress earlier this summer. Rahn commented then that governors of the Federal Reserve were political appointees who acted secretly and without accountability to anyone. He accused them of vagueness and even of misinformation. Now he accuses them of another economic crime, that of commiting the economy to recession. While the recession might not have begun yet, Rahn says it will be evident by the final quarter of this year and the first of 1991. While some economists can be dismissed as publicity seekers _ being in the public eye is essential these days for an economist seeking the big money _ Rahn must be listened to. He speaks for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. In his role as chief economist and vice president of that organization, Rahn has watched as the Fed's tight money policy squeezed small businesses, which the chamber has courted in recent years. Some of those businesses that are being starved for credit, supporters of Fed policy have argued, are speculative enterprises, often in real estate or construction, that should be allowed to die. But other small companies are the opposite. They are innovative. They have good products, markets and management. Today, their ideas and products keep the big companies alert. Tomorrow, they are themselves big companies. Many of these young companies also are being denied credit, in part at least because of tight Fed policies. The Fed, he said, has left no margin for error in aggressively pursuing its goal of inflation control, mistakenly assuming that economic growth somehow produces inflation, when the real reasons lie elsewhere. Rahn explained his thesis in his congressional testimony, during which he stated that the nation has a fiat money system controlled by government and outside the control of the rule of law. Government, he said, retains monopoly control of money simply by spending it _ and then compelling the Fed to accommodate the spending by manipulating the money supply to keep that spending from creating inflation. The Fed does this, in part, by cracking down on the economy and limiting its ability to grow, the rationale being that private-sector growth atop the already heavy burden of government spending might strain economic capacity. In Rahn's view, the effort is futile. He said ``as long as the government maintains a monopoly over money and relies on an unaccountable, government central bank to manage that monoply, inflation will persist.'' In an effort to accommodate government and its spending proclivities, he said, the Fed ``whipsaws the economy between inflation and recession,'' rather than pursuing a long-term policy consistent with stable economic growth. In the first instance, inflation, the Fed enlarges the money supply to avert inflation. In the second, Rahn suggests, it overreacts to its own policy and cracks down with tight credit, putting the economy into a tailspin. Get government spending in line, and open up the Fed's activities to greater scrutiny, says Rahn. Require that Fed policy be set and implemented in public. And if recession does come, as he forecasts, don't swallow the explanation that it was caused by Iraqi adventurism in the Middle East. Blame it on bad economic policy, he says.

DOC.HEAD: Mideast Turmoil Lifts Oil, Gold Funds; But Experts Say Sit Tight
DOC.TEXT: The Persian Gulf crisis has bruised stock and bond prices, raised most interest rates, and renewed fears of both a recession and higher inflation from a possibly explosive rise in oil prices. What should the average investor do? ``Sit tight and see what happens in a few days. The time to make decisions is when the markets are quiet, not when they're crazy,'' says Jay Goldinger, an investment counselor and principal of Capital Insight Inc. of Beverly Hills, Calif. Many other financial planners and strategists are saying the same thing to clients _ apparently over and over again _ as they report a steady rise in customer calls. So far, most individual investors seem to be heeding that advice. Although the stock and bond markets have fallen sharply since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait by Iraq, mutual fund managers say that haven't seen a mass exodus of money from their funds, which move in tandem with the markets. Some are even reporting buying interest among a few bargain-hunting investors. Not surprisingly, fund managers say interest has been particularly acute in the 52 inflation-pegged gold and natural resources stock funds traded in the United States, as their rates of return rise with the tensions in the Persian Gulf. But some experts caution investors against shifting their money there. ``It may be a little late,'' said Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services Inc. in New York, which regularly tracks mutual funds. Lipper said only the most nimble of investors who are betting that oil prices will continue to increase might want to consider moving in, then quickly cashing out. ``But if that's their approach, I don't think funds are the right way for them to go,'' he said, noting that most fund investors are usually in it for the long haul. The Iraqi-Kuwait conflict has pushed up crude oil prices by more than 25 percent to levels not seen since the mid-1980s. That, in turn, helped depress stock and bond prices and pushed up interest rates as the markets worried about rising inflation and a recession. During the week of the invasion, natural resource funds, most of which are oil based, had a 3.19 percent rise in the average rate of return, while gold-related funds were up on average 3.89 percent, according to Lipper. At the same time, general equity funds were down 2.04 percent, he said. Fidelity Investments in Boston said its four main gold- or energy-related funds remain standouts among its more than 180 funds, with rates of return between nearly 4 percent to nearly 6 percent higher in just one week. David McLaughlin, a financial adviser with Chase Investment Counsel in Charlottesville, Va., said investors considering buying into these funds, as well as related individual stocks, should do so as a hedge against inflation, not as a change in strategy. Even then, he advises: ``Don't buy your whole position all at once. Buy a little bit now and wait and see.'' McLaughlin said now may be the time to pick up some high-quality stocks of companies that can withstand economic changes. Consumer products and media stocks, for example, would fit that category. Goldinger recommends that those with extra cash consider Treasury bills and notes with maturities of two years of less. Because money is locked in for a shorter time these securities are less susceptible to higher inflation and market volatility. These days short-term securities are offering rates that are highly competitive to those of longer-term bonds, which earlier this week sustained their biggest selloff in nearly three years. The yield on the two-year Treasury note, for instance, stood at 7.98 percent on Wednesday, while the 30-year bond yielded 8.81 percent. Bank certificates of deposit and money market accounts also offer similar short-term protection. But banks have been lowering CD and money market rates, according the most recent random check by the North Palm Beach, Fla., publication Bank Rate Monitor.

DOC.HEAD: A Little Bit of Soul
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Stay out of the music scene for four years and look what happens. British soul stylist Paul Young can tell you all about it. After his third album, ``Between Two Fires,'' ran its course in 1986, he slowed down to start a family. He then took two more years to put together his latest album, ``Other Voices.'' While he was gone, the Motown sound returned to the charts with blue-eyed soul singers and fellow Brits at the helm: George Michael, Simply Red and Lisa Stansfield. Young returned just in time. ``People could say I've been away long enough to be forgotten,'' he said in an interview. ``In some territories, it is long enough to be forgotten, but in other territories, it's been a break, and that's not such a bad thing.'' Young began ``Other Voices'' with the same staff he had used on his three previous albums, but was unsatisfied with the results. Six months' work, as he said, went ``down the pan.'' So he started anew. He brought in plenty of guest musicians _ Pink Floyd's David Gilmour on guitar, singer Chaka Khan on backing vocals and Stevie Wonder on harmonica. Nile Rodgers produced a track, and two more were done with former J. Geils Band leader Peter Wolf. But Young still felt he had to get back to his roots in Britain and did some recording there as well. ``Working with Peter, I was coming up with music that was very different from what I'd done before, much more American,'' he said. ``My biggest audience is in Europe and I can't ignore that.'' ``Other Voices'' is filled with material by other artists, including covers of the Chi-Lites' ``Oh Girl'' and Free's ``A Little Bit of Love.'' Young sees doing these songs as a way of distancing himself from his own material. ``I'd like to forget that I wrote them and approach them as an arranger and then I could probably enjoy it more,'' he said. ``But underneath it, there's always my song and so I see it one particular way. That somehow stops me from doing certain things. ``With other songs, I've heard them one way, I see them another way, so straightaway, I've got this choice of things I can do with it and I think that makes it more enjoyable.'' He also sees doing covers as a way to keep great old songs alive, but likes to look for the less well-known standards. ``I tend to prefer finding songs that are little gems in the dust, as it were, and making them out to be something special, because maybe they (the audience) missed it the first time 'round,'' he said. ``I don't like a lot of music that loses track of its roots. I hope that what I'm doing when I do these things is keeping the old stuff in their minds, but keeping up to date in terms of how I work the arrangements, what instruments I use, stuff like that.'' On ``Other Voices,'' Young said he went back to ``playing a lot of stuff live again and not using too much machinery. I think the trick is to use the machinery but still make it sound very human.'' Songwriting is not his forte, he said, but he's looking to change that. ``I think I was working with a guy who also found it very hard to be a songwriter and that made it even more difficult,'' he said. ``So now I've made some contacts with people who actually enjoy the process of being stuck in a room for eight hours, which I don't find in the least bit inviting.'' Young's solo career began in 1982 after 3{ years with the soul outfit the Q-Tips. His first break came in 1983 with a version of the Marvin Gaye classic, ``Wherever I Lay My Hat,'' which stayed at No. 1 in England for three weeks. His debut album, ``No Parlez,'' also reached the top of the charts there. His long-awaited U.S. success came with the Top 20 song, ``Come Back and Stay,'' also from ``No Parlez.'' But his second album, ``The Secret of Association,'' released in 1985, contained his first U.S. No. 1 hit _ ``Everytime You Go Away,'' written by Daryl Hall of Hall and Oates. He doesn't necessarily see ``Other Voices'' as a progression, but rather a beginning of new things. ``I think I've now built myself another little base to work from,'' he said. ``It's a pretty good mixture of what the last three albums had done and it's now on one album. There's quite a few indications of ways I could go.''
