DOC.TEXT: Southern Baptist moderates have called a national meeting Aug 23-25 to consider what to do about the fundamentalist wing gaining full-scale control of the denomination. The gathering in Atlanta was called to explore ways to uphold principles that differ with the new fundamentalist directions and to consider alternate means for channeling giving to missions. ``I think we are ripe for God to use us in creating something new and visionary and historic,'' said the Rev. Daniel Vestal of Dunwoody, Ga., the moderates' defeated candidate in June for the denominational presidency. That victory by fundamentalists for the 12th year in a row completed their gradual solidifying of control over agencies of the 14.9-million-member denomination. A Houston-based moderate organization, Baptists Committed, and Dunwoody called the Atlanta meeting as a growing number of congregations across the country planned limits on giving to the denomination's cooperative budget. Moderate discontent was intensified by the recent firing of the top editors of the denomination's news agency, Baptist Press. Indicating moderates have given up regaining influence over the denomination, Vestal said they don't plan to enter a presidential candidate in 1991.

A gathering of Evangelical Lutheran Church in America clergywomen marked the 20th anniversary of Lutheranism's 1970 admission of women to ordination. The denomination now has 1,198 women among its 17,253 clergy.

A United Methodist missionary from embattled Liberia voiced dismay that the United States failed to send in troops to prevent the massacre in St. Peter's Lutheran Church in Monrovia, Liberia's capital. ``With 10 Marines, they could have guarded this church,'' the Rev. William Warnock said of the slaughter July 30 by Liberian government troops. As many as 600 adults and children were killed, reports said. Referring to the conflict there between rebels and the Liberian regime, from which U.S. Marines later brought out some Americans, Warnock added, ``Both sides respect the U.S. government and the Marines.'' He said the Lutheran church and Nagbe United Methodist Church across the street were among centers giving sanctuary to civilian refugees from the fighting under auspices of the International Red Cross.

Jews for Jesus, which has conducted month-long street campaigns in New York each summer for the past 15 years, says its campaign this time got bigger results than ever before. ``The spiritual receptivity quotient has shot way up,'' said Tuvya Zaretsky, campaign leader. He said there were l,2l2 converts and 2,798 others interested, compared with 568 converts last summer and fewer before. He added: ``It's been like knocking your head against the wall and, surprise, the wall begins to crumble.''

Rsponding to the dramatic changes in Eastern Europe, Roman Catholic bishops are sending fact-finding, goodwill delegations to that area, renewing ties and checking on ways to help. Archbishop Daniel E. Pilarczyk of Cincinnati said three delegations will fan out to various parts of Eastern and Central Europe to ascertain needs and coordinate aid efforts. ``These delegations represent the first major step in what the bishops envision as a substantial program of aid by American Catholics to the long-suffering church in those countries. ``Equally important, the delegations will be a key part of a process of renewing and deepening bonds of solidarity ... bonds that had been broken or severely weakened in the past decades due to government interference.'' One deligation, led by Archbishop Roger M. Mahony of Los Angeles, visits Hungary, Romania and Bulgaria Aug. 1-ll. Another, led by Archbishop Theodore E. McCarrick of Newark, N.J., visits Poland, Czechoslovakia and Yugoslavia Aug. 18-30. A third, led by Cardinal Joseph Bernardin of Chicago and Archbishop John L. May of St. Louis, visits the Soviet Union Aug. 27 to Sept. 6.

DOC.HEAD: Clear Purpose Counts More Than Money in Bettering Schools
DOC.TEXT: More money, often singled out as the key to improving schools, apparently in itself doesn't do the job. That's the conclusion of two different recent studies, one secular, the other religious. They say cohesive purpose, less centralized bureacracy and parental choice are what count. ``When it comes to education, money is not the panacea many politicians and educators would have us believe,'' says Brother Robert Kealey, chief researcher for a study by the National Catholic Educational Association. ``Placing more trust in teachers and parents is the key.'' This also is the general thrust of a recent study by the Brookings Institution of Washington, D.C., in calling for a reformed system open to parental choice of schools and competition among them. ``Money is not what makes some schools more effective than others,'' says the study, contending that reduced bureaucratic constraints and more freedom in decision-making about instruction and discipline are what gets better results. The book-long study, ``Politics, Markets and America's Schools,'' by John Chubb, a Brookings fellow, and Terry Moe, a Stanford University political scientist, says the U.S. education system is hobbled by topheavy regulations. ``Private schools _ which outperform public schools, on the average _ also tend to spend less than the public schools do in educating their students,'' the study says. ``They get better schools for less money.'' That _ with figures to back it up _ also is the contention of a study by the NCEA, which compares consolidated financial figures from U.S. Catholic elementary schools and from the National Center for Education Statistics. They show that the Catholic schools spent $1.476 per pupil in 1988-89, less than one half the $3,977 per-pupil cost for public school students in the 1986-87 academic year, the latest overall statistics available. ``The econmomies in the Catholic school network are related most directly to the leadership responsibility placed in the hands of Catholic school principals and teachers,'' says Sister Catherine T. McNamee, NCEA president. ``Their empowerment _ and their success _ precludes the need for high administrative costs.'' Previous studies have found that Catholic school students outperform their public school counterparts in reading, mathematics and science tests. The costs comparisons were based on data from 907 Catholic schools representing more than 12 percent of all U.S. Catholic elementary schools and from national composites on public schools. Kealey, executive director of the NCEA's elementary and secondary school department, said the findings correspond with those of the Brookings Institution _ that greater expenditures don't insure more effectiveness. The NCEA, noting that Catholic parents pay school taxes just as do parents of students in public schools, advocates tax credits to parents that would foster choice and competition among schools, ``The competitive spirit will engender excellence and initiative _ keys to educational success,'' Sister McNamee says. The Brookings study recommends a similar approach to financing in the form of scholarships. It says the present public system is ``fundamentally flawed,'' that ``America's children are not learning enough, they are not learning the right things, and most debilitating of all, they are not learning how to learn.'' The study says private schools tend to be more effective because they are not burdened by the bureaucracy and politics surrounding U.S. public schools and their greater responsibility for decisions makes for clearer purpose. ``The more school decision-making is constrained to superintendents, district offices, unions and the rules and regulations they promulgate, the less effective the school organization is likely to be,'' the study says. ``Extensive, top-down control of schools is simply inconsistent with the development at the school site of leadership and teacher professionalism.'' The Catholic report says the present average tuition costs in Catholic schools is $924 annually, with the difference between that and per pupil expenditure of $1,476 coming from parish or diocesan subsidies. Sister McNamee says parents of Catholic elementary students last year provided ``a financial gift to the nation of almost $8 billion'' _ the costs of 7,500 schools in which about 2 million students were enrolled. The study notes the Catholic schools are seeking added sources of income, such as endowment or development funds, and need to improve salaries and benefits for teachers. Catholic school teachers make an average $16,000 annually while public school teachers make about $27,000, the study says. It says public elementary school principals make about $44,000 while Catholic school princiapls average about $26,000.

DOC.HEAD: Purge of Officer Corps Main Obstacle to Peace
DOC.TEXT: Disagreement by the two sides over whether to kick dozens of allegedly corrupt officers out of the army could push El Salvador into another round of civil war. On July 26, government and rebel negotiators ended a third session of monthly U.N.-mediated peace talks with an accord on human rights. They are to meet again Friday in San Jose, Costa Rica. July's agreements skirted armed forces reform, the main item on the peace agenda and the key to ending a decade-long war that has killed an estimated 72,000 people, most of them civilians. Salvadorans, barely recovered from the bloody rebel offensive of November 1989, are waiting for the other shoe, a combat boot they expect will crash down in the next few weeks. Leftist rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, known as the FMLN, have warned of another major attack unless the government agrees to steps toward ``demilitarization.'' Acrimonious debate of the military's role has occupied more than 90 percent of the negotiating time and produced only cosmetic changes in positions, with no agreement. Each side accuses the other of intransigence. The army has been on alert since early July. Soldiers with assault rifles are everywhere on downtown and suburban streets, patrolling or manning roadblocks. Forced recruitment of young men has increased. Soldiers routinely stop intercity buses to induct those who cannot prove they have served already. Last month, citizens frightened by rumors of an imminent guerrilla offensive stocked up on beans, a staple of the Salvadoran diet, driving up the price. Seven points are on the peace agenda, but both sides agree the only really sticky one is what to do about the army. El Salvador has held periodic elections since 1982 and tried to consolidate some democratic institutions, but the military retains tremendous influence. The main obstacle to an armistice that would disband the FMLN is the dispute over the rebels' insistence that the high command be purged of officers they accuse of corruption and abusing human rights. The government and armed forces say that would amount to interference with the military. Oscar Santamaria, the chief government negotiator, said in an interview: ``The FMLN position appears designed to cripple the armed forces rather than to change or reform them,'' President Alfredo Cristiani's rightist government has proposed letting the armed forces police themselves. The rebels say history shows the army cannot be trusted to do that. Despite evidence implicating the military in torture, disappearances and thousands of murders, no officer has been convicted of a crime involving the politically motivated abuse of human rights. ``They are saying, `Trust us. We're going to be good from now on,''' said Schafik Handal, a guerrilla commander and the chief rebel negotiator. ``If we lay down our arms before agreeing on a purge and an end to military impunity, there would be another bloodbath like that of the early 1980s.'' Guerrilla demands for a purge and a drastic reduction in the army's numerical strength have struck a chord in a people who traditionally view the army with a mixture of fear and contempt. ``Chafarote,'' the popular term for soldier, is a combination of words meaning falseness and filth. ``I don't like the guerrillas, but I completely agree with their demand for a purge and demilitarization,'' said the owner of a tile factory. ``The military has been a scourge for this country.'' As often happens in this violent nation, he asked that his name not be used. Sen. Christopher Dodd, a Connecticut Democrat who follows Central American affairs closely, said in July that 40 to 50 Salvadoran officers should be retired early or otherwise removed. Guerrilla spokesmen talk of purging 200 officers, but that is seen as a negotiating figure subject to change. The rebels demand only removal, not trials and punishment. Col. Mauricio Vargas, a brigade commander and member of the government negotiating team, agreed that the military could benefit from a change in its upper echelons, but said the process must be gradual and internal. He said in an interview that about 10 top officers could be removed in the next year, but that a more drastic housecleaning would irreparably damage the command structure. The United States provides about $1 million a day in economic and military aid to El Salvador. Earlier this year, the State Department and U.S. Embassy appeared to be seeking some sort of military shakeup, but recent comments indicate Washington has eased the pressure.

DOC.HEAD: Old Names Coming Back, Maybe Even St. Petersburg
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Citizens of Tver and dozens of other Soviet cities are casting off the names and symbols of a painful past. The people of this ancient city 100 miles northwest of Moscow started by taking back the name it bore for centuries before Stalin called it Kalinin, for a henchman born near Tver. To Catherine the Great, the city was ``the most beautiful in the empire'' after St. Petersburg, now Leningrad, because of its 18th century architecture. As the namesake of Mikhail Kalinin, it became a reminder of repression and death. Gorky Street in Moscow, the capital's main thoroughfare, has been changed back to Tverskaya Street. Fashionable shops and stores lined the street before the Bolshevik revolution, and outside the city it became the main road to Tver. On July 19, the front page of Kalininskaya Pravda, the local newspaper, carried a decree signed by Boris N. Yeltsin, president of the Russian republic. It said the republic's Presidium ``decrees: Rename the city Kalinin to the city Tver.'' Yeltsin had reversed half a century and fulfilled a dream of many residents. A poem published with the decree said: ``Well, goodbye Kalinin. You were just a pseudonym of our returning Tver.'' Now, even the newspaper will have to call itself something else. The name game is sweeping this vast country. For decades, cities, streets, ships, farms and factories were renamed for Bolshevik heroes and officials. Then, as political times changed under Mikhail S. Gorbachev and history was rewritten, some of the officials were disgraced and the circle was completed. Naberezhni Chelny, renamed Brezhnev, was returned to its original name. Tsaritsyn, renamed Stalingrad, became Volgograd. Other name changes actual or likely include the emergence of old Samara from Kuibyshev, Nizhny Novgorod from Gorky; transformation of Kirov to Vzyatka, Sverdlovsk to old Ekaterinburg, Andropov to Rybinsk; the rescue of Marnupol from Zhdanov, Lugansk from Voroshilovgrad and Vladikavkaz from Ordzhonikidze. Some people who are fed up with the old order even want to change Leningrad back to St. Petersburg. The name of Mikhail Kalinin, the Soviet president in 1938-1946, was attached to many places other than Tver, which became Kalinin on his birthday in 1931. Koenigsberg, a historic German city incorporated into the Soviet Union at the end of World War II, became Kaliningrad. Major streets in other Soviet cities, including Moscow, honor Kalinin. He was a figurehead president hated by victims of the collectivization of agriculture, a dark period in the country's history. Millions of people were arrested and executed as ``enemies of the people''' during the collectivization of the 1930s, including many from Kalinin's home region. Some of the bodies are believed to have been dumped into mass, unmarked graves near Tver. The campaign to regain Kalinin's old name began in the 1960s, but did not get far until Gorbachev and glasnost came along. Eleven engineers and intellectuals founded a group called Return in March 1988 with that as its goal. Boris Yershov, a leader of the group and a local legislator, said Return's members were described at first as ``extremists, sometimes as hooligans.'' People asked, ```How could you insult the memory of Mikhail Kalinin, a leading figure in the party, government and society?''' Yershov said. ``When we said he wasn't a leading figure of the party and the government, people just didn't believe us. People were so fooled by the propaganda ... for years, for decades, about our leaders, they just didn't accept our words.'' Support for Return gradually increased, Yershov said, and people began asking: ``If Kalinin is not the person he's made out to be, why do we bear his name? Why such a supreme honor to a person who promoted Stalin's crimes?'' More than 14,000 of the city's 475,000 people signed a petition last year demanding it be called Tver again. Local party and legislative bodies eventually gave their support and the idea was ratified by Yeltsin, a radical reformer elected president of Russia, the country's largest republic, in June. Residents interviewed the day Yeltsin's decree was published said the move was welcome but they also wanted other changes. ``I'm not in a festive mood,'' said Natalya Drozdenko, a woman in her mid-30s waiting in a long line to buy chickens. ``It's only right to change the name and we have been struggling for it, lending our signatures to petitions, etcetera, but somehow I understand it's only symbolic and it won't affect our well-being.'' Alexander Bartyenyev, an 84-year-old World War II veteran strolling past the shops, remembers when the city was still called Tver and said Mikhail Kalinin never deserved the honor. ``Kalinin was treated as one of our own,'' Bartyenyev said. ``He was born here and worked here, but as president of the country, he could not stop the blood-letting.'' Yershov said his organization now would turn its attention to restoring monuments, churches and the old street names.

DOC.HEAD: Infiniti M30: Capable but Unpretentious Hybrid
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Infiniti. The name connotes luxury, distinctive ride, smooth, impressive power. Indeed, the Infiniti division flagship, the Q45 luxury sedan, provides all that and more. The 1990 Infiniti M30 two-door coupe _ the littler sibling _ is different, however. This makeover of the rear-drive Nissan Leopard, a model that Nissan has sold in Japan since the 1987 model year, is a hybrid composed of an admirable suspension system, an adequate powerplant, and a rather non-distinctive exterior. The result is a capable but unpretentious car that may be proving difficult for consumers to differentiate in the market _ even with the Infiniti badge it carries. The best part of the M30 is its handling on twisting country roads. A unique sonar device mounted under the radiator senses the coming contours of the pavement, plugs that data into an electronic brain that monitors speed, body sway and other factors, and quickly adjusts the car's suspension to give the driver maximum control. The driver also can select, from a button on the center console inside the car, whether to drive in ``sport'' or ``comfort'' mode. The ``comfort'' setting had a tad mushier feel than the ``sport'' mode but helped cushion road bumps. The M30 features MacPherson struts in the front and semi-trailing suspension arms in the back. Stabilizer bars are at both front and back of the car to aid cornering. The 3-liter V-6 is similar to the powerplant in Nissan's Maxima and can deliver 162 horsepower at 5,200 rpm. With four-speed automatic transmission, it moves the 3,300-pound M30 from 0-60 mph in 9.7 seconds. Compared with the refined yet exciting 278-horsepower of the Q45, where the car's tires never screeched, the M30 would pull aggressively as it went through the shift points during fast accelerations. And the large tires _ Dunlop P215-60HR15 sport all-season radials _ squealed a couple times as they worked to grab the road. Outside, the Infiniti M30 looked similar to a Honda and had minimal chrome. Even the Infiniti logo lacked the lacy, ornate design of the Q45 badge. Still, the car was well appointed. Leather interior, power windows, power door locks, sunroof, anti-theft system, air conditioning and antilock brakes are standard. The M30 trunk was a roomy 11.6 cubic feet, though you have to lift items up and over the car body. Rear seating was OK for two adults, with the front seats pushed up a ways. My knees were shoved into the netted map holders on the backs of the front seats when those seats were pushed back all the way. I had to slouch if I sat in the middle of the rear seat to keep my head from hitting the roof, and there I also had to contend with the rear-drive hump in the middle of the rear floor. The M30 fit and finish was good, save for a small, plastic cover that fell off the metal lever that activated the driver's power seat. The Bose sound system included dual radio controls: one located on the radio at the center of the dashboard and a second set on the dash behind the steering wheel for an easier reach for the driver. Infiniti spokeswoman Laura Fox said competitors include BMWs and Mercedes autos. The M30's $23,500 base price compares with a $24,650 base price for the BMW 325 two-door and a $31,600 price for the lowest-priced Mercedes. Early buyers of the M30 average 44 years of age, with household income of $96,000. Fifty-seven percent were men, Fox said, adding that most are married and are college educated. To bolster overall Infiniti division sales, the Q45 and M30 will be joined this fall by a new Infiniti, the G20 sedan, which is to be priced under $20,000. Because the M30 is a new vehicle, Consumer Reports magazine does not list owner complaints.

DOC.HEAD: California's Big Green Triggers Flashing Red Lights Among Critics
DOC.TEXT: Critics of the so-called Big Green initiative that Californians will vote on this fall say its restrictions on agricultural chemicals probably would mean the end of civilization. That is an exaggeration, of course. But there is alarm among some farm groups, chemical companies and consumer watchers. And it's not just in California, says an Agriculture Department report. If Big Green is approved, it would ban the use of chemicals that are suspected of causing cancer or birth defects. Overall, some estimates indicate 70 percent of the pesticides now used in California would be banned within two to eight years. Shannon Reid Hamm of the department's Economic Research Service said fruit and vegetable farmers ``may be left out in the cold if the initiative becomes law.'' Chemical manufacturers, faced with high costs of research and development, would be less inclined to develop new chemical alternatives for one state _ even when that state is California with its giant share of the fruit and vegetable market. ``California is the major supplier of fruits and vegetables to the United States and, in some cases, the world,'' she said in the August issue of Agricultural Outlook magazine. Last year, she said, California accounted for $8.5 billion, or 41 percent of the nation's farm sales of fruit, nuts and vegetables. During the 1980s, Hamm said, California had four consecutive years of below-normal rainfall, soaring land prices and reforms in labor laws. ``Alone, any one of these events would have strained local growers,'' she said. ``Yet these changes may not reshape the industry as much as the Big Green initiative.'' The initiative _ formally, the California Environmental Protection Act _ also has provisions for ozone depletion, offshore oil drilling and oil spills, and air pollution. A coalition of local farm groups, retailers and distributors called Californians for Responsible Food Laws, or CAREFUL, proposed a counter initiative called the Consumer Pesticide Act of 1990. This initiative was designed to address only those parts of Big Green dealing with food and farm worker safety, Hamm said. If both initiatives pass, the one with the most votes will supersede the provisions in the other that deal with food and worker safety. Hamm said there has been much public speculation about the physical and economic impact of Big Green but that estimates vary greatly. One USDA researcher has estimated that a ban on fungicides and insecticides on lettuce and tomatoes would cut yields 50 percent to 60 percent and boost consumer prices. Others believe that output of several important fruits and vegetables would drop about 28 percent and that prices would rise 50 percent, she said. But these estimates ``come from economic models and industry consensus rather than historical evidence,'' Hamm said. ``Whether Big Green or the CAREFUL initiative passes on Nov. 6, chemical availability probably will decline in the 1990s,'' she said. ``Initially, fruit and vegetable growers likely will face higher production costs and consumers will see higher prices, lower quality and tighter supplies as chemicals are removed from use in California.'' The higher prices will encourage production in other states and foreign countries, Hamm said. Other countries are watching the situation, and the Bush administration is concerned that California going its own way with Big Green could have world trade repercussions. Trade Representative Carla Hills has asked the U.S. International Trade Commission to investigate the potential impact of Big Green on world trade. An interim report is due by Sept. 31. Hills has said Big Green standards would be tougher than federal rules and thus create potential conflict. Also, she said in her May 8 letter to the commission, adoption of the initiative ``could seriously affect any new U.S. trade obligations'' that may result from current talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The American Farm Bureau Federation said if each state enacted its own pesticide regulations, the lack of uniformity would severely hamper U.S. agriculture production and trade. Paul Drazek, the federation's trade specialist, said the California measure would make the United States less competitive and would run counter to GATT efforts for a uniform set of international agricultural health standards based on scientific evidence. Supporters of Big Green, such as the Natural Resources Defense Council, contend that the initiative would have only marginal effect on U.S. trade because chemicals would be phased out over a long period of time and that alternatives would be found.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Aug. 12

DOC.TEXT: Any homicide is shocking, but when the lethal weapon is in a child's hand the horror is often beyond imagining. Meet Cameron, who was 9 years old when he allegedly killed a playmate with a high-powered rifle; no one knows why. Meet another little boy who was 8 years old when he killed his raging father. They will grow older, but these fatal moments will stay with them forever.

DOC.HEAD: Advertising Recession Greets New Chairman at Media General
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The ``for sale'' sign is hanging at J. Stewart Bryan III's newspapers, but media-hungry investors shouldn't get excited _ the deal is for advertising space, not the papers themselves. ``There are plenty of enticing offers, but they're not for sale,'' Bryan, newly installed as chairman of Media General Inc., said of the company's daily newspapers here and in Winston-Salem, N.C., and Tampa, Fla. Two years ago, Burt Sugarman, a California-based television game show producer, tried to parlay control of about 10 percent of Media General stock into three seats on the board of directors. But the effort failed because a two-tiered stock plan gave the Bryan family the upper hand in shareholder voting power. Sugarman eventually gave up his holdings for $44 million and a newsprint recycling mill valued at $56 million, which he sold a year later for $95 million. Bryan, 52, said he didn't begrudge Sugarman the profit. ``We think we made a good deal and we're happy with it,'' he said. But the Sugarman episode taught Bryan ``what a waste of company resources it is to spend money and time to fend off raiders when you ought to be spending your time trying to maximize shareholder value,'' he said. These days, tending to the needs of shareholders means coping with a sluggish advertising market. On July 1, Bryan succeeded his father, D. Tennant Bryan, as chairman and replaced James S. Evans as president and chief executive officer. The younger Bryan, a director of The Associated Press, is the fourth generation of his family to run the city's newspapers. His father, now 84, succeeded Bryan's grandfather as publisher in 1944, then founded Media General in 1969 and steered the company to a tenfold increase in assets over 20 years. During the senior Bryan's final quarter as chairman, the company posted $12.4 million in earnings, or 48 cents a share, more than double the $6.1 million, or 23 cents a share, in the second quarter of 1989. But Stewart Bryan said advertising, a key element in newspaper profits, is still ``troublesome'' for Media General's Richmond Times-Dispatch and The Richmond News Leader, the Winston-Salem Journal and the Tampa Tribune. ``You set goals all the time, but they're very hard to keep when you're in a recession, in an advertising recession, which is certainly what all media companies with very few exceptions are in right now,'' Bryan said. ``Times are tough.'' Bankruptcies and consolidations in the retail industry are a large part of the problem, he said. Three years ago, the Miller & Rhoads department store chain was the leading advertiser in the Richmond papers, Bryan said. ``And now Miller & Rhoads is no more.'' The chain filed for bankruptcy late last year. Although some Miller & Rhoads stores were sold to other chains, its flagship downtown store just two blocks from Media General's headquarters remains vacant. Media General's restructuring has meant selling much of its newsprint interests as well as the California papers. Last year, the company's revenues fell to $606 million from $756 million in 1988, largely because of divested assets. Operating profits of $65 million in 1989 were down 34 percent from $98 million a year earlier. What remains of Media General, in addition to the daily newspapers, are three television stations in Jacksonville and Tampa, Fla., and Charleston, S.C.; two cable television companies in Fairfax County and Fredericksburg, Va.; a 40 percent stake in New Jersey-based Garden State Newspapers, a chain of weeklies; plus a few smaller holdings. ``Instead of expanding, we are trying to get back to the core businesses that have been the basis for whatever success we have enjoyed over the years,'' Bryan said. Bryan came up through the business, working in circulation and editorial posts before becoming publisher of the Tribune Co. in Tampa. He subsequently became publisher of the Richmond papers and was named a director of Media General in 1974. ``He caught on real quick,'' said Tennant Bryan. ``It was time for me to go and time for him to take over. I think he has earned the high regard of his colleagues and his contemporaries in the press.'' ``I was never brought up to think I'd be running this company,'' Stewart Bryan said. ``I guess I began to think it might be a possibility in the last five years or so.'' Bryan, father of two daughters, said he has had little time recently for his hobbies of tennis, fishing and duck hunting. Taking over the top job ``feels pretty much the same as before, just a little less free time, a little more mail, a little more work to do, I suppose,'' he said. ``This is not any radical change. The same people are here.'' Bryan's father stayed on as chairman of the board of directors' executive committee, and Evans, who had been president since 1982 and CEO since 1985, moved to vice chairman. ``We try to seek a consensus on what it is we're doing or considering doing, and I think it will remain that way,'' Bryan said. Industry analysts see the company's shift in management as a good sign. ``Frankly, I think having a younger guy at the helm is a positive step for this company,'' said Peter Appert, a stock analyst with C.J. Lawrence in New York. The company's stock has sunk from about $42 per share in May 1988, when Sugarman made his foray, to about $25. In recent months, the stock has attracted the interest of New York money manager Mario J. Gabelli, who has raised his stake in Media General stock to about 17 percent. Gabelli did not return calls for comment. Bryan said he was not worried that Gabelli's holdings might be used in a power play similar to the Sugarman raid. ``His investment in us is really quite small when you look at it in terms of his total pot that he's got to invest somewhere,'' Bryan said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Aug. 12

DOC.TEXT: Persian Gulf war rumors raced through the financial world, pushing oil prices toward $29 a barrel and sending more jolts through markets for U.S. stocks and bonds. Increasing indications of a possible Iraq-U.S. showdown in the vital oil-producing region transfixed professional investors and speculators through most of the day Tuesday and made many markets seesaw without warning. Each suggestion of a conflict sent oil prices higher and stocks and bonds lower on the theory that a fresh blanket of oil-shock inflation would wallop the already weak U.S. economy. Conversely, rumors that the situation was easing weakened oil prices and sent money back into the stock and bond markets.

Gasoline prices at the pump hit nearly five-year highs, truckers sought freight rate increases and utilities warned of inflated electric bills as the impact of soaring oil prices widened. Economists said Tuesday that the uncertain future of the Middle East's oil fields goes beyond the gas pump _ it could hit American consumers in higher prices for products from frozen foods and fertilizer to car tires and aluminum foil. Self-service unleaded gasoline rose 1.5 cents overnight to $1.201 per gallon Tuesday, the highest price since the last week of 1985, the American Automobile Association said in a survey of 1,400 stations nationwide.

Congressional Democrats charged that oil companies are engaging in price-gouging and exhorted President Bush to stop it. ``Someone is making a killing,'' Sen. John Kerry said Tuesday at one of three public hearings on sharp increases in American fuel prices following Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. Charles J. Di Bona, president of the American Petroleum Institute, denied the accusation.

Taxpayers paid 7.5 percent more in state taxes in fiscal 1989 than they did in the previous year, the government reported. The Commerce Department said Tuesday that state tax collections totaled $284 billion in 1989, up from $264 billion a year earlier. Eight states reported increases of more than 10 percent, including Oregon, up 22.5 percent, and California, up 14.2 percent.

Americans took out $463 million more in consumer credit than they paid off in June, the government said, but the borrowing pace fell well below that of May. The Commerce Department said Tuesday consumer credit edged up just 0.8 percent at an annual rate following a 6.1 percent gain, or $3.65 billion, in May. Many analysts have been concerned recently over the caution displayed by consumers, who have fueled an economic expansion that would reach its eighth anniversary in November. Consumers represent about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.

With an expired contract looming, representatives of Western Union Corp. and 2,500 union workers planned to resume stalled negotiations. The negotiator for the union, the Communications Workers of America, reported progress Tuesday on a wage agreement but said the company had not yielded on demands that medical benefits be reduced, job categories be consolidated and the number of part-time employees be increased. A two-year contract between employees and the giant telegram company expired Monday, but workers decided to return to the bargaining table rather than strike.

Sony Corp. plans an expensive consumer-oriented advertising campaign to support its new line of blank videotapes Sony declined to say Tuesday how much it intended to spend on the campaign, but it said it would exceed the estimated $4 million to $5 million all the major brands combined spent on advertising blank tapes last year. Sony estimated U.S. blank tape sales amount to $750 million a year industrywide.

The Justice Department filed a lawsuit seeking to stop the maker of Pepto-Bismol from acquiring exclusive sales rights to Maalox. The Justice Department sought a court injunction Tuesday under the Clayton Anti-Trust Act to prevent Procter & Gamble Co., which makes Pepto-Bismol, from acquiring the exclusive rights to market and distribute Maalox. Court papers filed in federal court in Philadelphia charged that the proposed agreement between Procter & Gamble and Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc., which makes Maalox, would lessen competition in the market of over-the-counter stomach remedies.

Lemon yellow lovers paled and raw umber enthusiasts took umbrage. Despite good-natured protests, Crayola retired those and six other colors Tuesday, saying it needed to appeal to a new generation of kids weaned on flashy video games and color television. Gone forever from the familiar 64-crayon box are blue gray, green blue, lemon yellow, maize, orange red, orange yellow, raw umber and violet blue.

Stocks stumbled through a choppy session Tuesday but several market indicators eked out small gains. The Dow Jones industrial average lengthened its string of losses to a sixth straight session, falling 5.70 to 2,710.64. Bond prices fell amid uncertainty over the outcome of the Persian Gulf crisis and its economic impact. The dollar ended higher against all major currencies except the German mark. Cattle futures prices surged; pork futures ended mixed; petroleum futures were mixed; precious metals were mostly lower; and grains and soybeans were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: The Smell of Sweet Excess
With LaserGraphic
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Some magazine readers are thumbing their noses at ``scent strips,'' the fragrance advertising inserts that can make everything in the mailbox smell like a perfume store. These people want scent strips sealed in odor-proof wrappers to protect the health of the allergic, asthmatic and hypersensitive, as well as the olfactory sensibilities of everyone else. Legislation to regulate the use of the strips is even being considered in some states. Manufacturers and publishers defend the strips as an inexpensive, effective way to bring fragrances from the perfume counter to the kitchen counter. But some have agreed to stop using one form of the strips. The scent strip was first used widely in the early 1980s to introduce a perfume called Giorgio, whose manufacturers could not afford the usual television advertising and promotional giveaways. Women were able to sample the powerful perfume at their leisure, and anyone else not directly upwind also got a blast. Giorgio became America's best selling fragrance. Billions of fragrance inserts have been distributed over the past decade, and about 30 major magazines regularly carry them. The magazines love the ad revenue _ $15 million last year _ but some readers don't like the scents. One is Amy Solomon, 38, who opened a fashion magazine last spring on a train ride from Manhattan to Albany. By Beacon, she had a headache. By Poughkeepsie, she could barely open her eyes. By Hudson, she felt sick to her stomach. ``There ought to be a law,'' she told herself. As director of communications for New York state Sen. Martin Connor, she was in a position to help pass one. At Solomon's urging, Connor is sponsoring a bill to prevent distribution of cosmetic or fragrance samples unless they are ``enclosed in a sealant,'' such as a plastic or foil wrapper. Legislators in New Jersey and Massachusetts also are preparing bills. Several magazines are refusing strip ads, and New York magazine subscribers can request a strip-free copy. A scent strip is a coating, usually containing hundreds of thousands of microscopic capsules of fragrance oil, that has been slathered under the overflap of an ad page. In theory, the capsules are broken and their aroma released only when the overlap is peeled back; in reality, capsules often break prematurely in shipping and handling. But the worst culprit is something called ``free oil.'' By the late '80s, thick fashion magazines had become a riot of competing fragrances. In an attempt to grab readers by the nose, some companies began dousing their inserts with unencapsulated fragrance oil that soaks into the paper whether or not the flap is pulled back. Such magazines mingle with other mail, and even Soldier of Fortune could wind up smelling more like a boutique than a rifle range. Carolyn Wright, a letter carrier from Ravena, N.Y., says she gets a headache the day Cosmopolitan is delivered. Last month California barred free oil inserts. In an attempt to head off more restrictive laws, the leading makers of fragrance inserts agreed to stop using free oil on July 1. Although no one knows how many people are acutely sensitive to fragrances, experts say that between 10 and 20 percent of Americans may be sensitive to chemicals commonly used in fragrances. Michael Petrina, spokesman for the Cosmetic, Toiletry and Fragrance Association, says fragrances bother relatively few people, and that their hardship is offset by the benefit to advertisers, magazines and interested consumers. It's unclear, he adds, if any sealant could totally eliminate the possibility of exposure; it would, at any rate, increase the cost of producing each strip as much as 10 times. But Sen. Connor says some sort of sealant, as required by his bill, affords the only reliable protection. ``When a reader opens a magazine,'' he says, ``the only danger should be a paper cut.''

DOC.HEAD: Polish Capital Almost Out of Money
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The Polish capital is almost out of money because the nation's economic reform program has left thousands of businesses facing bankruptcy and unable to make tax payments, the city government reports. Large enterprises, small factories, craftsmen and foreign-linked companies all have had trouble meeting their obligations and a dramatic drop in revenues collected by the Warsaw government has resulted, the media reported this week. In the province of Warsaw, which includes the city and surrounding villages, local governments have paid only 3 percent of their annual dues to the provincial government, the Zycie Warszawy newspaper said. The local governments owe $50.6 million, money they are unable to raise because they managed to collect only 40 percent of the taxes owed to the village administrations, the newspaper said. Meanwhile, the national Finance Ministry is demanding the provinces pay their contributions to the central budget, the official PAP news agency said. ``All this has made it so that the (Warsaw) province is on the edge of bankruptcy,'' acting provincial governor Adam Langer told PAP. Langer said a precise review of the budget would be completed this month, but it appears some municipal projects would have to be halted. He said the province needs $15 million to complete municipal investments this year. The shock reform program initiated Jan. 1 nationwide is designed to turn Poland's weak centralized economy into a market-driven capitalist system. The massive national budget subsidies provided to enterprises have been cut off, forcing businesses to become self-sufficient or face bankruptcy. Meanwhile, prices for goods have risen dramatically, requiring companies to buy supplies at market prices. Many state-run and private enterprises have trimmed often-bloated work forces to stay in business. Unemployment, officially unknown under the Communist system that was toppled a year ago, last month reached 5 percent of the work force, or almost 700,000 workers.

DOC.HEAD: More Than Gasoline: Price Rises Could Hit Other Sectors
DOC.TEXT: If higher oil prices hold, the effect is expected to spread beyond gasoline to utility bills, home mortgages, foodstuffs, fertilizer, automobile tires and a myriad of other goods. ``The first victims in line will be utilities and transportation industries,'' said economist David Wyss of DRI-McGraw-Hill Inc. in Lexington, Mass. ``You can expect your electic bills going up.'' Wyss said inflation via high oil prices ``gradually dribbles down to almost everything in the economy.'' The American Automobile Association reported Tuesday that gasoline prices at the pump hit nearly five-year highs, as self-service unleaded rose 1.5 cents overnight to $1.201 per gallon, the highest price since the last week of 1985. In its sruvey of 1,400 stations nationwide, the AAA said unleaded fuel increased 12.6 cents since last Wednesday, the day before Iraq's takeover of Kuwait sent the price of crude oil skyrocketing on world markets. Spot checks showed gasoline prices up as much as 25 cents in the week at some Michigan service stations, among the biggest weekly increases since the 1973 Arab oil embargo. Spokespeople for various industries that rely on oil for transportation or production said rising fuel prices all add to costs that would have to be passed onto consumers eventually. ``If it turns into a long-term permanent increase, it will have an effect on all costs associated with fuel prices,'' said Michael Rourke, spokesman for the A&P supermarket chain, which operates 1,231 stores in 26 Eastern states and Canada. Frozen Food Express Industries Inc. in Dallas, which hauls perishable products nationwide, is one of several companies that has asked the government to approve a surcharge on regular shipping rates because of the oil price rise. Chairman Stoney M. Stubbs Jr., whose company has 1,000 refrigeration trucks, said up to 20 percent of costs are related to fuel. ``A 15 cents a gallon increase eats your profit up,'' said Charles Lambright, an independent trucker in Jacksonville, Texas. ``The only way we can stay in business is with a surcharge.'' Surcharges are passed on to the food companies or other users and economists predict those increased costs gradually will show up on supermarket shelves by October. Oil is a major component of the raw materials used to make tires. ``If oil prices continue at higher levels prices will have to reflect these higher raw material costs,'' a Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. spokesman said. Dow Chemical Co. faces $600 million in additional energy spending annually if the price of oil rises $3 a barrel, said Leonard Bogner, a Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. analyst. Petroleum-based raw material cost increases at comapnies such as Dow could directly affect prices of plastics, fertilizer and other products. Utilities that burn large amounts of oil pass changes in fuel costs directly to customers when the fuel is used. One benefit: Utilities use more natural gas in the summer, which could help forestall bill increases. Boston Edison Co. said customers will pay more for electricity if oil prices remain high after the utility's 30- to 45-day supply of oil runs out. The utility generates about a third of its power from oil in the summer and about two-thirds in the winter. Cameron H. Daley, senior vice president in charge of power production, said Boston Edison's most recent oil purchase was at $15 a barrel. If prices hold at $30 a barrel, the average customer faces a $6 to $10 monthly increase. ``When I start burning that more expensive oil they start seeing the increase in the bill,'' Daley said. Consolidated Edison Co. of New York said the price of low-sulphur residual oil it burns rose to $23 a barrel Monday from $18 a week earlier, and the added costs will be passed on to consumers. Spokeswoman Rosalie Zuckerman said the utility has a roughly six-week stock of oil purchased at lower prices. Home mortgage interest rates have risen as much as a half of a percentage point in recent days to above 10 percent, following Treasury bond yields upward in reaction to fears that higher oil prices would trigger inflation. ``Right now there is a general pickup in daily applications as people look in to lock in interest rates and protect themselves from subsequent increases,'' said Countrywide's chief financial officer, Stanford Kurland.

DOC.HEAD: Anheuser-Busch Defends Its Status As King of Beers
LaserPhoto ST2 of Aug. 7
DOC.TEXT: It might seem strange that Anheuser-Busch Inc. executives are pleased with only flat sales this year from their workhorse brand, Budweiser, but they are. After growing phenomenally in the 1980s while other premium brands sagged, sales of the King of Beers fell slightly last year, according to industry estimates. It was the first sales decline since 1976. This year, expected to be the industry's best since 1986, Budweiser is showing no growth, according to company figures. Meanwhile, one of its leading competitors, Miller Genuine Draft, which has only been around since 1986, is growing at a rapid pace and became one of the 10 top-selling beers last year. Patrick Stokes, who just took over as president of Anheuser-Busch Inc., admits the brand is not growing as much as it has in the past. But he's not worried about speculation by industry watchers who say the King may be in trouble. ``I think that people who are speculating about Budweiser would be right on target if it were down 5 percent, but it's not,'' Stokes said in a recent interview. ``Budweiser even, or up or down 1 percent is fine.'' Such growth is a new strategy for the St. Louis-based beermaker, which sells 42 percent of the beer in the United States and is pushing over the next few years to reach a 50 percent market share. And it's not surprising that Budweiser, which accounts for one out of every four beer sales in the country, is being excluded from the company's growth strategy. In today's beer industry, the future seems to be in light beers and other specialized niches. The nation's second-, third- and fourth-most popular beers are light beers. Two of them, Bud Light and Coors Light, are among the fastest growing. The premium-beer segment, beers such as Budweiser, Miller High Life and Coors, slipped 20 percent from 1980 to 1989, while overall beers sales remained fairly stagnant. ``They've (Anheuser-Busch) realized that you can't have one beer that's going to appeal to a mega-segment of the society,'' said Bob Bernstein, a stock analyst for Edward D. Jones Co. in St. Louis. ``There are more specialized tastes out there and the company is going after them.'' There's even a question as to whether Miller Genuine Draft is a niche beer rather than a premium beer. But if Budweiser isn't being counted on for growth and premium beers are on the way out, then what does the future hold for the brand, which has been around since 1876? ``Our job is to have Budweiser as a stable brand within our system and have the other brands contributing to give us a net positive,'' said Stokes, 47. Stokes took over the brewery job from his boss, August Busch III, the chairman and chief executive officer of Anheuser-Busch Cos. Inc. The company owns the brewery, the St. Louis Cardinals baseball team and several other subsidiaries. ``The question is can they do that and not let their very original brand, Budweiser, get clobbered too much,'' said Joseph Doyle, a stock analyst with Smith Barney in New York. In an unusual move and in an effort to prove that the country's most popular beer is not getting clobbered, Stokes has decided to disclose some usually private brewery sales figures. According to the company, Budweiser sales to retailers for 1990, through July, are exactly the same as last year. For just July, the brand was up 8.3 percent. The company is very happy with flat sales for Budweiser _ here's why. The brewery introduced its popular Bud Dry earlier this year and that brand has been eating into Budweiser sales. Stokes estimates that for every two Bud Dry beers that are sold, one Budweiser sale is lost. ``That's a rate that we could live with forever,'' Stokes said. Meanwhile, another member of the Budweiser family, Bud Light, continues to grow and take some sales away from Budweiser. Bud Light was up 9.4 percent from last year in adjusted sales to retailers through July. To Anheuser-Busch executives and industry analysts, that's an outstanding number. The whole Budweiser family is selling 5.9 percent more beer to retailers than last year and the overall brewery is up 6.7 percent. That increase comes in a year when industry analysts are predicting only 2 percent growth. ``Those are rather fabulous numbers. I'd say they're awesome,'' said Jerry Steinman, president and publisher of Beer Marketer's Insights, an industry newsletter. ``I knew they were having a good year but I didn't know it was this good.'' The significance of the ``sales to retailers'' numbers is that they are the best gauge of how much beer is actually being sold. They usually are well-guarded secrets. Normally, the nation's beermakers release ``sales to wholesalers'' figures that are not as illuminating. Anheuser-Busch's job for the '90s, Stokes said, is to manage the portfolio of beers it has introduced. Twenty years ago, the company only sold three brands of beer _ Budweiser, Michelob and Busch. Today it sells 17 brands, including four introduced this year. So far, the company's ``family approach'' to beer marketing seems to be paying off. Two weeks ago, Anheuser-Busch announced record profits and sales for the second quarter and the first half of the year, primarily because of the success of its brewery.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Commission Clears Path for Norton Merger
DOC.TEXT: The $1.8 billion merger of the Norton Co. with Saint Gobain of Paris is expected to proceed following approval of the merger by a federal commission. The Commission on Foreign Investment in the United States has determined that the merger of the Worcester, Mass.-based abrasives company with the French firm would not threaten national security, Rep. Joseph Early, D-Mass., said Tuesday. Norton's board of directors approved the merger in late April after British conglomerate BTR launched a hostile takeover bid. Saint Gobain, one of the world's leading glass makers, had come forward with a friendly tender offer after BTR's takeover attempt provoked outcries from Worcester officials and Norton employees and raised concerns among Massachusetts legislators. Norton is a leading manufacturer of abrasives and engineering materials that has defense contracts with the U.S. government. The company, with 1989 sales of $1.5 billion, employs 16,000 people and operates 113 plants abroad.

DOC.HEAD: Ratners in Talks to Revise Offer for Kay Bonds, Deadline Extended
DOC.TEXT: Britain's largest jewelry chain, Ratners Group PLC, said Wednesday that it was holding talks to revise the terms of its offer to bondholders as part of its $328 million takeover bid for the U.S.-based Kay Jewelers Inc. Ratners said it had extended the deadline for its bond offer by 24 hours until midnight EDT Wednesday. It declined to say how much of the debt has been tendered so far. The statement from the company said that it currently was negotiating revising terms of its offer with representatives of the holders of each class of the notes but it declined to elaborate. It added that ``there is, however, no assurance that any agreement between Ratners and such holders will be reached.'' The Financial Times reported that bondholders were unhappy with the terms, and that they wanted more money. However, Ratners could press ahead without bondholder approval, because shareholders have given the deal a green light, the Financial Times said. Ratners is offering $17 worth of stock for each of Kay's 12.4 million shares, and is assuming Kay's debt. Kay is based in Alexandria, Va. The addition of Kay's 494 stores would increase Ratners' U.S. outlets to nearly 1,000, making it the United States' second largest jeweler after Zales.

DOC.HEAD: Domestic Oil Patch Could Benefit from Iraq-Kuwait Conflict
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last 3 grafs, Oil prices ... with 5 new grafs to UPDATE with Bush asking oil companies for restraint and today's oil prices. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's invasion of Kuwait is driving up oil prices and causing some smiles on the faces of those who have struggled through the ragged recovery of the U.S. oil industry. In America's energy capital of Houston, a city still in the final recovery stages of the last oil bust, there are whispers of another boom. ``The oil and gas business has been down for quite a while, and so we need a little good news. But I hate for it to come as a result of a war,'' said John Faulkinberry, chief financial officer of Paramount Petroleum Co., an independent oil and gas exploration and production company. The oil industry has been inching toward a renewed vigor for some time, anticipating higher oil prices in the coming years. Companies began last year to increase their exploration budgets, and new drilling and exploration techniques have sparked regional booms in the oil patch. But with the cutoff of oil from Iraq and Kuwait, and worries about the rest of the Persian Gulf, the stumbling recovery could hit full stride. A sustained increase in oil prices could fuel domestic drilling activity, raise revenues and attract investors who were scared away when prices plunged in the mid-1980s, some observers said. ``There is an air of expectancy,'' Faulkinberry said. ``This one event could really heat things up. It could drive up (domestic) drilling activity and bring capital back into the industry.'' ``This probably means the business is really going to jump into second gear now,'' he added. ``I think a lot (of oil exploration companies) will be more aggressive in their businesses.'' The number of rigs actively exploring for oil and gas rose to 4,500 at the height of the boom in December 1981, but it plunged to a low of 663 after oil prices collapsed in the summer of 1986. This week, the count totaled 966 _ down 30 from the previous week but up from the 874 working rigs a year ago, according to Houston-based Baker Hughes Inc., which keeps track of the count. ``If prices remain at the current levels, I'd say you'd have a significant impact (on drilling activity),'' Ike Kerridge, a vice president at Baker Hughes, said. ``You could start seeing that in a few weeks.'' Others, however, are remaining cautious about the possible impact of the present turmoil in the Middle East. They still remember the devastating effect that plunging oil prices had on the entire energy industry. ``There are still too many of us who have memories of the previous boom,'' said Don Covey, president of the exploration and production division of Mitchell Energy & Development Corp., an independent oil company based in The Woodlands north of Houston. ``People are going to be moving slowly because of the uncertainty and because we have seen what has happened before,'' Covey said. Oil prices soared towards $40 per barrel in 1981, but by 1986 had fallen below $10 per barrel. The decline undercut the financial and real estate industries in Texas, while the rest of the country enjoyed cheap gas. ``Regardless of the progress that's been made, the state is oil and gas driven, Houston in particular,'' Faulkinberry said. ``Anytime you have an event like this happen that makes oil prices go up, it's going to have an impact on Houston.'' Oil prices increased since Iraq's invasion and already have been passed along at the pumps. In his address to the nation today, President Bush said he asked oil companies to ``show restraint and not abuse today's uncertainties to raise prices.'' Bush also said he will ask other oil-producing nations to replace embargoed Iraqi and Kuwait oil. Oil prices fell today in what traders said reflected confidence that there would be enough world oil production to make up for supplies lost in the wake of Iraq's invasion. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the cost of benchmark West Texas Intermediate was off 81 cents at $27.50 a barrel at midmorning. The contract had risen 26 cents in volatile trading Tuesday to settle at its highest level since Dec. 6, 1985. Oil prices also sank in London. The spot price of Brent Blend, the most widely traded international crude oil, fell $1.90 to $25.50 a barrel.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Open Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were narrowly mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade with corn and soybeans down slightly after a drop in crude oil reduced inflationary fears. Analysts also said traders were evening up their positions in preparation for Thursday's release of the U.S. Department of Agriculture crop report, the first official estimate of U.S. corn and soybean production levels. ``It's pre-report trading combined with nervousness about world developments,'' said William Biedermann, research director for Allendale Inc., a futures brokerage in Crystal Lake, Ill. Biedermann said that even after the report is released, the size of this year's corn and soybean crops will be difficult to assess and frost damage to late-maturing crops is real concern. Market analysts estimate this year's soybean crop at 1.86 billion bushels, down from 1.93 billion last year. Analysts estimate the corn harvest at 7.9 billion bushels, up from 7.5 billion in 1989. The USDA report will be released after Thursday's close. In early trading, wheat futures were \ cent lower to { cent higher with the contract for delivery in September at $2.81 a bushel; corn was 1 cent to 1{ cents lower with September at $2.53 a bushel; oats were \ cent to 1 cent higher with September at $1.17{ a bushel; soybeans were } cent to 1{ cents lower with August at $5.94{ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were unchanged to .25 cent lower with August at 77.67 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .40 cent lower with August at 89.55 cents a pound; hogs were .43 cent to 1.17 cents lower with August at 56.90 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .22 cent to 1.40 cents lower with August at 50.85 cents a pound. Cattle futures rose sharply Tuesday while pork futures were mixed.

The stock market rolled ahead today as traders assessed the economic implications of developments in the Middle East. Market analysts attributed the buying interest mostly to bargain hunting after a slump on Wall Street that pushed stock prices to attractively low levels. But buying enthusiasm was restrained by concerns that the market remains vulnerable due to the unfolding Persian Gulf crisis. Blue chip issues built on their initial strength this morning. By noon, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks was up 25.99 to 2,736.63. Gainers outpaced losers by about 5 to 3 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 851 up, 505 down and 482 unchanged. Activity slowed slightly from the recent brisk pace. Volume came to 93.78 million shares at midday, down from 127.74 million at the same point in Tuesday's session. The New York Stock Exchange composite index of all its listed common stocks added 1.63 to 185.08. The American Stock Exchange's market value index edged 0.08 higher to 339.92. Stock prices were expected to steady today, analysts said. The market's mixed performance Tuesday, with the Dow Jones average posting only a minor loss, indicated that the selling wave that had swept through Wall Street since the turmoil flared in the Middle East has eased.
