DOC.HEAD: Resigned Board of Trade Chief to Get $120,000 Severance
DOC.TEXT: Former Chicago Board of Trade Chairman Karsten Mahlmann, who stepped down amid charges his trading firm misused customer's funds, will get $120,000 in severance pay, exchange officials said. Mahlmann, who headed Stotler Group, Inc., resigned from his company and the BOT last week after federal officials charged the company with using customer funds to shore up its own finances. Exchange officials said Tuesday that Board of Trade directors voted last Thursday to pay Mahlmann, nicknamed ``Cash,'' for the rest of his term, which was scheduled to expire Jan. 22. His post paid $240,000 per year. Stotler was forced into involuntary bankruptcy Friday, and a special master has been placed in charge of three of the company's customer funds. U.S. District Judge Milton I. Shadur has frozen all of Stotler's assets.

DOC.HEAD: Honeywell Plans to Sell HFSI
DOC.TEXT: Honeywell Inc., said Wednesday it had tentatively agreed to sell Honeywell Federal Systems Inc. to Bull HN Information Systems Inc. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. Honeywell and Bull HN are seeking necessary approvals for the transaction, including approval by Honeywell's board of directors. Honeywell said the planned sale continues a transition begun in 1987 to focus the company on its controls businesses. In March 1987, Honeywell sold majority interest in its computer business to Compagnie des Machines Bull and NEC, while it retained the division of the computer company that marketed computers to the U.S. government. HFSI, based in McLean, Va., provides systems integration, marketing, computer products and technical services to the U.S. government and prime contractors. It employs about 1,600 people and had 1989 sales of $274 million. Bull HN, based in Billerica, Mass., provides proprietary and open information systems, software and services. With over 17,000 employees, including 8,100 employees based in the United States, the company had revenues of $2.1 billion in 1989. Honeywell is a global controls company that provides products, systems and services for homes and buildings, industry, and aviation and space. The company had 1989 sales of $6.1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: American Airlines to Hike Fares 10 Percent Because of Fuel Costs
DOC.TEXT: American Airlines said today it will increase its fares by 10 percent because of what it called the skyrocketing cost of fuel brought about by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Michael W. Gunn, the airline's senior vice president for marketing, said the increase will go into effect Friday for flights in the continental United States, Hawaii and the Caribbean and on Aug. 15 for international flights. In recent days, Pan American World Airways and Northwest Airlines said they would raise their fares because of soaring fuel costs. ``We regret the recent events in the Middle East have caused an increase in the costs of fuel, leading to an increase in our fare price. American Airlines wants to be fair and we are especially sorry to do this, because higher fares will create hardships,'' Gunn said. ``Airlines feel the impact of fuel increases almost immediately. Thus we must move rapidly to recover this cost since many seats have already been sold at prices that don't reflect the fuel increase,'' Gunn said. ``Even with the higher fares, we expect to recover only a portion of the increased fuel costs, since we have already sold half of our seats for the next two months at old prices,'' American Airlines spokesman Tim Smith said. The higher fares apply only to tickets that are bought after the increase goes into effect, Smith said. Fuel costs make up 15 percent of American Airlines' total budget, ``but at the higher prices, we estimate it will be at least 20 percent,'' Smith said. On July 1, American Airlines was paying an average of 57 cents per gallon for its fuel, Smith said. ``By today, the system average had risen to 68 cents. But the spot market is already at 85 cents, and the spot is what our market is based upon,'' Smith added. American Airlines uses 2.4 billion gallons of fuel a year. The increased cost of fuel at this point means the carrier's annual cost of $1.6 billion would soar to $2.3 billion, an increase of about $720 million, Smith said.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Negotiators, Wary of Middle East, Say They'll Press Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs with Bush, Dole comments; picks up 2nd graf pvs, If the. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today that the Middle East crisis and the resulting increases in oil prices have not reduced the necessity for a significant deficit-reduction agreement. ``I still think it's absolutely essential to get a budget agreement (with Congress) and that's going to require a lot of principle,'' Bush told a news conference. Congressional leaders and the administration have made little progress in devising a deficit-reduction plan, agreeing only to resume efforts next month. Bush implied that he soon will resume public criticism of Democrats' negotiating posture. ``I don't feel bound by an agreement that I've told the congressional leaders is no longer in effect,'' he said, apparently referring to an earlier concession to tone down political rhetoric about the negotiations. Congressional Republicans are unhappy that Democrats have refused to put forth a specific proposal, even after Bush backed away from a campaign pledge to oppose tax increases. Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole told reporters today the administration is still seeking a $500 billion, five-year deficit-reduction plan. He added, however, that there is little chance of raising gasoline taxes as part of that plan and questioned how deeply defense spending could be cut in light of U.S. military involvement in Saudi Arabia. Key members of Congress say they see no reason to ease up on efforts to reach an agreement. ``If the economy begins to look really bad, every element of the deficit-reduction package will be threatened,'' Rep. Bill Frenzel, R-Minn., ranking Republican on the House Budget Committee, said Tuesday. ``Right now, the major effect is to make an energy tax less likely.'' A military face-off with Iraq also could fuel arguments that slashing the $300 billion defense budget is a bad idea right now. ``It's living proof there are mean people in the world and we need a respectable national defense,'' said Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas. However, Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., said the proposed $10 billion to $15 billion in military cuts ``really aren't that deep in the first place.'' Petroleum prices have jumped several dollars closer to $30 per barrel since Iraq invaded oil-rich Kuwait last week. Fuel costs in the United States are already rising, along with prices for other goods and services such as airline tickets and electricity. Bargainers concede that with fuel prices rising, raising taxes on gasoline or other sources of energy becomes less palatable. ``I think it probably will kill any effort to have a broad-based energy tax,'' Gramm said. Congressional leaders and Bush administration officials have struggled inconclusively since May to forge a package of tax increases and spending cuts totaling $50 billion for next year and $500 billion over five years. The summit talks are on hold for Congress' August recess. Iraq's takeover of Kuwait _ and resulting military and economic moves by the United States and its allies _ means the American economy could be weaker when the bargainers reconvene in September. Negotiators said they would watch economic performance closely. ``Anybody who thinks we're not being forced into a re-evaluation these next few weeks is kidding themselves,'' said House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif. If the economy seems shaky, one option would be to lower the amount of taxes and spending cuts slated for fiscal 1991, which starts Oct. 1. ``Under any circumstances, we need to focus on significant deficit reduction over five years,'' said Panetta. But budget bargainers said no reasons have yet surfaced to shoot for a less ambitious deficit-cutting package. ``I don't think we can see clearly enough into the future to know how much we'll be affected,'' said Frenzel. ``I think the summiteers ought to go forward with the plan we've been discussing.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises, Gold Little Changed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout with closing rates from Europe, midday prices in New York.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose slightly Wednesday in dealings in Europe, supported by worries about rising tensions in the Persian Gulf. Gold traded in a narrow range. European dealers said the possiblity of a conflict with Iraq outweighed fundamental concerns about weakness in the U.S. economy that could drive interest rates lower and make the dollar less appealing to foreign investors. ``There's only one reason for the firmer dollar and that's the general situation in the Middle East,'' said Werner Esch, a trader at Bethmann Bank in Frankfurt. ``Something is going to have to happen here. Either Iraq will yield and withdraw from Kuwait or the Americans are going to march in.'' Bauer said as long as the situation remains unclear, the dollar will continue to gain support. Once matters are more settled, he said, the chances are that the dollar will resume its downward drift. Some currency dealers in Europe debated whether the dollar was the safest currency to hold, but they generally agree that growing tensions in the Gulf will help mute any aggressive attempts to take the dollar lower for now. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 150.00 Japanese yen from 150.60 yen at Tuesday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 150.15 yen. At midday in New Yor, the dollar was quoted at 149.90 yen. In London, the British pound fell to $1.8660 from $1.8765 late Tuesday. At midday in New York, the pound was quoted at $1.8680. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Tuesday, included: 1.5940 German marks, up from 1.5763; 1.3435 Swiss francs, up from 1.3315; 5.3445 French francs, up from 5.2995; 1.7955 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7785; 1,166.37 Italian lire, up from 1,155.37, and 1.1485 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1495. Selected dollar rates at midday in New York included: 1.5930 German marks, 1.34005 Swiss francs, 1,164.75 Italian lire and 1.14815 Canadian dollars. Gold fell in London to $382.25 a troy ounce from $383.25 late Tuesday. But in Zurich, bullion rose to $384.35 an ounce from $383.15 late Tuesday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell 87 cents to close at $382.65 an ounce. Silver bullion fell in London to $4.87 a troy ounce from $4.89 late Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: SmithKline Beecham Posts 47 Percent Profit Jump
DOC.TEXT: SmithKline Beecham PLC, the Anglo-American health and household products company, said Wednesday its second-quarter profit jumped 47 percent over a year ago. The company said the good performance was highlighted by continued sales growth, strong operating profits and significant debt reduction. Net profit for the three months ended June 30 came to 174 million pounds, or about $303 million, compared with 118 million pounds ($205 million) in the same period a year ago. Earnings per share rose to 9.3 pence, or 16.2 cents, from 9.1 pence (16 cents). Pre-tax profit rose 6.5 percent to 197 million pounds, or $343 million, from 185 million pounds ($322 million). Sales climbed 3 percent to 1.21 billion pounds, or $2.1 billion, from 1.18 billion pounds ($2.05 billion). The results are the second set reported on a quarterly basis since Beecham PLC and SmithKline Beckman Corp. merged in July 1989. Year-earlier figures were presented as if the merger had been in place in the second quarter of 1989. In the latest quarter, net debt totalled 822 million pounds, or $1.43 billion, down from 1.47 billion pounds in the first quarter. The company realized 352 million pounds ($612 million) from asset disposals. For the first six months of the year, net profit rose 45 percent to 399 million pounds, or $694 million, from 276 million pounds ($480 million). Earnings per share came to 20.1 pence, or 35 cents, compared with 21.4 pence. Pre-tax profit fell 1 percent to 416 million pounds ($724 million) from 420 million pounds ($731 million). Sales rose 14 percent to 2.3 billion pounds, or $4 billion, from 2.01 billion pounds ($3.5 billion). All figures were converted at a company-provided exchange rate of 1.74 American dollars to the pound.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares End Slightly Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices finished slightly higher on London's Stock Exchange Wednesday, after a hectic, choppy session in which investors assessed the minute-by-minute developments in the Middle East. ``Confusion remains extremely high in world equity markets,'' said Paul Harrison, a vice president at Salomon Brothers International in London. ``Money managers don't have a clear view on how the Middle East situation will resolve itself over the next days or weeks,'' Harrison said. ``Volatility is expected to remain high with constant watching of the news tapes for the next five-minute trend.'' Shares opened on a strong footing but were reduced to losses later in the session as a wave of war rumors flooded the market. However, stocks were driven from mid-afternoon minimums by an early burst on Wall Street. By the close of the London day, the Dow Jones industrial average was up 25.99 points at 2,736.63. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 1.7 points, or 0.08 percent, at 2,237.5 at the close. The sesion peak was 2,253.2, while its minimum was 2,217.9. The Financial Times 30-share index closed up 0.1 point at 1,748.5. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 0.3 point to close at 1,210.76. Volume came to 429.2 million shares compared with 497.5 million shares Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Contract Deadlock Continues Between Western Union and Union Employees
DOC.TEXT: Management and labor officials from Western Union Corp. said Wednesday they were closer to a contract settlement but were stalled on medical benefits. ``We're closer, but we've still got a long way to go,'' said Dan J. Beckstead, president of the Communications Workers of America-United Telegraph Workers Bargaining Council. Both sides said they were on call to resume talks, but no meetings were scheduled. A two-year contract between employees and the giant telegram company expired Monday, and a strike authorization vote, taken last week, is casting its shadow over the talks. But no settlement deadline has been set, Beckstead said. Western Union spokesman Warren Bechtel agreed that progress has been made, but declined to provide details. On Tuesday night, the company presented what it termed its final offer, a package that Beckstead said included a 4 percent wage increase and removed an earlier demand to boost the ranks of part-time employees not entitled to union benefits. Western Union continue to demand curtailed medical benefits that would require employees to pay higher out-of-pocket expenses and would place restrictions on eligibility after retirement. The final offer also scrubs a wage investment plan established in 1985 to repay employees for wage cuts and concessions, said Bechtel, noting that the company hasn't made a profit that has yielded a return to employees. Bechtel said the company, based in Upper Saddle River, is seeking a contract that will allow it to operate profitably for the first time in more than seven years. Past contract disputes between Western Union and its workers have provoked three major strikes, ranging from 10 days to 57 days, since 1952. Communications Workers of America represents operators, customer relations clerks, other clerical workers and field technicians that work for Western Union nationwide, Beckstead said.

DOC.HEAD: Copper Firm Awards $1,000 Bonuses to 3,000 Workers
DOC.TEXT: The Magma Copper Co. will give more than 3,000 hourly employees $1,000 each in bonuses for helping the company achieve record earnings, management and union spokesmen say. The company will give the workers two $500 bonuses, the first next week and the second near Christmas, the spokesmen said Tuesday. Magma spokesman Frank Harris said the bonuses were a way of ``thanking employees for helping Magma achieve significant improvement in operations over the last 12 months, since the signing of the current labor agreement.'' Don Shelton, president of united Steelworkers Local 937, said the action is ``a real indication of the spirit of cooperation that has been generated here. It is going to be a real boost in everybody's credibility.'' He said union leaders suggested the idea of a bonus last month to Magma's president and chief executive officer, J. Burgess Winter, after Magma announced record earnings and increased productivity.

DOC.HEAD: Treasury Auctions 10-Year Notes
DOC.TEXT: Yields on 10-year Treasury notes fell in Wednesday's auction to the lowest level in six months as the government's quarterly refunding continued. The average yield was 8.77 percent, down from 8.88 percent at the last auction on May 9. It was the lowest rate since 10-year notes averaged 8.59 percent on Feb. 7. The notes will carry a coupon interest rate of 8.75 percent with each $10,000 in face value selling for $9,986.90. A total of $10.5 billion in notes were sold out of bids totaling $16.7 billion. The refunding concludes Thursday with the auction of $10.25 billion in 30-year bonds and $10 billion in 36-day cash management bills. It began on Tuesday with the sale of $11.5 billion in three-year notes. The notes and bonds are regularly sold at auctions held four times a year to replenish the government's coffers. Undersecretary Robert Glauber said the proceeds would refund $20 billion of privately-held notes maturing on Aug. 15 and raise approximately $12.25 billion of cash. When the current auctions were announced last week, there was some concern whether they would have to be postponed as the government approached its borrowing limit. However, Congress approved a hike in the debt ceiling over the weekend from $3.12 trillion to $3.195 trillion and the Treasury announced on Monday the auctions would proceed on schedule.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Chamber Warns of Recession
DOC.TEXT: The nation's economy will not be able to avoid a recession later this year even if the explosive Middle East situation eases soon, the U.S. Chamber of Commerce said Wednesday. ``We anticipate that the economy will grind to a virtual standstill during the third quarter of this year and actually contract by 1.4 percent in the fourth quarter,'' said Richard W. Rahn, chamber vice president and chief economist. ``Our forecast shows the economy continuing to experience negative real growth in the first quarter of 1991 and practically no growth in the second quarter,'' he told a news conference. Rahn said the impending recession is due to ``misguided economic policy'' and not Middle East developments although, ``Iraqi adventurism in the Middle East is exacerbating this country's economic weakness.'' Even without the Mideast impact, a recession is unavoidable, Rahn said. Although the Bush administration and Congress must share the blame for a recession, the Federal Reserve is most responsible, he said. ``For over two years, the Fed has labored under the mistaken fear that economic growth causes inflation and has pursued a credit policy designed to slow real economic growth,'' Rahn contended. ``It is time for the Fed, Congress and the administration to adopt pro-growth economic policies.'' With ``correct policy choices,'' the economy will begin to rebound during the third quarter of next year, he added. Rahn called on the Fed, as he has repeatedly, to rescind its high-interest rate policy and allow markets to set the levels. At the same time, he said the Fed should open its policy-making process to the public. ``It is unconscionable that unelected central bankers are permitted to determine the nation's economic fate in secrecy without any form of public accountability,'' he said. Rahn also called on the administration and Congress to cease efforts to create a five-year budget deficit reduction package that includes tax increases. Instead, he said, budget negotiators should adopt ``pro-growth'' tax cuts, including a lowering of the capital gains rate and reduction of the Social Security payroll tax.

DOC.HEAD: Retailer Posts 4.2 Percent Quarterly Profit Gain
DOC.TEXT: Woolworth Corp. on Wednesday reported it earned 4.2 percent more in the second quarter than a year earlier as revenue rose 10 percent. The retailer had net income of $50 million, or 39 cents a share, in the three months ended July 28, up from $48 million, or 37 cents a share, in the corresponding 1989 quarter. Revenue grew to $2.19 billion from $1.98 billion. Harold E. Sells, chairman and chief executive officer of the New York-based retailer, said profits declined in the specialty chains of Woolworth's U.S. apparel group and Canadian and Australian operations due to increased promotional activity. Those declines were offset by earnings improvements at the European, domestic Woolworth and domestic Kinney shoe operations, he said. The corporation owns numerous strings of specialty retailers in addition to its Woolworth variety store chain. Among its retailers are the Foot Locker and Lady Foot athletic shoe stores and the Champs sporting goods chain. For the first half of its fiscal year, Woolworth earned $88 million, or 68 cents a share, up 4.8 percent from $84 million, or 65 cents a share, through two quarters of 1989. Revenue rose 10 percent to $4.26 billion in the first half from $3.86 billion a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Wheat Futures Gain on Export Ideas
DOC.TEXT: Wheat futures prices rose modestly Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade following news of export sales of the grain and speculation that more such sales may be in the works. Corn and soybean futures edged lower. Sales of U.S. wheat to Egypt, Mexico and Algeria were confirmed Wednesday, said Katharina Zimmer, grain analyst with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets Inc. She said the market also was supported by Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter's statement at a news conference that he hopes to see an increase in subsidized export sales of U.S. wheat. The comment ``gave people an idea that he knows more than he would be willing to tell the press,'' she said. Ms. Zimmer also noted that wheat prices have fallen more than 60 cents in the past two months. ``It's about time we have a rally,'' she said. Corn and soybean futures retreated slightly as traders evened their positions ahead of Thursday's release of the U.S. Department of Agriculture crop report, the first official estimate of this year's U.S. corn and soybean production. At the close, wheat futures were 3 cents to 3{ cents higher with the contract for delivery in September at $2.84} a bushel; corn was 1} cents lower to 1 cent higher with September at $2.52} a bushel; oats were 1 cent lower to } cent higher with September at $1.17\ a bushel; soybeans were } cent to 2\ cents lower with August at $5.93} a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Arco Freezes Whoesale Gasoline Prices for One Week
DOC.TEXT: Atlantic Richfield Co. today froze wholesale fuel prices for one week, becoming the first U.S. oil company to heed a request by President Bush to control prices during the Middle East crisis. Arco, based in Los Angeles, said prices of gasoline, diesel and jet fuel would remain at today's level. ``We hope the market will stabilize during this time, but if at the end the week our position is out of line with world market prices we will have to recognize that fact,'' George Babikian, president Arco Products Co., the company's refining and marketing division, said in a statement. ``We will not raise our prices even then unless we are substantially below the general market,'' he said. ``Otherwise, if we remain below the market we risk a run on our stations which could drain our supply and create a panic buying situation in the marketplace.'' Arco said it was encouraging its dealers, who by federal law set their own prices, not to increase pump prices. The company also called for the driving public to begin conserving fuel ``in support of the president's effort to lead the country through this crisis.'' In a televised address on the Middle East situation earlier today, Bush called for oil companies ``to do their fair share'' in holding down gasoline prices, which have risen about 13 cents a gallon at the pump in the last week. An Arco spokesman said the company had raised wholesale prices by only 4 cents a gallon since Iraq took over Kuwait last week while the spot market for gasoline had jumped 20 cents. Arco receives most of its crude oil from Alaska and not the Middle East, but the spokesman said the cost of its crude oil still reflects world market prices. Company officials acknowledged that it could lose money through the price freeze, but said they wanted to comply with Bush's request. Other oil companies today said they supported Bush's call for restraint, but blamed market forces for rising prices and said they had behaved fairly in raising prices.

DOC.HEAD: Chemical Expands Office Of The Chairman
DOC.TEXT: Chemical Banking Corp. said Wednesday it named Robert J. Callander, a vice chairman, as president of the corporation and its flagship bank. The company also announced it was expanding its office of the chairman to include Callander, three newly named vice chairmen of Chemical Bank and the chief executive officer of its subsidiary Texas Commerce Bancshares. ``The new composition ... provides us with the advantages of experience, at the same time ensuring management continuity by drawing upon a new generation to help provide senior leadership,'' Chairman Walter V. Shipley said in a statement. Among the appointments: _William B. Harrison, formerly group executive officer in charge of the banking and corporate finance group, was named vice chairman and director of Chemical Bank. He will become responsible for institutional banking activities worldwide. _William H. Turner, who was in charge of the middle market banking group, was named vice chairman and a director of Chemical Bank. The company said that Marc J. Shapiro will continue as president and chief executive officer of Texas Commerce Bancshares, although that position will become part of the chairman's office. It said Richard S. Simmons, a vice chairman, will retire in October.

DOC.HEAD: Failed Thrift's Owner Says He's Innocent
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The former owner of the defunct Lamar Savings Association said Wednesday he is innocent of federal criminal charges in the failure of the $2 billion thrift. Stanley E. Adams Jr. said he did nothing wrong or different than many other S&L executives. ``If I am to be indicted and tried for my actions, then every banker and savings and loan official in Texas during the past decade should be indicted and brought to trial,'' said Adams, whose S&L once applied to open a branch on the moon. Adams, an unsuccessful Democratic gubernatorial candidate this year, was named late Tuesday in a 14-count indictment alleging misapplications of $121.1 million in S&L funds; so were three other ex-Lamar officers and two borrowers. The indictment accused Adams and the others of trying to hide Lamar Savings' poor financial condition from the Federal Home Loan Bank Board and of arranging ``sham'' loans to fund purchases of repossessed real estate from the troubled thrift's portfolio. ``The blame for this tragedy should be laid where it belongs _ at the doorstep of the Reagan administration,'' which deregulated S&Ls, Adams said in a written statement. ``These indictments against me are part of what has become a political issue and little more.'' In Washington, Attorney General Richard Thornburgh called Lamar ``one of the most notorious failures in the Southwest and among the top 100 S&L fraud cases'' being investigated. Adams' lawyer, Henry Novak, contended the former thrift executive is the victim of a double standard under which the government allowed certain S&L business practices in the early 1980s, but now calls them fraud. Novak said Lamar's transactions were legitimate. But prosecutors now are applying new ``theories of criminality'' to what once was standard S&L practice, he said. ``It was business as usual in the savings and loan industry in 1983, '84 and '85. But now Bush administration _ since the entire industry has collapsed _ what you're doing is taking the position that that was fraud, that that was wrongdoing,'' Novak said. Novak, who is defending Adams in a $100 million civil suit filed by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., said government regulators long were out to get Adams because he was an innovative maverick in a staid business. ``Stanley Adams had been the target for quite some time of bad feelings on the part of the regulators. He was an innovator. He was different. He was a maverick in an industry in which conformity was a very important thing,'' Novak said. Adams was principal owner of Lamar Savings from 1973 to December 1985. Government regulators shut it down in May 1988. It was the biggest thrift failure in central Texas, and officials have estimated the cost to the government at $1 billion. The colorful Adams, 56, unsuccessfully ran for governor in this year's primary. When filing for the Democratic nomination, he listed his occupation as ``alleged white-collar racketeer.'' Several years ago, Lamar applied to federal regulators to open a branch office on the moon, naming a crater where the National Aeronautics and Space Administration proposed to build a space station. No action ever was taken. At a news conference Wednesday, publicist Garry Entress released Adams' statement and one from a second defendant, former Lamar senior vice president Reuben Coleman, who said he was innocent and also protested what he called political interference. ``The current climate in Washington _ what I would describe as a feeding frenzy of vindictiveness _ played a role in this action,'' Coleman said.

DOC.NOTE: $adv12
For Release Sunday, Aug. 12, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: More Homes Going, Going ... Sold! Under The Gavel
With BC-Home Auctions-Guide
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Architect Stephen Chiang always wanted a home in bustling midtown Manhattan, but skyrocketing real estate prices during the free-spending '80s relegated him to the life of a New Jersey commuter. With the bang of an auctioneer's gavel, Chiang, 30, finally got his wish: a luxury studio apartment in a prime New York spot for $129,000, nearly a third off the asking price. Dozens of other successful bidders snapped up about $9 million worth of what they considered bargain condominiums during a recent auction. In turn, the cash-strapped developer quickly disposed of hard-to-sell property. Once the dismal realm of bank foreclosures, bankrupt farmers and estate liquidations, auctions have become an increasingly popular way to peddle property in today's sluggish market. Even individual homeowners, frustrated by a dearth of buyers, have resorted to the auction alternative. ``The auction marketing industry is no longer a last resort,'' said Jim Gall, president of Auction Co. of America in Miami, which expects to auction a record $100 million in residential property this year. ``It's not a giveaway process. It's a way to bring the top dollar. ``We're seeing it in distressed areas, but also where the markets are reasonably strong.'' Stephen Martin, president of the Gwent Group, a real estate consulting firm in Bloomington, Ind., estimates the volume of all real estate sold through auction jumped to $26.5 billion last year from $10 billion in 1980. He predicts overall volume will rise by at least 10 percent in 1990. Auctions offer sellers the prime advantage of speed, while giving buyers the chance for a bargain. Developers of the Manhattan complex, where Chiang got his condo, probably are saving at least $1 million in annual ``carrying costs,'' since it might have taken them as long as three years to sell their remaining 55 vacant units under current market conditions, said Michael Fine, senior coordinator for Sheldon Good & Co. of Chicago, the auctioneer. Fine said the apartments sold for an average 32 percent off the asking price. In nearby Queens, N.Y., developer Tim Naples said he expects to pay off most of his debts on a 207-unit townhouse project after auctioning the last 68 units this past spring. The carrying costs, which include mortgage payments and utilities, had amounted to about $150,000 a month. ``We couldn't have gone on much longer,'' Naples said. ``I'm sure the banks would have taken over the place and done their own auction or sold it to some investor at a lower price.'' Auctioneers say they can offer the same help to individuals trying to sell their homes. A growing number are feeling squeezed by the worst market for housing since the 1981-82 recession. ``An auction is ideal for people who are caught between two houses ... (and) can't afford to wait a year to sell one of them,'' said Steven L. Good, Sheldon Good's president. Auctions also can work in strong markets by helping bring the best price when competition among buyers is brisk, Good said. About 20 percent of Sheldon Good's $250 million in residential auction sales last year were from individual homes, and Good expects that to rise to 30 percent of an anticipated $350 million in sales this year. Many real estate experts are predicting that by the end of the decade individual homeowners will be using auctions just as frequently as developers do now. They've long been an accepted practice overseas. In Australia, where people attend auctions the way Americans go to garage sales, at least a third of all home sales are sold by the gavel. ``We don't believe it's an end all,'' Good said. ``Conventional brokers are here to stay. But in a number of situations auctions are preferable, and the broker community has acknowledged that.'' The National Associaton of Realtors once resisted selling homes though auction, considering it a direct threat to the property brokerage profession. But the group has begun to embrace the practice. Last November, it set up a special committee to advise members how to work with auctioneers. All this comes as the government prepares to auction billions of dollars in real estate from insolvent savings and loan institutions, a potential windfall to the auctioneering industry. ``It's not competition. It's more cooperation,'' Norman D. Flynn, president of the National Association of Realtors, said of the auctioneering business. ``It fits closely into what we're doing.'' He said brokers can act as consultants to auctioneers by pricing or inspecting a home within a familiar marketplace, or they can represent prospective buyers by inspecting a property or even bidding on their behalf. Auctions are conducted two ways. In an absolute auction, property goes to the highest bidder regardless of price. In a reserve-basis auction, a minimum acceptable price is set, or the seller can be granted 48 hours to decide whether to accept or reject the highest bid. Sellers prefer the reserve-basis method, while buyers prefer absolute sales. In cases where a large number of units are auctioned, auctioneers usually recommend sellers set aside a few for absolute sale as a way of drawing buyer interest and sell the rest the reserve way. Regardless, there are potential pitfalls for sellers and buyers. For one thing, selling property by auction is more expensive than using a traditional broker. The auctioneer takes the region's prevailing broker's fee _ from 4 percent to 10 percent of the sale price _ plus often charges for advertising the property or renting an auction hall. That can cost as much as 5 percent more and is payable regardless whether the property sells. Buyers could lose money, too. Immediately after a bid is accepted, they're required to sign a sales contract, so in most cases there's no turning back. Unlike offers to buy a house through a broker, auction sales agreements aren't subject to a successful bidder's ability to obtain a mortgage. Some buyers have lost their deposits because they couldn't follow through with a purchase, auctioneers say. Also, in cases of multiple-unit auctions, buyers may not always get their first choice. ``The ones (apartments) I wanted bidded out in the very beginning,'' said architect Chiang. ``I still got a good bargain. A few years ago real estate was unreasonable in Manhattan. It's getting reasonable now. I hope it's going to rebound right now.'' Walter Carr, a Charleston, S.C., real estate agent who recently picked up a couple of two-bedroom apartments via auction in his hometown's posh historic district, says he already has seen a rebound. Not only did he buy the units for around 50 percent below the asking price but has resold one for a profit exceeding $50,000. Douglas Clemens, president of Louis Traiman Real Estate Auction Co. of Philadelphia, said auctions can be seen as a way of validating the price of real estate _ similiar to the workings of the financial markets. ``The auctions will produce the markets,'' he said. ``They (property) are like a commodity.'' Nonetheless, it's difficult for many people to think of their homes in that way, especially if they bought when prices were at a peak and have watched helplessly as prices have declined in recent years, auctioneers admit. ``(Individual) sellers are too emotional,'' said Joel Zegart, president and founder JBS & Associates Inc. in Chicago. ``A lot of people bought a year or two ago and don't have the equity yet. They may have thought their property will go up 10 percent every year. ``It's like a game of musical chairs. The music has finally stopped.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Sunday Aug. 12

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Stage Rebound as Bargain Hunters Snap Up Good Buys
DOC.TEXT: The stock market made a comeback today as investors snapped up issues that had been pushed to attractively low prices during Wall Street's recent weak spell. A retreat in oil prices and strength in the bond market this morning contributed to an improved attitude toward stocks. The perception that tensions in the Middle East might be diffused without prolonged difficulty also helped restore investor confidence and encouraged renewed buying. ``A lot of stocks looked like real bargains,'' said Hugh Johnson, investment strategist at First Albany Corp. ``There were plenty of stocks that were either dirt cheap or, at a minium, undervalued.'' But some buying enthusiasm was subdued by concerns that the financial markets remain vulnerable to shocks from developments in the Middle East. The slide in petroleum prices caused a selloff in oil and related stocks. The contract for September delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, pulled back by $2.35 to $25.96 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Analysts took comfort from the stock market's ability to maintain its advance today despite an afternoon downturn in bonds and a jump in interest rates.

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: interest rates.
DOC.TEXT: The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 24.26 to 2,734.90, according to a preliminary calculation. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by better than 5 to 3 on the New York Stock Exchange, with about 1,010 up and 595 down. Full figures were not available. Big Board volume eased to 190.40 million shares from 231.58 million in the previous session. The NYSE's composite index rose 1.95 to 185.40. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 340.03, up 0.19.

DOC.HEAD: Union Trying to Buy Forest Products Company
DOC.TEXT: A millworkers' union says it is drafting a proposal for employees to buy Roseburg Forest Products Co., in an attempt to protect jobs. ``I assume we will make a viable proposal unless something breaks down in the next few days,'' Mike Draper, executive secretary of the Western Council of Industrial Workers, said Tuesday. Draper said he was not overly optimistic about the buyout's success, but said, ``We will make our presence known.'' Roseburg Forest Products is the largest privately held wood products company in the nation. It owns 14 mills in southern Oregon and Northern Californa and about 850,000 acres of timberland. Draper said it has 4,500 employees. The company is controlled by founder and board chairman Kenneth Ford, 82, and a few family members. The Oregonian newspaper quoted an unnamed timber industry consultant as estimating the purchase price could exceed $1 billion. No asking price has been revealed, and Roseburg has refused comment on a proposed sale of the company. Draper said the union has retained Keilin & Bloom of New York to draft a purchase proposal. The firm helped plan the March buyout of Colt Firearms in Connecticut and the proposed employee buyout of UAL Corp., the parent of United Airlines. Though preliminary planning has been conducted without consulting union members, no plans would be made final without a vote, Draper said. ``You've got to get your oar in the water if you're going to paddle the boat,'' he said. ``We will keep them informed if we get to round two.''

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Firm Buys 50 Percent Interest in Lipstein's Magazine Company
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese media concern has purchased a 50 percent stake in the magazine company that publishes Mother Earth News, Psychology Today and the men's magazine Smart. The investment, disclosed Tuesday, was seen as a key part of publisher Owen Lipstein's effort to save his New American Magazine Co. Lipstein announced that Japanese Independent Communication Co., a 20-year-old media company based in Tokyo, had paid an undisclosed sum for a half-interest in his company. Published reports said the price was less than $15 million. The acquisition was believed to be the first major investment in American magazine publishing by a Japanese company. JICC publishes 10 magazines and more than 300 books a year. It also produces records, music videos and compact disks, computer software and films. The Japanese company said it hope its partnership with New American Magazine will result in developing a ``leading edge publishing and media organization in the United States.'' Lipstein said he will continue as chairman and president of the company, as publisher of Mother Earth News and Psychology Today and president of Smart, a magazine he owns with its founder Terry McDonell. McDonell will continue as chairman of Smart and will serve as that magazine's publisher and editor in chief. Lipstein's company has faced severe financial problems over the past year as he struggled to pay the debt incurred in buying Mother Earth News in 1985 and Psychology Today in 1988. He sold American Health magazine to Reader's Digest Association last year for $29.1 million, but that did not resolve the financial problems. Psychology Today suspended publication in December. It is expected to be relaunched this fall.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended higher Wednesday against all major currencies except the Japanese yen and Canadian dollar, boosted by the rising tensions in the Middle East. Gold prices declined following a mixed performance overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $383.20 a troy ounce, down $1.30 from Tuesday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $382.70 an ounce, off $2.80. Currency dealers said the dollar started out sharply higher, then fell back on technical factors. President Bush said Wednesday that U.S. warplanes and combat troops, backed by an armada of Navy ships, took up defensive positions in Saudi Arabia to protect that country against a possible invasion by Iraq. The announcement seemed to calm the financial markets. Nonetheless, the possiblity of a conflict with Iraq pushed the dollar higher, dealers said. Those concerns, they said, outweighed any fundamental worries about economic weakness that could drive interest rates lower and make the dollar less appealing to foreign investors. ``On fears of the Middle East the dollar was way up,'' said Robert Ryan, corporate foreign exchange manager for the Bank of New York. Some dealers in Europe, though, debated whether the dollar was the safest currency to hold right now. In fact, after Iraq invaded neighboring Kuwait last week, which touched off the Mideast tensions, currency dealers flocked to the German mark. The dollar had declined on worries that a rapid rise in oil prices eventually would push interest rates lower. In Tokyo, where the global trading day begins, the dollar fell to a closing 150.00 Japanese yen from 150.60 yen Tuesday. It traded at 150.15 yen in London, and at 149.90 yen in New York, down from 150.90. The dollar was stronger against the British pound compared to Tuesday. Sterling traded at $1.8660 in London, down from $1.8765, and at $1.86885 in New York, down from $1.8715. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.5920 German marks, up from 1.5875; 1.3380 Swiss francs, up from 1.3370; 5.3365 French francs, up from 5.3230; 1,165.00 Italian lire, up from 1,162.25; and 1.14785 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15125. Late dollar rates in Europe compared with Tuesday: 1.5940 German marks, up from 1.5763; 1.3435 Swiss francs, up from 1.3315; 5.3445 French francs, up from 5.2995; 1.7955 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7785; 1,166.37 Italian lire, up from 1,155.37, and 1.1485 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1495. Gold fell in London to $382.25 an ounce from $383.25 late Tuesday. But in Zurich, bullion rose to $384.35 an ounce from $383.15. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell 87 cents to close at $382.65 an ounce. Silver prices slipped. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.843 a troy ounce, down from $4.857 Tuesday. Silver fell in London to $4.87 an ounce from $4.89.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Falls, Stocks Rise As Oil-Shortage Threats Appear To Diminish
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices sank and stocks rose Wednesday as the markets assessed prospects that many oil-producing nations could step into the breach and pump plenty of crude to prevent shortages from further Iraqi militance in the Persian Gulf. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the cost of key West Texas Intermediate crude for September delivery plummeted $2.35 to settle at $25.96 a barrel. The contract had risen 26 cents in volatile trading Tuesday to close at its highest level since Dec. 6, 1985, according to Mercantile Exchange records. Prices for petroleum products also declined sharply. The near-term contract for unleaded gasoline plunged 6.18 cents to settle at 76.21 cents a gallon, while home heating oil finished at 70.13 cents a gallon, off 5.01 cents. Other contract months declined by lesser amounts. Stock prices gained ground around the world as traders searched for bargains and expressed relief that events in the Persian Gulf appeared to show signs of stabilizing, despite the virtual shutoff of oil from Iraq and its occupied neighbor Kuwait. ``It's not as volatile a situation as it was perceived to be, and (investors) are a little more confident of taking a position,'' said James Schroeder, an analyst at Chicago-based MMS International. The Dow Jones industrial average, which slipped 5.70 points on Tuesday for its sixth straight loss, gained 24.26 points to close at 2,734.90. ``Clearly the dominant factor in the market ... was the alleged commitment by the Saudis that they are going to increase oil production,'' said Bob Baker, senior energy analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Experts said Iraq and Kuwait together produced about 4 million barrels of crude daily, but increased Saudi production could cover about 50 percent of that. A number of other oil producers, including Venezuela, Mexico, Iran and Nigeria, also indicated they could up production. Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez, for example, was reported to have offered to sell the United States an additional 500,000 barrels of oil a day. But there remained no clear indication that oil producers actually had begun pumping extra crude. In fact, OPEC President and Algerian Oil Minister Sadek Boussena said ``individual initiatives'' by OPEC members ``should be avoided.'' He said fears of supply disruptions were the result of ``psychological and speculative factors, (rather) than real market fundamentals.'' Analysts interpreted Boussena's statement as a call for the West to draw down its petroleum stocks before OPEC would move to fill any supply gaps. There was a growing perception that oil reserves are plentiful. President Bush also sought to allay fears of an oil shortage by saying Wednesday that he was considering dipping into the nation's strategic reserves to bolster supplies in the face of an absence of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil exports. Traders in the oil pits were anticipating an escalation of hostilities, but nothing unexpected surfaced. A statement out of Baghdad declared Kuwait part of Iraq but stopped short of saying Iraq had annexed the tiny emirate following last week's lightning raid led by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. The statment came less than two hours after President Bush told the nation that U.S. troops were taking up ``defensive positions'' in oil-rich Saudi Arabia to guard against a possible attack by Iraq. In London, the spot price of Brent Blend, the most widely traded international crude oil, fell to $25.40 a barrel from $27.40 late Tuesday. Stock prices rose on major foreign markets. In Tokyo, the Nikkei index of 225 shares recouped 856.07 points, or 3.10 percent, ending the day at 28,509.14. Traders said the rebound reflected stability in bond and currency markets. The Nikkei lost 946.46 on Tuesday and had dropped 3,184.92 points since Thursday, when Iraq invaded Kuwait. Prices got off to a bumpy start in Europe but managed to close higher on the London Stock Exchange. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 1.7 points, or 0.08 percent, at 2,237.5 at the close after seesawing throughout most of the session. In other financial markets, bond prices narrowly mixed. The Treasury's auction of $10.5 billion in 10-year notes went off worse than expected and depressed the credit markets. In the currency markets, the dollar was down against the Japanese yen but up against most European currencies. The dollar fell 0.60 yen to 150.00 yen in Tokyo but was quoted in London at 150.15 yen. It slipped again in New York, closing at 149.90. The U.S. currency rose against the German mark, the British pound and the Swiss franc. Elsewhere, gold prices were mostly lower. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $383.20 a troy ounce, down $1.30 from Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Arco Freezes Wholesale Fuel Prices After Bush Request
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 2nd graf pvs to UPDATE with Exxon statement; PICKS UP 3rd graf pvs, `Arco, the...
DOC.TEXT: Atlantic Richfield Co. on Wednesday froze wholesale fuel prices for one week, the first oil company to respond to President Bush's call for restraint during the Middle East crisis. Other big oil companies said they already are practicing restraint and denied widespread allegations they have been using instability in the Persian Gulf as an excuse to gouge consumers at the gas pump. Exxon Corp. said it would continue pricing its products ``in a responsible manner that reflects overall market supply conditions.'' The world's largest oil company said it buys 2.7 million barrels of oil daily and ``must compete on world markets and pay world market prices. Arco, the eighth-largest U.S. oil company, said its freeze affects prices of gasoline, diesel and jet fuel. Arco also said it was encouraging its dealers, who by federal law set their own pump prices, to avoid increases. Bush earlier Wednesday asked oil companies ``to do their fair share'' in holding down gas prices, which have risen more than 16 cents a gallon at the pump since Iraq invaded Kuwait last Thursday. ``We hope the market will stabilize during this time, but if at the end the week our position is out of line with world market prices we will have to recognize that fact,'' George Babikian, president of Arco Products Co., the company's refining and marketing division, said in a statement. ``We will not raise our prices even then unless we are substantially below the general market,'' he said. ``Otherwise, if we remain below the market we risk a run on our stations which could drain our supply and create a panic buying situation in the marketplace.'' Arco operates 1,700 stations in Arizona, California, Nevada, Oregon and Washington. Arco gets most of its crude from Alaska, but the cost of its oil still reflects world market prices. The American Automobile Association said Wednesday the price of self-service regular unleaded gasoline rose an average 3.6 cents a gallon nationwide overnight to $1.237 a gallon, for a rise of 16.2 cents since Aug. 1. Other oil companies said they supported Bush's call for restraint, but blamed market forces for rising prices and said they had behaved fairly. ``While we have raised prices, to date we have recovered only a fraction of the higher costs incurred,'' Mobil Corp. Chairman Allen E. Murray said in a letter to Bush. Mobil also planned advertisements headlined ``Where's the Rip-off?'' stating its position on the editorial pages of Thursday's New York Times and later this week in several other publications. ``Restraint has been a longstanding policy at Texaco,'' that company said. ``We have been doing so and we fully intend to continue exercising restraint in gasoline prices.'' Executives said crude oil prices had increased much faster than gas prices in the last month. Some attacked recent allegations of price gouging by politicians and consumer groups as opportunistic and unfair. Already bruised by bad public relations after the Exxon Valdez oil spill, oil companies also had to contend with revived memories of profiteering allegations that followed the 1973 Arab oil embargo. Oil companies frequently have been criticized since gasoline prices soared from about 39 cents a gallon in 1973 to 53 cents a year later following the Arab oil embargo. Prices climbed to nearly 69 cents by 1978, before surging above $1 when Iranian supplies were cut off by its 1979 revolution deposing the regime of U.S. ally the Shah. More recently, the industry came under attack when prices jumped after the Exxon Valdez spill off the Alaska coast last year and heating oil skyrocketed during a December freeze. Despite allegations, no profiteering or collusion by companies was proven. ``The Sun Co. is not recovering its costs at the present time,'' Robert McClements, chairman and chief executive of the Philadelphia-based oil company, said in an interview. ``Unfortunately we are in an election year and there is a temptation on the part of many of those in the political arena who, in the desire for public exposure, thrash out one more time at the oil industry,'' he said. Amoco Oil Co. said the price it charges gasoline dealers has increased about 10 cents a gallon in the last week, compared with 20 cents on ``spot'' oil markets for immediately fuel delivery. But the Chicago company said ``the market system of supply and demand and open competition in petroleum pricing can allow for rapid price increases.'' ``Supply disruptions at a major company like Amoco could be far worse for consumers than temporary higher prices,'' it said. ``The consumer is better served by a market system that reacts and distributes products efficiently.'' Several executives said even though it can take up to 90 days for crude oil to reach the United States from the Middle East, companies usually pay the market price in effect when it arrives at the refinery, not the price when it was contracted for. They said about 50 percent of crude oil in the United States is produced from domestic sources, where delivery time is much shorter. Also, large amounts of gasoline are purchased on often volatile ``spot'' markets. Finally, as with other commodities, market prices can rise immediately as companies seek to cover future replacement costs.

DOC.SECOND: AM-Neil Bush: S&L Poster Boy, Adv 12,1296
DOC.NOTE: $adv12
For Release Sunday AMs, Aug. 12
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
Bush's `Sensitive' Son a Lightning Rod for S&L Scandal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The ``Jail Neil Bush'' posters have sprouted around town, making their way from the bohemian side streets of Dupont Circle to the broad avenues of the capital's downtown. The third son of George and Barbara Bush has become, literally, the poster boy of the nation's savings and loan scandal, his patrician face plastered on lamp posts in a parody of an FBI ``Wanted'' handbill. His family name, which catapulted him into the altitudes of wealth and power in Denver five years ago, now has thrown him into the vortex of public controversy. In August 1985, with scant banking experience behind him, Neil Bush joined the board of directors of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association, a Denver thrift that went bust three years later at a cost to taxpayers of $1 billion. Now Bush stands accused by thrift regulators of conflict of interest for not disclosing business links to big Silverado borrowers _ he denies any wrongdoing. He also could be a target of a negligence lawsuit that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. is considering filing against him and other Silverado directors. Federal investigators are looking into thousands of cases of S&L fraud and mismanagement, and scores of similar lawsuits could be filed by the FDIC. But Neil Bush's case is different. As a symbol of the thrift crisis, he could become a political liability for his father and the Republican Party in a $500-billion campaign issue. Neil Mallon Bush, born on Jan. 22, 1955, was recently described by the president as ``probably the most sensitive of the four boys, maybe the second-most sensitive'', ``a good kid.'' His childhood problems with dyslexia inspired his mother's avid interest in reading programs. He was 30 years old when he joined the Silverado board _ a tender age to assume such a position of trust at a federally insured institution. Only 1 percent of all savings and loan directors were under 35 in 1988, according to a survey by the U.S. League of Savings Institutions. The average age of a thrift director was 57. Bush's only work in banking before becoming a Silverado director was a summer job at Republic National Bank in Dallas. ``I worked in the trust department filling out forms,'' he told regulators in a closed hearing last December. The regulators have asserted Bush was ``unqualified and untrained'' to be a savings and loan director _ although that doesn't excuse him, they said. Flashback to the heady days of the oil industry in the American West in the early 1980s. The Iranian oil cutoff in 1979 had spawned skyrocketing prices and long, aggravating waits in gasoline lines at home. The rugged oil fields of Colorado and Wyoming, which overnight had become economic to develop, were gripped by a gold rush fever. Suddenly, it seemed, everyone was in the oil business. Legions of brash entrepreneurs swept into town, eager to take risks and get a piece of the action. Neil Bush was one of them. He came to Denver armed with a bachelor's degree and an MBA, both from Tulane University in New Orleans, and some experience working in his father's 1980 presidential campaign and his brother George's unsuccessful bid for Congress in Texas. In the summer of 1980, Bush was hired as a landman by Amoco Production Co. in Denver, negotiating oil leases. ``Neil was very, very tough,'' said Tom Vessels, a Denver oilman who negotiated lease deals with Bush. He also was ``all-round curious,'' asking more questions than most landmen, recalled Vessels, who owns a small oil company bearing his name and is president of the Independent Petroleum Association of Mountain States. Few others in what's now left of the Rockies oil industry seem to remember Bush. That's not surprising, since there were scores of small independent oilmen in the region in those days. ``I've never known anybody who's dealt with him in the oil business,'' said Bill Owens, executive director of the Colorado Petroleum Association. Bush left Amoco in late 1982 and set up an oil partnership with two geologists called JNB Exploration Co. For an investment of only $100, Bush acquired 23.4 percent of the business. For two years, JNB drilled a succession of dry holes in Wyoming's Powder River Basin and failed to become profitable. That was common in those days. What was unusual, oilmen say, was how Bush's ``silent'' partners kept pumping money into the business despite its track record. The fact that Bush was a son of the vice president likely had something to do with that. His silent partners in JNB _ wealthy Denver developers Kenneth M. Good and Bill L. Walters _ probably reckoned they might get more than oil from the millions of dollars they invested in Bush's company. Influence and connections can often be as valuable as money to people like Good and Walters, who were already heavy borrowers from high-flying Silverado when Bush joined the board. Michael R. Wise, the chairman of Silverado at the time, also knew the value of connections. He was on the board of the U.S. League, the S&L industry's main lobbying group, and had personal contacts with regulators. In mid-1985, Wise invited Bush to join the board of Silverado, which was at the zenith of its go-go period. Silverado was making huge loans for grandiose real estate schemes right and left, though many of the ventures were never finished. The thrift was a gold mine for fast-and-loose developers, since it was playing with depositors' money that was insured by the federal government. Good and Walters, two of the biggest borrowers, got a combined $117 million in loans that they never repaid. The leading borrower, Bell Savings and Loan Association of San Mateo, Calif., got $124.8 million. Its chairman at the time, David Butler, pleaded guilty last year to loan fraud and was sentenced to two years in prison. ``Management of Silverado took excessive risks, engaged in abusive or questionable practices to generate short-term gains and undertook innovative manipulations to avoid recording losses,'' the Office of Thrift Supervision said in a report published last May. ``The board did little beyond rubber stamping the activities of (Silverado's) sophisticated, bright and manipulative management team.'' As a director, Bush voted to approve loans _ including some of the projects sponsored by Good and Walters. The regulators have accused him of conflict of interest in not disclosing to Silverado his links with the two developers through JNB. Bush denies the allegations. He concedes, however, that his family ties helped him get the Silverado position. ``I would be naive if I were to sit here and deny that the Bush name didn't have something to do with it,'' he said in a recent interview with Time magazine. ``Maybe the advantage of being part of the vice president's family at the time was that I was accepted more quickly in terms of age and years in this community (Denver) than others of my peer group.'' The family name, however, has become a double-edged sword. Because he is the president's son, Bush has captured the public imagination more than any other player in the national S&L drama. The unsigned ``Jail Neil Bush'' posters haven't reached Main Street, but across the country, Neil Bush's face is now recognized by many of the taxpayers who will have to shell out $2,000 each to cover thrift losses.

DOC.HEAD: Rising Oil Prices Could Help Coal
With AM-Iraq-Consumers, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soaring oil prices aren't expected to create any abrupt increases in coal prices, but experts agree the coal industry could receive a much needed boost if oil prices remain high. ``I think you're very unlikely to see any massive switching (from oil to coal),'' said John Gresser of the National Coal Association. But he said the industry is in a good position to increase production if other countries move from oil to coal. Coal prices have remained fairly stable at $22 to $26 a ton in recent months because of intense domestic and foreign competition, experts said. Gresser said coal doesn't compete directly with oil, so a rise in oil prices has little effect on coal. And he said U.S. utilities cannot quickly switch from burning oil to burning coal in power plants. But experts said more plants in European can be converted, and there, the sale of coal may increase. ``We could see maybe a jump in (European) demand from 3 million to 6 million tons,'' Wyn Holbrock of the A.T. Massey Coal Co. in Richmond, Va., told the Charleston Daily Mail. Japanese plants can also switch from oil to coal, analysts said. ``In Europe and the Far East, there is a distinct possibility over a longer trend of time that the price of coal as an exporter would be impacted,'' said Mark Cohen, a coal analyst for Kidder, Peabody and Co. Wayne T. Ewing, president of Peabody Development Co. and chairman of the National Coal Association, said the demand for coal exports will be greater if the oil crisis continues, especially because prices are soon to be negotiated for next year. ``If this thing continues to escalate, it will have some effect here in the U.S.,'' Ewing said. The experts said oil prices must continue to remain high, however, before the U.S. coal industry will see major results. ``High oil prices must stick around for a long time with implications of no improvement,'' said Rafael Villagran, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. If some utilities do switch to coal, they can be assured of a large supply, Gresser said. He said 1 billion tons of coal will be produced this year and the coal industry can easily increase production. ``After the last oil embargo, people thought there would be more of a demand for coal,'' Gresser said. ``Many people purchased coal mines and that capacity is still there to meet any sort of increased demands.'' But Villagren cautioned that an increased European demand for coal does not necessarily help U.S. coal producers. ``The U.S. has stiff competition from the Australians and the Far East,'' he said.
