DOC.HEAD: Market Makes a Comeback Amid Bargain Hunting
DOC.TEXT: The stock market rebounded Wednesday as investors hunted for bargains among the issues battered during Wall Street's recent weak spell. A retreat in oil prices eased inflation anxieties, contributing to an improved attitude toward stocks. Also, a perception that tensions in the Middle East might be diffused without prolonged difficulty helped stabilize shaky investor confidence and encouraged renewed buying. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials snapped a string of six straight losing sessions and advanced 24.26 to 2,734.90. Advancing issues outnumbered declining ones by better than 5 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 1,015 up, 601 down and 406 unchanged. Trading activity slowed from the brisk pace of recent days. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 190.40 million shares, down from 231.58 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 237.91 million shares. ``A lot of stocks looked like real bargains,'' said Hugh Johnson, investment strategist at First Albany Corp. ``There were plenty of stocks that were either dirt cheap or, at a minium, undervalued.'' Some buying enthusiasm was suppressed by concerns that financial markets still are vulnerable to shocks from the Middle East. The full economic implications of the turmoil caused by Iraq's invasion and subsequent occupation of Kuwait are unknown. There has been speculation, however, that the struggling U.S. economy could be pushed into recession. Market analysts said the U.S. decision to send troops to Saudi Arabia, in what President Bush emphasized was a defensive role, deterred speculation that the crisis would worsen. The slide in petroleum prices sparked a selloff in energy stocks. The contract for September delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, pulled back by $2.35 to $25.96 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Among the blue chip oil stocks, Chevron dropped 1~ to 76~, Exxon tumbled 1| to 51} and Texaco fell 1} to 62}. The retreat in oil prices gave a lift to transportation stocks, particularly airline issues. The Dow Jones transportation average rose 26.64 to 991.42, posting its first gain since July 25. Woolworth, which reported a 4.2 percent increase in its second-quarter income, climbed 1{ to 28~. Several other retailing stocks joined Woolworth in moving higher. Wal-Mart added 1| to 30\, department store operator Dillard jumped 4\ to 84\ and May Department Stores moved { higher to 44. Disney surged 4| to 108 while MCA gained 1{ to 47 and CBS advanced 6} to 176. Speculation circulated in the market that Disney might be preparing for a major acquisition. Actively traded blue chips included: Philip Morris, up ] to 45|; American Telephone & Telegraph, off ] to 35; Boeing, up 1 to 53; International Business Machines, up [ to 103[; General Electric, up | to 67~; Eastman Kodak, up 1[ to 41[; and McDonald's, up ] to 30[. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market gained $27.68 billion, or 0.87 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 1.95 to 185.40. Standard & Poor's industrial index went up 3.86 to 398.96, and S&P's 500-stock composite index ended at 338.35, up 3.52. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market increased 5.65 to 407.73. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 340.03, up 0.19.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Falters, Copper Gains As Oil Price Falls
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices fell Wednesday and copper futures climbed as a downturn in oil prices prompted an abrupt change in speculation about the economy. On other commodity markets, pork futures fell sharply; cattle extended their gains; and grains and soybeans were mixed. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold futures settled $1.20 to $1.50 lower with the contract for delivery in August at $383.20 a troy ounce; silver futures finished 1.5 cents to 1.8 cents lower with August at $4.843 a troy ounce. Copper futures ended 2 cents to 3.65 cents higher on the Commodity Exchange with August at $1.31 a pound. The moves reflected a shift away from the inflation and recession fears that began building late last week, when Iraq invaded Kuwait and touched off a runup in oil prices and a plunge in stock prices worldwide. The gold market responds quickly to inflation fears because the metal is perceived as an investment hedge against inflation. Copper is used heavily throughout the construction and manufacturing industries, so its price is especially sensitive to signs of economic expansion or recession. Economy jitters eased Wednesday as the price of crude oil fell and the U.S. stock market rebounded, partly in reaction to the movement of U.S. forces into Saudi Arabia to defend against Iraqi threats to oil-producing nations beyond Kuwait. Analysts said word that Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and other major oil-producing nations would increase their output also worked to suppress crude prices. OPEC President Sadek Boussena urged members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to avoid such ``individual intiatives.'' But Tom Bentz, director of trading with United Energy Inc., said OPEC is likely to cooperate with the cartel's customers. ``It's not in their best interest to let prices go to $35 or $40 a barrel, because then people start looking for alternative sources of energy,'' Bentz said. West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures settled 83 cent to $2.35 lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange with the September contract at $25.96 a barrel; heating oil was 2.46 cents to 5.01 cents lower with September at 70.13 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 2.13 cents to 3.8 cents lower with September at 76.21 cents a gallon. Pork futures plummeted on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, reflecting seasonal factors and a bulge in hog production. ``We've had a year of good profitability in the hog market and we're beginning to see the results in increased slaughter,'' said Thomas Morgan, president of Sterling Research Corp. in Arlington Heights, Ill. Most hog contracts and some belly contracts fell their permitted daily limits of 1.5 cents and 2 cents, respectively. Live hogs finished 1.22 to 1.5 cents lower with August at 56.57 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .32 cent to 2 cents lower with August at 50.75 cents a pound. Cattle futures rose moderately, extending strong gains posted Tuesday that were linked to a better economic outlook and strong cash markets. Live cattle futures ended .02 cent to .23 cent higher with August at 78 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent lower to .28 cent higher with August at 89.95 cents a pound. Wheat futures rose modestly on the Chicago Board of Trade following news of export sales of the grain and speculation that more such sales may be in the works. Corn and soybean futures edged lower. Sales of U.S. wheat to Egypt, Mexico and Algeria were confirmed Wednesday, said Katharina Zimmer, grain analyst with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets Inc. She said the market also was supported by Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter's statement at a news conference that he hopes to see an increase in subsidized export sales of U.S. wheat. Wheat settled 2{ cents to 3} cents higher with September at $2.84{ a bushel; corn was 1} cents lower to { cent higher with September at $1.17\ a bushel; soybeans were 1\ cent to 3 cents lower with August at $5.93\ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Documents Ordered Released, Trump Lawyers Get Stay
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: New Jersey regulators ruled Wednesday that more than 1,000 pages of documents detailing Donald Trump's financial rescue package must be made public, but they still remained secret while his lawyers appeal the decision. The Casino Control Commission, which must approve the plan involving Trump's three Atlantic City casinos, said the release would not constitute an unwarranted invasion of Trump's private business dealings. The public's interest in casino operations takes precedence over Trump's desire to keep his business affairs private, the commission ruled. The commission is expected to hold a public hearing on the restructuring plan within the next month. Trump lawyer Joseph Fusco argued that the documents contain sensitive financial information, much of which has nothing to do with his casino holdings. He also argued the arrangement with the banks has not yet been made final, and the release of information could jeopardize negotiations. Fusco obtained a delay and will appear before Superior Court Jude Arnold Stein Thursday in Morristown in his effort to reverse the commission's ruling. Only one document, Trump's application to the commission for approval of the financial package, was released before Trump's lawyers obtained the legal delay. Commission Chairwoman Valerie Armstrong said it was virtually impossible to understand that document without examining the host of other financial reports. The application appeared to shed little new light on Trump's financial arrangement with nine banks to make ends meet over the next three to five years. It reports that Trump will receive a $65 million line of credit and will be able to defer about $85 million in annual interest payments for between three and five years. Under the agreement, Trump for the first time is using his casinos as collateral for financial assistance. The agreement with the banks will restructure about $1 billion of his $1.3 billion casino debt and $1.9 billion in other debts. In exchange for providing the fresh credit, Trump's rescuers have gained some control over his holdings and will closely monitor his personal and business dealings for years to come. The agreement also requires him to appoint a senior executive officer to oversee his operations. Sources have reported that the $65 million bailout and debt restructuring package also requires Trump to sell assets to raise cash, but the document released Wednesday did not refer to the sale of assets. Trump has discussed selling his Trump Shuttle and the Trump Princess, the 282-foot yacht he bought for $30 million. Trump has confirmed in the past that the agreement limits his household and personal spending to $450,000 a month for the rest of this year. The banks hope that by deferring about half of his $2 billion bank debt for up to five years, Trump will gain time to sell his assets in an orderly way. The document released Wednesday also says the restructuring will protect the Trump casinos from claims by creditors and will not affect the payment terms of the casino indebtedness. The three casinos, and their indebtedness, are Trump Taj Mahal, $725 million; Trump Plaza, $275 million; and Trump's Castle Hotel and Casino, $402 million. The documents were public information for about two hours, but commission officials refused to allow reporters to see the material, saying copies were being made. About two hours later, and after only one of the one less important documents had been copied and released, Trump's lawyers obtained the legal delay.

DOC.HEAD: Thorn EMI Beefs Music Title Catalogue
DOC.TEXT: Entertainment giant Thorn EMI said Wednesday it had added 90,000 titles to its vast catalogue of classic songs by paying 61.5 million pounds, or about $115 million, for a music publishing company. The acquisition of British-based Filmtrax and its U.S. subsidiary, Filmtrax Copyright Holdings, means Thorn EMI now owns the rights to music from many top Broadway shows, Hollywood musicals and pop songs like ``Stormy Weather'' and ``Itsy Bitsy Teeny Weeny Yellow Polka Dot Bikini.'' Thorn EMI's catalogue contained 600,000 titles before its latest buy, which will add considerably to the company's earning power. Film scores include those from ``Tootsie,'' ``Ghostbusters'' and ``Close Encounters of the Third Kind,'' as well as jazz greats like ``Stardust'' by Hoagy Carmichael, Fats Waller's ``Ain't Misbehavin''' and ``Sophisticated Lady'' by Duke Ellington. Colin Southgate, Thorn EMI chairman and chief executive, said of the new acquisition, ``It will extend the success already achieved ... making us the world's pre-eminent music publishing company.''

DOC.HEAD: Flint Strike Could Hamper Other Plants
DOC.TEXT: Employees walked off the job at a General Motors Corp. parts plant Wednesday in a strike GM officials said could shut down other assembly plants. The walkout at GM's AC Rochester Division Flint West plant came after negotiations on employee grievances about health and safety issues broke off about 9:25 a.m., said Duane Zuckschwerdt, a United Auto Workers union bargainer. ``Hopefully, it won't be a long strike,'' Zuckschwerdt said. ``We're obviously disappointed,'' said GM President Lloyd Reuss, reached at a meeting at Traverse City. Reuss estimated that the walkout could force production cuts or shutdowns at six to eight assembly plants. He declined to identify which plants could be affected, but said, ``I would expect the assembly plants to be impacted in the next two to three days.'' With a typical assembly plant employing 5,000 people or more, the numbers of employees affected could be in the tens of thousands, GM spokesman John Maciarz said. The strike would affect other plants that rely on just-in-time delivery of parts made at the plant in Flint. Under the just-in-time system, such parts as gas tanks, van doors and grilles are shipped as needed rather than kept in storage. ``There are no big warehouses out in back any more,'' Maciarz said. If the strike at the 2,800-employee Flint complex isn't resolved, he said, ``Certainly a large number of our assembly operations would be impacted, and other supplier divisions would be impacted because of not being able to send parts to assembly plants. By Monday, anyway, we would begin to see an impact.'' Maciarz said GM negotiators were ready to continue talks with the union, but he didn't know when they might resume. Zuckschwerdt said bargainers from UAW Local 659, representing the AC Rochester workers, and GM had met until 8:40 p.m. Tuesday and reconvened at 6 a.m. Wednesday. Because the impact would spread rapidly to other plants and other employees, the local is under pressure not only from GM but from other UAW locals, said David Cole, director of the Office for the Study of Automotive Transportation at the University of Michigan. Reuss wouldn't speculate on whether the Flint walkout would have any impact on national contract talks going on between the Big Three automakers and the UAW. ``You don't want to read too much into this,'' he said. He said GM will be pressing for a settlement because its car inventories are at their lowest point since the early 1980s.

DOC.HEAD: Fed: U.S. Economy Slackening Before Iraqi Invasion of Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS first reference to Boskin in 10th graf, ``It could...
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. economy was slackening well before higher oil prices following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait threatened to push it closer to a recession, the Federal Reserve reported Wednesday. While a survey of the 12 Fed districts found the nation's economy continuing to grow, ``most noted that the pace was slow or had slackened recently,'' the central bank said in releasing its Beige Book, a periodic economic assessment. Many economists fear higher energy costs could shock an already soft economy into recession. The U.S. Chamber of Commerce on Wednesday predicted that even without higher energy costs, the economy would grind to a standstill during the current quarter and then fall into a recession starting in the fourth quarter. The Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta completed the survey July 27 for use at the Aug. 21 meeting of the central bank's Federal Open Market Committee. The committee, which establishes U.S. monetary policy, adopted a tight credit policy more than a year ago to slow the economy and lessen inflationary pressures. But as evidence of a weakening economy mounted even before the Middle East eruption, many officials and economists were calling for a looser grip to stimulate growth. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said Wednesday he and President Bush want the Fed give economic growth a boost by lowering interest rates, saying strong growth is particularly important as the United States responds to Iraq's invasion. ``Everybody wants lower interest rates. ... At this point in time in the United States, economic growth is very important,'' he said told a news conference. Meanwhile, the chairman of the President's Council on Economic Advisers said it was too soon to forecast accurately the potential effects of recent oil price increases on the nation's economy. ``It could be significant and it could be modest,'' Michael Boskin said in Traverse City, Mich., while attending a management seminar. ``For the kinds of price increases we've seen thus far it's likely that the economy would be able to absorb them.'' But he said if the price of crude oil settles in a $25 to $28 a barrel range as has been estimated, it would shave 0.5 to 0.7 percentage points off of increases in the gross national product and would add one percentage point to the consumer price index. ``Then the inflation rate would drift back down,'' he said. The Commerce Department reported the economy grew at a meager 1.2 percent annual rate in the quarter ending June 30 and just 1.7 percent in the previous three-month period. Another sign of a slowing economy came last Friday when the Labor Department reported unemployment rose to 5.5 percent, the highest level in two years. While the Fed's latest survey found sluggish growth continuing in the third quarter, it also indicated inflation was not subsiding. It said wages in some districts were rising between 3 percent and 5 percent, in most cases excluding benefits. At the same time, some districts reported widespread price increases while other said businesses were having to absorb higher costs at the expense of profit margins. ``Retail sales were generally described as a little better than a year ago or soft, with weaker-than-expected demand for big-ticket items cited most often,'' the survey said. ``Retailers in New York City are less optimistic about the outlook given the continuing layoffs at banks and brokerage firms, while those in St. Louis expressed similar views in light of anticipated defense cutbacks,'' it added. Residential real estate construction and sales were below their 1989 pace, often because of high inventories which in many cases caused falling prices, the survey found. The soft housing industry also was causing weak sales of home furnishings and appliances. Overall manufacturing activity was flat, the survey found, although it varied from industry to industry. Demand for domestic steel was up, partly due to auto production. At the same time, the survey found vehicle sales either flat or below year-ago levels. But with the exception of steel and commercial aircraft, manufacturing inventories and lead times were said to be slowing. Most districts also reported employment was either flat or likely to weaken based on announced layoffs. ``Several districts report that the pace of commercial loan growth has recently slowed and some indicate that its levels are below those of a year ago,'' the survey found. Lending to consumers also was off, but not to the extent of commercial loans. The survey found the outlook for agricultural production generally good, although poor weather conditions were hurting crops in some areas.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
American Airlines to Hike Fares 10 Percent Because of Fuel Costs
DOC.TEXT: American Airlines said Wednesday it would raise fares by 10 percent because of skyrocketing fuel costs resulting from the Persian Gulf crisis. Michael W. Gunn, the airline's senior vice president for marketing, said the increase will go into effect Friday for flights in the continental United States, Hawaii and the Caribbean and on Aug. 15 for international flights. ``We regret the recent events in the Middle East have caused a significant increase in fuel prices, leading to the need to increase air fares,'' Gunn said. Delta Air Lines, based in Atlanta, said it would not raise fares immediately, but said increases were likely. ``Travelers who can confirm their plans might be well advised to make their reservations and purchase tickets now,'' Whit Hawkins, Delta's senior vice president for marketing said in a press release. In recent days, Pan American World Airways and Northwest Airlines said they would raise their fares because of soaring fuel costs. Every one-cent increase in the price per gallon of jet fuel adds more than $2 million a month to the airline's costs, Smith said. American Airlines uses more than 200 million gallons of jet fuel each month, American Airlines spokesman Tim said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Stock Prices Move Lower in Early Trading
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against the Japanese yen in early trading Thursday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange lost moderately. On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues lost 113.80 points, or 0.39 percent, moving to 28,395.34 in the first 15 minutes of trading. The index gained 856.07 points on Wednesday. The dollar started trading at 149.50 yen, down 0.50 yen from Wednesday's close of 150.00 yen. Currency dealers said the dollar's retreat was carried over from New York trading, where the currency finished at 149.90 yen, down from 150.90 yen on Tuesday. Kan Sugita, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo, said that although the dollar moved slightly in early trading, ``many market players are very nervous'' over uncertainties about Middle East. Sugita said the market did not show ``immediate' reaction to U.S. President George Bush's announcement Wednesday that he has sending U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia to guard the world's largest oil-producing country against a possible attack by Iraq. ``People wanted to take a wait-and-see position to see whether there's any military clash'' with Iraq, Sugita said. In bond dealings, the yield of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds slipped to 7.910 percent from Wednesday's close of 7.915 percent. Their price edged up to 83.82 points from 83.80 points.

DOC.HEAD: UAL Board Extends Deadline to Obtain Financing in Buyout Attempt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf, Samuel Buttrick ..., after eighth graf pvs, A man ..., to UPDATE with analyst comment; minor editing throughout.
DOC.TEXT: United Airlines' parent company Wednesday gave an employee buyout group an extra two months to arrange financing for its $4.38 billion bid. UAL Corp.'s board of directors said it was willing to extend the deadline, which was due to expire Thursday, because of the crisis in the Middle East. The buyout group ``reported that the recent turmoil in the world oil markets had slowed the progress of its discussions with financing sources,'' UAL said in a statement Wednesday evening after a regular meeting of the directors. The company said, however, that if financing is not arranged by the new deadline, Oct. 9, UAL will terminate the buyout agreement it reached with United Airlines employees last April. The directors indicated that they had doubts about the effort's chances of success. ``UAL emphasized that especially in light of events in the Middle East, state of the financial markets and softening economy, there can be no assurance that a transaction can be completed,'' the statement said. There was no immediate comment from the United Employee Acquisition Corp., the group formed to buy UAL. A man who answered the telephone at the group's office, but refused to give his name, said there would be no comment Wednesday. Samuel Buttrick, a stock market analyst who follows UAL for Kidder Peabody & Co. in New York, said the Middle East crisis had exacerbated trouble the group was already having obtaining financing. The buyout group got a boost earlier in teh day when the Los Angeles banking company Security Pacific Corp. said it had joined two New York banks in loan talks with the employees. Some industry analysts have speculated the employees would restructure or reduce their $201-per-share offer, which UAL's board accepted April 6. The UAL statement said the directors had instructed its advisers to engage in further discussions with the employee group ``to explore any changes in financial structure that may be necessary to obtain financing.'' Company spokesman Robert Doughty would not elaborate. Earlier Wednesday, UAL stock recovered some ground it had lost in trading during the last couple weeks. Analysts said the rally in UAL's stock after a plunge of 38 percent in less than two weeks stemmed mainly from Wednesday's sharp drop in oil prices. UAL's stock rose $13.50 to $114.50 a share Wednesday on the New York Stock Exchange. UAL's stock tumbled from $163 to $101 a share in the seven business days ending Tuesday amid waning investor confidence that the deal would get done. Much of the skepticism was prompted by the withdrawal of three large New York banks _ Chase Manhattan Corp., Chemical Banking Corp. and Citicorp _ from a five-bank group that had begun loan talks with the buyout group. The two remaining banks, Bankers Trust New York Corp. and Manufacturers Hanover Corp., have been joined by Security Pacific, said Penny Maines, a spokeswoman for the California bank. The employees also have asked some of UAL's suppliers, including aircraft maker Boeing Co. and engine builder General Electric Co., to invest in the deal.

DOC.HEAD: Upscale Retail Stores Cuts Workforce by 10 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Sharper Image Corp., an upscale retail company that sells unique high-technology goods, on Wednesday announced a 10 percent cutback in its nationwide workforce. The layoffs of about 110 of the company's 1,100 workers included corporate and store employees, said Jennifer Grellman, vice president of marketing for Sharper Image. ``The corporate office cutbacks began today and the cutbacks in the stores began last Friday,'' Grellman said. ``But we did give severance packages to the employees absolutely. And we also had an outplacement program. We tried to be as humane as we could.'' The layoffs come as the retail industry suffers from reduced sales. Grellman said Sharper Image saw its first losses during the second quarter of this year _ .15 to .20 cents per share. That compared to earnings per share of .01 cents during the same quarter the previous year. Grellman said the company is predicting profits during the fourth quarter of this year. Sharper Image has 70 stores in about two dozen states, mostly in the West and East, and it has international outlets through eight foreign licensees.
